review
being killed over and over again is fun
I write this review as I have 100% completed Elden Ring. And yet, despite this, I still find new things every time I play the game.  Elden Ring is an experience to say the least, and I won't be dramatic and say it is life changing but it feels like this is THE video game to play if you're ever going to play a game. It's immersive and full of story, every little thing is made with such refined detail that you can easily miss the little things. Everything feels so interconnected and it is so easy to get lost and find yourself on an adventure. It's been a long time since I've felt like a game really wanted me to just... go explore and have fun with the world. It feels punishing but no punishment in this game goes unrewarded.  Here's my breakdown of the game, I'll try not to spoil but I'll post spoiler warnings just in case.  *Story*:  As any Fromsoft game is, the world is vague and extremely open ended. Which can be a huge mess if done wrong but this is done entirely right. Story is not handed to you on a silver platter, however if you do wish to go find it through character storylines, you're given plenty of exposition and development. Characters are made to make you care about them or hate them. A lot. Where Elden Ring shines is the characters that they weave into the story and how important bosses feel to kill due to story context. The context you are given bit by bit really sell your journey.  *The Endings*:  (I have not done Golden Mask or Dungeater's ending as they do not really interest me too much. Do note there are spoilers up ahead so skip this section if you don't want that)  -Ranni's Ending was actually one of the most satisfying endings to a Souls game I've seen in a long time. She was a compelling character and her roster of companions feel fun and diverse in their own ways. They take you on this meaningful journey with twists and questionable moral choices. And to wrap it all up nicely after taking you underground to Nokron, Fromsoft has you revisiting areas previously to ground you in Ranni's backstory via Liurnia. I 100% recommend getting this ending and I'll be posting a guide soon!  -Frenzy Flame Ending was... something? It wasn't exactly remarkable but I did really enjoy the voice acting! I can't say the way to get it was entertaining though, go through some sewers, comet azur Mohg, and take 5 minutes to jump on some graves and now you have an ending only 15% of people this game have. It didn't feel satisfying but it was visually neat and the eyes look really radical.  -Elden Lord. Nuff said, you become elden lord. A decent neutral ending!  -Fia's. This one was actually really mysterious and fun. Full of deceit and conflict. You don't get an achievement with this alas but it's worth doing. Fun bosses, neat story, Fia being based.   *Gameplay*  It takes some getting used to. I grew up on the souls games and I am used to fast paced movements. But I really had to be patient with this one! Lots of delay which forces you to pay attention to the details of certain bosses. Also adding jumping in with some of the mechanics was really neat! Albeit a bit annoying from time to time (Cough, Godfrey, Cough).  The dungeons and caves are plenty of fun and remind me of old legend of zelda mechanics. The bosses are fun and engaging, always on your toes. Although Rennala was a slight bore phase 1. You can take your time or zoom through the Main Story. Going back to back in the story takes around 2-4 hours. But there's so much to do in the game that it might take you 100+ hours to even complete it.   So, yeah. Play it.

gut
Honestly fun, challenging boss fights. Keeps the mechanics of previous titles, and makes it more friendly for new players as they can just explore and come back later.   A vast arsenal, and chances are you can use the weapon you want to use because for most non unique weapons you can add weapon arts to them. These weapon arts increase damage/ let you choose what they scale with, and add a new ability onto them.  Plenty of spells, and most of them all generally have their uses, some for insane cheese (Dragon rot breath, Comet Azur). The most frustrating thing about them, is that enemies input read to dodge your shots, so delaying and or just trying to get a quick hit will normally be futile. The counter to the enemy dodge, is to just do it again. For some reason they decided that the ai should only be able to dodge a certain amount of times.  And leading on from my last point: Bows, I am doing a bow only build, it is painful to just have the game decide half of your shots aren't going to hit, and if you try to attack while a boss is channeling something, generally the bow will lock you out of dodging away. Unless you are using a composite bow/ a quick bow that has a dodge attack you will be hit if your not a mile away from the boss. Using a small bow to relieve these issues kind of suck, as they are only really useful for applying status effects and not damage. Though it is understandable that bows should be weaker, but when you compare them to mage/faith counter parts it feels rough.  Biggest downside to me of this game is [strike] it's not darksouls 4. [/strike] is that the open world kind of makes the game less linear, which is what appealed to me in ds3. (Which is a great game that I highly recommend)

I'll keep it short with this one. I have played a truckload of games since I've been a little kid.  Elden Ring is the best game I have ever played. Simple as that. This is an absolute masterpiece, challenging in all the right ways, an immersive world with a unique atmosphere that pulls you in, story bits that you can discover yourself, loads of hidden content that rewards exploration, epic boss fights, a perfect scaling of game difficulty with your learning curve, incredible graphics, incredible soundtrack, immense replay value, rewarding combat, deep RPG elements, a huge selection of very different armaments, spells and equipment.  This game takes you serious as a dedicated player and shows exactly what western adventure/RPG/AAA games have been lacking so badly over the last... 10 years? I've finished the game 1 month after release and I'm still constantly coming back to it.  FromSoftware, you outdid yourselves with this one. This is the one in a million, this is literally the best game ever made.
Top-notch gameplay and graphics, not so good "story".
Stunning
This game is definitely a worthwhile playthrough for anyone who may take the slightest interest in this genre. Though, I must say this game's end game does not have the most polish when compared to the beginning of the game. Bosses are overly punishing and overly active. The philosophy of bosses seems to have been very muddied. Bosses with large health pulls will have attacks capable of nearly one-shotting any build that does not dump vigor. Most early-game bosses are challenging, but well made enough to be beaten at any point in the game depending on skill level. The later bosses are very different on the other hand. The over-aggressive nature of bosses and their habit to end combos just to immediately begin a new one before you can properly achieve a hit is an incredibly frustrating one. Leaving you to always be overly cautious in order to even get an attack in. Forcing the players to constantly be on the defensive and break the flow of combat creates a less interesting environment and gameplay loop. It seems like the developers decided to focus on making the bosses more "challenging" rather than fun. Bosses being challenging is a perfectly fine mechanic and is fundamental to the franchise, but Elden Ring seems to tip the scales, several times, into the frustrating territory. Having to wait an entire Youtube Ad's length of time for a proper opening in a boss only to do minimal damage is just not a fun way to play the game. Spending several minutes whittling a massive health bar, only to be instantly killed by singular mistake is not a fun way to play a game. Bosses with small health pools that are incredibly punishing are completely fine and enjoyable challenges. Bosses with massive health pools that spend most of their time whittling you down for your mistakes over time are also completely fine and enjoyable. It's when the two are mixed, is when you create an overall frustrating experience. Do not get me wrong. I love this game and enjoyed the many hours I put into it, but the game's late game bosses make it a difficult choice to want to replay it. 7/10 game trapped in a 10/10 frame. I would love to see this game get a sequel that irons out the issues.

The music isn't as memorable this time around, and the inter-connectivity of the levels isn't as intricate as their previous titles, but nothing is perfect. The open world exploration is rewarding. The quests are hard to figure out, and often leave a sour taste in your mouth. It's a beautifully dark world that rewards skill and planning.

Unironically one of the best games ever made, sincere opinion
"I offer you an accord."   Elden Ring is truly FromSoftware at its peak, while I love the Dark Souls games, I think Elden Ring's world and lore are by far my favorite. The characters all feel like they are moving towards their own goals, and you are just a pawn for most of them. By the end of the game you could accept your fate or align your goals among one of these many characters, or flip everything on its head for yourself. I think the endings for the game are very interesting, and investigating to learn the lore of the game for myself was very fun for me! The design of characters and bosses in this game is also very interesting, as some have strange connections to the lore that lead you to learning more as you examine and play. Some just make for good mysteries too, leading you to craft your own theories about things. While I hope we get more explanations for things in future DLC's I'm also fine with things remaining mysterious, as it allows everyone to keep their own theories about the game. Gameplay feels a lot smoother than the clunkiness of the other Souls games I've played too. As a heavy greatsword builder I've also never been happier with how easy it is to achieve the build you're going for.  The soundtrack is also killer, as most souls games are when it comes to their tracks. Wandering the world had to be my favorite part of the game, whereas in other Souls game, trekking along can feel like a drag.   I look forward to more! Truly one of the best games I've played.

Should you play Elden Ring?  FromSoft and the Soulslike genre certainly have a strong, dedicated following, but maybe that's not you. Perhaps you've never played this kind of game before and you aren't sure if you can trust they hype. I humbly offer my perspective, as someone who entered the world of Elden Ring (hereafter referred to as the Lands Between) with absolutely no experience with other FromSoft games or the brutally unforgiving genre from which it arose.  I finally took the leap and bought Elden Ring because I love exploring open worlds. Linear gameplay can be great, but there is something especially appealing to me about a huge world that I can wander through freely, especially those with a sword-and-sorcery aesthetic. From RuneScape and Guild Wars to the Elder Scrolls and The Witcher, just give me a sword, a bow, some spells, and a world to get lost in.  Here was a new world to explore in the Lands Between, and please believe me when I say I was not disappointed. The Lands Between are at times beautiful, terrifying, breathtaking and disturbing. The world is vast, and it seemed that every time I thought I had explored it all, there was still another hidden area to unlock and explore. This amazing world seemed all the bigger, I think, because of how small I felt in it.  I am just an average gamer, no slouch but nothing to brag about either. My early experience in the game involved dying (a lot) to very basic enemies. I crept slowly through every cave and dungeon, constantly on guard for wolves and imps waiting to jump out at me. When I encountered my first dungeon boss, I probably fought and died a hundred times, determined to beat it (not realizing at the time that I was just too weak, underleveled for the fight, and really should have moved on and come back later). It was frustrating, but I loved the world and I was determined to explore it all.  So... should you play? It is an excellent game on many levels, and I can attest that it is accessible (with a learning curve) to gamers new to the genre. That said, I would only recommend Elden Ring if you have patience and can emotionally tolerate repeated failure. While the open world design offers more freedom to avoid the hardest fights until you've leveled up, there are still some very challenging enemies that can take multiple attempts to defeat. If getting killed by the same boss for the twentieth time might make you punch your screen, maybe look elsewhere.  But if you are willing to learn and grow from defeat, and especially if you love exploring vast new worlds, then I hope you take a chance and journey into the Lands Between. Elden Ring is an experience you likely won't forget anytime soon.

Good game
The profound impact that the first Dark Souls had on me during high school left me skeptical that Elden Ring could be as meaningful to me as an adult. I was close to skipping it altogether, but my friends convinced me to give it a shot with the Seamless Co-Op mod last month. Although we didn't make much progress as a group, I had a blast finishing the game solo.  Even though I started playing Elden Ring a year after its release, I believe that it was worth the full price of admission. I had some issues with the game's pacing, particularly with regards to the open-world exploration, but the stunning landscapes and compelling lore made the journey worthwhile. Now, I find myself eagerly anticipating the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC, even if I am not quite as hyped as I was for the Crown of the Sunken King back in 2014.

One of the greatest games ever. Beautiful sprawling open world that gives the sense of freedom, adventure, and danger we felt gaming as children. The first 40-50 hours of this game are pure unadulterated art. It's rare an open world game makes me *want* to explore, but the mystery danger and lack of markers in Elden Ring had me checking everywhere. Several absolute banger "dungeon" levels.   Combat is tight and responsive, weapons have a weight that feels appropriate for their size. There are a variety of different builds, styles, and choices based on personal preference and skill. The game even includes Ash Summons which can help new players wade their toes into the water of souls games.   The game stumbles a bit near the end especially with tuning on some fights, but even then has a few of my favorite fights that really help it get over the finish line as a top 5 all time for me. Dark Souls 1 had a similar issue with its post O&S content, and if I can forgive that, I can certainly forgive this one when it throws several of its best fights near the end. There's even a JRPG style super boss that anyone with any familiarity at all with the series is well aware of, given she tells you her name each of the hundreds of times she will kill you  9.5/10   Total Banger

hehe uchigatana go brrrr
As many have said, it's quite an adventure and definitely worth playing for souls fans and anyone who likes a true action rpg. It's certainly not a 10/10, but not for lack of content. In fact, the game would've benefited from a few features/areas being cut.  There is easily a full game's worth of unique content here, looking at the scale of the world, the number of areas, weapons/spells, and bosses. However, a lot of the content is repeated to the extent that the game is the scope of 2 or 3 full games. So instead of a normal-sized game where everything is unique and has a purpose, the game has a lot of re-used content and is a bit bloated. So after the 80-ish hour mark, the scope of the game actually works against itself, in my opinion.  The first 40 or 50  hours are sheer bliss and rival my best experiences playing almost any other game, but it falls off bit by bit as you explore more of the worlds areas, finding nearly identical catacombs or caves, consumables that just have a different coat of paint, the same ruined churches/enemies, and mini bosses that are re-used over and over with slight alterations or coupled with other enemies for increased challenge.  enemy and item placement is generally fantastic, and i always felt like the developers were right next to me, watching me play and placing everything by hand. So even when the content is re-used, exploring is still pretty engaging because there are very few empty dead ends.  The overall narrative is intriguing, but any actual explanation of the characters/world/who you are/etc are pushed so far to the sidelines that my biggest bit of positive feedback on this front is that it doesn't get in the way of the experience. And I'm absolutely forced to mention that characters' names are just unbearably similar, I really have no idea what they were thinking here. They took so many liberties with the narrative that they seem to have said to themselves "it's probably better if it just doesn't make any sense and leaves the world in a state of mystery." I'm not sure I agree.  I'm tempted to say that the core systems (that is, the combat, menus, and upgrades) are excellent, but honestly there are some big holes in the experience that I can't overlook. It's difficult to summarize, but certain aspects of the game are too obscure considering how critical they are to the whole of the experience. Magic is a great example, as summons, incantations, and sorcery and more are all handled differently and are obscure enough that I wouldn't blame players for skipping most of these mechanics entirely. Sorcery in particular involves finding a specific NPC in the world that is hidden in a copy-paste hole in the ground that could EASILY be overlooked given the size of the world. Summons are granted through the use of an item which is obtained through an NPC that only appears during one part of the game's day/night cycle (which influences very few other parts of the game afaik), and incantations require equipping and using "seals," which is not very obvious. All these things and more are likely explained/hinted at early in the experience but given how much is thrown at you, it's impossible for all of it to stick.  Although it's sort of magical how every game mechanic is veiled in an in-world name (Runes = XP, Ashes of War = special skills for weapons, "Tears" are health flask upgrades, etc), this makes for a very, very laborious process of trying to figure out if an item is even important or not. Speaking of importance, consumables make up a lot of the loot in the game, and in a game where the biggest challenges is bosses which will regain all their health when you die, consumables seem meaningless to me. My first 5 attempts at the more difficult bosses will just be learning attack patterns.  Crafting is pointless because you only craft one-time-use consumables which I've already stated that I find useless. Crafting should've been excluded entirely from the game but I'd guess it was left in as an additional incentive to explore/revisit ares of the map.  'Questing' is executed poorly enough to be a considerable net negative on the experience. NPCs appear in different places seemingly at random and the world is simply too big for this too be acceptable, especially without a questlog of some sort.   There are a few types of loot that I was always happy to find: Smithing Stones (used to upgrade weapons), Talismans (usually stat modifiers that can be easily swapped out to sort of re-spec your character on the fly), armaments/armor, and Runes. Every other bit of loot was almost always pointless and I would shrug and say to myself, "well, exploring and killing enemies is its own reward.   Talismans are great and maybe one of my favorite systems in the game. XP and weapons/gear are pretty straightforward, as loot at least. Smithing Stones, however, change the game in an important way that I love and hate, and ultimately wish was different. Upgrading weapons means that you can stick to certain weapons long after they should be obsolete, which is good in that you can use your favorite weapons for most of the playthrough, but because some weapons are so much better in terms of DPS than others, i found myself using only 3 different weapons during 90% or more of my 160 hours. There are an insane number of interesting weapons, so it's a shame that I never saw a path to success by trying lots of different ones. Smithing stones are also a pain-point in that finding a specific 'level' of stone is required to upgrade each stage of the weapons' power. what this means, is that at times, A level 7 smithing stone may be more valuable than an 8 or 9, simply because your weapon's upgrade is gated at each level and you might have run out of 7's. Still, smithing stones are always an exciting find and make exploring fun.  I'm not going to say much about the visuals; in terms of asthetics the game is an easy 10/10. It's truly a breathtaking game and I can't count how many times I said to myself during my playtime "wow. I've never seen anything like that before."  Audio is great, OST is pretty spectacular and the music always matches the tone of the situation it accompanies.  Last thing I want to cover is bosses, which are sort of a mixed bag. I'm not surprised this is a big point of contention for the community; some of them are very fun once you get the hang of their moveset, while others are just simply too cruel and unfair to be enjoyable or satisfying once you've conquered them. Almost every boss requires carefully timed dodges and a mastery of stamina management and character building. That's fine. What really isn't fine is bosses reading player inputs to trigger attacks the exact moment you do something, bosses that track perfectly, forcing dodge rolls instead of just clever footwork, absurdly long combos, Multiple boss phases, incorrect or very sloppy hit boxes and one hit kills. A boss could have one or two of the above and still be a fair fight, but I'd say the majority of the main bosses (and quite a few of the minibosses) have most or all of those features. I'm not saying any of the bosses aren't possible with time and effort, I'm saying a lot of them aren't very fun. Given the various types of character builds, the length of the game, and the fact that co-op is potentially part of the experience, I think the devs erred on the side of making bosses too overpowered, unfair, or tedious. If fighting bosses was less common I might give this a pass, but such a large percent of my playtime was spent in boss encounters (often fighting a new boss immediately after beating a previous one), that I really just got tired of the experience and wanted it to end.  Now, this review has mostly focused on the negative features of the game, but I think the positives more than make up for it. This is really a breathtaking epic experience that, despite being flawed, is definitely worth a recommendation. Game of the Year? Maybe. 10/10? nope.

FROM SOFTWARE DOES IT AGAIN
A masterpiece of a game. It was my first introduction to the souls games and it didn't disappoint.   Challenging and worth the money
So many amazing things were achieved with Elden Ring, and although its undeniably a masterpiece and genius in terms of world building and design. There are significant issues that might ruin the game for a lot of the player base, especially on subsequent play-through's.   With the exception of Godrick being a near perfect boss in terms of gameplay and design aesthetic. The boss quality of Elden Ring doesn't match up to their previous titles, Dark Souls 3 notably. Pretty much every main story boss in the game has at least one attack or more that is unreactable or purely unfair, with the end game bosses being the biggest offenders. But I will say that even though this may be an issue in terms of game design, Elden Ring is probably the easiest game Fromsoft has made given all the resources that are offered to you in game.  Upon first play-through, someone might not have a problem running through the many side dungeons in the game because the act of finding a secret in the world adds spectacle, but this also has to do with the fact that most players wont know that the layouts and enemies used in these dungeons are reused over and over again, with little nuance. The side dungeons in Elden Ring are basically just the chalice dungeons from Bloodborne but worse; because Instead of getting something useful as a reward from a chalice dungeon like you would in Bloodborne, because of the extreme build diversity in Elden Ring, you are going to get something completely useless to your specific build ninety percent of the time. In addition to the side dungeons, certain bosses like the Ulcerated Tree Spirit are reused at least 10 times if you go through the trouble to find them all. Fromsoft has handled reusing bosses in the past very well but it isn't done well here. With all this in mind you might think that, "Well maybe you're only SUPPOSED to have one good play-through.". But this just isn't the case when you factor in the sheer number of different builds and weapons you can use and the fact it has a New Game + option.    Considering the many flaws this game has, it doesn't stop this game from being one of the best games I have ever played. And without any of these flaws, Elden Ring would be undeniably one of the best games ever made. But it might still be up there even with its flaws.   So maybe I just typed all of this out for zero reason.  -20/10

Even tho im only 17h in on PC, i did a full playthrough, missing only the optional endings on the PS4.  There is nothing more to add on what you already eard about Elden Ring, however, i want to give my opinion on the game.  Being this my second playthrough, now on PC, im surprised im still having a BLAST playing this again.  The first time you enter the Lands between, it's a magical experience as the world is full of things to discover, hidden paths that lead to places you already visited or not, or even get teleported into the skies.  There is nothing quite like this game in the sense that the world is carefully crafted to the tinniest detail.  As i read on a review a couple of months ago, this game is on sale even at full price.  Don't sleep out on the Lands between, its a masterpiece.
Exploration here is everything. Elden Ring is an RPG. Rather, it's a game that elevates role-playing to the point of realism. You are a stranger in a land as strange as your avatar. Some of the basic controls and mechanics are explained in the past for the game's tutorial. But that's about it. no mission log There is no mini map with icons. There are no screen overlays or bread crumb trails telling you what to do next. or even where to go otherwise have to learn Whether deciphered from in-game italic item descriptions or gathered from the precious internet community. Death is not so much an avoidable setback as a necessary provision on the path to enlightenment. It might sound scary in theory. But in practice it's exciting. Every inch of progress in Elden Ring feels earned and therefore infinitely more rewarding and Elden Ring is a very difficult boss game. OPEN AND HANDS-OFF EXPLORATION I haven't enjoyed the open world much since Red Dead Redemption 2. It's hard, satisfying, and a great game!

i do highly recommend this game, i have enjoyed it very very much, i also do recommend for new players to the souls games if i'm honest it is by far the easiest souls game made by from software, if it had the title dark souls it would be the easiest dark souls game, now this doesn't mean the game isn't challenging, making builds still takes time to get right, enemies can and will one shot you, bosses can and will most of the time one shot you, but once you progress further into the game and become better you can limit one shots, there are lots of armor and weapons to use, even though i've said this would be the easiest dark souls title if it had the title do not expect it to be something as easy as a hack and slash game it will challenge you, the story is very hard to pick up at times for the most part like me you wont even know what it is like 60% of the time, it is def a recommend play, you will enjoy it as a i have, you will create your own story to become elden lord while also completing other story lines that are taking place during your own, you will find things the second time you play or going back into the area you didn't spot the first time.  i def recommend it!  tldr: good game, highly recommend, easy but will challenge.

hidetaka miyazaki and george r. r. martin created a beautiful world with a vast history and mythology. if you like the politics and characters of a song of ice and fire, lord of the rings, and/or the witcher, you will enjoy this universe. there are some amazing lore videos  on yt about elden ring and the lands between. if you delve into the lore i promise your game experience will be elevated! it feels like i learn something new every time i play.  i've had the most fun playing builds and with items i think are cool. there are so many options that pretty much any build is possible. the game is mostly easy with help from co-op. if you want to challenge yourself play solo or with summons for a bit, but try online play because it is really fun. you can go at your own pace and do most things in any order you want. you can gain as many levels as you want to make your play through easier or give yourself a level cap to make the final boss fights more difficult. i think this game gets better each time i play and the more hours i commit to it. ultimately, i would recommend this game to anyone who likes history, mythology, mysteries, likes to learn, dark souls/bloodborne/sekiro, and/or games where choices are important. i think if you want a game to put 1,000 hours into, this is a great choice.  i would not recommend this game to anyone who doesn't want to commit at least 50 hours to it, dislikes the fantasy genre,  dislikes adjusting their playstyle to beat different enemies, shudders at the thought of being humbled, and likes to smash controllers and keyboards to express their frustration.

Great game, love it. I have more hours in it than any individual Souls game at this point and I'm still eager to play through on more characters. But you know why this game is good, so let me just say that it does have some flaws.  The biggest flaw imo is the repeated assets. While the world and enemies are still diverse overall, if you explore everything you will notice some similar mini-dungeons and repeat enemies (most notable is when you see the same side/mini-boss again). Did you think 3 asylum demons in dark souls was too many? Well now there are a dozen!  HOWEVER, even if this brings the game down a bit for you, you will probably still have a lot of fun with it.  ONE MORE THING. Please don't let anyone tell you how you are "supposed" to play the game. One of the best parts of Souls games is the diversity of tools available to you, and the ability to make the game as easy or difficult as you want depending on how you play it. So play in whatever way is the most fun to you.

I'm not even really a souls guy but the last game that made me feel this way was Skyrim. The way there's literally always something just ahead to investigate. The way the reward for doing so isn't just a Korok seed or whatever (until it is, but then you read a note saying "Why is it always mushroom?" and it *feels* like you were rewarded, even when you weren't). The way every individual region of the world is just teeming with art direction and high fantasy imagery. The way the enemy designs are so interesting you flirt with death just to see the whole moveset. The high number of equipment items that all look genuinely unique.   One of the things that turned me off about souls games in the past was that if I lost my souls I felt like I had to grind back through an area I already completed to get them back or I'd be underleveled for the boss. I've never once had that feeling in Elden Ring. In part because the spawns are a bit more forgiving (directly in front of a boss room, for example), but also because of the fundamental gameplay design changes that come from it being open world. I'd go into it, but I'd rather get back to playing.  11/10 best open world game since Skyrim.

But god damn, I liked this game a lot My enjoyment came not from combat, but the exploration and character building It felt like everything I explored contributed to my strength, even though it didn't really  I only hit two walls: - Margit, because I was severely unprepared and unskilled - Malenia, counting 80 actual tries, the only time I broke my self imposed rules  I put some restrictions on my run a little after Margit: Solo, No summons, No consumables, No Rune Arcs, No guarding, Heavy affinity only Even so, the game felt easy with my heaviest armor / STR only / Colossal Sword build  Played the Grafted Sword for more than half of the game, and the other half was basically the Greatsword I wanted to try other weapons, but those felt like they were the best options I had for my build Smithing should have been more affordable to give room for experimentation  The story went right above my head, I have no idea what was going on I only knew I had to kill, and boy, did I kill Only character I grew attached to was Hewg, the blacksmith, who I liked a lot for reasons unbeknownst to me  Killed all the bosses and saw the Ranni and Fractured endings Failed most quests because wiki gaming sucks Great game despite everything  110 hours of play, 12 of them at Malenia :)

The game's combat system is fluid and satisfying, and the inclusion of summoning options adds an additional layer of depth. w game 
I'm just going to go over gameplay and the world because I don't hold any opinions anywhere else.  This is first of all just a combat focused game, it's open world dark souls and it is what you would expect. There are no mini games, no towns, there's one little guild you run into and very rarely do you come across someone or something not hostile. Your traversal options are mostly being just grounded with the situational high jump being granted to you. You can't swim, fly, or glide. The game has A LOT of abilities and gear to collect, and it starts you off well with classes to go into and from there you can just start setting goals of what you want to tackle with guidance or experience. Playing blind can be a bit frustrating if you're exploring for rewards and not strictly for challenge because you may not find something that suits your class. The enemy variety is insane, there's also a lot of traps in this game inside dungeons, so check your surroundings. Also make sure you follow the tutorial all the way through to get the basics of the game unlocked, don't try to go gallivanting after you step out into the world, follow the light. The game has some balancing issues, magic is very strong, bleed is very strong. I never found much use for crafting, but I heard it's a bit helpful. The combat is sluggish compared to other action games and the enemy attacks are sometimes strangely fast and relentless as if they should be in Sekiro instead, trying to pick your moments with melee can be frustrating unless you use summons, which are also broken (especially mimic tear) because they distract the AI. Lastly, co-op in this game is a tragedy because people can invade you.  score: 7/10  Positives:  -Lots of enemy variety -Lots of skill and gear variety -PVP -Decent exploration  Cons:   -Forced PVP in co-op -Sluggish combat system -no variety in activities outside of combat and character building -very unbalanced combat builds.

Personally I do enjoy this game and while this game certainly does have its ups and downs, I am not here to praise or criticize this game. I am here to offer a phenomenal 4 Cheese Ravioli recipe!  Here are the ingredients you will need!  Ravioli Dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 pinch salt, 1 teaspoon olive oil, 2 eggs, 1 1/2 tablespoons water.  Ravioli Filling: 1 (8 ounce) container ricotta cheese, 1 (4 ounce) package cream cheese, softened, 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, 1/2 cup provolone cheese, shredded, 1 egg, 1 1/2 teaspoons dried parsley.  Pesto-Alfredo Cream Sauce: 2 tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 3 tablespoons prepared basil pesto sauce, 2 cups heavy cream, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 (24 ounce) jar marinara sauce.   1. Mound the flour and salt together on a work surface and form a well. Beat the teaspoon of olive oil, 2 eggs, and water in a bowl. Pour half the egg mixture into the well. Begin mixing the egg with the flour with one hand; use your other hand to keep the flour mound steady. Add the remaining egg mixture and knead to form a dough.  2. Knead the dough until smooth, 8 to 10 minutes; add more flour if the dough is too sticky. Form the dough into a ball and wrap tightly with plastic. Refrigerate for 1 hour.  3. While the dough is resting, prepare the ravioli filling. Combine the ricotta cheese, cream cheese, mozzarella cheese, provolone cheese, egg, and parsley and mix well. Set the filling aside.  4. Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic and pesto sauce and cook for one minute. Pour in the heavy cream, raise the heat to high, and bring the sauce to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the Parmesan cheese and stir until the cheese melts. Remove the pan from the heat and keep warm.  5. Meanwhile, in a separate saucepan, warm the marinara sauce over medium-low heat.  6. Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Beat the egg with the tablespoon of water to make the egg wash.  7. Roll out the pasta dough into thin sheets no thicker than a nickel. To assemble the ravioli, brush the egg wash over a sheet of pasta. Drop the filling mixture on the dough by teaspoonfuls about one inch apart. Cover the filling with the top sheet of pasta, pressing out the air from around each portion of filling. Press firmly around the filling to seal. Cut into individual ravioli with a knife or pizza cutter. Seal the edges.  8. Fill a large pot with lightly salted water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Stir in the ravioli, and return to a boil. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the ravioli float to the top and the filling is hot, 4 to 8 minutes. Drain well.  9. Grease a baking sheet. Place the cooked ravioli on the sheet pan and bake in the preheated oven until brown, about 4 minutes.  10. To serve the ravioli, divide them among four warmed serving bowls. Drizzle the marinara sauce over the ravioli and then top with the cream sauce.

The more I play the more I hate the game, all I can do is complain about this game. However I come crawling back so from software clearly did something right.
I love Malenia, Blade of Miquella.
THE GOOD:   * New open world setting. This works phenomenally, the change from the cramped and claustrophobic gauntlets in older Fromsoft titles to open plains in the Lands Between feels amazing. The freedom of engaging the world at your own pace is such a wonderful introduction. The areas introduced all feel unique with it's own stories to tell.   *A fantastic, intricate and engaging lore.  How can we describe the story and lore of Elden Ring? Well, I'd say Early Christianity, western alchemy, Gnosticism, occultism and mysticism. The historical foundation that serves as a base for the game's storytelling has been greatly expanded compared to earlier titles and is now bigger than ever. This makes this game such a joy to unravel, puzzling together the historical references.   *Stunning and unparalleled visuals This game offers some of the most stunning colors, weathers and atmospheres I've seen in a game. Each zone has it's own unique climate, flora and color palette that it nails perfectly. From the ever-clouded plains of Limgrave, the starry skies of Liurnia to the snowy mountaintop of the Giants.   THE BAD:  *The game sadly plays too much like an older Dark Souls game And what I mean by this, despite Elden Ring's adaptation to a more modern open world RPG, it still plays out like the titles of yore. It's a railroaded boss slaying game that offers very limited effects of player choices and world interactions. Many NPCs questlines feature interesting early stages that can be skipped altogether (Rogier, Ranni etc), without any punishment or loss of valuable items.  It makes the game feel extremely streamlined as it doesn't reward thorough gameplay more akin to a RPG.   *Limited weapon and armor variety  My favorite thing about Dark Souls 3 was the absolute variety of gear in the world.  Soldiers and knights in the Lands Between all carry more or less identical gear.  The pinhead knight armor having the same model across all factions is disappointing.  Not to mention they all wield the exact same weapons. The Brass Shield, the Lordsworn Straight- and Greatsword, Knight's Greatsword and Partisan. A world filled with different heritages and traditions should enable a more diverse selection of styles.   *Low enemy variety  This somewhat follows in the same track as the previous one, just as we see a lack of variety of gear on enemies, we also have a lack of variety when it comes to enemies.  What truly makes an area feel unique is it's denizens. Sadly, as we progress to the later stages of the game we can really notice how the enemy variety fizzles out, and in the final zones of the game we end up fighting more or less the same enemies we've fought before, but now they have a lot more HP, defense and attack. That's it.   *Unfinished and cut content  "First you should do when you're done writing, is rewriting"  Anyone who followed the initial announcement of Elden Ring probably expected what a rollercoaster the development process must've been. Ultimately, we ended up with a game worthy of the GOTY title, but in the end we can't help but notice how certain things feel missing or incomplete.  A cross comparison of item descriptions from the 1.00 version of the game reveals fundamentally different lore implications. A plethora of NPCs and questlines have been cut and reworked (Kale and the Great Caravan is one example), and we cannot know for sure what impact that might have had on the original vision of the game. Will these be reworked and reintroduced in expansions? Perhaps, but remember these were NPCs that were supposed to be in the base game (looking at you Rico).   THE VERDICT:  9/10  Elden Ring is without a doubt one of the best games of the decade. Maybe you think my criticism of the game are silly nitpicks, but for a game of this caliber and quality I do reserve myself the right of taking these observations.   Ultimately, Elden Ring is an epic unlike anything we've played before, it has truly set a new bar in the gaming industry.  All that I can ask from Fromsoft is to take some steps outside of their Dark Souls comfort zone in the future.

its no bloodborne
Elden Ring is a masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling.  As a result, it is very different from other open-world games I have played such as Skyrim and Far Cry which are story and questline driven. From the get-go, Elden Ring doesn't impose any particular playstyle or route on you. You are completely free to do what you want to from the very start of the game. You can finish the main storyline and beat the final boss or you can explore the entire map without ever seeing the main bosses, it truly is up to you with no outside influence. It is truly refreshing to feel this sense of freedom in choice and exploration in any open world game.  Elden Ring has also mastered the art of sublety. For example, for a game like Skyrim, there are various elements such as the character dialogues, leveling system, various landmarks that I could clearly point to in contributing to the game's success. However, this is not the same with Elden Ring. It's hard to place my finger on one specific thing that makes the game so enjoyable. Many times I've gone in to play this game for half an hour, only to become immersed, losing track of time and playing for hours on end. I belive that it's each of the game's features: its combat system, transportation, landscape, lore, storytelling, etc. that complement each other in a way that none of them are overbearing and at the same time, come together in such a fluid manner that I as the player can't notice it and am drawn into a level of immersion that I haven't felt from any game before.  Other, more objective factors of Elden Ring are equally as impressive--it's hard to believe this is a $60 game. The map is massive, far bigger than I could've ever imagined, with more content packed into it than any other world game I've played before. I have not had a single moment where I've felt the map felt desolate or empty, there was always something to see and explore. The combat system is rich, balanced, and rewards each playstyle. The difficulty of the game is refreshing and I feel that I'm being challenged to improve and innovate as I play the game instead of relying on old hacks. The subtle details, such as changes in behavior over time of day or cross-NPC interactions add a layer of immersion that makes the world feel alive. It is also a very polished product: while games today are released with game-breaking bugs and issues, I haven't encountered a single bug in Elden Ring even given its massive map aside from minor visual glitches. It is truly astounding how much that adds to the immersion of the game.  Overall, I feel that Elden Ring is an amazing game. While it isn't perfect by any means, in fact, the imperfections of the game give me something to look forward to for what will be the sequel to this, it will be hard to find a game from the last decade that is as immersive as this. I am truly impressed by From Software's work and I look forward to their next game. Elden Ring will inspire the next generation's set of games and I hope to see what comes from this. I've thoroughly enjoyed playing Elden Ring and I hope to see you too enjoy it.

[h1] Elden Ring is the pinnacle game in the Souls-like genre. Building on the foundations of previous FromSoftware titles, Elden Ring is a standout title and is the spiritual successor to Dark Souls. Elden Ring comes at a great time in a nosediving era of AAA gaming, and is the best new game I’ve played in a few years. [/h1]  Building on the shoulders of Demon’s Souls, Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro, Elden Ring seems to bring everything together into an all-encompassing epic which smashes the scale and complexity of previous titles out of the water. Thrust into a new high fantasy/dark fantasy setting, the player is put into a world which dwarfs the map size of previous titles; it’s full of more secrets and treasures than we’ve seen in other FromSoftware titles. Although some open areas are a bit dead, the quality of many of the game’s hubs is enough to overpower these “mile wide, inch deep” areas – including the great mage academy of Raya Lucaria, the game’s first castle in Stormveil Castle, the fiery peak which holds Volcano Manor, and the game’s central location which is the golden multi-leveled city of Leyndell. Of course, there is much more, with several vital, detailed locations spread out across a large world. You’ll find golden forests, caves full of crystals, icy fields and icy peaks, mighty castles, and great underground rivers. Speaking of underground areas, Elden Ring’s underground areas are less like dinky caves and are more like entire world spaces, complete with lost ancient cities, mighty bosses, and dark or mysterious secrets – for me, this may have been one of the most standout parts of Elden Ring. This is almost like if Zork was given the AAA budget it always needed.  Elden Ring has more quests and storylines than FromSoftware fans have ever seen, and it has several distinct endings. Elden Ring has a story that is fairly easier to interpret than past FromSoftware titles, yet I would argue it is also more open to interpretation in general, and has quest progression that is quite complex. Quests, especially main story quests, have several steps to follow, which may not always be stated explicitly. The game’s many endings each have different steps to achieving any specific ending, where these steps may run through different and separate areas of the world entirely – your only hints may be on an obscure item description, or just happening to find a NPC in the perfect specific place. When you consider this alongside the fact that a full playthrough of Elden Ring can easily take over 100 hours, it becomes clear that this game is intended for those who will truly explore every detail of the world. This game will require serious exploring, item description reading, and a deal of abstract thinking. You should know that there is no quest log at all, which only adds to the vagueness of quest progression.  In essence, the game is a massive riddle and puzzle – whether this is all a problem or not is up to you. It may mean missing out on entire quest lines and important characters or bosses, or it may mean finding secrets which few have found organically. This notable challenge is not helped by the game’s infamously harder-than-average combat – but, for me, if it’s not that hard then it’s not even worth playing.  Elden Ring is a darn difficult game to play through. A third-person fast-flowing M&M (magic and melee), Elden Ring’s combat system allows the player to dodge, evade, block, and counterattack in many ways, where each element must be timed very well – and, where small miscalculations can mean an easy end. While the game features some difficulty-reducing facets such as fast travel, a horse to ride on, and several opportunities to grind for skills, levels, and weapon upgrades, the bosses are still quite difficult to pass through, especially a few of the late game bosses. The fanbase may argue on who has the biggest stick among the FromSoftware games, but I kid you not – it’s far from a breeze. You must be on your toes at every second, and you must learn almost all of your enemy’s moves to persist and persevere. I thought Elden Ring’s late game was more hair-tugging than any of the other Souls-like games so far, and when it can be a 100 hour game you must steel yourself for far longer than your average game. This game is meant for people who desire a serious challenge, or at least is meant for those who can tolerate a serious challenge, although of course it can be cheesed if you so desire.  If you want to be pushed and shoved until you’re any good, and then still want to be pushed and shoved beyond that, this game is up your alley.  As a Dark Souls fan, it is time for me to admit that, deep down, I think Elden Ring is simply the better title now. Elden Ring’s quality has surpassed the older titles – there, I said it. In addition, I think this game is the best fantasy title in many years, and it has taken a jump beyond contemporary and established fantasy series.  If we’re looking a bit deeper into the storytelling and themes of Elden Ring, the concept of ambition appears frequently throughout the game, which could lead to one of many interpretations from the game: “life is what you make it”. While you could look at this for the very concept of “truth” itself, in my own subjective way I take it to mean “the world is my oyster”. A pinch of inspiration followed by a mountain of hard work may get us to the sea beyond the mountain, where our coveted oyster’s pearl lies. Ambition must be followed primarily by dedication, persistence, a Spartan’s courage, and a life of tough work to get to anywhere of meaning. While ambition alone is never enough, it is the dire lifeblood that builds empires, discovers worlds, and creates new kings. It is the very thing which underpins the motivations of Elden Ring’s characters, and which powers those of any value in the real world in front of us. For me, it is like a third lung or a second heart, while those without ambition are but a kite fluttering in the wind with its strings cut off – lost, without real direction, defeatist, and will remain in all flavors of mediocrity until they are dust in the wind.  “A man’s worth is no greater than the worth of his ambitions.” - Marcus Aurelius, Meditations  Still, this is just one interpretation of Elden Ring, when it may also seem there isn’t only one true interpretation from this game. From another philosophical perspective, I think Elden Ring may highlight a great point which is lost in many minds, especially within Western philosophy: there is not, or at least may not be, one universal truth or narrative, or at least that the concept of “universal truth” is subjective, with several coexisting “truths” or narratives happening at once. Some would probably pick this thought apart on the semantics of “is not” versus “may not be”, and moralists or objectivists would have a field day on the latter parts of that sentence, but frankly I don’t care. For me, Elden Ring mainly embodies these concepts within its several endings, as it may leave breadcrumbs but will never suggest any one truth or narrative for you. With what you may see later on in the game, you might see multiple truths and narratives taking place at the same time.  What is “truth”? What is “free”? Who decides what “truth” is? Who gets to rule? Who enforces “truth”? Who may be free? These are many of the questions posed by Elden Ring – questions which are not objectively answered and which are left to your own devices. The minds of FromSoftware and Westeros aficionado George R.R. Martin come together in a very interesting way, and offer several competing, separate philosophies to analyze.  [b] Elden Ring is the capstone project of FromSoftware, and is one of the few great AAA games in recent years. With more of Elden Ring still to come, it will be hard for a game like this to get beaten anytime soon, and it’s a great new addition to the fantasy genre. [/b]

Damn.
112 hours and I haven't even beaten the game. I've just now gotten to Deeproot Depths and still have the city to explore and the Giant area. This game can be as long or as short as you want it to be. The action is what you've come to expect out of FromSoftware but with a particular polish that makes it more accessible to a more mainstream audience while still holding on to the "get gud" mentality. So many ways to build your character, and even if you're not big on replayability, there's always PvP and DLC! The world feels immersive, almost uncomfortably so at times and the music adds to that ambience (I'm always looking over my shoulder playing this game, feeling like someone might sneak up on me, that's how much it grabs you). 4.5/5

The best souls game for me by far. I've played every single souls game since DS1 but this game takes the crown for me. I've heard a lot of people have an issue with the lore and what not but I'm the opposite, I think the lore is great and the setting is what does it for me. I think this game is going to be either an S tier or an A+ tier for you depending on how much you like this style of game. The game is a souls like game but with a heavy emphasis on "open world", which IMO is amazing and there should be more of this. I'm a big enjoyer of these open world games so for me it was an easy S tier maybe even S+ with the DLC when it comes out. Most people who criticize this game are used to the classic souls like experience where you just follow a set guideline and stay on it, meanwhile this game throws that out of the water and lets you go anywhere you want whenever you want. I already beat the game once just rushing through it and even then it was extremely fun. The game has lots of replay ability and some people have even 10+ replays, every time you discover something new and different than your previous play-through. Right now I'm doing my 100% play-through, meaning I discover and do every single thing the game, get every single weapon, talisman, etc. I think this is the way to go in terms of playing the game and brings the most out of it, very fun game and definitely recommend it even for the somewhat steep $60.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Elden Ring and in less than a week, he had already played for over 28 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

An extremely entertaining game with beautiful views. What really sets this game apart, makes it S-tier, is the open world design. It's perfection. You'll be traversing this awe-inspiring landscape, and something will catch your eye. Sometimes it's a distant structure, other times it's a ray of light through a cliff wall, or a cave. Nearly every time. if you take a moment to explore what caught your attention, you'll be reward with a hidden path, dungeon, material, or at the very least another player's message. Open world games should all take a lesson from Elden Ring.

Alright folks, this is Donald Trump here, and I want to talk about Elden Ring. Now let me tell you, this game is tremendous, okay? It's like nothing you've ever seen before.  First off, the graphics are beautiful. The colors are so vibrant, it's almost like you're really there. And the gameplay, it's phenomenal. You're fighting dragons, battling evil monsters, and exploring vast landscapes. It's like the Wild West of video games.  Let me just say, the creator of this game, Hidetaka Miyazaki, he's a genius. He's created something truly special here. And the music, it's fantastic. You'll feel like you're in the middle of a movie with the way the score builds and falls.  Now, I know some people might be hesitant to try this game because it's a little bit hardcore. But trust me, if you give it a chance, you won't regret it. Don't listen to those fake news critics who say it's too hard, they just don't have what it takes to conquer Elden Ring.  In conclusion, Elden Ring is a winner. It's a game for winners, okay? If you're looking for an adventure that will test your skills, then look no further. So go out and get yourself a copy, you won't be disappointed.

Quite literally the best soulsborne game I have ever played. And I should know, I've been playin' them all since Demon Souls.  This title combines the best of the best when it comes to the amount of choices of play, and is probably the best place for someone to start with the series due to the game being open world, enabling players who are stuck with one thing to go to another and eventually slowly learn as they go. And for returning players, they'll find familiar weapons and mechanics, plus all new ones leading into some really interesting styles of play.   My only complaint with this game: Due to the game being open world like it is, it is rather difficult to continue and very easy to completely miss some NPC quests and stories. The game is still completely enjoyable without doing them all, of course, as this is the kind of game that encourages players to play it multiple times to really experience what the game has to offer, and if you're really desperate then you can always consult a guide online these days.  I highly recommend this game, and consider it in the realms of 10/10. Great music, beautiful awe-inspiring environments, wild creature and character design, an absolute ludicrous level of freedom. If you must play a singular souls game in your life time, this is the one I recommend. And that's just the base game alone, we'll see just how much better this game is when the dlc arrives! This game is well worth the base price, but I understand if you'd rather wait for a sale. Just be sure to give it a go!

A very addictive and mostly fun game ... YET ... it is also a frustrating time-sink.  This is a PvE-single-player-explore-and-conquer dream.  But I don't recommend it.  It is frustratingly difficult at times.  The story is non-existent.  There are no quest guides to help you navigate the open world.  I am playing the game with a 12900k + 4090 yet it frequently stutters during combat, even though it's weirdly locked to 60 FPS.  My 2017 7700k + 1080 Ti could do 4k60 so ... what gives?  This game feels a lot like Elder Scrolls games: sure there's a main questline / goal but you can totally ignore it and just wander around and do stuff.  I never finished Oblivion or Skyrim; I wandered around, leveled up, did some quest lines, joined some guilds, then got bored and stopped playing altogether.  Elden Ring has been similar ... I'm 160+ hours in and have leveled a lot and explored but now feel fatigue & boredom.  Since there's no story development, I don't feel any connection to the world and the characters in it ... why do I even care about becoming the Elden Lord and stopping the baddies in this world?  Since there are no quest markers, I often find NPCs dead (as evidenced by them being a pile of lootable armor) having missed meeting them at the correct time.  But, I usually just shrug at this because the game doesn't give me a reason to care.  Will I come back to this at some point and play more?  Absolutely.  And, if you choose to buy this game, I'm sure you'll enjoy it at some level ... just understand what you're getting into.

ELDEN RING  I wanted to be objective on this review so I left it for some while and waited for my excitement to go down. Fromsoftware and their games are my favourites. I love Souls-Borne series the most of all games. I started with Dark Souls 2 and after it played through Dark Souls 3, Bloodborne, Sekiro. DS1 and Demon Souls I saw on the live stream.  Then I played an absurd amount of souls-like games from other studios or indie developers, for example: Surge 1+2, Hellpoint, Lords of the Fallen, Nioh 1+2, Ashen, Mortal Shell, Salt and Sanctuary, Code Vein, Thymesia, Death's Gambit etc. The point is I love the souls like formula in the games and all these games that I mentioned are great but I wanted something fresh, because all of these game follows the same pattern.  When Elden Ring was first announced I thought of it as no big deal, but man was I wrong.  Elden Ring took the souls formula and pushed it to another level - open world. It could sound terrifying but it isn't, trust me. The masters from Fromsoftware did absolutely amazing job in implementing all that we like into an open world. The world is full of activities, enemies, bosses, items (every one item except consumables has its own specific place), NPCs and stories and full of amazing lore that we love. The game challenges you at every corner and I thought not even once that I'm bored. Worlds on Ubisoft "checklist" basis are nothing compared to the world of Elden Ring.  Build variety is as amazing, maybe better than in Dark Souls. Main dungeons are sweet and complex locations like in the previous games. Side dungeons are okey, sometimes they look similar to each other, but it depend on "biome" in which you currently are. There are lot of secret tombs and theres questline for witch Ranni, that opens a whole area of the map that you cannot find otherway. Skills, spells, weapons feel epic and adds a lot of flavour to your playthrough.  It's a fresh wind for souls games and I hope the coming DLC would be even better than the main storyline.  Pros and cons: + Amazing open world + It feels like Dark Souls but better + Graphics are slightly better but nothing big, so I felt like home from the beggining + Epic bosses, even better than in previous games (I mean main bosses) + Great lore and exploration  - It's not ideal for a newbies to souls games  For me Elden Ring is 10/10 game, that will have a place in my heart for eternity.
best game I have played, second only to Gex
Very nice
Elden Ring is one of the first Souls-Like games to really capture the feeling while changing the formula.   The ability to jump with Torrent and other mechanic changes somehow make you still feel like you are in a souls game while adding fun and challenge.
Had some stuttering issues at launch, and it's still not the most optimized title From has ever put out, but that's to be expected of Japanese dev PC ports.   Peaks a little early in my opinion, the first half of the game feels like a true adventure with challenging difficulty and new content around every corner, but once you reach the halfway point, some of the content starts to feel a bit stale and a bit easy if you're using all the tools the game gives you.  That being said, it's a fantastic game, and probably the most complete/polished game From has ever put out.  9/10.

"Even if it does violate... The Golden Order."  These are some of the first words you will hear in Elden Ring. It plants a mystery in your mind that persists until the very end. I knew right then that this game was something beyond special.  Elden Ring is a difficult game, especially for new-comers like me, who are new to the Souls-series of games, but that did not stop my endless amazement and sense of wonder every step I took. The environments, the bosses, the silent storytelling of the world around me was so.. unique. The more I played, the more I wanted to know, and I fell deep down the rabbit hole of this game's world.  I will never forget the cinematic landscapes you see for each new area, the distant castle walls or giant golden trees. It is truly something you need to experience.  The gameplay itself is quick and tight, the bosses pose interesting challenges that respect your time. Slaying a boss, especially the ones in the main story, feels like you really did something substantial, as often the world changes around you in their absence.  You are only ever given one goal in Elden Ring that truly matters.  Become the Elden Lord, no matter the cost.
This deserved game of the year

It's Elden Ring.
I bought Elden Ring shortly after it came out because I missed playing some souls-like, and man was I blown away by how beautiful and well made the game is.   And HUGE. Oh my... is the map huge. There's just always more and more and more even when you think you've seen it all.   The addition of horseback riding has definitely been a nice new thing that I know a lot of players are liking. (though I didn't really mind walking in previous games) I also think spells are probably better and makes more sense now than they have in the past in FromSoftware games. Which is good cause I always found spellcasting to be pretty weird in their games.  The world and its colours are absolutely stunningly beautiful, the bossfights are epic and fun and you have a massive arsenal of weapons and armor to choose from, with 'Ashes of War' to add new abilities.   Overall with how well made the world is and how much effort you can feel has been put into it I would call Elden Ring a masterpiece and I'll give it like a 9.5/10   The only downside I have with the game is stuff like quests are still so vague and weird like I think they have always been in FromSoftware soulslike games which is a bit ugh for me and some of my friends. But I know it's kind of in their style at this point. It is just not very appealing in my opinion.  But you can always just focus on the main storyline in the game and you will still have plenty of stuff to do in this huge world. :)
It's one of the best, if not the best, open world games i have ever played. The feeling after finally defeating a boss thats been massacring the ever living shit out of you is so rewarding.

Excellent open world RPG. Elden Ring is my first Fromsoft/Souls game and boy was it a trip, to sum it up although difficult it was very rewarding. This game is just art, pure plain and simple art. Its actually astonishing the amount of content they were able to fit into this game (one playthrough can take 40-60 hours) which is well above the industry standard (due to Elden Ring's success it might be setting the new one). Because of my experience was I definitely envision myself playing through the other souls games but not before I go back and replay the game as a wretch just for that extra challenge and because the game is so expansive that I actually didn't even get to do everything I wanted to do on my first playthrough. If you are looking for a new open world fantasy rpg game to absolutely immerse yourself in for a minimum of 50 hours this is your game.

If you were holding off on playing this game because you heard it was hard, just know that Elden Ring is the most accessible soulslike game ever. There are mechanics built into the game to make it an easier experience, because everyone should experience this game.

Best game, somehow I sucked myself into doing a second play through without New Game Plus. Just a straight up second character going with a Faith/Dex build rather than Str/End. Needless to say, this game is amazing. One of the best RPGs to ever be made. While some boss encounters are definitely bs, all the important ones are really well designed. The game, while not forgiving in combat, has tons of options to help players get ahead and grind away the difficulty of the game. Don't gatekeep yourself from looking at guides either. There is so much to do, so much fun to be had.
TLDR: This is my favorite game of all time, and I think you should try it. :)  (Below includes a few details like mechanics, but does not mention any spoilers for major events, locations, or characters)   [Gameplay]  - Freedom of choice - Choice in Elden Ring is abundant. The game begins with the ability to select a class, each including different armor, weapons, and starting stats. Picking any one of these DOES NOT lock you into a specific playstyle for the rest of the game, they merely give you your choice of starting gear to begin your journey. As you progress, you will be able to find and equip different armor pieces, weapons/combinations of weapons, skills that can be applied to most weapons, and spells/incantations. Despite these being the basics of defense and offense, there are many other ways you can play that include things like sneaking, a flask you can mix ingredients into that have many varying effects, craftable temporary throwing weapons, horseback combat, spirits you can summon into battle, and many more. Most importantly to me, you can use your environment to your advantage such as destroying explosives, knocking enemies off ledges, ambushing, etc. Choice may also be applied to how you finish the game, as there are multiple ending you can achieve in wildly different ways. Some of these endings are straightforward and easy to find, while others I know for a fact I would never have found if I didn't hear about them. Being an open world game, it becomes obvious that you have multiple paths that you can go at any given moment, but Elden Ring does it very well. MOST OF THIS GAME is content that isn't needed to finish the story, and there are entire locations that are hidden off the beaten path with ZERO indication of their existence.  - Difficulty - It's no secret that this game is difficult. I have played multiple games made by this developer that are just as infamous for their difficulty, and I still had a hard time getting through it. If difficulty is something you don't enjoy, then this might not be the game for you, but I suggest you at least finish reading the rest of this segment. Difficulty in this game does not vary with an "Easy, Medium, or Hard" set of modes, but instead, the difficulty comes from choice and circumstance. The playstyle you choose may make some parts of the game more difficult and some more easy. I found that in order to make the game easier or harder comes purely from how you limit yourself. The multiplayer mechanics of this game can mean that you don't have to lift a finger to win this game. Doing a challenge run where you limit yourself in specific ways can make it a run that isn't humanly possible. If you feel that the game isn't hard enough, then you can subtract certain elements of the game to make it a more challenging and fulfilling game. Another thing that makes the game more difficult is after beating the game. When you finish the game, you have the choice to "Start Journey 2" which bring your character, armaments, level, and all, to do the story again, but the enemies hurt more and have more HP, but also drop more runes for leveling. Each cycle that you do amplifies these things up until Journey 8, which is as hard as it gets, but you can still restart the game with the same character endlessly if you wish. Benefits of starting a new journey with the same character also include trying new endings, and doing/getting things in case you missed them last time. But if you want the game to be easier for you, you have multiple options. You can summon up to 2 players at a time to aid you or use spirit summons in areas they're allowed. You can also go somewhere else to grind for levels so that you stand a better chance in an area. You can even look up enemy weaknesses if you'd like, as there is a massive community for this game that has knowledge about it all.  - Friends and Foes - There are multiple ways to interact with other players within the game. The first thing to note is that there aren't other players simply walking around in this open world, but instead, you see messages and bloodstains. The messages are written by other players using a small list of words. These messages can be helpful, funny, pointless, or deceitful, but generally it's a good idea to read them on your journey. Bloodstains can be interacted with to show a red phantom of another player's last moments before death, which can show you how dangerous an area is. White phantoms can sometimes be seen phasing in and out of your world. These phantoms are other players as they simply play the game, and they're a nice reminder that others are doing just as you're doing. Summon signs can be placed down so that you can be summoned into another world to help another player. Up to 2 players can be summoned by the host at once, and once at least one has been summoned, your world can be open for invasion. An invasion is when a player uses an item to search for worlds to invade so they can kill the host. Red summon signs can be placed to to bring another player into your world so you can fight them. If you want a fair pvp experience, there are 3 colosseums throughout the land that have their own sets of rules to play by or choose from. Lastly, if you are invaded, you can use an item to call for help so you have an ally summoned to rid the invader.  No matter how you want to play this game, the right way is the way YOU choose.   [Design]  - How the design affects the gameplay - Elden Ring has a massive amount design elements that merge amazingly with the gameplay. The developers of this game are known for environmental storytelling. By surveying your environment, you can get insight into the story of the game, or know if an area is dangerous. But many of the design elements of the game can influence a player's decisions. I suggest that you pay attention to your environment as you travel. :)  - Music and Ambiance - If the visual elements don't make a good enough of an environment for you, I found the ambiance to be perfect for every area I visited. The songs are elaborate and beautiful, and fit each situation very well. I haven't had a single issue with audio choice.  - Story - If you're a fan of lore, I have fantastic news for you. There are pieces of lore in just about every corner of the game. Weapon descriptions that give crucial detail on a specific character or location, the architecture implying the origins of a place, enemies being in specific places.   [My Thoughts] - My Experience - I have always been a fan of titles like The Elder Scrolls, Destiny 2, Call of Duty, Pokémon, Dark Souls and such; games that give you an abundance of choice so you can play however you wish. Elden Ring to me is the best game I have ever played. The care put into it is immense, and I consider it a masterpiece. I can see myself playing it for years to come, trying new things or reliving the experience. Subjectively, it's a 10 out of 10 for me, because the shortcomings pale in comparison to the strengths, and that's how I think. Objectively, there is no such thing as a perfect game. There will always be imperfections and issues a game will have, but I can see Elden Ring as being one of the top games of this decade.  - Is this game for you? - Regardless of what games mean to you, I suggest that you try it out for yourself to see if it's for you or not. Generally, if you like open world, challenge, choice, multiplayer, and stunning graphics, I would say it's likely you'll enjoy Elden Ring. Issues that I saw from myself or other friends that played the game, it's a pretty demanding game when it comes to your PC specs. Often times a friend of mine would have FPS issues and needed to turn the graphics down a bunch, and it ended up looking pretty rough. Although lag is an issue in every pvp experience, it was especially frustrating to me in Elden Ring because much of the core gameplay revolves around timing your inputs, and any delay is a big difference.
Great gameplay, stunning visuals, amazing characters. If you are looking anything in a game, this one has it.
