Great open world
I always found the Souls games to be a bit inaccessible, but Elden Ring was the first time I really "got" what is special about the genre and about From Software.   The unique world, with lore as deep as you care to delve, full of brilliant design and art direction, makes Elden Ring stand out as uniquely enticing among a sea of same-y open world games. There are no quest arrows or compasses, and minimal hand-holding in general; a refreshing harkening back to a time when RPGs didn't focus on being streamlined as much as they did on being immersive. Everything has an exciting air of mystery. You have to explore in Elden Ring, and it doesn't feel like a chore or a distraction or a time sink standing in the way of getting to the good stuff. None of the content here feels like filler. (The vast majority of it is optional, in fact. Side quests are not afterthoughts, they're the core of the experience.) Exploration is rewarding here. It's what you'll want to do as you play, and the game's design philosophy is all about encouraging it, letting the player mostly direct their own journey.  Combat can be difficult, yes, but also rewarding and deep, offering tons of build options where most things feel viable and nothing feels particularly obligatory. Most of what turned me off about the souls-like genre before, was not wanting to reach a sticking point and becoming frustrated with my inability to advance. Elden Ring is full of challenging bosses that you may bang your head against, but the open and non-linear nature of the game means you always have some other content you can go do instead if you get stuck on a particular encounter. Leveling up and finding better gear is basically always an option. Elden Ring challenges, and can sometimes frustrate, but never quite enough to keep you away. And the feeling of accomplishment when you are successful is all the sweeter.  It's clear when you play that for the game's creators, this was a labor of love. It's not perfect, but what flaws it has are easy to overlook in face of it's many virtues. If you're like me and you're apprehensive about it because of the Souls genre's reputation for difficulty and high skill floor, do yourself a favor and take the chance on this one. You may surprise yourself, and this game will probably surprise you.

This one hurts. I want to like this game. I really REALLY want to like this game.  But I don't.  Why? Becuase the first 1/2-2/3 of this game is good! Very fun, lots of enemy variety and exploring every nook and cranny is a fun and rewarding experience! The bosses for the most part were a great time to smash my head against. And then i got to the Atlus plains and the game became a boring irritating slog. Almost instantly too. The bosses become repeats of bosses you've already seen, the basic enemies are the exact same as the enemies that you've seen for the last 4 areas, just tankier and hit harder. The game feels like they front loaded it with all of the exciting content then desperately had to fill in the rest of the game with copy and pasted content.  It managed to retroactively dislike previous boss fights by having the exact same boss show up again, and im not talking about some random enemy demon or tree, im talking about storied named bosses that you beat and then they just randomly show up again. There are roughly 10 bosses that you have to fight only once. Out of 170. It is honestly one of the most frustrating games i've played in where the first 2/3 are really really fun and then you run into a steel wall of disappointment and frustration. Honestly is worse than Dark souls 1 and 3.
BEST GAME OF THE YEAR   
All of the things of this game is amazing. But the true reason i bought this is because of the wide amount of player information and jokes held inside. (even if it does get old sometimes). Unlike some of the other games i have or want. this game is leagues above in both stunning video quality and audio. the audio in this game is unlike any other with each boss seemingly having their own "theme" and even some regions having their own genre. such as the stormveil castle sounding completely different than Raya Lucaria showing the inventors brilliance and self inflicting torture of attempting to make a good game greater Reliant on nothing except the backgrounds. Honestly, if you do get this game for a few minutes just listen to the ambient sound, the birds chirping the horses clopping, the strange dog man hiding as a tree, and the random sound of a huge ass arrow being shot at you from 50 miles away. For me at least simply the visual(until you see some of the bosses!) and auditory features of this game make it worth the 60 dollars completely worth it.
A souls-like rpg that over-delivers what it promised.  - The character creation screen is fine with several customization options and a template.  - The gearing system is great, seeing the way your character changes during the journey, and wielding stronger armaments. Even though there are many tier lists, you are fine with any weapons as long as you enjoy them. - Boss fights are different from one another making them feel unique when you roll spamming for your life. - The huge map makes it easy to miss out on some of the optional bosses, so make sure you explore every corner. - The lore is great, but you have to watch some videos to better understand it. This is the first time I'm playing a souls-like game and after my first playthrough, I can easily say that this is one of the best games I have ever played if it's not the best.
After sekiro this was my next from soft souls-like game. Sekiro as a first time experience in this genre was tough. took me years of on and off playing to beat it. But this... I dont know if I would call it a game even. Its more than that. I think I can say that what FromSoft does is well passed extraordinary. Its changed my view on how I like, view and experience video games. And i've been playing games since i was 5 (am now 1 month away from being 24).  You know how people say "oh it grew on me" this does that but it doesn't stop growing on you. We're all curious naturally being human beings its in our DNA, our blood to explore and try. There's endless amounts of that in this game. The only thing that has more to offer, in that area of exploration and curiosity, is life itself. And as odd as that may sound for me to say talking about a video game. its true.  I might be a little off the wire becuase its 12:45am and I've just come off of a grueling 14 hour shift. nonetheless, if you thought about playing this game and can afford it then you should buy it and play it. But in your own way and in your own time.  All love. Ty for reading

First souls game for me.  I hated it.  Put it down for several months.  Decided to try it again because a buddy of mine kept playing it.  But during those several months, I was grinding the crap out of monster hunter world which I believe helped me understand the mechanics of Elden Ring.  You're grinding a lot, you want to build your character as much as you can in order to die less and in order to defeat the boss.  A game that i once hated but now I love because you realize how flexible this game is.  You play the game how you want to play it; you set the difficulty how you want to set it.  There are so many ways to play the game and i believe that is how a game should be.  On top of that, a very beautiful game.  Give this game a shot, be patient with it and it will give you the tools you need (literally like spirits to help you tank for example) if you choose to use it to enjoy the game throughout.  It's no wonder it won game of the year.  I've yet to beat the game and I've put in 180 hours already.  it's that big to get yourself lost in and have fun with it.

I was very on the fence about giving this a thumbs up. I am a  fond owner of most of FromSoftwares work even own an old copy of King's Field running around here somewhere. I feel like this is an awesome game in the skin of a Souls project. The open world is refreshing, the story is better told in a way to understand whats going on and you have some idea of where to go but often find yourself wondering whats around the bend. The combat for me is a slippery slope. The combat while fun and engaging fall short of feeling fair due to the balance of enemies HP pools you often feel like even basic enemies can be spongy and bosses are giant sponges and this really threw me off from enjoying the game thoroughly. Unless you lookup a build that breaking the game in some way, there isn't a great way to nab a regular weapon and feel okay going about your play without wanting to pull out your hair. Even though I don't care for the tanky HP I still feel like this game is the proper evolution of the souls franchise and can't wait to see what else comes out FromSoftware.

vewry godo 
"After about 50 hours in; I'm extremely disappointed. The obvious flaws of previous DS games is present once again (jank movement, enemies swinging through the same walls you bounce off of... the list goes on) but NOW there's even more jank! You have tedious ass platforming on a swivel stick goat, you have scaling bosses negating any sort of leaving, getting stronger, and coming back... you have no inspiration to explore because the boss you're stuck on will be just as (if not more) difficult when you return.  There are BROKEN npcs in this game. Example: There's a singing harpie in the lake that does piss all damage to you. You can sit still and solo him and the entirety of his guards. Unless. Unless he uses one move that AUTOMATICALLY HITS (it actually puts your character into an animation at it's start that becomes uncontrollable) and one shots you.  A random, singing, low level harpie. Has piss all stats but contains a ONE HIT KILL.  And there are a LOT of these scenarios. Balancing doesn't exist in this game.  The movement issues and fighting problems could be EASILY identified by even 10 hours of play test from one human, so I'm beyond sure they're aware and just throw it into the "Difficulty is fun regardless of design" basket they love to bank on.  The game is a slap in the face. It takes away the core concepts of an ARPG, but keeps the difficulty of pretentious level movement. And the pausing. Holy ever loving fuck, the ability for enemies to slow down one of their attacks at random in a string of nromally quick attacks. What the fuck? It's not something WE can do so why would you have to contest with it?  This game amounts to 100+ hours of jank deaths then RnG'ing through moves used into a victory that honestly... feels hollow as fuck by the end. I don't feel as if I mastered their moveset and could destroy them at any time now that I have; I just feel that one of their moves didn't AUTO KO me and I happened to pull a win. I don't feel like I put the work in to get stronger to surpass it, I feel as if it's the same fight as before I went and leveled. Once again negating my effort.  I'm sorry but. Not sorry. This game needs a massive overhaul to become enjoyable. Right now the only people sucking this game off are diehard souls fans who believe that FromSoftware can do no fucking wrong.  But. It can. And does. 1995 PS1 titles had better programmed clipping ffs." - DragonfruitCapable  The real reviews are on reddit. And theyre accurate save your money.

Never been so sad to finish a game in all of my life. Best game I have ever played, hands down.
Coming from someone who's played through every Souls game multiple time, plus Bloodborne/Sekiro, with Bloodborne being my favourite, this game is such a let down! They've essentially taken Dark Souls 3 and slapped it into an open-world.   My biggest gripe with the game is they've seemingly made the game hard just for the sake of being hard. It seems like most enemies, especially bosses, are all running at Bloodborne speed (with 360 gymnastics, jumping all over the place, infinite stamina, spamming combos, crazy damage) while the player character is running at Dark Souls 1 speed. Gone is the challenging yet fair game-play of their previous games.  My second gripe is the open-world aspect. It's so boring! There's not enough in it to actually explore, so you're essentially just running from one major area to another, with a few bits and pieces in between. The atmosphere and the look of the world is great though.  Elden Ring would've benefited so much more from proper interconnected world design.  Nearly everything else is also just copy pasted from previous games, the combat, the animations etc.   I'd say if this is your first From Software game, you may enjoy it, but, I would suggest you play Dark Souls 1 and/or Bloodborne instead.

Looking forwards to more and more Elden Ring! <3

Despite the open-world singleplayer RPG genre continually devolving into pointless fetch quests, poorly written dialogue, and excessive hand-holding, Elden Ring stands out by doing everything exactly how other games don't - and it works beautifully.  This is essentially my first Souls game. I very briefly played DS3, and barely played Sekiro, so I began Elden Ring with an open mind and virtually no expectations. I assumed I'd be in for an interesting, combat centric pseudo-RPG that would be confusing and frustrating.  That's what I got, however for some reason, despite initial frustrations with difficulty, the overload of information that is the stats screen, and the complete lack of guidance in what to do, Elden Ring is absurdly captivating. The environments are varied and gorgeous, dungeons are clearly crafted with care and attention to detail, and characters are interesting (lovable sort ahead).  This is the first game that has had me absolutely and entirely immersed since some of my all-time favourite single-player experiences such as Fallout: New Vegas or Skyrim. The Lands Between is an expanse packed to the brim with fun content, interesting loot, and once you start exploring you never want to stop. The questlines are interesting (though you'll definitely need some help from Fextralife), and the boss fights are straight up epic. The music is downright beautiful and the visuals are so unique, so stylized, and so gorgeous in so many different ways.  I have tried to write and rewrite this review for months, and every time, I feel dissatisfied with my own ability to convey exactly how much this game has blown me away. But now, I think I've found the perfect way to put it:  I put down Elden Ring after playing non-stop, clocking almost 300 hours. Wanting to scratch my open world RPG itch, I revisited Witcher 3 and put in a cool 70 hours then put it down for a reason I couldn't understand. So I put together a new Skyrim modlist, spent probably 30 hours modding and troubleshooting and then another 30 playing, then put it down for a reason I couldn't understand. Hogwarts Legacy came out, and despite my love for the Harry Potter universe, for some reason I couldn't even push myself to finish the main story. I finally relented, and came to terms with the fact that I'd just rather be playing this game.  Elden Ring is a masterpiece. It is an undeniable champion amongst a stale genre saturated with mediocrity and tired franchises. It is a tour de force, a chef d'ouvre, a pièce de résistance. Yes, I pulled up a thesaurus.  Could this be a dog?

Litteraly best gem ever
NOTE: I played this game at launch.  It's okay.  This review will compare Elden Ring to Dark Souls III a lot for obvious reasons.  The open world formula hurts this game a lot. A sense of bewilderment is common when you move around with barely any direction at all. You get indications to sites of grace, but that's it. When i tried going someplace interesting on my own i got stomped instantly. If i didn't explore the crevices of the vast empty land, i was under leveled. If i explored everything then i saw the same ruins asset and enemies scattered everywhere. It felt like a grind and exploration for the sake of exploration.  When i moved on to the "correct" path, and there certainly is one, although the game nor the players tell you that, it all felt very good. The pacing was amazing. This harkens back to my previous statement; when the developer guides you in and puts you through the curated experience (i.e you play it like Dark Souls 3), it's really, really good. When you actually do open world content, it actually kind of sucks.  A huge flaw in design for me is the way they introduce you this danger. Spoilers: There is a point in the game where you get transported from the starting zone, to a much higher level Zone, Caelid. It's very obvious you are supposed to, and should, run. So i did. I got to a site of grace and went back home. This is introduced if you enter an obscure cave with a chest at the end. The run where i didn't do this, and entered as i normally would with Torrent, i got stomped by the enemies and lost my runes.   Therefore, it's apparent to me that the game is made to be explored and scoured for treasure. However, this content is repetitive. The same reused caves and bosses are littered across the map and give you cool stuff. The enemies here are annoying and the same in all of them, with varying layouts. Completing these is mostly a chore you do to unlock things. Not once did i do a dungeon and find it a refreshing or interesting experience. Oh, and if you skip all these you will likely be under leveled and miss out on all the cool stuff.  Following the curated experience is good. I wish they had taken more steps to gently guide you in game instead so they could lean into what they do best, the "dancing" with the bosses. Dark Souls 3 had exquisite combat flow and each boss had a built-in rythm to learn, with few exceptions (looking at you, Oceiros). The satisfaction from completely dismantling a boss by learning their every move was amazing. It truly felt like you rose from the ashes and became stronger by learning every time. The bosses in Elden Ring attack you so mercilessly that you offload some hits to your summons instead or just abuse magic so you avoid the combat.  The openings you gain are therefore the boss attacking your meatshield instead of your own skill dodging their attacks and abusing these openings, especially if you use heavy weapons.  I repeat, the intended way to play the game is by not interacting with the boss.  To see the anthisesis of this, and my ideal version of the game, look at the Iudex Gundyr or Dragonslayer Armor fight from Dark Souls 3.  To summarize, I feel the design around summons and the bosses are poorly done. Removing summons in boss fights, if not altogether, would drastically improve the game. There is no option to not use summons unless you want to use exploits, metagame or otherwise play OP builds, and not what you find fun.  The weapons and ashes of war are good. The combat is better with more variation and more moves to learn. The progression is there.  TL;DR The game is okay, but ultimately dissapointing coming from Dark Souls 3. Two steps forward in some directions, two steps back in others.

I have to say, Elden Ring is easily one of the best games I've played in recent years. The world is absolutely stunning, and the level of detail that has gone into creating it is truly impressive. I found myself constantly getting lost in the game's vast open world, always discovering new areas and secrets.  The combat mechanics are also top-notch, as expected from a FromSoftware game. Every enemy encounter felt like a challenging and rewarding experience, and the boss battles were some of the most epic and intense I've ever played in a video game.  But what really sets Elden Ring apart is its storytelling. George R.R. Martin's involvement has clearly had a significant impact, as the game's world and lore are rich and deep, with plenty of twists and turns that kept me hooked throughout.  Overall, Elden Ring is a masterpiece of a game that truly deserves all the hype it has received. It's a must-play for any fan of action RPGs or FromSoftware's previous titles. I can't wait to dive back into the game and uncover even more of its secrets.

[h1]Pretty damn good. - 9.25/10[/h1]  Alright, just to start off, I truly believe this game is fantastic. But to truly appreciate it, you have to go in with the right mindset. Oftentimes it seems like people hop into this game to prove something to themselves or others and then have their fragile egos shattered when the game proves to be a bit of a challenge. This was sort of how I went into the game. A buddy of mine who was a bit of a Souls veteran decided to brag a bit about beating the Tree Sentinel (first field boss you come across) at base level (they chose Vagabond, I think). So I thought to myself, "I'd like to do that too". And if you've never played a Souls game (me), it's a bit of a humbling experience. However, your persistence WILL pay off. My first time beating the Tree Sentinel took probably more than 40 tries. My successful run was about 20 minutes long and I felt great since I beat him with a Level 1 Wretch. Now, I've learned to beat him in under 3 minutes. That's the thing, you just get better. When you can keep your appreciation for the game above your ego, you can have hours upon hours of fun while watching yourself become better at the game. I'm currently about to reach 500 hours as I'm typing this. Still having a blast with the whole thing. That being said, there are some definite pros and cons to the game which I'll list:    [h1]Cons:[/h1] [hr][/hr] -[b]Mouse and Keyboard controls.[/b] Honestly, I played through the entire game with mouse and keyboard. It wasn't horrible, but it was quite frustrating. From what I've heard, it's a constant FromSoftware issue. The games are supposedly just meant to be played on controller. I had a constant issue trying to do charged heavy attacks. Any time I'd hold down the heavy attack button, I would be locked into a light attack immediately after. I eventually managed to fix this by uncapping my frames with a mod, but we shouldn't have to risk getting banned to enjoy the game properly.  -[b]60 FPS cap.[/b] Last I checked, the game is still locked in 60 FPS. It plays very smoothly, but if you have anything over an RTX 3060, you probably want to see what Elden Ring can do. So I ended up playing the rest of the game at 170 FPS and 140% FOV using a mod. Was silky smooth after that.  -[b]Multiplayer limitations.[/b] So, if you're expecting to just hop into the game and play the whole thing with your friends, guess again. FromSoftware decided that you need to craft an item every time you want to play with a friend. On top of that, you lose access to your horse, summons, ability to traverse freely, sitting at graces, and from what I've seen, the ability to parry. It's just not a fun experience at all. However, there is a Co-op mod which fixes all of those things and is quite fun to play with. Invaders absolutely hate it, but nobody cares what they think anyway so mod it up. Just remember to disable EAC. v:  -[b]Awkward quest management.[/b] So, unless you're following along to an online guide, there's a pretty high possibility that you're going to progress passed a quest and potentially lock yourself out of content because of it. This then forces you to either make a new character, reload your save (assuming you're aware of how to do that), or go into New Game+. It makes for a unique first playthrough, but it is a tad annoying when you realize all the cool stuff you missed the first time around.  -[b][i]Some[/i] limited fashion options.[/b] Not really an issue, but you might struggle to find some decent armor combinations. I know I personally did, but I'm pretty picky.    [h1]Pros:[/h1] [hr][/hr] -[b]It's a complete game.[/b] You're not going to find any areas where it seemed that the devs were cutting corners. You could maybe make a point about some repeat bosses, but all in all, nothing seems unfinished. Some people had some glitchiness when the game first came out, but I didn't have a single issue aside from anything I've said above. Honestly, these last few years, we've sort of grown accustomed to the consistent theme of game developers who just want to release a product and fix it over the game's life cycle. ([i]*cough* Call of Duty *cough*[/i]) That's just not a problem here. FromSoftware had an idea and they saw it through to the very end.  -[b]Amazing design.[/b] It's not hard to get caught in awe while looking around in this game. It's insane to think that a group of people got together and made this. From the boss design to the environments to the animations to the UI elements, it's just beautiful. There are some funky looking things here and there, but you can look up the lore behind them and your appreciation for them increases tenfold.  -[b]Replayability.[/b] There are so many different builds you can run in this game. You wanna run a Bleed build? Level your Arcane and get a quick weapon like a twinblade or dual katanas. Want to just go around slicing things with a big sword? Well, there are plenty of big swords in this game. Two-handing a weapon goes a long way, applying a 50% increase to your Strength stat. Like magic? You can choose between Sorcery or Incantations, both with their own respective stats and equipment scaling. Or, if you're really hardcore, go around with a naked Level 1 Wretch and bonk things with your club. That'll teach Malenia.  -[b]Good confidence builder.[/b] A lot of people insist that this is one of the easiest Souls games. Whether that is true or not, the fact of the matter is, the game is difficult. If you can beat Malenia, that's something to be proud of. Most people uninstall at Margit. So beating this game is something you can consider an actual achievement. Not to say it's a rare occurrence, but it's a long shot from the straight forward goals of many other games.    [h1]TL;DR[/h1]  The game is worth a try. Even if a challenge scares you, the scenery and design of the world are quite the spectacle for anyone with a taste for quality. But if you're here for a challenge, buckle up because some of these enemies aren't throwing punches.

its like getting ur balls crushed repeatedly  and youre asking for more  10/10
I've been an avid action rpg player since I was a kid, starting with Phantasy Star Online on the Dreamcast.  In 2022 and 2023 I played a lot of Splatoon 3, Monster Hunter Rise, and am more recently Playing Risk of Rain 2, Valheim, and Deep Rock Galactic.  All of these games I listed have superb combat and very fitting combat.  They feel good, they're fun, and I find all of these games to control in an enjoyable way.  By that, I mean that they have excellent gameplay.  Elden Ring's gameplay feel and loop are very poor.  The controls and gameplay itself have offered me the least fun that I have ever had in an action rpg game.    Now, before you begin harassing me in claims that I just don't like "difficult" games, I found that Elden Ring is one of the least punishing action rpgs I have ever played.  If you are spending your runes, as you should, then death in this game is literally not a problem at all and there is no reason to fear dying.  So punishing is definitely not a term I would use. "Difficult" is somewhat of a subjective term, but what I am assuming players mean by "difficult" in this context is not "difficult", but actually tedious.  You really only have about 3 things that you might do:  One is to dodge, dodge, dodge, and of course to dodge again and again.  The main gameplay loop is to continually dodge poor optimized, in terms of time, attacks.  The key to not getting hit is to time your dodge, but if you play this game or watch gameplay, there are so many times when you expect to get hit but don't or expect not to get hit but do.  Ultimately, this leads to nothing more than spamming the dodge button like a madman as a go around to this issue.  And that ultimately leads to boring gameplay.    The second thing you might do is attack.  Attacks are done on a controller using the R1 and R2 triggers.  The R2 trigger gives you a kind of charge attack or a slower but heavier hit.  However, as we talked about timing issues, R2 is just far too impractical to even bother using with a basic melee weapon.  It is better to get your poke in with an R1 then run, or rather, to continue your dodge-athon.  Which leads me into explaining why this is so terribly boring.  You are spending most time avoiding combat and being disengaged for one, but more importantly, there isn't a lot of action coming from the player, or combos, or effects that might compromise the opponent, or disable them, or lead to giving the player some kind of advantage due to their fight strategy and so forth.  The action part of the action combat is the player running and evading a barrage of attacks or projectiles from an enemy combatant.  Sure there are spells and you can summon pets or something to spice things up, but if you want to play, or rather, engage in combat, your access to participate in the process of action within this ACTION rpg are incredibly limited.  The third main thing that might comprise your gameplay is using items, which would be a bomb, or a heal potion, or mana potion, whatever you are carrying with you.  These potions are your main source of healing or mana rejuvenation and you will be using them a lot to continue your combat participation.  However, there is a very very big problem with this system.  You want to make sure that you have the item you may need to use on the fly as your selected item because you do not want to have to change active items during combat, as the joystick that controls your sprite is separate from the joystick to change items, which would be your d-pad.  Now, strategically this adds excitement into what would be otherwise very boring gameplay, due to the strategy of selecting items before engaging or running away so you can switch to your mana potion to continue casting spells, or whatever, but the real problem here is that you are literally taking control off of your character in order to access your items.  The switching of items requires a letting go of control of your character and creates a back and forth of engagement and disengagement.  Monster Hunter does this too with their item system, but in the case of Monster Hunter it has very little effect on your ability to continue engagement in the battle.  You can wire bug and dive back in.  In Elden Ring you dodge like a madman, get far far away, then switch items or heal or whatever, then dodge dodge your way back in.  It's simply tedious and boring and this is because your sprite completely lacks mobility.  And,  Monster Hunter does not make you feel like you are giving up control of your character to access items.   In sum, there are better games out there.  The popularity of this game just goes to show that it is not quality that people desire but to be a part of the popular.   The best I could give this game is a 7/10 and even that 7 seems overly generous.  The combat is boring, does not feel rewarding, makes you feel gimped and weak (not in a positive way), discourages engagement, and is severely lacking in complexity or technique.  Defeating an enemy gives you no satisfaction due to anything you have done and simply leaves you with an empty feeling of relief.  I would not recommend this game to anyone.

Video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MWIkdB7Gn8E  ELDEN RING is what I always hoped and dreamed modern gaming would become. I am a huge DARK SOULS franchise fan and I would also declare this one easily the objective best one yet through the sheer hours of content at your fingertips.  You are tarnished. A forgotten and unimportant soul who is maidenless. Luckily you meet Melina who is willing to guide you through your journey as your personal maiden / waifu. She gives you the reins to a spiritual beast named Torrent and your objective it to defeat the Shardbearers and ultimately become Elden Lord through one of the various ways of doing so.  ELDEN RING is insane because it's a 2022 released game that is superior to all of it's predecessors and does not feature any kind of cheapness or monetization whatsoever. It's really a breath of fresh air and every waking moment spent playing this game is true peak escapism and entertainment factor. Featuring beautiful visuals and a way larger than necessary / expected world to explore. I've always liked the SOULS franchises' NPCs but this game takes it a step further in elaborating and explaining each and every character not to mention how cool they look and how they all stand out from each other.  The bosses are the reason to play these games and whether FromSoftware realised that or just decided to go with an open world filled with seemingly endless bosses isn't actually important. The fact the player has a map, a steed, and fast travel from the get go between Sites of Grace make the quality of life so good for veterans of the series who just want to ride past everything, enjoy the scenery, and defeat some legendarily high quality bosses. Many people claim this is the easiest SOULS game but they are definitely wrong since there are some bosses in this game that are far more difficult than anything we've ever previously encountered; the hardest bosses from past games were Orphan of Kos & Darkeater Midir, and those two do not even compare to the likes of someone like Malenia, Blade of Miquella in this game who is borderline impossible to do solo no matter how good you are. The world and it's levels are obviously easier then past games and I prefer it this way actually; because it rewards thorough exploration and gives the player the ability to choose how much of a challenge they actually want since they can seek out more powerful weapons and Ashes if they want, and get early upgrade materials that will out-scale the majority of the game, or you can simply follow the linear path and go from story required boss to story required boss in a straight line without enhancing your character too much which will prove much more challenging.  ELDEN RING is a one of a kind game and shows us how far FromSoftware has come from the cash grabby low effort days of something like DARK SOULS II. There will be nothing like this ever again I assume and if you only play one video game for the rest of your life, choose this one.  10/10.

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1] You are are revived and you find yourself in the Lands Between. Embarking on an epic quest you will need to find and to do what it takes to become and Elden Lord.   [H1]The good[/H1] The visuals, sound and music are stunning. The world building is great: there are so many locations to explore, so many secrets to discover and the monster design never gets boring. And then when you have thought you saw everything you are thrown in another big adventure. There are optional areas in the game that you may just walk by because you don't realize they are there. There are bosses and mini-bosses that you will not see unless you look for them. It brings you back to how games used to be: explore and find new things without everything being served on a plate to you. Being able to complete the game and then realize the game wasn't serving you all the content but instead you need to discover it is great.   The multiplayer portion is similar to Death Stranding where other players can leave you messages and you can see little blood spots where other players died. It's also cool to see the ghosts of others moving through the world and of course you can PvP if you want if you have the correct items. It's a good thing to fully integrate this in the game as prevent you from feeling lonely. There is some PVE and PVP and with the right items equipped you can select what you would like to do.  The items and equipment that you can find is absolutely amazing: even more when you realize that there are no DLCs, microtransactions or other schemes. You pay what you get and it works. I wish other games were still like that.   [H1]The not so good[/H1] The difficulty can be punishing at times - it's part of the charm of the game / series but you might get frustrated because you feel it's unfair. You will need to build your character and get to understand the game mechanics or the bosses will make quick work of you. Without the right tactics you will die a lot regardless whether you are a high level or not. It can be frustrating but all it means you are not good enough - level up, practise, get better and rethink your tactics :-).  You will need to use a gamepad to play this game. I cannot see how you can play this with mouse and keyboard. I used a Switch Pro Controller and that worked great.   While not experiencing bugs or system issues I got several disconnects from the multiplayer part because of "Inappropriate Activity Detected, Unable to Start in Online Mode". I have no idea what happened here as I was just riding my horse at those times. Usually after 10 - 15 minutes I was able to logging back on.  There are many extended quests in the game. You will not realize this at first as there is no quest book, tracker or even on-screen notification. As you can kill NPCs you may lose their story lines without even realizing it.   You will have to make choices but there is not really a good or bad one so it's much how you want to role play. Because of this system as you may like to explore a lot you will find that quests have moved on: NPCs moved to a different location than you expected or you just don't realize there was a quest at all. This can be a bit annoying at times especially when you have play sessions every few days. It's hard to get back on track without making lots of notes.  The marker system on the map only allows 100 bookmarks but there are so many more areas to explore. I wish the limit was raised as in the end I had to keep track of my progress in a notepad. Very much how I used to play old style games.  Why can't we turn off chromatic aberration? I know there is a mod but I didn't want to play my first play through using a mod.  Your character cannot swim or climb I loved that in Zelda Breath of the Wild or Assassin's Creed and I wish we could do it here as well.  There are many, many systems in the game that you find or miss. Basically, you can upgrade just about everything but you need to find the right location, NPC and items. The game will do little to hold your hand it's up to you to discover.   [H1]Summary[/H1] I enjoyed my journey through the Lands Between so far and I will definitely return. It was tough at times but it felt like a breath of fresh air. The visuals and audio are some of the best, I have ever seen. The world building is amazing and I enjoyed all the secrets that I found but also that I learned there is even more to find. Hopefully other developers will study what Elden Ring does well and learn from it as it sets a new milestone for open world gaming.
Greatest game ever made. I've said all I wanted.
I want to love this game so bad. The exploration and world building is only next to a game like outer wilds. Just wandering around this world feels so great and fills me with so much wonder and it baffles me to think all this land with rich history was forged by a game studio. Coming over a hill to see more land after I though I'd reached the edge of the map and the excitement that I get filled with is literally incredible. But that excitement is immediately thwarted by a large sigh and disappointment when I see a boss that's going to be tedious and frustrating to fight.  This is why I know I can't love this game because the bosses in the game are just not fun to fight and there's over 100 of them spread over every inch of this beautiful map.   The bosses are just tedious and feel more like I'm supposed to put more hours into leveling up than practicing to beat them. A large majority of the bosses contain move-sets and combos that can last up to 20 seconds only leaving the player to get in a measly hit which does a sliver of damage. So the player has to hope that within this insane, unreadable dance of attacks they don't get hit lest they die and then barely make a dent in the boss's health...Then repeat over and over again and then you have a large majority of the boss fights in this game. This form of combat feels less like a duel between worthy adversaries and more a like a toddler against Mike Tyson. Its just so tedious and doesn't leave the player satisfied for beating a challenging foe but instead leaves them exhausted and glad they don't have to do that fight again.   I do recommend this game though. Its like actually insane how fantastic this open world experience is. I just think its unfortunate its bogged down by the horrendous and tedious boss combat. I don't think Elden Ring is a masterpiece by any means but its definitely the best concept game I've ever played. If FromSoftware can make another game of this same scope and open world combined with lets say the combat of Sekiro, my god would that be the game of my dreams. But unfortunately the combat drags down one of the best open worlds I've explored.

⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⠟⠋⠁⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠉⠻⣿ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⠁⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⢺⣿ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠆⠜⣿ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⠿⠿⠛⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠉⠻⣿⣿ ⣿⣿⡏⠁⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⣀⣠⣤⣤⣶⣶⣶⣶⣶⣦⣤⡄⠀⠀⠀⠀⢀⣴⣿ ⣿⣿⣷⣄⠀⠀⠀⢠⣾⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⢿⡧⠇⢀⣤⣶ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣾⣮⣭⣿⡻⣽⣒⠀⣤⣜⣭⠐⢐⣒⠢⢰ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣏⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⡟⣾⣿⠂⢈⢿⣷⣞ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣽⣿⣿⣷⣶⣾⡿⠿⣿⠗⠈⢻⣿ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⡿⠻⠋⠉⠑⠀⠀⢘⢻ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⡿⠟⢹⣿⣿⡇⢀⣶⣶⠴⠶⠀⠀⢽ ⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⣿⡿⠀⠀⢸⣿⣿⠀⠀⠣⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⡟⢿⣿ ⣿⣿⣿⡿⠟⠋⠀⠀⠀⠀⠹⣿⣧⣀⠀⠀⠀⠀⡀⣴⠁⢘⡙ ⠉⠉⠁⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠈⠙⢿⠗⠂⠄⠀⣴⡟⠀⠀⡃

After finishing a slow playthrough, throughout last year I would return to elden ring when I just wanted to exist in the lands between. The combat feels the best of all the souls-like games, the world is gorgeous, and all the bosses are anime as fuck! If this is your first souls game, this is definitely the game to play, as they have really streamlined a "choose your own difficulty" mechanics. Spells are more varied and magic is less intimidating to play at the start, spirit summons can make a lot of bosses way easier, and it is easier than ever to get summoned help. Use your mount if you can! Torrent is amazing, I've never played a game before where I felt the power of calvary, horses op, but in a good way.  I think Elden Ring has taken Bloodborne's place as my favorite souls-borne game, and I can't wait for the DLC!

What an absolute masterpiece of a game. Definitely deserved GOTY.  I have never played souls-like game before and I was very skeptical. In the beginning you are thrown in a massive world with little to no guidance and everything is written inside description notes found deep in your inventory. I, ofcourse, didn't knew about it and was banging my head around to find any useful information if possible.  Getting killed many times by Agheel Lake Dragon and eventually entering the trap inside ruins behind it xDD (I am pretty sure everyone suffered from it). Game felt unforgiving right from the start.  But, this is where open-word and true freedom started showing it's charm. I could just smack some dude and see if I am remotely capable of defeating them or not. Roaming around and going to depths as well as far away corners started paying off little by little. Although I was very slow at levelling up in the beginning (level 44 after 45 hours) but atleast I could explore at my own pace.  Took little bit help from "Elden Ring Discord Server" (very nice people) and kept going ahead. Beautiful locations and nicely optimized game were added bonus.  After a while, story and progression started to make sense and I could piece together progress map to move ahead and this is where the game began to look much more enjoyable. It almost took me 55 hours to fall in love with Elden Ring and realise it's GOTY awards. Completed lots of side quests and defeated almost every boss except (2 evergoals and dragon placidusax). Some bosses felt punishing even after learning so much and they gave true satisfaction upon defeating them.  My Rating - 10/10 (even without sale) Gametime - 100 hours (if a noob like me took 130 hours, I am pretty sure average player will take a lot less) 100% completion time - 150 to 160 hours.

Only complaints I would have is the horse combat and movement could use some work as well as some of the bosses having spammy combos that are hard to dodge unless you get lucky or dodge at the exact right frame. Looking at you Malenia and your water fowl dance. Overall the game is great tho. Difficult but not impossible. Still doesn't stop the feeling of accomplishment once you get past that one boss you've spent an hour trying to beat tho.  Plus the game is gorgeous and some of the bosses are a spectacle to behold if you're into that sort of thing. Definitely a must buy for anybody that's a fan of souls-likes. If you've never played any games in the genre this is a good place to start too.

Men, if someone gave some money i'll probably rebuy this game. Maybe the optimization is ass, but aside of that is great and best way to play a Dark Souls experiencie.
(Note that all of my play sessions were exclusively with the seamless co-op mod because yay co-op and screw invasions and EAC.)  It's the dream. An open world Dark Souls game. What's not to love? Shame it lost game of the year to Bill Clinton. So many ways to play and it's fairly noob friendly while still chewing you up and spitting you out like a Souls game should. I can't beat bosses naked with a ham sandwitch like some people, but once you find a build and figure things out, it's godly. Iv'e got a Sephiroth rivers of blood thing going on for my main character and it's great.  If you love co-op and hate PVP like me, grab the Seamless co-op mod from Nexus Mods. It uses Steam servers and a .ini password instead of Fromsoft's servers, a separate executable and bypasses the need for Epic's performance sapping spyware known as EAC. Make sure you get your steed and your summon bell before starting because you may miss them during co-op, but it's 100% full time co-op without the usual Souls summoning signs and boss restrictions. It's glorious fun. Watching your friend get yeeted off a cliff by a pumpkin head never stops being funny.

Probably one of the best games I've ever played. Despite filling me with so much rage, I'll never get back the experience I got playing this for the first time in its entirety. I don't think a single game in history had gotten as much hype as Elden Ring pre and post-release, and it's super nice to see that people are still exploring and making Elden Ring content.
I only recommend this game for it's adventure; exploration and beauty is unparalleled and cannot match any other soulslike.   However, it's combat is simultaneously a repeat of old soulslikes but done in the worst way possible. The beauty of the soulslike combat system was one-on-one combat: attack, dodge, and parry. Keeping perfect time and rhythm. This game doesn't have rhythm or timing. Just constant barrages of attacks from every single enemy barring the largest and most awkward. You will feel under pressure every second but never a chance to retaliate except for only in the most minute openings.   From Software's games have certainly felt the pressure of being "Difficult" and are being pressed to take it's formula and press it to it's logical maxima until it no longer resembles the original. These enemies and bosses do not feel like they are from the original or from any soulslike that has come out since, but enemies from non soulslike games. Games where the player should be able to return with equal force, but never can because they feel like they themselves are ripped from DS1.  This game will never reach the infamy of DS2 but so many encounters encompass what made that game more frustrating than fun: ambushes and memorization. Great hard games test reaction times not memorization, like the difference between the first and second Halo Legendary campaigns: where the second involved little reaction and plenty of memory after first failing many many times, the first always presented you with tests of skill for things you've previously gone through, clearly presenting the danger up front and allowing thought for your next moves for every encounter. The first Halo respected the player and wanted them to win, it understood it was a game and while it challenged the player it did not provide a wall that required narrow windows and laugh at you for not finding them. Elden Ring feels like the Dungeon Master that hated their players, the teacher that wanted you to fail, or the backstabbing friend that never was on your side.  If this was not a game then I would recommend it beyond exploring, if learning software engineering was a game I wouldn't recommend it, if learning art was a game I wouldn't recommend it, if being alive was a game I wouldn't recommend it. It doesn't matter how hard the anything is, you will eventually get good enough at to beat it. When people complain about souls games, they're not having fun. Its not because it's hard.  TL;DR/Bottom Line: The game is only kind of fun, but if every hobby, and almost every other game bores you, then you may find this game thoroughly fun after the exploration runs out.

A truly fantastic open world Fromsoft game. With almost no cutscenes, the game manages to tell a fantastic narrative by placing items, enemies, NPCs, designs, and the landscape itself in areas that have importance to their locations. Beautifully designed and intelligently connected, the world will leave any player mystified.  The game play is another rhythm game, learn how the enemy fights and one can become untouchable. While being easier than other Fromsoft games, Elden Ring enemies will have quite a few tricks up their sleeves to give Souls-like veterans a skill check. Overall the game is amazing, graphics are top notch, gameplay smooth and fun and a lot of customisation for your character (such as classes, weapons, spells, etc) but you can also pretty much choose to be anything as long as you keep leveling. Story is good and the fact that you're being called ''maidenless'' at the beginning is funny. The only down side of the game unfortunately is the coop. It's pretty horrible because if you plan to play it with your mates, it's pretty hard. While I was doing a boss (The rider near the church at the beginning), I was almost killing the boss and dodged him extremely well and played good, however me and my mate got invaded by some high level player and pretty much healed the boss with half hp). Yes you heard it right, not only the invaders are not being targeted by the mobs, but they can also use the bosses to easily kill you. For a new player that's pretty discouraging for them to even make em try to touch coop, considering that's the best part about a multiplayer, especially a souls game. If you plan on playing this on coop, I'd suggest another game like Nioh 1 or 2. It's a souls game and it may not be the same style as this one but it has amazing coop and I highly recommend that one too. I was going to give Elden Ring a 10/10 but due to this coop problem which is honestly pretty unfortunate, I give it an 8/10. Worth the shot.

good game
Most games are rollercoaster rides that guide you from one point to the next while trying to keep your attention through exposition that rarely amounts to anything more than popcorn. While there is nothing wrong with that and said games can provide entertainment, the overall experience tends to be forgettable.   Elden Ring takes the established Souls formula and puts it in a Zelda like open world. After 500+ hours I still find new stuff, uncover dialogue with NPCs, etc. While all the elements to keep you entertained for hours upon hours are there, there is also a lot more. It's like a digital painting, a work of art. From the colour palette to the music. Even though the world is a bleak, surreal and dreamy nothing feels out of place. Every item, NPC, piece of dialogue feels like it belongs there for a reason. This unfortunately isn't always true for the side content, which is one of drawbacks of an open world.  The obvious shortcomings of an open world game are easily overlooked by the overall experience that is present here. It makes the Souls formula accessible to a larger mainstream audience without handicapping the experience or the artistic narrative. Elden Ring will undoubtedly go down as a masterpiece along fondly remembered titles like Grim Fandango or Deus Ex.
Master piece

This game simply shows how much love and hard work the devs have put in. I have played a lot of games and admired the craft put in them. But Elden Ring stands out from all of those. Initially when I started playing, seeing the map, I thought how can the world be so small. Little did I know that it was just a small part of the entire world. As I progressed through the game, I realized each area is distinct and very well made. The eerie feeling in dark dungeons and thinking that a strong enemy may sprung out of the dark any moment keeps you on your toes all the time. There are a lot of variations in enemies and the boss designs are of different level entirely.   I find most games that have a playtime of 10-20 hours are very detailed. But creating such a huge world and taking into account each and every detail is very impressive. Never did I encounter any bug as well. This game is well worth the money spent and even more.   I conclude that this is the best game I have ever played (keeping into mind RDR2 and KCD)

It’s alright I guess
Good god this game is a masterpiece. I have played it pretty much nonstop since I got it almost every free moment I have (I am writing this as I play). The only reason I wouldnt recommend it is its addicting. This is my first souls game and very rarely do I have issues with it.  Pros: Hours of side content Rich environmental and lore storytelling Interesting characters Open world and a non-linear experience letting you go at your own pace Bosses are usually pretty fun and unique, even ones that reoccur as normal enemies later as it is incredibly satisfying to fight something as a boss and come back and beat it to a pulp as a regular enemy Bosses are rarely unfair and it usually feels like your fault for dying either by being under leveled or unskilled Speaking of being underlevel, leveling and power leveling to make fights easier is completely viable and legitimate way to play Tons of secrets to explore and find granting new rewards Cons: Its a souls game, if you rage easy its not for you Early game is brutal and hard and basically requires some grind or incredible skill Camera can be buggy getting stuck and spinning with lock on Lock on can fuck you as often as it helps you by randomly switching targets or body parts from slight mouse movements making you miss or get stuck Horse combat can trivialize fights Attacking with colossal weapons is sluggish but also seems to eat inputs meaning mashing can make you commit to extra attacks and take damage When a something DOES feel unfair it feels EXTREMELY UNFAIR. (For me it was putting a magma wyrm in a tiny arena where it can basically take up the entire stage with one move it likes to spam that leaves lingering magma) Some puzzles are insanely complex, almost requiring a video making blind playthroughs hard Jumping and falling on someone COUNTS AS AN ATTACK and will make them hostile or OUTRIGHT KILL some characters, which can lock you out of some quests and even endings, This can be fixed with a specific item at a specific place but the location is never revealed or explained until you randomly find it. Scaling feels wonky, and some enemies will seem overly tanky despite being much weaker previously, or youll come back after a few levels and theyll be a joke Overall though I would definitely recommend this game. I will be going for a second play through to go for other endings!

this game cool
This game is Space Ace for the 2020s.    Through trial and error figure out the combo of block, roll, little hit, big hit, roll, rinse repeat.  Finally beat bad guy.   Next screen, new bad guy.   Figure out new combo on up down left right.   Beat guy,  New screen, rinse repeat.     Sorry those that love this genre, but this is just lame.   I've been playing games for over 40 years, and this game reminds me of those crappy early games that were simple memorize the combo games, that threw in randomness to just make them unfair.    I've beaten many games on hard/insane level but this one takes the biscuit. The only Souls-like game that actually has combat where you can plot your way through a mixed group of bad guys is Jedi Fallen order.    For all those who will call me a troll, answer this question.   Did you get through this game without dying 500+ times???   If not, then this game is pure luck.....The only people that can claim to be "gud" at this game are those that went all the way through without dying once.    The rest just spammed your way through. The only thing that would make this game bearable is to be able to save it when I want to, like just before the locked door you know insta-death is waiting behind.........but Nooooooo, I have to die coz my perfectly timed counter just missed and I'm dead, so I have to wait 15 seconds for the reload then battle my way through the same axe fodder for 10 mins, to get back to the "boss" to then watch and learn their moves, oops, lag, missed roll or missed counter......dead......rinse repeat.   jeez.   Is this gaming?

good game
I recommend this game based entirely on the fact it is a solid, well made game, that should be enjoyable for a few people, not for others.  But make no mistake, absolutely overrated, just a re-skinned dark souls with a few new features that were probably thought of by one of the designers while taking a shit or having a wank or something.  Re-skinned enemies from previous games.  Same old gameplay, gets a bit stale, same shit different type of corn inside.  Personally for me the open world aspect only served to make the game more tedious than souls games usually are, I ended up getting "souls fatigue" about a quarter into the game, as the start of it is honestly quite dull overall.   Not actually sure why this got GOTY, isn't that award just a popularity contest nowadays anyway?   But other than that, sure yeah it's objectively fine I've no reason to not recommend it, have fun playing Dark souls 4 open world edition.

It's the newest Dark Souls. This game has a huge number of PvP balance issues, but PvP has always been nightmarish in this game series, so it doesn't bug me. There are noob friendly weapons in the game that will help someone wanting to experience the PvE arc without actual danger, but if you're a legit Dark Souls original player then you can choose not to use those. It's From Software's latest opus and this series will remain legendary for years to come.

Incredible game. FromSoftware knows how to make a game. This is my second Souls game and I put it personally below Dark Souls: REMASTERED. I think FromSoftware did an admirable job making an expansive open world, but personally found it to fall into the same pitfalls as any other open world game: repetition, boring caves, etc. I think it is better done than most, but it would have been a much better experience if it was more like Bloodborne or Dark Souls.   My personal gripe is that despite the game rendering 21:9, it puts vertical black bars over the sides to force it to 16:9. I would beg FromSoftware to fix this. There is no reason to do this when the game obviously supports it. I have loaded into the game several times and not have the black bars on the screen and it is everything I wanted.  All of that said, I would still absolutely recommend the game. 9.5/10

Elden Ring is a masterpiece of a video game. It has it all: intriguing story, stunning visuals, unique NPCs and best of all, incredible combat.   As an avid Bloodborne lover, good combat flow, and combat enjoyability is a must for me. One of the problems with most souls/soulslike games for me is when I beat a boss, I often feel a “ugh thank god that’s over with” feeling. I don’t get that victorious hell-yeah moment, I’m just glad it’s done and lowkey dreading the next boss that I come across. Elden Ring? Every boss fight is hard fought, but incredibly satisfying. The elation of taking down these gorgeously designed bosses is unlike anything I’ve ever experienced before with any video game. It feels good to win. So good that I find myself constantly coming back to try new builds and new ways to challenge myself.   If you’re new to the souls genre, I almost want to recommend waiting to play this game till after you try something like Dark Souls. Elden Ring feels so vastly different, and superior in many quality-of-life ways that it feels almost unfair to compare it to most of its predecessors. With that being said, I can’t emphasize enough that this game is a must try.

Note: This is not strictly a negative review, but the game’s overall design makes it hard for me to openly recommend it.  Elden Ring is an open world combat RPG, where battling with enemies is the center of everything. There is a huge world to explore where you find various items, that help your character you make in the beginning to become stronger statistically, but everything you find centers on your combat capability of course, since this is not an adventure game. Albeit this approach, the game offers some impressive vistas throughout the world you explore, somewhat curious NPCs that talk to you and most importantly challenges in the form of varying enemies and boss battles. There are many places you can visit, also underground, which all help you, at the end of the day, to become stronger by giving you more runes, that are basically a currency you buy levels with at checkpoints.  If one is familiar with the developer’s, From Software, former titles, the risk reward mechanic is the same in here and the actual fighting mechanics are also the same as in Dark Souls games; you lose your runes when you die, but can retrieve them from your death spot, but lose them completely if you die again before that, and the fighting is basically careful observing of enemies while dodging (by rolling endlessly) and blocking.  The game is fun at the beginning, offering decent challenge, and at any point if you find the game too tough, which is likely, you can gain more levels by collecting runes for slaying enemies or simply exploring easier approachable areas. Since the game is very long in length due to the sheer size of the world, most players might wish to follow the main path straight to the end without much additional exploration, but alas, the game’s difficulty, even despite the help of a selectable phantom fighter (spirit ashes) who you can call in for help in tough spots, forces exploration to gain runes for the vast majority of players to overcome later tough enemies. This might not sound like an issue, since this applies to some other open world titles too, but the time it takes to explore to be strong enough is in tens of hours – I’m not exaggerating.  While the beginning is fun and quite exciting, the more you play the more repetition kicks in, even if the areas around the map are visually different, but enemies repeat and so do bosses; they use the same models. Even the overall quality of level design is better at the beginning, the Stormveil Castle being at least to me the most exciting place to see and explore, after that perhaps a few notable places existing in the game. This castle is at the very beginning and after that the quality slowly drops the further you get, endgame being very tough and a slog to get through, mostly due to some nasty bosses.  The bosses are a big part of the studio’s focus and they are admittedly often fun to fight, but in this game most bosses are annoyingly designed, scaling in damage too much from the very beginning till the end. This vast damage they tend to inflict in a single strike makes the game more a hectic rhythm based act to avoid the worst hits, while waiting patiently for an opening to strike pretty much freely when the enemy takes it’s pause. I find this limiting character building wise, since I’m sure the game is extremely hard without putting many skill points on vitality (max health) to sustain more damage.  The bosses also have cheap moves and combos, which often rightfully makes you feel like you die an unexpected and unfair death, but this is thankfully mitigated by the phantom helper that can take hits from enemies instead of you and even slightly damage them, so you can heal up on the side, perhaps cast a spell or incantation and prepare to strike again. So even if boss design is most often not as great as in previous games from the studio, especially compared to Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, occasionally being even bad, the phantom helper is there for you making some bosses actually pretty trivial, which is not a bad thing if you don’t wish to be stuck on them in this - in my honest opinion - too long game.  I personally have explored almost everything in the world and I’m likely ”over leveled”, which would mean that in the main progression path I’m fighting enemies on a higher level than players usually are, but still, after playing so long, easily over 100 hours in fact, I’m still currently momentarily stuck at one mandatory very late game boss that, once again, has upped damage so that it can kill you in a short sweep of attacks. This fact is saddening to me, since the game has pretty fun exploration, the best yet character building in the studio’s history, amusing places to discover, and of course the action is intuitive and most often entertaining, but yet the game is enough of a slog to get through at many points and too repetitive. If you decide or rather need to explore much because of the difficulty that can spike, the game starts undoubtedly to feel overall as following: cheap. It is a cheap game in the end with talent and quality at many places, but filler content and bad design all over the place. This game should have been shorter in my opinion, or at least easy enough to complete quicker going straight through the main path, but for me - and I’m not a noob mind you since I have completed Dark Souls 1 and 3 and Sekiro, Elden Ring is simply too tough to my taste to call it enjoyable.  As a side note, I might find the game so hard due to a faith build, meaning I use incantations in the game that are slow to cast in the heat of a battle, but this fact just tarnishes the game even more, because it truly doesn’t allow too much freedom in building the character if you want to excel as care free as possible - which you want, trust me.  Now you might find this game fun and most players looking for combatting challenge will do at the beginning for a long while, but I label this review as negative due to the overall quality throughout the experience and the too cheap and frustrating challenge you will face eventually, no matter how good you are. If you are good, you will overcome the challenge, perhaps even quickly, but I doubt many of the fights are that fun in any case, unlike in Dark Souls 3 for example, where the game is thoroughly quite carefully designed, albeit unforgiving.  Consider this game if you are ready to face this disappointment I’m feeling here and in the case you are a fan of the studio’s previous work, but for many, you should think twice, remembering that this game is far from GOTY material like some might claim, because the quality is so varying. I think sound design and graphics should be better as well to call this a GOTY, since the tech is like a mix of last-gen and current-gen, leaning more on the last-gen.  Lastly about the mentioned technical side: The game runs decent enough if you have strong single core CPU performance and my RX 5700 XT plays it almost always at 60 FPS on max settings at 1440p, which the game is unfortunately capped at, but this hasn’t bothered me mentionably. There are areas that are bound to drop the framerate below 60 FPS, somewhere around 40 – 45, which is a slight annoyance, but those moments are rare. The game’s current version 1.08.1 is bug free, though it’s worth to mention that I experienced one freeze-up.  Enjoy, suffer, be numbed, overcome, that is the formula of Elden Ring. Take this as you wish.

At first feels like a good old souls game, then you get the horse which feels VERY weird but still acceptable as a progression from dark souls 3, but then for some reason they require random items to progress and make these items unobtainable if you dont lookup a guide at which point this game completely takes a nose dive.  It essentially is many tiny little dark souls tunnels on a gigantic map without any kind of coherence or connection between them. Its as if they just took all the crap levels they had left over from the previous dark souls games and smushed them together into one game using the "open world" excuse to not have to build any kind of atmosphere or continuity between the levels.  Enemies repeat constantly. You get to see the same copy paste enemies all over the map which would work if this was dark souls tunnels but not with these large "open world" levels.  It feels like a cheap korean mmorpg open world with dark souls "dungeons" which you go into and get absolutely nothing at the end of the tunnel because the tunnel does not interconnect with anything else. Theres really no reason to play this game theres no sense of accomplishment and no atmosphere. Its a mediocre dark souls game and a very bad open world game they really completely failed.

Elden Ring to me was a experience like no other. The challenges were great, the suspense and tensions were high, and the characters completely memorable. Nothing is more thrilling and/or relieving than finally killing that boss that took between ten to a hundred attempts to subjugate. Sometimes I cheer at my victory over my opponent, and sometimes I solemnly stare in the spot my opponent turned to dust, realizing I just put down a poor innocent creature that became a monster out of circumstance. Its not a game for the feint of heart, but if you are up for the challenge, Elden Ring is entirely worth it.

                                                                                      7/10   This game is amazing and disappointing at the same time, I feel like a lot of these problems is the symptom of being a open world game.   The dungeon design is incredibly frustrating with the way forward being chosen at random it seems, I think this was done to encourage exploration but it just leads to multiple times you run loops around a dungeon while getting very confused.   The bosses are doable at lower levels but incredibly tedious to fight since they take ages to kill. This is the result of them being given a very generous amount of health and one mistake can lead to you getting one shotted. But also this works in the other way where bosses you missed feel way too easy and die in seconds.  Despite all the mistakes, and trust me this game has mistakes, I love it! But it sure has areas to improve in.

busiinm
This game absolutely is massive, with an absolutely colossal map and another huge map underneath, there's tons of stuff to do. There are piles of awesome spells and super fun upgradeable weapons, crazy bosses and wicked powers. There's a lot of flexibility to experiment with different builds because you can re-spec like 9 times per playthrough if you want to change up your playstyle.   It seems to have a really nice community, in game and online that enjoys helping each other out and sometimes invading others to role play the bad guy and try to stop the hero! Awesome fun!   The game is beautiful and hopeful but also filled with despair, from a lore standpoint. This game is definitely challenging but there are many resources online to help the player though tough parts or community members or NPC spirits that can be summoned to assist in clearing hard bosses or areas.  The cut scenes and some of the areas you find in this game are so badass and gnarly. Very metal, which i love personally.  Now for the bad because honesty is key, there are times that you have to jump from object to object and its easy to die doing that. These parts of the game aren't generally necessary to go to thankfully, but can have really good rewards at the end, so there's incentive.    The game punishes mistakes and that can be frustrating.

This game simply fulfills every need for a game, Character Customization, Adventure, Story, Lore, EPICNESS, and in-depth playing fields. Above all else, I could play this game until the end of time. If you have 60$, I promise you're getting the deal of a lifetime.

This is epic.
Elden Ring is an action role playing RPG game/PP crusher simulator created by FromSoftware where you explore the open world of the Lands Between and fight hard bosses in between completing quests and trying not to die. I fell in love with the Soulsborne series when I first started playing Bloodborne on the PS4, after which I went out on a whim and bought myself Demon's Souls for PS3 as well as Dark Souls 1-3. I heard about this game a while ago, got hyped and pre-ordered as soon as I could before waiting a year to start the game. Having platinumed the game on PS5 and hoping to start on Steam someday in the future, here are my thoughts:  The Story is one of those things that you just have to kind of explore and figure out by piecing together pieces of dialogue, item descriptions as well as environmental cues. I can't even tell you much of anything about it, but what I can say is like all FromSoft Souls titles, I love it. It keeps the goal simple: You're a Tarnished (an individual who was banned by the former queen from the Lands Between) who is going for the spot of Elden Lord and to do so has to fight through several different demigods in order to do so. You'll run into several characters via out in the world or the Hubworld, Roundtable Hold, who could do anything from basically nothing to giving you entire new endings. That's all I have to say for the plot:  The Gameplay is basically almost the same as the other games in the Souls Series. You go from area to area to loot objects, fight bosses, complete particular quest lines for certain rewards, invade/fight enemy invaders except one caveat: It’s open world. And I mean it’s OPEN world. The other games were a lot more simplified as well as complex: they were a bit open in terms of pathways, shortcuts etc but they also had a straight way from point A to point B as well. In this game, everything is basically tenfold in terms of it’s game play design from how you get to certain areas to how to fight certain bosses. One example: [Spoiler] In order to get to Leyendell there’s a couple different ways you can get to that region. One is you could ride up the Grand Lift of Dectus, where you need two halves of a medallion in which you can get each at Forth Haight and Fort Faroth. Another way you could do it is by going underneath a church near the Lift, going through a village and climbing up a mountain before killing the Magma Wyrm and getting up that way. ANOTHER way is to get killed/abducted at the bottom of the waterwheel in Raya Lucaria where you wake up in an area at Volcano Manor and fight your way out of the caves.[/Spoiler] Stuff like this is mindblowing and is amazing how much attention to detail and scope it took to truly create such a thing. And keep in mind this is only one example, I can’t list everything because truthfully, like this game, there’s so much stuff TO list that I’d be making a f u c king video essay on it. But also in essence I do think that can be to this game’s detriment as well: It’s so huge that it’s kind of overwhelming with its scale, and with that it can lose some of it’s uniqueness when you see multiple of the same bosses repeated over and over again with different skins. I also found the combat to be hard definitely, challenging is a yes, but I’m not sure if it’s just because I suck but I felt that now in this game it’s definitely more geared towards having summon spirits for boss combat? I’ve always been someone who liked to coop anyways so I’ve been cool with it but it can be kind of frustrating at times with certain bosses. I guess to finish this off just be aware that this game is difficult yes, but the community is great. Sure, are there a s sholes who will just tell you to “Get Gud'' and make believe they aren’t a bunch of basement dwelling pee larpers? Yes. But the amount of people who will go out of their way to help you for no reason other than why not is amazing. Just know in order to summon people: Get the Furlcalling Finger Remedy. They can be found as loot, crafted via Erdleaf Flowers, bought from certain merchants, etc. Also for certain places to be able to summon other players you have to activate summoning pools so keep a lookout for small statues.  Sound Design/Art/Graphics; all of this is great and I’m not even sure I could expand upon it other than I don’t feel that the Soundtrack is as memorable as the other souls games? Either way it didn’t matter to me as it fit in the background and made everything memorable as I played even though when I got out of it I didn’t remember much. Still it looks great, the art design is amazing and graphics are good too.  I can’t do justice to this game in a single Steam review, but if you’re new to the series or you wanna try it out just know this: Play fresh, wing it a bit and have fun, try not to get overwhelmed and experience EVERYTHING because it’s impossible (though it is possible to get all the trophies in one playthrough if that’s your thing). Research the game a bit, see what builds you want to go for (though your starting class does kind of gear you in certain ways so I’d say research BEFORE you start the game unless you just kinda want to wing it), farm a bit and upgrade your stats. But please god take breaks and take it at your own pace; because you will die and die and die some more and then die again; it can be a frustrating and strange loop but when it clicks with you it clicks with you. And if it doesn’t? That’s ok too and there’s no shame in it. Elden Ring is the culmination of all the things that FromSoft has done with the other Souls games and expanded upon it with great effect (and sometimes mixed results in certain things), but to me it certainly deserves the Game of the Year title.
