From the very beginning, Elden Ring will whip you into shape, throwing you into a world full of sadistiic enemies and punishing gameplay. Every corner you turn is like a new level of torture, a new level of submission to your gaming overlords.  But don't worry because the pain is worth it. There's nothing more satisfying than finally defeating that boss that's been spanking you for hours. And when you do, you'll feel likea real badass!  Elden Ring is also full of surprises, just like a good dominatrix. You never know what's coming next, and every new challenge is like a new way to be punished.  The graphics are gorgeous, and the soundtrack will have you begging for more. But let's be honest, you're not here for the aesthetics. You're here to be put in your place, to be dominated by a game that knows no mercy.  It's no wonder that Elden Ring has been hailed as the game of the year. It's a true work of sadomasochistic art. The unforgiving difficulty, the punishing combat, the unpredictable challenges - it all comes together in a way that's truly amazing.  Sure, you'll rage and scream and maybe even throw your controller across the room a few times. But in the end, you'll be left with a sense of satisfaction and accomplishment that few other games can provide.  So if you're a true glutton for punishment, Elden Ring is the game for you. It's totally worth a buy, and it might just leave you begging for more.

Eighty-ish hours and one trophy later, five takeaways from The Lands Between™:  * The game's hardware requirements are correct: if you want to play Elden Ring at a consistent 1080p60, your CPU needs at least 6 cores and 12 threads. Never mind the main storyline, the true final boss is realizing that lowering the display resolution and graphics quality to 720p/Low won't get you a stable 60fps on an otherwise-serviceable quad-core CPU. If you don't have a hexacore CPU, see if your graphics software can lock the frame rate to 30; I found a steady 30fps to be a better visual experience than a stuttery ~45fps. * After a single, pseudo-100% clear spanning several weeks, speedrunning this twice for the other ending achievements was a breath of fresh air.  * Vigor and armor can prevent being one-shot in combat, but nothing can prevent getting one-shot by fall damage. This rule applies to your enemies, too. * In a world where 'RTFM' is sage advice, if a game isn't going to explicitly tell you what's going on, never be ashamed to do your own research. It's always easier to search for information out-of-game than to search for your lost runes in-game. * Whoever made the final call on the HUD only displaying piecewise elements that were recently used without flickering or cluttering up the screen deserves high praise. Conversely, whoever made the final call on putting a boss directly in a pile of scarlet rot *more than once* needs to update their resume. * Bonus 6th takeaway: Malenia's a bully, but Waterfowl Dance is the only truly threatening aspect of her kit. Try complaining less and getting better at the game. Or you can equip Blasphemous Blade/Magma Wyrm Scalesword and press L2 after dodging, that works too.

What to say that's not already been said about sliced bread?
Ignore the hype, ignore you're friends, don't bother playing this game. REQUIRES AT LEAST 10 hours of tutorial videos on builds, basic game mechanics, and side quests that exist in the game before actually playing. The game does not teach you anything about how to play it, you need to rely on outside help in order to progress. This includes basic things like how to navigate the menu, how to create a strong character, which weapons to use, etc. The difficulty curve is set up so that you NEED to learn these things early on, else you will not progress in the game.  To start off, here is the entire plot to the game: you want to be elden lord, maybe. That's it. Some characters are more or less keen on that, but it's not really clear. Most of the lore and "story" of the game can be found in item descriptions, and its the most ineffectual way to tell a story that I have ever encountered. Side missions have zero logic to them, basically you need to talk to every NPC in the game in order to progress a mission without referencing a guide or tutorial. Most missions have a point where you grab some item like "the sacred toenail of Ira the dancer" and for some reason you are supposed to know that "Ephesius" needs that to make it to Narnia or some nonsense like that. Many of these side missions are necessary to beat the game at a reasonable difficulty level, else you will be under leveled or poorly equipped to face required bosses.  Honestly I can't talk about this game without referencing the menu, it is the most poorly organized, laziest feature to any video game I have ever played. This studio has had an entire decade to hone the menuing system in their RPG game, and the best thing they can come up with is a literal grab bag of items organized like a pile of clothes on a teenagers dorm room floor. I cannot tell you how many times I grabbed an item only to never use it in my play-through simply because I lost it in the menu. There is a lantern in this game, and I have to play Where's Waldo every single time I try to equip it simply because I picked something up on the ground in an open world RPG game, and it reshuffled my items.  Gameplay wise, its a souls game. That is to say, its a rhythm game that tries to cheese you every step of the way. In some ways, I find this rewarding, especially when facing groups of enemies in the games various dungeons. Assuming you have min/maxed your character to make the fight doable of course. Most of these encounters are well set up to challenge you to figure out a strategy to beat them consistently, given limited space and resources. Unfortunately, this is an open world game, and the majority of encounters occur in the open world. In these cases, it is easy to bypass encounters by going around them, or fighting them one on one. To make up for that, the game designers added lots of harder enemies that are required fights for one reason or another. All of these fights devolve into "big guy with sword in field" or "big guy with axe in field", and have basically the same move sets. The best way to deal with them is to grind levels until you can easily combo or one shot them, otherwise you're in for repetitive, uninspired fights. A majority of enemies are direct copy pastes of one another, and it's a shame.  It's a shame because the art might be the best I have seen in a video game. There are many biomes/areas to explore, and each their own unique artistic style to them. You can easily tell which area you are in just by the art style of the world around you. I visited every single area in this game simply because I wanted to explore the environment that the artists created, and I put up with all of repetitive gameplay and the obnoxious bosses to do it.  The bosses in this game suffer the same issue as the enemies. At least half are re-used throughout the game, the worst example being used at least 6 times. Many of them share similar move-sets as well, making the artistically unique bosses seem like copies of earlier ones. Put simply, fighting them is a chore. The bigger, "demigod" bosses are more unique, at least early in the game. But more often than not, they can only be defeated by a "normal" player by cheesing them. Multiple times in this game I have been impressed by a boss design, only to realize the best way to defeat them is an unsatisfying cheese that the game gives you as an apology for making their boss unbeatable at the level you are supposed to face them. Towards the end of the game, it becomes a boss rush, and there are no more cheese strategies available. In order to beat these, you need to enter into an hours long gameplay loop of getting one shot to each combo they throw out so you can learn the precise moment you need to dodge in order to avoid their attacks. If you grind hard enough, you can eventually see the ending to a game with zero story.  I played this game because a friend recommended it. They said they enjoyed it, and they hoped I did too, and then apologized for telling me I should play it. Many people on here have the same story, and many of their friends say they enjoyed the game as well. The only explanation I can come up with is that this game is Type 2 fun. When you are in the moment, playing the game, its terrible. Once you are done, and you've completed it, the feeling of accomplishment you get overshadows those moments of frustration, the monotony of grinding, and the times you left the game defeated. You commiserate with your friends, and it becomes a shared experience that you can connect with. Eventually you forget the negative feelings you had while playing the game, and the memories that persist are those of the adventure you embarked on, and the feeling of growth that came out of it.  But when I play this game, I can't help but wonder what I actually am supposed to get out of it. I pressed dodge the exact millisecond I needed to five times in a row, and won a boss encounter because of it. Was that worth it? Is practicing this one button press for an hour straight really what I'm doing with my time? More than anything, thing game makes me question why I spend time playing it instead of doing something else.  The first encounter in Elden Ring is with a hulking mass of thrashing bodies, congealed in a spider like blob of legs and arms. If it is your first playthrough, it easily dispatches you with a few swipes of its relatively tiny sword, shrugging off any damage you attempt to inflict. Veteran players, expecting the monster, can beat it with well timed dodges and strikes, though it is no easy feat. The reward for doing so is a short walk to a nearby pathway, where the ground gives out, killing you instantly. The same can be said for the game as a whole. No matter what you do, the end result is the same, you get nothing for your time, your energy, your frustration. In the end, it is a futile waste of effort.  Go read a book instead.

Elden Ring is unique even in the soul-like genre. Unlike previous titles that rewarded u for pushing on challenging boss after boss, Elden Ring rewards u for exploration. Instead of finding amazing weapons from main game bosses, exploring dungeons or fighting open-world bosses seems to be the most rewarding and gifts you with some amazing weapons. I like seeing the "YOU DIED" like 20 times a day
It's been two and a half months now since I 100%'ed this game. I haven't had the urge to go back to it a single time since. I didn't hate the time I spent with it, but I wouldn't say I enjoyed it either. I had never played a FromSoftware game before – whenever I saw someone play one of their Souls-games I thought "Wow that looks absolutely horrible and about as fun as going to the dentist." And I didn't necessarily mean the difficulty (and more specifically the way in which they are "difficult"), but also the aesthetics and how the movement and physics looked like.  But, given the absolutely insane hype levels for Elden Ring I decided to finally give one of them a shot. Unfortunately my intuition was correct: The movement does feel like you're controlling a semi truck on molasses. It just does not *feel* fun to do anything in this game, be it running around or fighting. I'm not talking about the way heavy vs. light loadouts feel, the very foundations of movement and physics in this game just don't appeal to me. Of course as a Souls-beginner it also took some getting used to, but that happened fairly quickly. I didn't have any trouble with it, but it's not something that would draw me to the game – which is problematic, considering that movement makes up most of the gameplay.  The other part, the aesthetics, also mostly didn't click for me just as I expected. Don't get me wrong, I can appreciate that the art direction in this game is very well done. (I do think that it's a tad bit overhyped, though – the game looks good, but it doesn't look great.) But with very few exceptions it is all just pain and despair, mud and dirt, darkness and gloom. There's not enough contrast between areas that are some variation of "big end of the world mood" and more light-hearted areas. I understand that this makes sense from a story perspective, but it's just not something I enjoy very much. Why would I want to spend 100+ hours in this utterly depressing hellscape, with no respite to make it all worth it?  Speaking of story… well. It certainly has some GRRM aspects to it, but not so much the good ones that gave us amazing stories well over a decade ago, but the ones that just drip feed the idea of something bigger and better still to come, pinky promise, anytime now! If you're lucky enough to even stumble upon some story, it's usually confusing and feels irrelevant/disconnected. I hate modern Ubisoft open world games as much as anyone else, but Elden Ring absolutely does not even come close to do this right in the way that Breath of the Wild did. The fact that most players will go to a Wiki to be able to figure out how to finish (or even find and begin…) quest lines is a scathing indictment of how badly the game fails at telling its stories.  The "async coop" did not click with me either. The ghosts of other players pretty much never revealed anything of interest to me. At best they could be ignored, at worst they were a distraction. Far worse are the hints, which gives a pretty good insight into the headspace of the fan base of this game. "try finger but hole" is their idea of peak comedy, and everyone falls over themselves making this same joke for the billionth time. More serious ones like "enemy/treasure ahead" are worthless as well, because you can never know if it is a troll or not. So you do check any nooks and crannies anyway – and there's nothing wrong with a game wanting you to do so, but what's the point of these hints then.  Finally, the difficulty. Yeah, it's pretty hard if you don't farm XP and overlevel yourself. The game does an okay job of being a difficult game. Considering that it's a fairly complex 3D open world game, you can't expect great loading times after you die, but the gameplay also isn't designed for dying as often and freely as for example something like Celeste – which lets you continue playing after death within milliseconds. There's a couple of spots that are just infuriating, though, mostly to do with elevators. Site of grace next to the elevator, you ride it up and there's an area where you most likely will die a whole bunch of times before getting through. Every damn time after dying and respawning at the site of grace you not only have to ride back up – you first have to call the elevator back down because it is still above from your earlier ride. Of course that is logical and "correct", but that doesn't make it any less annoying. Resetting an elevator next to a site of grace to be on your level upon respawning would have been such an obvious QoL improvement, but Elden Ring does not give you any of those. And hardcore fans will defend that as realism, or a counter to the oh so horrible hand-holding that games do these days. But that's bs. Little annoyances like that don't make a game harder or "more real", they just make it more annoying.  It's these kinds of things that make me think that Elden Ring was rushed out in the end, and I'm genuinely baffled by the praise it gets for supposedly being "one of the good ones" when compared to other AAA games and their need for day one patches. I didn't _mind_ the stuttering issues the game still has on PC, but they haven't even been fixed. I had _a ton_ of bugs and glitches and some crashes even. Nothing too bad or unexpected for a game of this scale, but Elden Ring is not some magic outlier here that does things much better or differently than other good AAA games, of which there is still plenty.  So, do I recommend this game? No, I personally do not. If your taste in games is like mine, you won't enjoy it very much. I don't regret my time with it, because now I know definitively that Souls-games just aren't for me. But that thumbs-down is not meant to say that it's a bad game, despite all my criticisms above. A lot of them are very subjective, and the ones that I'd say are a bit more objective aren't dragging the game down too much. I can absolutely understand why people love this game, but unfortunately I didn't.

As I have fully beaten Elden Ring and gained all the achievements, I think I am more than qualified to say:  Elden Ring is certainly by far the game of all time.  In a world filled with interactive movies, glorified quasi-gambling services, online-only dystopia, and games saturating the market with the same tales, again and again... Elden Ring offers the most important aspect of any video game: Actually gettin to flippin play it. (And LOTS of it.) The others have their reasons (I'm not getting into it), but it is always good to return to the roots of video games by focusing heavily on gameplay. You wanna play a video game? You wanna play LOTS of gamin'? Then get this game. Does it have flaws? Absolutely; quite a few. But the game is still well worth it, I think. Most of them are from a vet's perspective, so I can't say much. If you are new to the Fromsoft games, though, you should be much less irked by these things, assuming you even see any to begin with. I look forward to them polishing up and making Elden Ring a much more complete experience, and I'll see you all on the battlefields of Elden Ring 7: Quest 4 The Onion Ring. May The Golden Order shine through you all. Good luck.

While I did give a yes vote as a recommendation, it comes with a few warnings. This game is NOT made for the PC, it is/was made strictly as a lesser game build for the consoles and it shows. The graphics are not as great as they should be on a PC title. In the first 25 hours the graphical tricks used are obvious and show through the facade of standard console tricks used to help consoles with their performance issues.  Another warning is the beyond nonsensical game interface, it was made strictly for a game pad, and it shows. While it is up to the developers to provide proper access and proper ports to the PC, the effort was minimal to the point the PC port of this game is a meme by itself in regards to the keyboard layout and interface choices and key binds.  While a huge number of people chime away with "This is a souls title" to wave away the criticism in regards to the poor PC keyboard layout and control options. I do not let these developers off the hook. The keyboard layout and UI suck in a big way. If you do not have a game pad, or do not like to use one, you will be at a disadvantage as there is no assigning any interface controls in a common sense layout. It took me quite a while to get used to the console style approach to minimalist, multi-function buttons in a rotary layout instead of the standard assign whatever action on whatever keystroke freedom I am used to.  Another part of the game I do not like is the forced pvp aspect with invasions or the multitude of notes that can be left. The notes clutter the areas, have questionable messages and do nothing for immersion. The invasions, even in a password protected setting is a very stupid choice on the part of the developers. it adds nothing to the game experience and actually degrades the games lore and entertainment values.  These things are simply immature carrots for the drop in and drop out crowd and do nothing for the game itself except to let the worst in people ruin an otherwise good game experience. If you want to experience the game without these poorly executed interruptions, play offline, trust me on this.  If you are willing to re-learn a bunch of control movements and a very poor UI interface, the game does have a large world and a great challenge with tons of secrets. Though I feel a big part of that challenge is wading through the developers lazy design choices and not the story itself. Elden ring is not the first souls games and is a foray into the bigger RPG market in which it is a mild success. Recently Elden Ring began touting it's sales figures and not giving info on returns so i contacted them. I was told they do not give out that info. I laughed at that reply.

[h1] Foul Tarnished [/h1]  [i]muhteşem[/i]  Bu incelemede hem Elden Ring'i yorumlayıp (spoiler olmadan) hem de yapımcı şirket ve tür benzediği için favori oyunlarımdan Sekiro ile karşılaştırmalar yapacağım.  Öncelikle Elden Ring'in devasa bir dünyası var, harita değil dünya. Açık dünya oyunlarının çoğunda olduğu gibi haritası bomboş/tekrarlama değil. Gittiğiniz her noktada işinize yarayacak farklı objeler bulabiliyorsunuz. Renk paleti bana soluk gelmedi, bazı yerler inanılmaz renklerde sonbaharı yaşarken bazı yerler olması gerektiği gibi karanlık.  Sekiro'da bu durum doğal olarak tamamen farklı çünkü lineer koridor mantığı olan bir oyun. [b]Haritada keşif yapma hissini Elden Ring inanılmaz başarılı yapmış.[/b]  [b]Oyunun yönetimi ve hikaye kısmında George R.R. Martin ile Hidetaka Miyazaki var haliyle doyurucu. Türe alışık olmayanlar için hikaye ilk başta bölük gelebilir, saatlerce hikaye namına ne bok yaptıklarını bilmeden etrafta gezebilirler.[/b] Souls oyunlarında oyunun hikayesini öğrenmek için önemli eşyaların açıklamalarına bakmalı, NPC'lerin senle veya diğer NPC'lerle konuşması varsa dinleyip parçaları birleştirmelisin. Girişte ana hikayeden biraz bahsedilse bile hikayeyi tepside sunmayacak. [b]Hikayede negatif olduğunu düşündüğüm şey birden fazla görev ağı bulunan NPC'ler. Bazı karakterlerin görevlerini devam ettirmek için kesinlikle internetten araştırmalısın, o kadar alakasız yerlerde bir şeyler yapman gerekiyor ki araştırmadan bulmak imkansız.[/b] Yapımcı Miyazaki zaten oyunlarının internette bol bol konuşulup hakkında fikir alışverişi yapılmasını isteyen bir tip.  Dövüş sistemine gelirsek oyun burada gerçekten işi senin tercihine bırakıyor. Birçok farklı build, sayısız silah seçeneği ile seçenekler çok geniş. Soulslike oyunlarına alışık değilseniz savaşırken yüzlerce kez ölebilirsiniz fakat mantığı oturttuktan sonra her şey kolaylaşıyor. Seviye mantığı olduğu için çok tokat yersen seviye kasıp gelme şansın var.  Sekiro'da dövüş hissiyatı kat kat daha iyiydi, elinde kumanda değil de kılıç tutuyorsun hissiyatını verebiliyordu. Elden Ring'de kesinlikle böyle bir seviye beklemeyin. Sekiro'dan sonra ağaç kesiyormuşsun hissiyatı veriyor.  Müzik konusunda ise [i]yeterli[/i] diyebilirim. Gerçekten epik bir savaşa girdiğini hissettirmeyi başarsa bile sonradan açıp dinleyeceğim bir albümü yok bence.  Bazı yorumlarda optimizasyondan bahsedilmiş fakat ben R5 5600x ve RX 6600 XT sistemimle maksimum ayarlarda fps düşüşü yaşamadan oynadım.  Sonuç olarak keşfedilmeye fazlasıyla değer bir dünya, oynadığım en akılda kalıcı oyunlardan biri.

Lousiest game I ever purchased. Tried to return it but I played for two hours they say. No story at all.
There's very few ways I could talk about this game that are unique or interesting, because enough ink's been spilled that even reviewing it feels trite. I've been following Fromsoft games for the better part of a decade, starting with buying Demon's Souls way back in 2011, just before Dark Souls dropped on the PS3.   So I'll start by stealing words from someone who's smarter than I am, specifically Noah Caldwell-Gervais: "Elden Ring is not a perfect game, but it is idiosyncratic, which is almost as good and just as rare."  It's pretty remarkable that From Software's brand of animation timing-based combat, meticulous level design and striking art direction and tone not only translates to the open world format but even makes it truly worthwhile and interesting. The map is huge, but I still know its peaks and valleys, sheer cliff faces and miserable swamp lands like the back of my hand; I was concerned that the expansion of scope would mean it would be harder to get an idea of the layout of the Lands Between just because of its sheer breadth.  That's not the case because its layout is still every bit as crafted as any other fromsoft map. Sheer cliff faces from a map that dares you to traverse its landscape, jagged rock like fingers reaching out, as though the land itself wants to grab you, swallow you whole. I've never seen an open world so fearlessly use its verticality to limit the player's exploration and force you to find a way around. Sure there are games with taller skyscrapers, bigger mountains, but there's a difference between something being tall and something feeling tall. You can take an elevator to the top floor, but it means a lot more if you had to drag yourself around Mount Gelmir's smoking caldera.   It's embedded in my mind, every inch, every facet, every corpse in Caelid, every freestanding structure in Liurnia...and yet despite how much I know, there's still so much I missed. It took me a year to find out about Albinauric pots, and I only looked it up because I got smacked by one when I was invading!   Fromsoft has never been afraid to just hide things from the player; these games are utterly indifferent about whether or not you find every single item or every nook and every cranny and it makes me wish more titles were willing to just let the player miss things. I had a friend who had no idea there was an entire sector, a massive drop by an NPC just barely hidden; a huge chunk of a necropolis you can only visit towards the endgame.   There are maybe a few complaints to be made about how the combat is put together (and there are degenerate playstyles out there, but that's kind of inevitable in a game with this much breadth), but I still think it's by far some of the best that Fromsoft has made. I would argue it's even better than Bloodborne's combat loop, partially because you don't have to hunt for vials, partially because there's just more variety.   I won't go into the boss fights, mostly because you will know how Fromsoft's combat rhythm is if you play any of the other games. I would go so far as to say this is probably fromsoft's best boss lineup in a base game. If that sounds like hearsay, do keep in mind that even DS3 had way less consistency in boss quality, DS2's base lineup is truly terrible, and DS1 had both bosses that were kind of jank and a lot who were just...not very good. That's not even getting into DeS' lineup which is truly rough after 15 years of iteration. ER doesn't share that problem in its main lineup. Like, frankly the remembrance bosses, several of the optional fights, are all pretty consistently interesting to fight (save some truly insufferable lingering hitboxes. Looking at you, Fallingstar Beast.)  Elden Ring is three Dark Souls games stapled together, laid in a map with combat that takes queues from Sekiro and build variety that even exceeds DS2. It says a lot that even now, a year into this game's life cycle, I am still getting invades.   I mean I'm not exactly going to convince anyone who wasn't already looking at this game and I'm not really gonna be swayed by discourse because I've had a long, long time to percolate my thoughts.   ER good, actually. Basically.
I know my 4 hours are not much but I have roughly 800 on console. This is possibly one of my favorite games of all time, though it definitely takes some getting used to compared to something like CoD. Very fun, amazing looking (cutscenes can be somewhat goofy but never bad), the flow of fights are amazing and it's always fun no matter if I'm starting a new character/build or grinding on my main. To people immediately put off by the difficulty I severely recommend you spend a good bit of time trying more. This game has many ways it can be played and youtube videos are always your friend if you are stuck. 15/10 worth the price.

good
This is the Dark Souls II that FromSoft WANTED to make, as opposed to the one we actually got. It has many of the same annoyances—gank-heavy enemy placements, questionable hitboxes, a lot of fights seemingly being designed with only one strategy in mind—but it also corrects many of the worst aspects of DS2, and you actually get an entire continent to explore instead of a convolution of impossible spaces. If you liked DS2, you'll probably like ER—and if you didn't like DS2, as I and so many others didn't, there's still a very good chance you'll like ER anyway.  It's not a perfect game. The open world GENERALLY avoids feeling boring and empty like in many other open-world games—but some areas still feel like a slog. Enemy strength scales by area, just like in Dark Souls, not according to your level or equipment, which makes exploring some areas a bit more frustrating, but you can always hop on Torrent for a quick getaway—though that only applies to certain definitions of "quick," because Torrent feels like the slowest horse in video games and turns like a boot. Still, he can double-jump, which allows for some interesting routes.  All in all, though, this is the best Soulslike I've played. I didn't think I'd like it better than DS1, but it exceeded my expectations. But this long after it came out, are you really still looking at reviews to decide whether you want to buy it?

Do I recommend this game? Yes and no. Why the "no"? It's not a game meant for everyone, and I mean that. It is a challenging game, and can be extremely frustrating at times. However, if you like to be challenged, if you enjoy the feeling after overcoming a difficult fight, then this is for you.   The lore is not an in your face type of story. You've got to do some digging. I suggest reading item descriptions, it goes a LONG way in clarifying the story, as well as exploring and going off the beaten path. As someone who played DS3 (a LOT), I absolutely love this game and the story. It's dark, gritty, and most of all sad; but it is compelling. It draws you in and throws you for a loop.  Gameplay wise, it runs smoothly, and I have no issues. Controls are nearly the same as Dark Souls 3 (with the addition of jumping). I don't suffer from my game CTD'ing (crash to desktop) or anything.  In terms of style of play, there are a lot of different builds. More than just the spell slinger or sword and board styles. It's fun, interesting and I enjoy the freedom of it. Some builds (scarlet rot/bleed) are OP, that mainly applies to multiplayer/pvp and less so for solo play.   Overall, is it worth the pricetag on it? Absolutely, worth the buy.

I'll start off by saying I've been enjoying Dark Souls since DS1. Fromsoft makes some excellent games and this game is good, but my negative review comes from a few things I don't enjoy and I don't think the series needed.  We didn't need a open world. It's as wide as an ocean and shallow as a puddle. I prefer the old linear experience that Dark Souls has always provided. I also stand that I wish we could get back to the inter connectivity that DS1 demonstrated so excellently.  I become incredibly disappointed when I clear a side dungeon only to fight a boss I previously killed. It ruins the excitement of finding something new only to experience something old. The reuse of bosses in this game kills the experience for me.  The boss design is also another factor in my review. I've always been a hyper aggressive player. I look for openings in between attacks while still being able to roll dodge as well. I'm aggressive and hate playing passive. I enjoy optimizing and looking for zero downtime if possible. That said, these bosses will string together a Marvel Vs Capcom string for 30 seconds and I'm just stuck standing away and looking at the boss like I'm stupid. After that string they have almost zero downtime and begin to run the string once again. It's not fun to constantly be dodging for 30+ seconds only to maybe hit once or twice.   In closing, we sacrificed quality for quantity. The game has the highest highs of the series followed by devastatingly low lows that ruin it for me.
Best game
Not sure what to say that likely hasn't been said. I've never played a "souls-like" before this one and, while there's definitely a learning curve, there's something so satisfying about finally beating that enemy. There are virtually unlimited ways to play from the massive amounts of items, weapons, spells, gear, etc plus customization of your character and their skills. The world is absolutely massive with more secrets and questlines than you could ever hope to discover or complete. The messaging system was weird to me at first as I'm the type of player that loves to discover everything on my own, but I think it actually adds to the game due to the sheer volume of secrets. If a lot of the messages weren't there I'd probably have half the gear I have now and still be stuck somewhere in Limgrave. 11/10 and I haven't even finished my first playthrough yet.  And that's all without even talking about how breathtakingly beautiful this game is.

Great game if you love exploring a vast world with a ton of interesting things and lore to find. It's definitely a game that wants YOU to piece together the world as you play, which in my opinion, is a masterclass in storytelling elements. It took me about 150 hours to beat it with one character and that was with pretty heavy exploration. Even after all of that time, there are still many things to find and I'm still finding neat new stuff even after beating it. This game is pretty hard, especially if you aren't used to the gameplay style. Returning FromHeads will feel right at home in The Lands Between. Tip for newbies: Use a shield or make sure to jump attack often if you're dual wielding and don't be afraid to rely on summoning a Spirit Ash or other players. This game is a wonderful addition to the FromSoft lineup and to me is the second best game in there second only to Dark Souls 1. I was pleasantly surprised it replaced Demon's Souls as my #2

For one I feel as though the souls format transitioned into the open world format quite well with the way they tell stories, and with how the previous souls games have taught it's players to look for secrets everywhere. Elden Ring's world is just teeming with things to find! In fact I feel as though Elden Ring has done something that many other open world games have failed at, which is making the player WANT to explore everywhere, and rewarding the player for doing so with things like weapons, spells, armor, charms. extra bosses, and even hidden quests, and stories! I would definitely recommended this game to anyone who in joys the souls format, or games with lots to see, and explore. Lets hope that FromSoft takes what they've learned from Elden Ring, and apply it to future games "cough" Bloodborne 2 'cough.'

I strongly recommend this game for anyone who is looking for an adventure and enjoys looking for things!  I have spent the last 11 hours of game play exploring, dying, killing, gathering, learning, and having fun overall.  I was unsure about this game when it first came out and was hesitant to pick it up.  I am glad that I bought the game and have had a chance to experience it! Even if you have never played a "souls" like game... you should give this a try.. very fun!   I have enjoyed the open play and open world.  You can explore and stumble upon things that will either kill you, bless you or reward you with items.  There are many different npcs to discover, mobs that you can easily kill or come back to when you are stronger.  The world is amazing!  You can hear the ocean waves crash against the shore, the thunder of water against the cliffs, you can actually see whitecaps and waves make their way to the shore.  I still have much to discover and do.   You get a selection of classes to play that can be customized to fit your own style so there is no "cookie cutter" build.  You get to choose how you want to play your given class and the weapons, skills etc.  If you want to be a magic wielding rogue, it looks like it could be done.  I am not sure how viable or survivable it would be but you have the option to do as you please.    I really have no negative things to say about this game.  I have only just started the game... keep your eyes & ears open. Be alert and if you die... you die.  Make sure to level up every chance you get.. don't hoard your souls you may get caught off guard by a big bad boss and not have a way to retrieve them. It is a risk you take!  Just play & have fun!

Elden Ring, developed by FromSoftware and published by Bandai Namco, has been eagerly anticipated by fans of the studio's previous games, such as Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. From early impressions and gameplay footage, Elden Ring appears to deliver on the studio's signature style of challenging gameplay, immersive worlds, and cryptic storytelling.  One of the most notable aspects of Elden Ring is its open-world design, which is a departure from the more linear levels of FromSoftware's previous titles. This new approach promises to provide players with a greater sense of exploration and discovery as they venture through the game's expansive environments.  In addition, Elden Ring features a deep and complex lore, which has become a hallmark of FromSoftware's games. The game's story is said to be written in collaboration with renowned fantasy author George R.R. Martin, adding an extra layer of intrigue to the game's narrative.  Elden Ring also boasts a range of new gameplay mechanics, such as the ability to mount and ride various creatures, adding a new dimension to exploration and combat. The game's combat system, which is a staple of FromSoftware's games, has been refined and expanded upon, with new weapons, spells, and abilities to master.  Overall, Elden Ring appears to be a promising addition to FromSoftware's impressive catalog of games. With its open-world design, deep lore, and refined gameplay mechanics, the game is sure to appeal to fans of the studio's previous titles as well as newcomers to the genre. the true Demon's Souls starts here
2011 saw the release of two of the most influential games for the RPG genre, Dark souls and Skyrim. One was a complex and mysterious game, with some of the greatest level designs in modern gaming and the other was an adventure through a seemingly limitless fantasy world. Both were fantastic games in their own right, but even back then I always dreamed of a Skyrim with the addictive combat and difficulty of dark souls, and likewise I dreamed of a dark souls that had the sandbox freedom of Skyrim.  Fast forward to 2022 and this dream has been realised. The open world element of Elden Ring reinvigorates the souls-like core gameplay. The great level design and inter connectivity of dark souls is still here, and so is the great combat and progression. But now we have a huge open world full of secrets to uncover. In dark souls sometimes the difficulty could be suffocating, with your only option to “get gud” and grind your way through a cruel place like Sen’s Fortress. In Elden Ring when things get hard you can teleport across the map and set off in a direction of your choosing. Leveling up while uncovering lore rich dungeons and points of interest. It honestly never even feels like grinding.  This game still isn’t for everyone, if you’re looking for a game that is completely accessible and has the best graphics of the decade, this might not be it. But if you’re even slightly willing to give the souls-like combat a decent try, and if you love fantasy RPGs this is absolutely the best game of its kind since 2011.

Elden Ring is the culminative mastering of Fromsoft's design for the past decade on top of treading new grounds in the form of an open world with horizontal progression compared to past games which were much more linear in design. It is unabashedly masterful in execution; it feels like the Soulsborne series was always meant to reach this.  By far this is the game where it is the easiest to get into; progression gating is very limited, most of the map is accessible without the need to defeat bosses. There is a plethora of play-styles that are viable; Miracle builds are now finally made viable, its on that level. The Spirit Ashes add a new option for solo play that's more available for players to use.  The story feels much more cohesive and fleshed out than any previous Fromsoft game that I have experienced. Not going to drop spoilers, but its amazing how things feel connected as you progress through the story.  There are a few prominent pain points. There is some reusing of bosses, which in an open world game is perfectly fine, however there are instances where they are poorly placed, such as two different instances of a boss enemy with different movesets in a small arena, which makes the encounter feel arbitrarily difficult. There are a few enemies that are less than enjoyable to fight as well, and there is a big difficulty spike in the later areas. However these are relatively minor flaws that can be circumvented.  Elden Ring feels like a childhood dream of adventure. Its easy to lose yourself to the adventure. Take it from me; game already ate up 100+ hours in the first week. To the veterans of the Soulsborne games, this is a worthwhile purchase. To the newcomers, this is probably the best first game for the series, it will take some learning but if you really want to get into souls games, this is one.

Does another game exist?
I will start off with, the game is fun and it is worth playing if you are new to the Souls series, or you suck at the Dark Souls games.. but... I don't get it.Id rather go back and play Dark Souls 3 personally..   I have easily several Hundred hours in DS1. well over 2000 in DS2 and at least the same amount in DS3. I don't get it.  Elden Ring is not that great. After nearly 200h I can confidently say, Dark Souls was Better. The game is clearly made for Casuals, and the combat is kind of Braindead easy when you aren't being cheap shotted by a Boss with a mechanic that is unavoidable. Like, a lot of enemies will attack you as you are recovering from a Knockdown, hitting you BEFORE the animation even ends of you standing up, making you unable to avoid it. and that is the only thing you need to learn.. once you learn how to avoid the cheap shots.. the game becomes trivial.  In the Souls Series, there were virtually no Cheap shots.. this game is littered with them, giving it Artificial difficulty. These things make it Seam difficult, but its really not. 9/10 Bosses in this game I can literally just sit there and Charged-Heavy the Boss to death with Caesti, no need to Dodge or avoid at all. Even with my Insane Regen build in past games, I never could do this. I get up to over 1000 AR with FISTS. FISTS! I can get a Guaranteed 3 hit combo off on another Player that deals a total of 3k damage, before Defenses.. even after defenses, most people are Dead after that...   they Ruined Poise. While it is nice to have DS 1 and 2 Passive Poise back, even at Max Poise you can only survie 2 swings from a Longsword or equivalent. Anything Bigger still 1 tap staggers.   If you just spec for Jumping Attacks, congrats! you beat the game.  The Open World is nice, but it really  doesn't offer much after the 1st playthrough.  in the 1st Play through, the open world is fun and exciting. in the NG+x Playthroughs, its tedious and actually annoying to have to constantly navigate.  80% of this game is not mandatory to get to the next playthrough, as opposed to the Souls games, where it was the exact opposite. It is an interesting take, but since 80% of the game is just useless past the 1st playthrough, whats the point? You will get through NG+ in like 30 mins.. Its really not all that.  The Ashes of War system is amazing and opens a lot of Options. Maybe in the future we get another game that gives us the option for actual Skills instead.   If you don't want to go Punch enemies for 1k damage at level 70 and up, just go mage... you can nuke anything from Players to Bosses as a mage and they cannot do anything about it.   Dont get me wrong, the Game is fun.. its just nowhere near as good as any of the People here want you to believe.  there are Detrimental bugs that will piss you off in PvP, like a Bug to increase Rivers of Bloods Phantom reach by like 100x. And its damage doubles as well.  Considerable amount of hackers are also still existing in the game.    all in all, this is a perfect game for the Dark Souls Novice, and the Casuals that don't feel ready to enter the Tryhard community of the actual Souls games.  but be prepared to know that most people are actually rather casual in this game, especially in PvP.. even in the Arenas, most ppl seem rather casual :/ RIP Dark Souls PvP standards

IS NICE
As of 2023, this is the greatest game I have ever known.  It's not perfect, but it cannot be compared to any other.   On every play through I find more areas and items that I had not found previously.  Even after 400 hours, I still find massive areas and fierce bosses that guard unknown treasure.  The graphics are beautiful, the sound design is top notch, and the controls are tight. I would recommend using a wired controller, because you will notice even the slightest input lag.    This game will punish insanity.  But, if you are able to refine your tactics you will feel a sense of accomplishment from victory that is unparalleled.  Sure you will get frustrated.  There will be times it feels unfair.  But there is always another approach to any situation.  I would not say that Elden Ring is "Hard" but survival does require your full attention at all times.    It is absolutely worth every penny.  Elden Ring has ruined every other RPG for me.  It is Pandora's box.    Beware, this game will destroy your life.  It will become an obsession.  And you will never be the same.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. AMAZING GAME WITH GREAT REPLAYABILITY
In Tetris, players must arrange falling shapes called tetrominoes in a way that creates horizontal lines without any gaps. As the game progresses, the tetrominoes fall faster and the player must think and move quickly in order to keep up. One of the great things about Tetris is that it is very easy to learn, but difficult to master. This means that players of all skill levels can enjoy the game, but there is always room for improvement and challenges for those who want to push themselves. Tetris is also a very social game, with many different variations available on Steam that allow players to compete against each other online, either cooperatively or in head-to-head matches. These variations can add an extra layer of fun and challenge to the game, as players must compete against others to see who can score the highest.

I think this game lived up to its hype. It's kind of unique in that it's an open world souls game, which really lets you choose your own path. There's tons of lore if you want it to be more of a story game, and there's a ton of really strong enemies if you prefer a more hack-and-slash adventure. Before this game, the only From Software game I had played was Sekiro. So I came into the game expecting something similar, just with a new backdrop. I don't know how they fucked it up, but this is leaps and bounds worse of an experience. Compared to its contemporaries, the combat is slow and unintuitive. There's a lot of fucking around with your build and other RPG elements (which is fine if that's what you're looking for). Coming from the simplicity of the Sekiro combat system, it is a lot to take in.  There are blatant levels of polish that have not been applied here. Weapon textures clip on your back, the platforming is abysmal (though sparse), there is no pause feature, you can't see the enemy's stance meter for some reason, and other little details that add up. The one small thing that peeves me the most is the lack of an indication that you're going to backstab someone. In Sekiro this big red icon comes up that tells you "hello this is going to be a one hit kill," but in elden ring I got to give the guy a rimjob because I don't want to accidentally hit him with a light attack.  I do enjoy how the open world is handled, every time you get to a checkpoint it points a big arrow in the direction it wants you to go in so you're not fucking around lost all over the place. It takes the best of both worlds in that way (being linear and open world storytelling). For what I have experienced, the story seems genuinely intriguing, I just with I could experience it rather than crawling through this castle. I could not bring myself to finish this, just not the kind of game I like.

After having played for over one hundred hours, I believe that this is my favorite game FromSoft has ever released. My first playthrough took sixty(!) whole hours to complete, so the game obviously has a plethora of content to enjoy. As with every other dark souls game, there is an immense amount of fun builds that you can choose from to suit every player's desired style. This make it all the more fun to challenge the game's difficulty. Difficulty in this game is set up in a way that makes it easier or harder depending on however the player decides to prepare themselves for something, due to the open world nature of Elden Ring. This makes it, in my opinion, the easiest game FromSoft has created to get into for a new player. I would recommend this game to anybody who does enjoy a challenge and loves open world games when they're actually made with love rather than by EA. Much love if you get this game <3

A modern gaming masterpiece. Elden ring is a culmination of over a decade of game design by Fromsoftware. An intriguing open world ? Check Amazing combat ? Check Diverse enemy types ? Check Diverse builds ? Check Frustrating gimmicks in fights ? (looking at you Mohg) Check A ton of lore, but no exposition ? Check.  Overall, this game is an instant classic. And is meant to be played along with some helpful lookups. The game is designed with the community in mind, and you can see it with the integration of player messages in the game.  Play it for the gameplay, stay for the Vaati's lore videos. Don't bother with PvP, there are always tryhards with dual naginata's poking you from a mile away, and from barely does enough to balance that.  The most accessible souls title. You can completely trivialise the difficulty of this game, or roleplay a character, who is going to have a tough time.   Arise Tarnished.

Pros:  -Incredible Graphics (Like seriously man, this game is like a movie) -Incredible Weapons and Builds (speaks for itself) -Sick bosses and enemies -Well designed areas, love Limgrave and Caelid and Lurnia of the Lakes is a slight big below both of them but so far I love them all. -Super Satisfying  Cons: -Some supper annoying bugs such as the stuttering that still occurs a full year after release which is just embarrassing, can really get on my nerves because it always happens at the worst times.  -They should make multiplayer easier (not because I'm bad but because it would just be nicer to have that way, but I've seen opposing opinions saying it ruins the "souls-like" part of it but come on man its annoying to have to have a limited number of summons to do things) -This game is so good it makes me hate other games that aren't a similar god-like level  Easy 10/10 could not recommend more. As someone who started out playing this game clueless on the souls-like genre it became a lot more fun when instead of cluelessly mucking about I got some help from people/internet to find out what I was doing. Don't be afraid to do things like that if it helps you enjoy the game more.
For souls fans: It's a mish-mash of the other soulsborne's all smashed together with some awesome new things as well.   For those new to the series: It's a big open world that is very challenging. If you are stubborn/ prideful, you will probably be frustrated. Don't bang your head against the wall. You're supposed to go other places and level up a little.

After 220 hours I can say that I have killed every boss gotten every grace and every weapon and almost every armor set with all achievements completed. While I can’t show you my first time playing this game I can describe it to you. It Began with a beautiful customizable character being able to choose your class and your keepsake I decide to choose wretched and no keepsake as I didn’t fully understand what that was yet. A beautiful opening making me feel excited to get into gameplay. I spawn in a church wondering what I should do next taking my time until I find the item needed. Making my way out of the church I quickly run into the first boss shaking with excitement not knowing how to attack even roll I quickly died. Waking up in a cave I run to a double door and open it seeing a grace waiting for me just past. Finally making my way up on the elevator opening the gate to see the vast world of the Lands Between. Quickly being insulted by an NPC saying that Im maidenless I assault him I lose over and over again until I finally kill him. Feeling accomplished I run over to the first church and run into the Tree Sentinel. Words can’t describe how many times I have tried to kill that boss and failed. I feel as if every input I made was not my choice but as if it was his choice that I was going to do a jumping heavy and positioned himself perfectly to not only dodge my attack but get two attacks on me. Try and try again, I said to myself, not knowing that this would be the hardest boss I would ever fight. After all the attempts at killing the tree sentinel, I felt demolished I couldn’t find the motivation to continue playing I say I only played 5 or 10 minutes of exploring the west side of Limgrave before I stopped playing.

Department of Motor Vehicles: The Game  After having to pay way too much just to be there, you're treated to a lengthy, boring wait. Although it's dull as fuck, you try to occupy yourself by looking around the room for anything remotely attention-keeping. Time eventually drips by, and you finally find yourself called to take the written test.  You happen to be pretty familiar with traffic laws, but some of the questions aren't even in English. That's too fucking bad, it's not there to hold your hand. Since making more than three mistakes will result in you failing, you find yourself having to bare all the boredom and dreariness of the wait, over and over again.  Hopefully you git gud at driving enough to memorize all of your wrong choices thus far, and by sheer will and refusal to move on, finally pass the written test. You will, at this point, have access to the next uneventful wait; The road test...with a tractor. The process will repeat itself ad infinium until it simply cannot be failed.  Finally, after X number of loops through hell, you can finally walk away victorious, having outlasted the DMV and all its bullshit.  And don't expect your driver's license. Passing the test was reward enough, right?

So, before I even begin, let me clarify some stuff  I tried Dark Souls 1, 2 and 3, and hated all of them. I don't mean they're bad games, I definitely agree they're among the greatest series of all time and are an example to follow in terms of philosophy. But the gameplay is just not for me.  I played Sekiro, almost reached the end but eventually dropped out long enough for me to become too rusty to actually finish it. But I enjoyed it a lot!   So, what about Elden Ring? Well, just have a look at my hours on record and check the achievements on my steam profile. You'll see that I have... quite a different opinion !  To make it simple:  [h1] YOU. CAN. BEAT. IT. [/h1]  It is hard. Oh god is it hard. 188 hours of struggle and difficulty. But damn did I enjoy every single one of them.  Overall, it's your typical dark souls gameplay and experienced, but streamlined, improved and with a more intense and dynamic approach. Your moveset has so much more variety, and weapons are all so diverse (and every weapon type is viable!) that you will definitely find a playstyle that will suit you (mine was two greatswords, jump attack spam and I loved it).  But the main thing that made a huge difference for me was the open world. Not because I like open worlds in particular, but because that meant if a boss was too hard for me I could just leave and come back later with better gear and a higher level.  Just trust me, it's the most accessible Soulsborne game you'll find. it's actually great.

First and foremost, Elden Ring lives up to the hype. The world is expansive and breathtaking, filled with secrets to uncover and enemies to defeat. The combat system is fluid and satisfying, with a range of weapons and abilities to master. But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its sense of discovery. Every corner of the world feels alive with potential, and every encounter feels like a new challenge to overcome.  But beyond its gameplay, Elden Ring tells a compelling and deeply philosophical story about the nature of power, ambition, and the consequences of our actions. It's a game that rewards patience and reflection, asking players to consider their choices and the impact they have on the world around them.  Overall, Elden Ring is a masterpiece that will undoubtedly go down as one of the greatest games of all time. If you're a fan of challenging action RPGs, rich world-building, and thought-provoking storytelling, then this game is an absolute must-play. Don't miss out on the chance to experience this unforgettable adventure.

There are things done RIGHT: The Open World is intruiging, Combat feels great, It runs fantastic, The World looks GORGEOUS, There are some areas inside the Open World that are legitimately INSANE, The Mobs, Bosses and NPCs are well desgined, The Sounddesign is good and weapons, attacks, etc all are fantastic  However this can't carry the negatives I found with this game:  Feeling Lost: I know it's a meme, but hear me out. I literally SKIPPED the tutorial by accident. I walk here: "oh the enemies are too hard, you need to go elsewhere" my friends tell me. Well so I did. I walk there: Now I'm oneshotting everything since I was MEANT to go there much earlier. That is no fun. How should I know which level of  "hard but fair" is acceptable? No idea.  I wanted to play this game blind, but I literally could not - I would've quit the game 5 hours into it if I had no friends to teach me. I frequently find myself asking: "can I fight this one?", "Am I supposed to be here?", or "How do I find X?"."Go find out for yourself!" say my friends. "The game tells you when you are not meant to be here", they say. This is where I don't agree: No guidence at all lets me feel lost, clueless, I had no idea on how to do basic things, sometimes I'm overlevelled, sometimes I'm underlevelled. Elden Ring, for the love of god, is HORRIBLE at communicating information to the player. I know you all are down to BASH hand-holding the player, but SOME guidence should be given. And NO, The questlines and storylines all don't make sense and are rather missleading, sometimes leading you to areas you most certainly shouldn't be, to be fully honest. Being Open World makes this problem 10x more apparent. Let's talk more about that.  Variety: Going Open-World has it's problems. I frequently find myself uninterested in the exact same Dungeons, Bosses, Boss-Rooms, Enemies. The entire copy-paste of some sections had me feeling disappointed. This hits much harder because I know they CAN do better. Some of the most breathtaking areas I've ever experienced are in this game. But you can't fully build the Open World on these areas, right? Well you just have to look at other Souls games to recognize that this is very possible. A lot of bosses also get reused or become normal Mobs - which apparently is normal? I'm not getting exited anymore when seeing (most) BOSSES. Think about that. Meta is also a big part of Variety. I personally have no idea about this stuff tbh, but I frequently heard about meta builds being broken or nessassary to defeat harder bosses, PVP-builds all being the same, etc. This hurts the integrity and one of the best aspects of the game: play however you want. Point proven: Elon Musk literally got flamed and people wrote articles about him for using an "off-meta" build. wtf? I'm HEAVILY discouraged of doing so, because X is most broken, ,Y is nessassary to beat stuff or, going to my next point, I levelled Z.  Limitation: Some limitation is very good and welcomed. However I REALLY dislike how weapons and Arts are Stat-Locked. How come I defeat the X-Dungeon or boss, wasting hard-earned Stone-Keys to play them, just to come out with a lackluster experience and a weapon I can't use? This feels genuinely HORRIBLE. Yes, I've been told I can respec, but 1) I have literally no idea how (feeling lost), and 2) I can do this only a limited amount of times. And no, I don't want to REPLAY the entirety of Elden Ring because, and this is the singular reason my friends replay this game, I want to try a new build. This seems INSANE to me.  It's unfair: Some Bosses and Mobs felt very unfun to play against (don't get me started about this invisible dude). I don't really want to waste 6 hours for the TUTORIAL BOSS. So what did my friends do? (this was one of the biggest mistakes I've done); we cheesed a Mob way beyond my league (but accessible for some reason; that doesn't make sense), giving me an INSANE amount of Levels. I've become overlevelled to the point where I still first-try bosses 40 hours into it. As a Newbie to Souls-Games. That doesn't feel right nor fun. Hearing that the lategame gets worse, with frequently more unfair enemies, I feel very discouraged to go on.  I came into Elden Ring and wanted a "Hard but Fair" game, but this couldn't be further from what I've experienced.   Story: I literally have no Idea why I play this game on a story-perspective. I know I want to be this Elden Lord, go to that Tree or whatever, but that's about it. The only reason I kept playing is because I want to find special places, see something I didn't see before. It comes down to everything feeling VERY confusing. I have this quest where I needed to go down a well to find some NPC. The Well-part was rather easy, but down there and without guidence by my friends I would've probably searched for a bit - then I found him and CAN'T EVEN PROCEED this questline. "The next part is out of my reach for some time" my friends tell me, seeing no problem with that.  Multiplayer: Multiplayer was a mistake. It's frequently laggy, It takes AGES to play together,  it's very limited and there are exploits that feel like straight up cheating. This shouldn't be the way you play this game imo. PVP is also very unfun, running into the same builds a lot of times ("YO It's another Guts-Build"- my friends shout in exitement). This is a personal point to be fair, but let it be mentioned here. This game is far better enjoyed in Single Player.   This is where I stand: I intentionally didn't go deep into the positives to prove my point but trust me: This game got GREAT things going for it. That's why I'll keep playing after all. It's far better than many Triple A titles (which is not hard to be fair). I first thought Souls-Games are just not my type of game, but I've disproven that by liking other souls-games I've played recently. I've truely thought I'm a noob, that the game is too hard because... well... I'm too bad. But that wasn't true aswell. I've finally stopped giving it the benefit of the doubt, "breaking my silence" one might say, and saw it for what is it: A great game with huge deal-breakers and impossible problems to solve. It's near impossible to play this game without any help, it lacks direction, multiplayer is bad, the story is a confusing mess, the Open World hurts the game more than it does good. This game is far from being the masterpiece people praise it to be.    To my friends: Tut mir Leid Alex und Christian, ich hab euch häufig getriggered, aber Elden Ring hat zu viele Probleme, welche mir den Spaß richtig oft rauben. :(

In 2 words - a masterpiece. Considering myself a casual gamer I ignored this game for so long and that was a huge mistake. The world is big and beautiful, for the first time in an open-world game I felt the true joy of adventure and discovery. I scout every corner not because there is some kind of quest reward or collectable, but because it's always something new and interesting. Battling is as difficult as you want it to be, I am yet to encounter a situation where I feel trapped in having to overcome some kind of an impossible challenge. Can't win for some time? Go do something else, level up, find new gear, improve your skill, then come back and have a fair fight. Considering there is always something new to do and discover - it never feels grindy.

As a long time fan of Fromsoftware's modern output, Elden Ring has easily became my favorite next to Sekiro (though, you can't really compare these two). I'm not going really dwell on each aspect of the game as a whole, so I'm just going to say some helpful tips:  * PERFORMANCE Performance isn't really good, but it goes away after a while and by the time I went deeper into the game it was for the most part resolved. It does leave a bad first impression though sadly, and I'm generally disappointed at Fromsoftware for this, but in the end I kind of forgot about it since it really starts to go away after a while (it's classic shader stutter apparently). If this is really upsetting but you do want to keep playing, here are some tips: - Try going offline, it doesn't help much, but it's worth a shot - If you have enough memory, try setting shader cache to a higher value in your GPU setting After a while it's easy for the game to lock on 40-50 in the open world and 60 in dungeons on recommended specs, but I won't say that this is ideal, it's easily the weakest aspect of the game.  * GAMEPLAY TIPS If you are yet to play the game, here are my tips that I think can improve your experience (especially if this is your first Fromsoftware game):  - Pay absolutely no attention to the "Meta", meta is the enemy of fun. It's quite easy to build really high damage builds in this game, especially towards the end. Just pick up something that you like for early to mid-game. You do need to at least somewhat prioritize higher damage in the end-game though, but by that time, you'll probably have more than enough tools on your hand.  - There are quite a few multi-enemy bosses in the game. Don't treat them like O&S in Dark Souls, they were clearly never designed with the intention of you fighting them solo (which is a shame really). Summon a spirit, and if you do want to keep things "fair", remember that you can summon your spirit back by using the same item for summoning after the fight becomes one on one. Remember that spirits are an actual part of your build, rather than just some tools on the side. Once again, forget the meta, use whatever you like.  - Also on spirit summons, if you think that your summon is "stealing the fight" from you, there is talisman called "Shabriri's Woe" that you can get early game. Put that on, and the boss will prioritize you over your summon. It's surprising how well the summons can support you this way, while keeping you in control of the fight.  - Have multiple weapons with varying levels of upgrade. The game showers you with upgrade material just by clearing the major dungeons, and most of your damage comes from upgrade level instead of your stats. As long as you have the minimum stats and the correct infusion on the weapon, you'll have a pretty reliable weapon on hand. The reason that I suggest this is that it's quite easy to miss major areas and become over-leveled for those areas. Of course, the game has no problem with you destroying bosses, but if you do want a challenge, switch to a lower upgrade weapon, that'll be more than enough to level the field. Beyond that, it's just fun having multiple weapons to use in this game.  - Horse combat is almost completely optional to engage in. There are fights that I personally think are much more enjoyable with the horse, but there is no force on you to do that. If you do end up using the horse, I recommend you use a halberd or a long weapon. Short weapons just don't work on your horse if you are moving fast (at least I couldn't make them work).  - Don't sleep on the Ash of War system. Some of them are really useful. You can make entire playthroughs around some of these ashes (like the magical parry thingy ... or the one that restores your health when you hit someone). The infusion also means that you can use many weapon classes effectively. This is quite different from Dark Souls or Bloodborne, you really aren't bound to a class of weapons based on your build, and the game I will go as far to say, expects you to roleplay as different builds frequently.   - The crafting system isn't really that much in depth, but some of the consumables like Volcano Pots can completely melt some enemies; It's really funny. Give it a try once, if it doesn't interest you, then just forget it exists ...  - Invest at least a *bit* in Faith. Like maybe up to 12 or 15. Some incantations serve only defensive purposes, and are extremely useful in the end game, when the enemy damage becomes ridiculous. If not for that, just take a look at Lake of Rot ... you'll thank me later.  - On topic of defense, this is the first time I think your armor actually matters. Not only in the end game, but even as early as mid game, you can start getting chunked for like half your health quite easily if you are not careful. So either wear good armor, or use defensive talismans.  - There are a few "holes" on the map that the game gives you (like little brown circles ...), make sure you check them out. They are mines that usually always have bell bearings that you can trade in the hub for infinite supply of upgrade materials. Don't miss them.  Hope these help
I mean it's Elden Ring...Need anything else be said? From Software has time and again shown us that there are still awesome gaming companies out there, that don't half-ass things and deliver everything as promised.  Any true fan of the Dark Souls series will love and cherish this game.

Man, what a game.   This is my first introduction into the 'souls like' scene and I personally really enjoy this type of style.  Ever since I started playing Elden Ring, I always wanted to keep at it, even though I was getting absolutely flattened by everything, which is something incredibly rare.   Basically, in this game, you start out in this incredibly detailed open world where you play as a “Tarnished” of no renown, who is blessed by the guidance of grace, and your compelled to make the journey through The Lands Between and become "Elden Lord."  Elden Ring has a variety of boss battles (of course) that are uniquely hard and challenging in their own way, in other words, you never get bored. The sheer size of the map is incredible with separate underground areas, catacombs, caves tones of other stuff.   Elden Rings' game play is nothing like iv'e ever seen before and it's really awesome. I find that your always dealing with enemies who are stronger than you, introducing a high risk high reward concept.    Also, be prepared to open your browser because there's so much stuff that I found difficult and was confused about when playing this game, its just so complex. (Just for reference I've played this game for 190 hours and I still haven't explored everything.)   I have experienced a lot emotions while playing this game, one of them being anger, a lot of it. But when you finally defeat that boss that you needed to kill to progress, it is so rewarding and makes you feel really good about yourself.   In conclusion, Elden Ring is by far the best experience i've ever had the pleasure of witnessing. And simply put, the best game ever.  - 10/10

Gaming game
Given all the hype this game received, well, eventually I should probably learn to not trust "professional" game reviewers.  I'm not sure if this is the studio's first open world game, but it sure feels like it.  It's a bland and boring (but beautiful) world with no direction and incredibly repetitive mechanics that become boring after the second dungeon you go through.  You don’t need direction in a linear game like dark souls (rather, its linear nature IS the direction).  But open world games need at least some of it. Given all the hidden secrets in this world, I can tell just how much effort the devs put into crafting it.  But with how they just point you in a vague direction and say “go kill that boss to advance!”, they utterly fail their lovingly crated world by not giving the user any real reason to explore it.  I saw a lot of reviewers saying that you should use a notepad with this game to keep track of side quests because there is not quest log.  If your players are having to use external tools to keep track of something in the game, that’s a failing on the game’s part.  It does not add to the experience or mystique of the game.  In fact, it detracts, since you have to consciously put the game aside to take notes.  I didn’t get far enough into the game to really judge how much you’d have to use the wiki to find secrets and solve puzzles, but if what little I did get is an indication of the rest of the game, then another symptom of the lack of direction is just how often people have to search online to figure out how to find something or what to do next.  Again, if your players are have to use external tools to play the game, it’s a failing of the game.  I've yet to find any appreciable story after 15 hours of play.  And no, a few lines of dialogue every now and then are NOT story.  They're a pathetic attempt to pretend to have a story.  Maybe if I played longer, I'd see more interesting content and more story, but if I'm not seeing any real story even after I down the first major boss, I do not count that as having a story.  It's flavor text, at most.  As a final note on the negatives:  This is a lazy console port.  Framerate is capped at 60, Field of View is too narrow for computer screens, and not adjustable.  Interface is taken directly from the console, and that's almost never a good thing for a PC game.  Control scheme has terrible pre-bound keys, and commands that should really be split between multiple keys on a PC are bound together.  Additionally, there are a number of commands that can not be re-bound.  Number keys can not be bound to any commands.  And there's probably more that I'm forgetting about.  This game is playable with a kb/mouse, would probably be better with a controller, but REALLY needed a interface/control rework for PC.  As for the last part, let me preface this by saying it does NOT factor into my negative review, because I know many people very much so enjoy the souls-like model.  This was my first souls like game, and it turns out I do NOT enjoy the punishing mechanics that you have to corpse drag through to learn fights.  I get that others do, and I won't review it negatively because of that.  Though piece of advice, if you think you won't like the punishing challenge of the souls-like model, do not buy a souls-like game, you'll just be miserable.  If you don't have really good reactions, you won't be able to handle combat in this game.  People say git gud, and that's the kind of game this is.  I just have no interest and do not enjoy it.  Again, this is not why I'm giving the game a negative review, just a warning to anyone who might be looking to try the souls like model.

Do I recommend this game? If you like souls like games, then absolutely. If you’ve never played one I’ll still recommend it but keep some things in mind like making your decision to buy. It’s a souls like game so of course it’s incredibly difficult, but rewarding when you finally master combat and/or defeat an enemy. The graphics look great and the premise is solid. RPG style gameplay is so-so. You have no guidance, meaning there’s no quest markers. You run around the world finding dungeons and NPCs for quests and it’s not always clear what to do next. You don’t get a helping hand. This isn’t a negative per say, it just adds to the games challenge. A warning though, if you die, you drop your collected experience and must re-acquire it. If you die again before collecting it you lose it forever. It’s a great mechanic in my opinion, just a friendly warning.   Combat is great most of the time but incredibly frustrating other times. Sometimes the controls are unresponsive or buggy. Enough so that if you’re an average skilled player you’ll lose your experience more to a bug than actually being bested by the games challenges. You’ll randomly stop blocking for a second, enough for a boss to get a clean hit in. Rolling/dodging is unresponsive sometimes. And because it’s a difficult game, a single mistake can mean defeat. I’d much rather lose to making the wrong decision, like dodging into an attack or mistiming a dodge. Mind you, I’m not referring to times when you get locked by animation, like healing or swinging your weapon. It’s when you’re standing still, and it won’t roll.  Doesn’t make the game unplayable and it doesn’t happen often, but it makes the game far more frustrating that it needs to be. Getting bested is one thing, losing all of your experience because of a bug is another. Again, it’s not terrible, just an advanced warning to approach combat cautiously.  Overall, I’ll recommend the game if you like a challenge. If you’re intrigued by the concept but are intimidated by the difficulty, you could try an easier souls like game like Jedi: Fallen order first. It’s pretty easy as far as souls style games go and doesn’t go into too much depth, but the combat is polished and rewarding.
