I bought this game a long time ago and just couldn't get into it. I played the first Souls game but just couldn't get into 2 or 3. I thought Elden Ring was similar.   However, every time I was bored with other games, I'd load it up and mess around with it. I'd get frustrated because it took forever to walk everywhere (I stayed away from game guides). I'd get frustrated and stop playing. A couple of months and I'd fire it up and start all over with a new character. Then I was visited while resting and realized I had access to a horse. But, it was clunky to open the menu, click on the Torrent ring and go back to the game. Then I realized there was equipment slots for quick use. Awesome. I slowly began learning the mechanics of the game and learned it by getting slaughtered. I learned how to level up. I learned how to heal. I learned what so much of the game does. I even accidentally found myself in someone else's game and helped him defeat a boss. I didn't remember what I did so I had to try things again until it happened a second time. There's still things I haven't figured out, but that's okay. Like I haven't figured out how to get someone else to join me to defeat a boss. I've done them ny myself. I'm now working on Lyndell Royal Capital and just can get past a certain area. Not because of a boss or anything like that. I can't figure out where to go. I can finally kill things pretty quickly even bosses. I dual wield swords (both buffed to +8 and magic and Flame damage, wield the Golden Halbred +7 on Torrent and am happy to use a bow for tough distance fights.  So, what do I think of the game a year later? I love it. I love the fact I am having to learn how it works and what I have to do just to get the mechanics of it working like it should. Its a pleasure to have a game not tell me what to do for every aspect of the game. It's about a journey and it's been one hell of a journey. I'm addicted now.
Seems well optimized. It ran fine on hardware that it should run fine on.  There might as well not be music, there are vague slow tones, regardless of what's happening. Combat is slow going, extremely clunky, and unsatisfying.  The gameplay seems to be wandering around and either killing something easily, or dying. Control scheme is reasonable, but inconsistent, and seemingly an afterthought for the PC market.  Graphics are average, if not slightly above. The world has some kind of desaturated filter on it that makes everything seem dull. It's a blurry mess unless you turn off motion blur and depth of field.  The art is good and consistent, which makes up for some of the visual shortcomings of the game. The plot in 2 hrs of play is totally incoherent. There's a lot of exposition in cutscenes without any bearing. The few characters you talk to dialogue dump about what I can only assume matters later. I would consider the writing below average. In 2 hrs of play, I leveled up, which increased some stats that didn't impact anything in a noticeable way. I got some armor that increased some stats which also seemingly had no impact.  This game reminds me of old dreamcast games from the bargain bin..It'd be an absolute gem if it cost $5 and  I only owned 4 or 5 other games, but with modern gaming, there is fierce competition and this did not hook me. Normally I am okay to 'wait and see' but with all the rave reviews it caught, this game was an extreme disappointment.

Elden Ring was my introduction to the Souls series of games-- and I think it might also be my stopping point.  I had not played any Dark Souls games prior to this point, and the style of 3D combat was brand new to me at the outset. I was not foreign to difficult games, but most of the souls-like games I'd gotten good at by this point were 2D platformers and metroidvanias! Making the adjustment to camera controls was a learning curve and not being able to see everything at once tended to be a bit frustrating (at least at the start).   That said, I knew the internet was an essential resource for the souls genre and a few beginners-guides later I was adapting to the game's language with relative ease. If this is your entry point, please, do yourself a favor and make a few google searches on easy class types and beginner's guides! You'll save yourself an immense amount of headache in the future.  Once I was able to adapt to the style of gameplay, the world really opened up for me. I was BLOWN AWAY by the scale of the game-world and it's (relative) depth and detail. I found myself repeatedly enamored, shocked, and awed by the amount of impressive locations! This game does something that I genuinely appreciate: it is not afraid for you to not see all of it's content. Games like those produced by Ubisoft and others are determined to scatter a myriad of location markers and it takes all of the fun out of exploration (especially when said locations are copy-paste activities).  But even a game world like Elden Ring's cannot avoid the curse of padding in some areas: particularly, the repeated cave dungeons and ruins started to become much less and less exciting. Running into them and trying to clear them out for items became a chore when I'd gotten through the brunt of the game's world but they're a necessity for progression due to the items they contain.   That said, I think that it's much less atrocious in a game like Elden Ring and the world makes up for it in many ways; It's time I told you about my eclectic approach to discovery within this game's world.  When I set out from the start, I ended up receiving a single map for the start of the game. The remaining game world was covered in unmarked brown spotted with clouds. A tiny neuron (or demon, depending on how you look at it) ignited and told me that I now NEEDED the full map of the game. This became my primary desire in the game moving forward: fill the map. Before I wanted to explore anything thoroughly, I would have to get the whole map. For games like Breath of the Wild, I was able to do this exact strategy and had a great time doing so.   For Elden Ring, however, this would prove a unique challenge. Many areas of the game require items, boss completion, and a good deal of exploration to find ways to access. I took to the challenge and immediately began pushing in all directions to see how far I could go with very little upgrades and levels. To spare you the details of my entire journey (spoilers) this was incredibly difficult, but I managed to pull it off. I made it to the final mapped area of the game and had completed the set!  From here, I began to explore the world more thoroughly and found it a great joy to go back to starting areas with my big boy items and absolutely cheese earlier challenges in the game. I made discoveries, I beat bosses, I played the game and had a lot of fun doing so: but it was around here that I discovered what I'd been enjoying most about the game and why that was about to change.  You see, I was getting almost all of my enjoyment out of exploration. Once I'd managed to do almost all of that (I am currently located in the endgame areas having explored almost all of the world prior but only haven beaten about half the major bosses) my enjoyment of the game was severely drying up. If I'm being honest, I am not a huge fan of the combat in this game.  Do NOT get me wrong, it is a superbly designed system which no doubt has been refined over the course of the Souls series, it provides a HUGE amount of strategic options (which I enjoyed making the most of as a Bleed-Build Warrior), and is accessible for a pretty wide range of skill levels, but it just wasn't my cup of tea. Like I mentioned earlier, the 3D environment makes it difficult for me to get a full picture of what's going on sometimes. The way the world is set up, enemies and bosses either tend to be really easy or stupidly difficult. I hate the four century wind-ups and waiting periods on some bosses, and while there were highlights, I would often give up direct approaches and trying to be good at dodging (as a melee build) and would eventually resort to either over-leveling, cheesing with summons, or any alternative strategy that would get me PAST the boss-fight and onto the cool new areas to explore.   To put it more succinctly, once there was little left to explore, the core gameplay of Elden Ring didn't really entice me. I think it's a fantastic game that will stick out in my mind for a long time to come, but it has given me the impression that this was the only game in the Souls series that's going to appeal to me. That said, I HIGHLY recommend anybody interested in this game give it a go, as my experience will likely not resemble yours. I recommend you take your time with it and if you get stuck, don't be afraid to look up some help! I heard someone describe this game as "the dream game of 90's RPG developers" and I agree. 9.0/10.

it gud
I don't like Souls games. I suck at Souls games. Bounce right off 'em. I didn't even like THIS game at first; it spits you into a hostile world, points you vaguely in a direction likely to get you killed and tells you to figure it out. That isn't immediately fun.  But then I started experiencing things I'd never associated with Souls before: A huge variety of weapons, with fighting styles and animations to match. Enormous freedom to build your character, including impressive magic systems (I'd always just associated Souls with fairly dry sword-and-shield combat). Exploration is always rewarding, with oodles of actually-useful, unique goodies to be found in the world's various nooks and crannies. A decent roster of summons to help with tough encounters, and many other tools to approach challenges. And while it does punish you in a way other games don't, you stop minding after a while and are never stuck in one spot, even at an important story boss. The art direction is superb, capturing both brightness and ominous dark. The game is so freeform that your way through it might be alien to another player, yet it feels rich and complete in a way that is rare in the era of microtransactions, battle passes etc. Elden Ring refreshingly has none of that.  Cons? The game needed a journal. Quests can break if you make the wrong bit of progress at the wrong time, and you'll frequently hit a roadblock because you haven't poked the right illusory wall in the right dungeon out of a hundred or so or didn't talk to that one guy in that backwater ruin enough times. This isn't a dealbreaker; most of the fun is emergent and I actually felt more involved by starting up a pen-and-paper journal to track stuff. The lore is good, and creatively imparted, but it exists to serve the gameplay and build the immediate world, so don't go in expecting depth on the level of Elder Scrolls, Mass Effect, Horizon, etc. (Sorry Souls fans, I know this is a point of pride.) The tone is also relentlessly depressing. The game world is pretty much post-apocalyptic, and outside a handful of NPCs the only people are maddened or otherwise hostile. Don't get attached to any of the characters you meet because there are almost no happy endings for any of them. I had to remind myself to come up for air occasionally to avoid it affecting my IRL mood. Performance isn't perfect even a year post-launch, with some unusual frame drops here and there, but it still ran okay on my old laptop as well as my stronger desktop. KBM controls are atrocious; you’ll want a controller.  None of this brings Elden Ring down. It's a deeply involving experience that has dominated two months of my life, and I don't regret it. It won't hold your and through any part of it I still don't know if these games are really my thing, but Elden Ring will stick with me for a long time for a lot of good reasons. I can think of several different builds and weapon classes I want to go back and try, and there are a couple of areas and major bosses I haven't even touched yet, never mind the other endings. Easy 9/10.

Ah, Elden Ring, the game that's so easy even a blindfolded monkey with one hand tied behind its back could beat it.  I mean, sure, the bosses are giant, imposing monsters that will make you feel like an ant in comparison, but once you figure out their weak points, they're about as threatening as a kitten with a ball of yarn.  And those open-world areas? Please. Who needs a map or a compass when you can just wander aimlessly and stumble upon all the hidden secrets and treasures without breaking a sweat?  And don't even get me started on the combat. It's like the game is playing itself. Just mash some buttons and watch as your character effortlessly decimates everything in its path.  Sure, you might die a few times, but that's just to give you a false sense of challenge. The truth is, this game is about as difficult as a Sunday crossword puzzle.  So if you're looking for a game that's so easy it's practically a walk in the park, then Elden Ring is the game for you. Just don't forget to bring a picnic basket and a frisbee, because you'll have plenty of time to enjoy the scenery.

this game is top tier 10/10
After almost a year with this game, after 450hrs or so playing this game on and off, completing all the achievements, playing with multiple characters, with my friends, dabbling in pvp and invasions, and slight bit of modding.  I can proudly say it was worth the hype.  I'll assume people familiar and those who have played previous FromSoft titles have already played this so for those WHO ARE UNFAMILIAR with the souls series and are wondering if it is worth playing. It is. I played this with two friends who have never played a soulsborne game in their life and we thoroughly enjoyed it. There are a few caveats for a new player but I'll base this both on my personal experience and my friend's opinions on our journey. Here are some things to consider.  * I'll preface what you need to consider before buying the game with this. This is a long game. You will have to devote a lot of hours into this game. Mind you, not just at one sitting but it will be a while to finish a new game. It can go from 60~150hrs for a first playthrough depending on how much you want to explore and how good you are at the game. So consider that this isn't an over the weekend type of game and if you are fine with that, then let's move on. * This is an action-rpg, you will have to learn the mechanics of the game and be somewhat adept to it. That goes for both understanding the role-playing aspects and the technical aspects of playing the game. Mashing 1 button with your starting gear can work for a while but without learning how to upgrade, using talisman's, boss mechanics, enemy and level layouts, you're gonna have a bad time. FromSoft's level design is impeccable and you'll slowly pick all of this up intuitively if you pay attention to what the game tells you. * There is no difficulty slider, there is one difficulty and that's it. Your playthrough's difficulty will depend on your play-style and how much you want to delve into the numerous in-game mechanics of the game. There is nothing wrong with asking for help, looking for help, and searching for help. Whether it be youtube, the wiki, reddit, or online players, it's fine as long as you're enjoying. * Co-op is super fun but is also annoying (sometimes). Traditional in-out multiplayer is not what Elden Ring offers, while I am familiar with Dark Souls co-op, invasions, and pvp, my friends were not. It takes about 3-5 sessions with friends before they'll get used to it and stop complaining. There are also invasions where the most fun and frustration was had. Pretending to be chairs and watching an invader get confused then corner themselves was fun but you'll also get the occasional god who can just destroy you as you run towards a boss. So, in conclusion, it's fun, convoluted, frustrating and the most unique multiplayer experience we had.  * Have fun. This is a challenging game, but a lot of enjoyment can stem from that challenge. IT IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. Anyone can play it but that does not mean they will enjoy it. If you feel that you won't enjoy the game, that's fine, it doesn't mean you are a lesser gamer for it. You can revisit the thought of playing someday. However, if you have been craving for a different experience from your typical open-world, map marker, get into the top of the tower and unlock the map game, then this might be a refreshing and even life changing experience for you. The game's approuch to open-world deisgn is phenominal. Interconnected zones that are inhabited with such unique enemies and are leveled in a way that doesn't seem unfair (at least not at the first half of the game). These zones intuitively show you where to go and how to get into them. So enjoy the feeling of exploring the beatiful world created by Miyazaki and his team. And if you do choose to buy this game, welcome fellow Tarnished, into The Lands Between.   Serious Critique Time:  (Here I put some of the things I observed that can I found viable for discussion)  * Performance - during the first week, the performance was abbysmal and while it got better over time, I am still getting dips from certain areas. I'm sure this won't happen but implementing DLSS or FSR into the game may help some or even in their future games. * 60 FPS cap - I know, it's for balancing with multiplayer. I personally got my ass whooped by a dude who kept stuttering while running and attacking. This is apparently caused by unlocking framerate. I'm unsure if it's the engine, netcode, or whatever reason but other multiplayer games have found a workaround for this so maybe in the next game, it would help if they could allow us to remove the 60fps cap since they have made a push for more multiplayer. * Boss and enemy variety - I always found it a strange critique due to how many different enemy and boss designs are in the game. There is an absurd ammount of unique enemies and bosses in the game as compared to other open-world titles. Even the repeat enemies for the later half of the game are unique enough for me to not find it annoying, however, what I do find annoying is the ammount of the damage they do. * End-game difficulty spike - I like the soul's challenge but by god does it suddenly kicks you in the balls then start spitting at you as you get up. Maybe I can say it wasn't that hard because my first time through the game I did not notice it but playing it again with friends suddenly made me realize how ridiculous the damage end-game areas can do to you, especially with multiplayer scaling. I don't know why I did not feel this in my first playthrough but with subsequent playthroughs it did seem unfair in a bad way.   Overall, these are nitpicks that I found after multiple playthroughs.   I played this game on release and finished it after a month. This game is an experience and will leave you amazed and overwhelmed with how wonderful and terrifying the world is. I just can't wait to see what's next for us tarnished. Please Miyazaki, give us the DLC.

my second ever souls game after ds1r. i got it two or so months after launch, while the online was still fairly active, and it was really fun at the time. it still is as long as you play with the seamless co-op mod, like everybody else is doing. why from software has not implemented similar multiplayer into a souls game themselves yet is beyond me. it is by far the most enjoyable way to play this game, especially with the absence of covenants in this title. invading feels like an optional chore you can do for no reward other than the experience. if you like the experience, that's great, but the incentive is sorely missed for me. the latter half of the game can be a slog and serves little purpose other than ensuring a full run take upwards of 50 to 60 hours. if you have friends to play elden ring with, then i can't recommend this game enough. otherwise, play dark souls 3. 8/10 with seamless, 6.5/10 without.

a boring, poorly-balanced shadow of Fromsofts past of designing tight, good-feeling games. the story and the aesthetics are top quality, and stand proud against the rest of the series, but every other core part of the soulsian experience has been gutted to deliver a large world with a sprawling story. the coop is muted and fairly pointless to be summoned by, invaders are either gangbanged by hunters and summons or blatantly min maxing builds just for the rush they get at the "host killed" screen. the boss fights have poor timing that are incongruous with the pace of the character. the bloated systems and half assed renditions of good ideas from previous games are lost in a whirlwind of sketchy combat, landscapes meant to be walked around until you find a cave worth exploring, and dungeons too small and too repetitive in design aesthetic and enemy types that the whole, massive world feels like the same area with the same enemies and the same annoying reasons to send you to the nearest checkpoint with a slightly different coat of paint on it. im sad to saay fromsoft have lost their moxy in taking on a project that they honestly shouldve reeled in a time or two. play at your own risk, most people wont even find the game fun because of the core systems.

Fifteen hours into Elden Ring, I defeated Godrick, the first of five Elden Lords. In the time between emerging into the Lands Between and striking him down, I'd discovered decrepit ruins, ventured into twisting caves, stumbled upon enemy encampments, and battled tooth and nail against challenging bosses. From Software's games have always made you feel small in many ways: They tell you that you're worthless--a plague-ridden rat or accursed Undead, unfit even to be cinders. They ask you to navigate unflinching brutal worlds and pit you against enemies that systematically dismantle your ego. Elden Ring maintains the nail-biting combat and air of mystery that has distinguished From Software's Soulsborne games, but it's elevated to new heights by the studio's interpretation of what an open-world game can be. Having brought down Godrick, the breadth of the world--and the way in which From Software has applied its signature style to an open world--was on full display, reinforcing how insignificant I really was and driving home the magnitude of the task that still awaited me.  Standing on the edge of a cliffside in Liurnia of the Lakes, the area beyond Godrick's arena, I took in the world laid out in front of me: the enormous Erdtree casting brilliant golden beams of light onto the land that exists in its shadow; the sharp peaks of a distant mountain that look like claws tearing at the sky; a castle standing proudly amidst ruins; a forest blanketed in an ominous fog. It was all overwhelming, and none of the hardships I'd experienced in Demon's Souls, Dark Souls, Bloodborne, or Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice have come close to making me feel as small. At the same time, I was overcome with excitement for what the Lands Between had in store for me and all the seemingly insurmountable battles awaiting--and it did not disappoint.  Elden Ring is From Software's crowning achievement in world design--epic in scale and scope. But what makes it special isn't just how visually stunning it all is, or that its open-world is vast, rich in detail, and teeming with possibilities. Instead, it's how the studio has applied its own esoteric design principles to deliver an experience that feels fresh, elegant, and uniquely From Software. The game's core pillars are built on the same strong action and role-playing foundations as previous titles while offering more freedom to explore than ever before. Elden Ring is an open-world game entirely in a category of its own. That delicate orchestration of highs and lows and the build-up and release of tension that From Software has mastered, coupled with the thrill of freeform exploration and discovery, is an intoxicating cocktail of game design.  In guiding the player, Elden Ring employs the lightest of touches. The Lands Between is truly open and offers the player complete agency in exploration, whether on foot or horseback. The world is ruled by five Elden Lords, each in possession of a shard of the titular Elden Ring. As a lowly Tarnished, you aim to defeat these corrupt lords, take their shards, stand before the Erdtree, and become an Elden Lord in your own right. With the premise established through a quick cutscene, you are let loose and left to forge a path through the world as you see fit.  A key part of From Software's design ethos is to strip down to the essentials, and in Elden Ring that process strengthens exploration and discovery, the heart and soul of the experience. The studio's games typically give the player very little while asking a lot, and Elden Ring is the most obtuse and demanding of its games so far. This is largely because everything you've come to expect from modern open-world games is absent; for instance, there's no map until you find an item that reveals the topography of a region. Even then, the points of interest in that region aren't marked until you've been there and seen them. There is no minimap, just a compass to show the cardinal directions and any waypoints you've placed.  Characters, meanwhile, aren't desperate for your attention; as with previous games, the quests they task you with aren't noted down or tracked in any kind of log--it's up to you to do your due diligence. Areas you go to won't be gated depending on your level, and there's no clear indication on when you should go to key locations. The best you get is at the Sites of Grace, which function as rest points in the same way Bonfires, Lanterns, or Idols did in other titles. At each of these sites is a dim trail of golden light pointing in the general direction of… something. Perhaps it's the next milestone in your quest or maybe it's just another area that has a dungeon--the only way to find out is to make the journey.  The challenge for From Software lies in the friction between the studio's design hallmarks and the expected conventions of a genre filled with games that try to be all things to everyone. And although the execution is an unmitigated success, one thing's for sure: Elden Ring is not a smooth-edged, one-size-fits-all kind of experience that will accommodate everyone. Instead, it's unrelentingly opaque, relishes in the savagery of confronting players with unfavorable odds, and delights in watching the ensuing struggle. Elden Ring's gameplay will feel familiar to those with experience of previous From Software games. The tried-and-true formula of measured third-person combat against enemies that are swift to punish foolhardiness is both as thrilling and nerve-racking as ever. Whether you wield a sword and shield, swing something that's closer to a heap of raw iron, or stand back as a mage and launch spells to topple your foes, Elden Ring tests patience and skill with tricky enemy mobs and ferocious bosses.

mint
worth trying on a sale, but has a significant amount of problems for the fifth entry in the lock 'n' roller + poison swamp series (6th if you count bloodborne). the gimmick this time around is the open world and the hybrid build diversity compared to the other games. consumables in this game are also significantly stronger than in the older souls games and summons are another accessibility or build tool available to players. the game suffers from strange combat feel problems and heavy content reuse, which I assume are caused from copypasting assets from sekiro and DS3. additionally, with a RTX 1070, i occasionally had microhitches during a handful of boss fights.  my playthrough was done exclusively with colossal swords, no summons in combat, limited consumables and limited magic use, so some of the complaints won't matter to those who are laser or summon enjoyers.  the combat: - attacking on the horse feels very clunky and is excessively powerful. you spend a lot of time on the horse and it ends up contributing a lot to a massive amount of dead air while exploring since any packs of enemies end up becoming busywork instead of being a threat. - the game is close to DS2 in terms of combat design, which is not a sin on its own. several fights are duos or trios, but enemies also will pace their attacks to not overwhelm the player which seems very strange given that most weapons have ways to deal with packs, unlike in DS2 - several bosses feel inappropriately boring, notably the dragon enemies that let you attack their legs for free until they die of old age. - several enemies have unique attacks that can't be easily sightread and hit like trucks. of these attacks, some have very ambiguous or no telegraphs on followups (e.g. [spoiler]radagon's wave of gold looking identical to most of the decals that he applies is a strange encounter choice, you eventually learn that his wave of gold is exclusively a frontal cone so his huge slams will never detonate[/spoiler]) that you'll only figure out either by just beating them before you run out of hp or exhaust evasion options until you find one that works. if you don't level vigor sufficiently, these fights can be particularly frustrating. additionally, there are a handful of attacks that require the player to just run away (e.g. [spoiler]Commander Niall's P2 Frostbite AoE[/spoiler] and these feel very boring to play against as there's no counterplay other than "don't be there" and imo dramatically slows the game down. - there is woefully insufficient camera settings, particularly when locked on. depth perception is a skill check depending on build. this is particularly annoying with my build as whiff punishing, stance breaking and knowing what attacks can interrupt bosses are vital to playing the game. bosses across the board have greater melee range than the player so it's very jarring when you commit and barely miss, even when the model looks like it connected. i ended up having to just fight most of my fights without the lockon and with the camera tilted up to make it clearer when it was safe to attack. additionally, some enemies can drag you with them during their command grabs which is extremely annoying if the camera moves during it. - enemies don't scale to you meaning you can very easily overlevel an area if you go out of order, which punishes exploration - the only ways to mitigate this are to either spend your runes on everything but leveling or to intentionally let them rot. - [spoiler]lake of rot[/spoiler] is an entire area dedicated to being a build check instead of a skill check. the only way to natively deal with that area is to AFK on platforms if you don't have the items or skills to reduce the burden that the area places on the player. if you have the health regeneration to deal with [spoiler]the scarlet rot without exploiting a lower level scarlet rot and then activating it[/spoiler] then you probably have also found the way to craft said items or obtain said skills, which are also missable. out of combat, debuffs that aren't fully built should decay much more rapidly. - [spoiler]rykard[/spoiler] should have been left on the cutting room floor. literal R1 spam boss with occasional skill ask - lethal fall damage past a 2 second drop is a strange include in a game that promotes exploration and punishes creative use of verticality in engagements, notably in mid-lategame areas. the only thing that killed me more than fall damage in the game was blind RL1 tree sentinel.  content reuse: the game suffers from heavy scope creep from the open world. - mines, graves, catacombs and other dungeons feel very similar. each type of location shares the same aesthetics as the rest of their family. - i fought the [spoiler]magma wyrm[/spoiler] 5 times and several bosses more than twice. even major bosses get partially reused, lmao. - some strong overworld enemies are dungeon bosses (though it might be vice-versa, which is still questionable) - the areas are so large that a lot of the locations within it are indistinct. imo, the world could have been compressed by 50% and maintained a much higher level of quality. - all weapons that aren't enemy drops are only obtainable once per playthrough. in order to get every item in the game without trading, you must enter NG++ or trade/dupe with someone else.

good game, hard game but good game 
Elden Ring is a fantastic and overall HUGE game that From Software has published last year. The combat is fun (especially if you are using an INT build and you can just OHKO bosses with Comet Azur lol) and the overall open world of the game is simply gorgeous.  I also have to give credit to the developers, because they did a really good job at optimizing the game, since it runs smoothly at 40-50 FPS on a 1050Ti (1080P Low/Mid settings), which is a lot for a GPU which came out many years ago.  The only minor inconvenience that I have found with this game is that some bosses are way too frustrating to handle for an average gamer (Malenia, for instance): it seems to me as if the developers have wanted to make this type of bosses overly complicated on purpose, making them very unbalanced in the process.  In conclusion, I recommend this game to everyone! Even if Souls-Like games are not your typical to-go game, it's still worth giving Elden Ring a shot. And if you find yourself stuck on a bossfight, you don't necessarily have to lose your mind and "git gud", you can just summon a bunch of friends and have fun!
boob 
Another good iteration of the Souls series. Quite similar to previous Souls games so if you liked them you will like this one.   Nothing major has really changed since before but there are some differences such as the following. Its open world so there is more flexibility to do other things if you get stuck on a boss. There is even better atmosphere and bigger scale than previous ones. You can teleport to any Lost Grace site (bonfire) at anytime from the beginning. You also get recharges of the health and magic potions as you progress through areas and kill enemies, this makes it possible to go for longer times between Grace sites.  Its typical Souls, if you don't know what Souls is like nowadays then a.) you should crawl out from under your rock a bit more often and b.) try it!

If you liked DS3 you'll like this one as well, since, in short: it is DS3 expanded. It is crazy how big it is, how many builds, weapons and pathways you can take. Be advised: if you want to beat every boss in a single run it'll be almost impossible, unless you do it with a guide.  Still, there is one downside to all of the virtues of this game: boss recycling. There must be around 15 bosses or so that will appear later on as a regular enemy, which is somewhat underwhelming.  BTW, try looking up any NPCs you may meet along the way, they'll probably have a quest that'll be in your interest to complete.

i killed the horse guy
TL;DR Overall 8/10. If you have not played any Souls-like titles before it's is a must-play. I will focus on the parts I didn't like in the review but there are a lot of good things as well. Level design, graphics and music are outstanding, 11/10. Boss fights: 3/10. Worst part of the game. Generally it's insanely unrealistic and stupid just for the sake of tricking a player. Bosses use their ultragigachad500kg hammers just like daggers, there is 0 sense of motion, inertia and weight. They can halt mid air, turn mid air and autoaim just to mess with your brain. If you have a melee weapon your tactics will be <roll> <roll> <roll> <hit> <roll> <roll> <roll><hit> almost for every past-mid-game boss, that's how they are designed to be `difficult`. It makes the fights unsatisfactory. Overall gameplay 6/10. Leveling up seems to be useless because every rat or naked hollow dude deals the same amount of damage as bosses no matter what armour you have. Perhaps the sewer rat should be the next Elden lord?  Killing mobs provide no rewards. Looting is a joke, because 99% of loot is trash. Since all weapons are kinda balanced you can finish the game with a weapon you have found in the first 10 hours, there is no much point in finding a new one stats-wise. Don't get me wrong, the game is good overall, especially if you have not played any DS title before, however for me the RPG and boss fights part was weak.
It's very easy, would recommend.

The game's fine (and the whole saga) but definitely it's not for me (and if you're anything like me, probably you'll feel the same). Allow me to explain myself  Au contraire of many reviewers, I don't see Elden Ring as a 'masterpiece' nor a game superior in any way to an ultramodded version of Skyrim SE or AE. Sorry about that.  Nah, it's not about difficulty, you heathen bitch. I was able to overcome some initial bosses searching for tips here and there, it's about the gameplay itself: the entire world wants you dead, it's hostile, creepy, inhuman, inaccesible, hermetic and fucked up all around. It's exhausting and boring. Go there, be trashed aprox. 20-30 times by some weirdos before going forward. Repeat.  You wanna have some fun by overpowering your build? Let's do your research before playing: forums, videos, fan websites and the like. And I'm a sort of a'soft gamer' with a life and family, I don't want my time to be wasted before playing, I just wanna have some fun playing the damn game.   Besides, I need a game to be plural, 'human', diverse, colorful; I need a game to tell me a story, providing me a challenge I really want to overcome while I'm enjoying the sights, the landscape, the NPCs.. In Elder Ring I'm just shitting in my pants all the time. Not funny, you know.   Perhaps I'll give it a shot someday. For the time being, I'm gonna stick to my Witcher, my CP2077 and my ultramodded Skyrim SE. Enjoy this torture machiner... I mean, this game :)

So far so good, I guess
It's too hard.  But quite possibly the best feeling responsive and fun mechanics of any game ive ever played.  So just running around and dueling mobs is a top 10 gaming experience.  But, If you dont consider yourself a hardcore gamer, with like 3+ months to invest into daily methodical grind, then dont expect to get far very soon.  Maybe dont even try,  I would honestly not recommend this game to your dad or your grandpa,  or your friends that are not very in keen with gaming.  You need to be a pretty good gamer to play this game.   They really actually DO need to tone down on the difficulty just a smidgeon for it to be perfectly balanced.  When people ask if its really that hard?  yes,  it is really that hard and harder than that when you actually jump in and see for yourself.  But it is also very satisfying.  You will play for a while, and think, oh this isnt that hard.  Until it IS that hard.  And you will understand the depth we speak about when reviewing this game.  The map is massive.  It is actually too big.  There is never a point during the game where you actually have a good feel for where you are or where youre going.  its just too much.  Even when I have grinded this game out to absolute completion,  the map still is too much for me to fully grasp at times.  I remember thinking multiple times that I must be near completion of the game,  and then realizing that I have only revealed maybe 10% of the game.  And then after unvealing even further like 10x deeper than my original, I would start to think that the end must be in sight very soon.  And yet, it wasnt.  The end is so far beyond anything you could perceive,  that you need to set aside all thoughts of ever finishing the game,  and just hunker down and enjoy the process.  Dont look for an end.  Dont try to play it like you are trying to win right now.  The game is just too long to think that way.  Its ebven more massivbe than mmo's I have mastered in the past.  I think there is a line in the sand when it comes to difficulty and progression.  This is a balancing act where too hard and its a chore that isnt fun to do, too easy and you are bored.  They nailed it, while at the same time, completely crossing way over that line and stressing the user out way beyond reason.  And this title really does cross into that threshhold of being just a little bit way too much for reasonable gamers especially if you have any other commitments to attend to.  I am a hardcore gamer, with titles to my name and a vast experience in pvp.  It starts out and you basically just die, and die, and die.  When You start to get a hang of it.  The difficulty ramps up x10.   And then the difficulty goes even further.  You play for another 3 days nonstop, and then the difficulty progresses even further to a point that you couldnt even imagine when first getting through the initial skill cap.  playing through this game reminds me, of like a journey through a difficult career.  Where it never gets easier, it only ever gets harder the further you go,  only, you become accustom to the increases of difficulty.   You get used to the pain.  You think the game will eventually even out and become fair as you level up and gain skill,  but it never does.  The ground you walk on, goes from being mountains and hills,  to being on fire and ticking away your health.  And it doesnt tick just a little bit of HP,  it chunks out large portions of health non stop.  And it isnt as simple as just use a potion.  As some items are non recurring.  Meaning you get a dead set # and you have to find these items.  To turning into poison that kills you in 5 seconds, but you have to survive in it and fight some of the most difficult bosses and mobs for 3 hours somehow.  The biomes continually get harder, in ways you wouldnt even expect.  It's like the devs have an incredible talent for making punishing biomes for you to experience.  If it ever gets too hot, maybe go back to that first biome where its all green bushes and grass.  Because if you arent at least walking in fire and getting rolled up on by something that has an entire set of boss mechanics, consider yourself lucky because it will not last for long.  What kept me going, is that the game is just so fun.  I would not play for 2 days,  and then I just NEEDED to play this game,  because its just so, damn, fun.  I couldnt stop.  Even when I beat the game,  I ended up doing 200 more boss run fights of just the same 1 boss I liked, just to figure out all the ways to perfect him so I could show off my skills in cooperative play.  Even then,  most boss fights, you can play 1000 times and still never get just perfect.  You will still take a hit, or die in some unforseeable way. this very epic and hard boss.    It only ever gets way harder to the point where you are finessing mobs with absolute skill and perfection,  and yet you still die, reguardless of your perfect skills and mechanics mastery.  The game is designed to be able to kill you even if you are playing perfectly.  And at times you cant even believe that the game could get that much harder,  but then it does, every step of the way,  the levels get even more treacherous and difficult, and yet somehow, you will figure out a way through it.  There are some fights you can get through 1 shot.  There are some fights you can be clever and find a walk around or cheese method, or exploit.  And then there are some fights where your currect charcter build demands that you just hunker down, and learn the fight absolutely perfectly, and then hope you get one lucky go.  There are boss mechanics in the game, that actually really do cheat and dont make sense.  You can play it perfectly and still get an unlucky go, and die.   You will have to just die and die and die and maybe on the 10th or 15th time youll get through it.  its a LOT of fun, but you need guts, and time, if you have the guts, go for it.  There will probably never be another experience like it ever again.  10/10.  Right now I probably would not play another game like this again, simply because its just too much most of the time,  unless they made a game where you could actually stand a chance on your own without looking up guides.  I had a constant 5 to 20 tabs open on my windows for guides for the vast amount of things this game has that you need to do or figure out.  Its, a lot.  It's literally actually too much.  I would suggest they make the map like half the size next time also.  And maybe not be such a complex maze even when you are standing in a grass and hill biome, its just too confusing and too easy to get lost.  Like all you have to do is take a couple steps forward and you are lost and confused.  look to the left, you are lost,  look right, you are lost.  That is one part they could improve in future designs.  Take out a LOT of the complex hills and shrubbery, ect.  Sometimes you just get tired of battling in a never ending maze, and especially when the maze is the size of the actual universe irl.  with all this said,  you cant play this game and not have fun.  it's all about the mechanics, skills, spells, and weapons.  they are just so good.
Amazing Game
magnum opus
An absolute masterpiece.  When I first started playing it, I quit after a couple of hours. Being a "Soulslike" player since Demon Souls, the open world somehow didn't really spark my passion.  After talking to a friend I gave it another try with a more open minded approach and just explored the world in a more Skyrim like fashion. And what a great suprise this was.  The world is just amazing, on every corner there is another area to explore.  What I love the most about Elden Ring is that it is not "forcing" you to do a looooot of it's content. It's not the classic content rollercoaster ride. If you don't explore you will miss half (or even more) of the game and I think that is a real quality of an open world game.  I love everything about the game, I only feel like I will have a hard time finding a new game that will live up to this for quite a while 😖

As a long-time fan of the Demon's, Dark Souls and Bloodborne series, this is a huge leap backwards and I'm left with a myriad of negative feelings on this. From its half-baked open-world, poor technical performance and it's constant recycling of bosses. The world is a half-realised bore-fest with barely any NPCs to encounter (ones I do find are not memorable in the least), oh and the bosses. Jesus are they awful. The constant reuses of the same bosses, over and over. I'm only 30 hours in and I must've fought about 7 of those goddamn gargoyles, all with the same copy-pasted movesets. I also remember when other Fromsoft entries had bosses  that were tough but FAIR. The bosses in ER are absolutely relentless, giving absolutely no room for openings. It's a battle of attrition of I hit, they hit. And those one-hit kills. Good god. FromSoft really needs to distinguish between difficult and cheap. The stutters and FPS drops are another thing. The game looks beautiful, I would expect no less from From Software's art department, sure. But from a pure technical level, it looks nowhere near as pretty, let's say, as Red Dead Redemption 2. Yet here I am fighting with constant stutters, FPS drops, while trying to dodgeroll, which require frame-precision. This is inexcusable.  So yeah, overall, one of the most disappointing games I've had the displeasure of playing. Not a bad game perse, but an incredibly disappointing one nontheless.

My roll is still on cooldown
As an older MMO and fantasy game player any mention of the souls games and their well known cranked up difficulty have scared me away. Don't get me wrong I love a harder game and if it's too easy I lose interest really quick. I knew a few people who played it and they told me just how great it was and I honestly just ignored it. Not until it made game of the year did my I feel some interest in the title. Maybe I was missing something here.. Well let me tell you..it's true. The game is pretty damn hard, especially the bosses. I'm talking throw my controller harder after 15-30 deaths. BUT Wow everyone was right. It is soo satisfying when you finally kill one of those epic mobs. I'm talking about jump out of your chair, swear at the dead mob, and shout holy s*%^! It's that moving. The world is incredible looking, the combat is just thrilling, the exploration seems to be never ending, dungeons and caves have you on the edge of your seat, the customization of weapon and character are rich, and I just can't get enough. If your like me and heard all of the horror stories of dying a lot, they're right. You will die and die and die but each time your learning. You're adapting. Soon it all feels natural..and then you'll die again haha.  At first I hated seeing all the messages around and the ghosts of other players. Now, I stop and read most as there's some good information about secrets you'd probably never find. There's also some that try to trick you.. usually the 20 blood stains all around let you in on the disaster that awaits. When I'm in some dark deep cave system and I a short glimpse of the  ghost of a player it now calms me and let's me know I'm not alone in this adventure. It's really pretty cool. Trust me, if you love a good RPG, and you love seeing locales and monsters that make you step back and go WOW that's awesome, Get this. You won't regret it.

Very fun and challenging!
Having never given any souls-like games a try, I finally decided to jump in with Elden Ring. With a deep, rich world full of lore, extremely compelling combat, and beautiful scenery, Elden Ring is an actual masterpiece and, in my opinion, is one of the greatest games ever made.
Absolutely excellent. Everything I'd want from an open world souls game and more. Everywhere you go is exciting because there's always a good loot to be found in any cave. Even if I didn't use 96% of it, just knowing I had a new weapon, spell, or shield was great. I'd frequently find something I collected a long time ago was worth trying. If a cave has gear you don't care about, it probably has upgrade materials in it, so it's almost never a wasted trip.  The summonable creatures is a great addition. Even if you don't need their help, just throwing out some wolves or demi humans at a small town of hostiles is fun!   The ash of war system might be my favorite addition to the souls formula. Being able to switch my weapons from heavy to bleed to sacred at a whim made me more incentivised to try different strategies compared to previous souls games. I mainly used Zweihander early game, but even after I switched to Ruins Greatsword/Guts Greatsword, I put sacred blade on Zwei for death birds and skeletons!  Definitely one of the best games I've played in a long time. Also, rune bears and Malenia are BS.

first time playing a fromsoftware game; really good first impression i enjoyed it thoroughly but i wouldn't recommend this if you're a casual player and don't have a lot of time to play a game. first off the map is HUGE, like i wouldn't be able to put in words on how big the map is, the best example i could give is the fact that when i first started playing and found my first map piece i thought "damn this game is pretty big" not taking into account the fact that the piece of the map i just got was the starter area and the only about 1/16th of the total game, maybe even less- so in short what im saying this is gonna be a pretty long review.   next thing i want to talk about are the bosses, this game would absolutely not be complete with the countless challenging (yet annoying) bosses, but i really appreciate the fact that the developers didn't make it so if you encounter a boss that you can't beat you have to spend hours, days, or even weeks trying to so you can progress in the story, but in elden ring you can actually just leave that area, go to a different area that you can manage and spend a couple hours there to get something that can beat the boss.   i'd say my two main complaints about this game are balancing, and how the sheer size of the game affects the story and all the things that you miss due to it.  the balancing:  again as much as i love this game and how it lets you deal with not being able to beat a boss i feel like dying in two hits or even one hit makes it so when you do spend your attempts with said boss trying to actually predict the move-set just to accidentally dodge the wrong way or dodge half a second late you feel like you've just been cheated out of finally beating the boss because of some stupid glitch despite it just being part of the game. this is a really easy problem to fix as all you have to do is go back to a few bosses and adjust the damage output on them, or the amount of health they have. i remember (SPOILERS AHEAD) when i first encountered maliketh there was a draconic tree sentinel in front of his boss room, i spent nearly an hour trying to defeat them, only to enter the boss room and kill maliketh in a few minutes, this is the kind of shit i talk about when i say "balancing issues".  pacing and guidance: now when i first started the game i remember accidentally roaming to the mid-game part of the map, to say the least i was vaporized the second i encountered an enemy, of course now its a walk in the park but back then it was like hell. the problem with this is the fact that the map is enormous and i spent hours just trying to get there since i didn't have torrent to travel, i didn't have torrent because the game didn't give me any hints on to where i should be going for it. talking to white mask varre and following the grace paths are the only decent guides you get at the start of the game and even if you figure that out those options barely work. for the rest of the game you're fated to just listen to the boring, bland dialogue of what to do or where to go not even knowing if you're supposed to listen to that advice due to you not understanding where to travel to next because of how incredibly vague the descriptions of your supposed path are made. i didn't even finish going to every map portion before i completed the entire game and was severely under-leveled for like half the main bosses because the game never gave me a clear path on what i should do next. the real only way you can experience this game at its fullest is looking up a basic guide on what order you should do things or asking a friend thats completed the game for instructions. i still barely understand the story and didn't even get a special ending to the game because i missed all the quest-lines for those endings  as much as this makes me seem like i despise the game it's still definitely a top 3 for me. i do still find my complaints valid but the experience i've had from this game is like no other, i never thought of getting it when it first came out but now that i have i don't regret it. again i wouldn't consider buying this game if you don't have a lot of free time because of how large it is but if you do decide to get it i'd first consult a friend that does have the game and ask them for guidance.  final rating: 9/10

Elden Ring leaves me conflicted, it is a good game, no doubt about it, definitely deserves GOTY. But the thing is, after playing the Dark Souls trilogy, it just doesn't hit the same. At the start of the game, it didn't really grab me and I didn't find it all that enticing. But once I reached the middle of the game, I got intrigued. Questlines like that of the volcano manor, were very well written and I found myself caring for a lot more NPC's in the game than in Dark Souls. Then the end, it was just underwhelming, after beating [spoiler] Malenia [/spoiler] and feeling one the greatest satisfactions I've felt, the end bosses were just a let down and the ending left me indifferent.   [b]Furthermore:, some other smaller critiques I have:[/b] - Dual Boss fights, my god why so many. Slapping two enemies that are practically the same in one boss fight just doesn't work. - They really went all in on delayed attacks in this game my god, annoying! - Either the one of the hardest FromSoft games, or the easiest depending on what you limit yourself to. - Sometimes I felt overwhelmed by the intricacy of some areas like [spoiler]Stormveil Castle[/spoiler] or [spoiler]the capital[/spoiler]  [b]The good:[/b] - Music 10/10 - Looks gorgeous - A lot more NPC's that actually matter and have an interesting questline. - Good sidequestlines! - The DS3 weapon art done right. - A lot more dynamics in your build through e.g MIxed Physicks, Rebirth and Ashes of War. - UI is defintely better than previous games. - The world is a lot more dynamic, espcially in dungeons were it sometimes felt like you were in liminal spaces. - The use of verticality in cities or castles in this game is amazing, the realization that I could just jump on a roof and explore an entire different part or route, took my breath away.  Overall Elden Ring is a good game, the middle part of the game is where all the meat will be found and I will remember it for that and not it's endgame. 8/10

Amazing. Just goodness. I mean after actually sticking with Dark souls III I knew soulsborne was for me, but this just leveled up all my love for it. Even though you can recognize some poor models and textures, you will overlook them. Because all the flashy, lovely places, well visually designed bosses will make you forget. Audio design? Chills down the spine. After just turning the game on you are welcomed by the most epic track I have heard in a while. It is well-done soulsborne with some new techniques. Summons are an amazing addition to the game, spells and incantations are beautiful and impactful while not leaving the weapons behind. There are also way more options with PVP cause they added an arena in one of the updates. My biggest problem is the reuse of stuff. The world is big and pretty, but it got so huge, that it seems there was a problem with creating enough original mobs and bosses. It is common to fight bosses as normal mobs and vice versa. Another usual occurrence is fighting one boss multiple times (I killed that white fuck like 7 times in one playthrough). Overall it will hang high in my hall of fame.

Git Gud
I really enjoyed this game (PvE only), but there's a lot of hype and it isn't for everyone. If you're looking for a well-told and gripping story, characters you get attached to who develop through the game, and interesting quests, this IS NOT the game for that. If you're looking for a cool open world with beautiful scenery, minimal NPC interaction, a deep RPG system with lots of build flexibility, and super fun combat, this IS the game for that.   You can adjust the difficulty by over/under leveling; I was probably a bit over-leveled most of the time because I explored a lot, so I thought it was hard, but not as hard as many other games I've played. There's enough to do that you can save the tough parts for when you're overpowered, or you could choose to never level up and go for a no-hit run.  The Bad: Most of the quests and NPCs are boring, and some of the quests need to be completed before others for no obvious reason. This leads to some items being easily missed. The story itself is kind of interesting, but it isn't presented in a compelling way, so it's hard to care about the world or the people in it. This is compounded by the fact that there aren't really any towns, townsfolk, etc. to grow attached to. Finally, while for the most part the boss fights are awesome, there are one or two that are glitchy and/or tedious.  The Good: The world is beautiful, and the locations are interesting and varied. The combat is wonderful, and the RPG systems are deep and flexible. There are lots of viable builds, weapons, and spells that can make gameplay feel very different. After the second main area, you can respec more or less freely. Exploring the overworld and various dungeons is fun and rewarding. Your mount can double jump and is a good boy.  Overall, I loved this game, and it's one of my all-time favorites now. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a mechanically and aesthetically brilliant action RPG who doesn't care too much if the story and characters are a bit mediocre.
Game of the year over God of War Ragnorak for a reason.

definitely not hard
Pretty decent for a victim simulator. There are several big big problems, though.  Foremost, there is absolutely no information in the game about any of the (side) missions - you have to rely on information got from NPCs only and this info they give you is severely lacking. It is literally impossible to do the missions without the help of our old pal internet, unless you are simply lucky with your actions in crucial situations or find out the next mission steps and locations by blind luck. The idea of the environment and NPCs telling you the story is refreshing and certainly a million times better way than Assassin's Creed-style IN YOUR FACE display of too much information, but in this game it is the other extreme - not getting enough basic information.  Secondly, the controls are simply utter shit. Console port in its worst possible meaning. Keyboard macros alleviate it a little, as does playing with a controller, but this should not be the default option for a PC game.  Thirdly, the bosses suddenly get unnecessarily tough compared to the previous gameplay.  Also, I do not understand the hype around the size of the map. It is big - yes, but not THAT big. You could drive your horse from one edge to another in a couple of minutes, the landscape permitting. What makes the feeling of the map bigger is the fact that it is artificially fractured by unpassable cliffs so that you have to go around via longer routes and hence the feeling of the map being bigger.  Also important - WTF with the limited 60 FPS? This crap must be fixed ASAP.

I don't really know what to say. This game is a mixed bag for me.  On the one hand, I don't like this game. It's too big. The side dungeons/caves/catacombs are all half-baked and don't add much to the game. I feel the game is simultaneously too easy AND too hard. It suffers from a lack of focus and I think doesn't do a good job at making travelling from point to point interesting. Again, I really think the game is far too big. Remove the side content entirely and focus on making more legacy dungeon content/ actually interesting open-world engagements, and it'd be much, much better in my eyes.  On the other hand...  God. This game changed my life. I don't know what it is, but I find myself appreciating life more, appreciating the things I have, and have gained a deeper understanding of what I even look for in life. A bit dramatic, sure? But I'm a very emotional person. I can't really describe my feelings without turning this review into a dissertation, so I'll keep it brief. Elden Ring showed me that things are beautiful in spite of all the ugly things around it. And it taught me to appreciate what I have, and not to force things to be the same just because they feel good.  I love playing this game with my friends. The issues I have still exist, and I think the way that co-op is handled does not fit the nature of an open-world game. I prefer the Seamless Co-Op mod for this reason. I feel as if Seamless is the way the game is meant to be played as far as co-op goes (even if the Rot mechanic is stupid as fuck. The game is hard enough already.)  I dunno. I guess I recommend it? It would feel disingenuous to not recommend it after the effect it's had on me. I guess I should just say: Temper your expectations going in. Don't buy into the hype. Don't focus too much on what other people have to say. Just make it your own experience.
Frankly, easier than Bloodborne which I'd consider the easiest souls game besides DS3.

Tl;dr:  Read a book or something. If you aren't a streamer or unemployed you wont have the time to play this game. Its size makes it a huge slog. Not a good introduction to the Souls Series and not a good continuation for returning players. If you enjoyed the bosses, you will be dissapointed, their moves are poorly telegraphed. If you enjoyed the multiplayer covenants, you will be dissapointed, covenants were removed, as were worthwhile multiplayer rewards. If you enjoyed the arena matchmaking from DS3's dlc you are in luck, it has made a return and since Elden Ring is relevant you will find arena matches. Go phone your parents or friends or go to a bar drinking, those will fullfill you more then elden ring will.  Rant start. Elden Ring expands and streamlines systems from previous games, while showhorning in crafting and an open world. The weapon infusion mechanic combined with the new ashes of war, that allow customisation of a weapons moveset, are great. The invasion multiplayer experience has been neutered, there are no more covenants. The cooperative experience has been streamlined, with a single item ones summon sign now appears all over the game world at certain unlocked summoning pools for other players to find. The rewards for any type of multiplayer? Nonexistant. Multiplayer rewards consist of the equivalent of a humanity/ human effigy/ ember and something called a furlfinger remedy, an item to reveal summon signs. The furlfinger remedy can also be crafted by mashing together two of the same flower that can be picked from any roadside. Elden Ring has seperated the boosting aspect of a humanity/ human effigy/ ember from the multiplayer enabling aspect. This results in two severely devalued items. The default reward for multiplayer has as such not changed from previous games, but the percieved value is much lower. The removal of covenants and their unique twist in multiplayer means there are no longer any covenant specific rewards, that could at least act as a trophy. The new open world itself is bloated, to much space, to little substantial reward for exploration. Most exploration rewards are now crafting materials in unsubstantial amounts. Heavy expendable item usage now demands farming for materials from monsters, or prancing around the world picking flowers. There are traders, but not all crafting materials are buyable in unlimited amounts. Want to toss a kilo ton of tnt worth of bombs? Have a fun time farming materials. Want to do a bow only run? Have fun killing small animals for their bones to craft arrows until you find the right merchant. Then farm even more to upgrade those arrows with different effects. Want to use more special arrows? Hit or miss if they are craftable/ buyable/ must be farmed.  The lock-on system is completely unusable. Not a large problem for melee builds, but anything using magic will quickly grow frustrated with the inability to properly focus a target in group fights and switch the lock-on target. Bosses are frantic and unpredictable. Their combat is intense, with every combo being able to chain into the next with little downtime. The boss ai has been 'improved' meaning some bosses can now read your inputs and toss a fireball into your face, if you go to heal. The combos themselves can also be incredibly dependant on your position with no clear stopping point, meaning that going for a swing from the wrong direction after the combo seemingly ended, can net the player an attack to the face. The percieved weight of a bosses attack can also vary wildly. Perhaps they start their combo with their weapon swinging so quickly that one is hardpressed to react on time, just to suddenly take an awkward pause mid-swing, catchin you off-guard. Elden Ring bosses can be described as experienced pvp players; they only use weapons with incredibly short startup animations, they are masters at input staggering and roll catching and they have deceptive attack ranges. But unlike another player they cannot be staggered in two hits. I can't remember where i heard this, but Elden Ring does indeed reward exploration instead of perceverance; exploring the bloated and empty game world eventually nets one enough levels and upgrade materials to overlevel any boss, allowing one to ignore the poorly telegraphed attacks of bosses  simply by the means of more healing resources and more damage. In previous games the bosses are consistent enough for the player to gather alot of experience with a bit of perceverance and use that perceverance to finally beat the boss. In Elden Ring the bosses have been 'polished' to such a degree, have recieved so much love in the form of varying movesets and combos, that i wished the animator in charge of telegraphing those attacks was forced to actually test them first. Being hit by the same high damage move over and over again, because the wind-up animation towards it has so little visual cues it might as well be a rythm game is not fun, its infuriating. Does this mean i am bad at the game? I would agree to that retort, if it weren't for the fact that every boss in this game has at least one such attack, an attack with a ridiculous pause mid swing. Every boss, with criminal consistency is guilty of this. Its either you overlevel the boss, or cheese him in some way, or you spend the rest of the year persevering through staggered animations that are meant to uproot any sense of movement coherency you might have learned over your whole life. The open world also quickly looses its novelty after you find another secret place only to be rewarded with a flower you could have just picked from the wayside in larger quantities. Towards the end i quickly rushed through every new area, because i knew that my time was better spent searching for anything worthwhile on the wiki and backtrack for it later. It was no longer a game, it was a chore i wanted to be more efficient to hopefully get to the good part. But there is no good part later. Perhaps the multiplayer could have been a major upside, but there are severe limits on playercount. The world is huge and the game is unable to fill it with either interesting secrets or wothwhile multiplayer.  Rant end.

Con's: The story is hidden, and hard to figure out without help from a guide or video. Hard (it is both a pro and a con) The amount of variety in combat and magic can be overwhelming and confusing. I am a longtime Soulsborne player so take that for what it is.   Elden Ring is a fantastic game, maybe my least favorite in the souls franchise, but still an amazing game.   For all the things I was excited about like the open world and crafting, I think that ended up taking away from some of the games charm, I never thought I would think something like this but I actually miss the somewhat linear setup of Dark Souls compared to the totally open Elden Ring - the open world becomes a little bit redundant when everything everywhere wants to just kill you (with one or two exceptions I think).   For someone new to the franchise, I would definitely start with elden ring as it has the most quality of life improvements, the game is fun and polished. its fire. what else is there to say that hasnt been said lol? game of the year.
This is the culmination of all the previous Souls titles, into one gigantic game that seems to have somehow fit the same amount of content and detail of previous titles into a game multiple times larger than them. there are hundreds of weapons, spells, armor sets, weapon arts and they all come together to offer more variety in builds and play styles than any other Fromsoft game. However, this is not without a few faults that this game has that cannot be overlooked. Because this game is gigantic, shortcuts had to be made when it comes to content like bosses and mini dungeons, so reused bosses and environments can be found. This can cause issues with the lore and immersion, as sometimes a boss can be found in an cave that doesn't make sense wielding a weapon it usually shouldn't. While previous titles had a couple re used bosses, such as dragonslayer armor, guardian ape, or the cleric beast, in Elden Ring, there are actually only a few bosses that are not re used. This can take away from the suspense of fighting some of the better bosses, such as Godfrey and Mohg, since you already had experience with another version before their real fight. The other flaw is the very strange variance in difficulty, especially in the late game. World enemies become harder than bosses, with gigantic health pools and often are in large groups, like the zamor warriors in the mountaintops or the banished knights in castle sol. This combined with the lack of meaningful rewards from these enemies can mean the best course will be simply running past them, which is not an ideal strategy in a game centered around combat. This is offset by the endgame boss guantlet, which is one of the best I've ever seen. All in all, while I highly, highly, highly recommend this game, I do not recommend it as your first fromsoft game. Dark Souls 3 is much more streamlined in its difficulty and is much more straightforward and easy to approach, as opposed to the sheer scale of Elden Ring which might scare some people away. If you  do want to push through and go into this game as your first, my best advice is to not give up and keep trying. If you're stuck at a boss or section, don't tunnel vision on that and instead go someplace else and check it out, find your own path that matches the difficulty experience you want, rather than what others may tell you to take.

5 stars 10/10
I got this game when it first came out. I reached Stormveil (the first 'stronghold' area) while streaming to my friends (all of whom were super deep into the game already), and after getting lots of super in-depth tips from them, I rage quit after some bullshit (a friendly NPC steals your runes every time you die in his area, and I ended up going broke and losing all the souls I got from the 2 big previous bosses). After that, I uninstalled Elden Ring and didn't play it for a whole year. I thought about leaving a negative review for a while, because the experience I had first playing this game was dog shit, with too many secrets and too much emphasis on getting your time wasted fucking around and finding out.  A year later, I've dusted Elden Ring off to give it another try, except this time I played it my way. I didn't let anyone tell me what the "objectively best starting class" is, or take advice on what build to make, or which direction to go after I spawned. I just ran towards whichever horizon I wanted, killed what I met, ran away if I couldn't, looked up whatever guides I needed to to avoid wasting time with groundhog day-esque death-heavy puzzle segments. It was an entirely different experience, and said experience is the only way I can really recommend you play this game.   If you're going to play Elden Ring, do it the way you want to, and try to limit the number of outside voices telling you how you should be playing. There's a huge temptation to, just like in Tarkov, let Reddit-dwellers (or your friends in VC) do the thinking for you and tell you what you should be using for the most DPS or whatever - don't do this. Don't let elitist slimes tell you that you have to fight every boss head on either, or that you can't use summons, or that magic is 'gay', or that you shouldn't play any starting class besides the Samurai. Use however many quest guides or maps you feel you need, and just experience the fucking game with the features it has, in any combination that you want. If you're someone that gets frustrated when a seemingly meaningless decision causes something disastrous to happen, make sure to look up each NPC you meet to see if they're someone who's going to help or hinder you.  Oh and the story sucks, so stick to being impressed by visuals and cool weapons rather than by trying to make sense of all the dumb names and plotlines.

Elden Ring is marketed as an Open-World RPG that doesn't focus on it's open nature, instead pretending to be Dark Souls 4 (with too much space). Enemies frequently do too much damage per hit, meaning that players should either go all-in on HP or not bother with the stat (focus on evading instead). This game still punishes casters (as DS3 did: no FP-regen, staggering stat sinks required, sacrifice healing for FP flasks, etc.) while getting rid of weapon durability (infinite melee). FromSoft is clearly too heavily invested in making a "harder" game (difficulty is always subjective) and failed to flesh out key details of this title. The questlines are convoluted and offer no guidance, even Majora's Mask (2000) included an in-game utility to track NPCs. The worst part for me was finding out after refund-eligibility expired that the game didn't live up to its hype and the first real boss can easily be more than 2 hours in. Now I'm stuck fighting a game I should be enjoying instead. C'est la vie!

why do people simp for ranni?
This was my first From Software Souls game and I absolutely did not expect to enjoy this as much as I did. I have some gripes with it but overall this was one of the best RPGs I've ever played.  First, a few negatives; As my first Souls game I had no idea what I was doing for the first few hours of the game and I had to constantly rely on YouTube as my companion. The tutorial at the start of the game was pretty bare bones, I didn't even realise you could run until a few hours in.  The difficulty was extremely punishing at the start of the game. For returning players I imagine this isn't a problem as the mechanics transfer from previous games, but for me I had a hard time until a few YouTube videos taught me the basics. After you get over the initial hurdle you learn that the game rewards patience, it's all about learning the enemies attack patterns and punishing them when they show an opening.  Although the world itself is magnificent and the enemy variety and design were great, the game really sucks at telling a cohesive story. I had no idea what was going on and what my motivations were through a lot of the game. And my final complaint... no ultra wide support, that sucks on a game this big.  As negative as that all sounded, I still think this was one of the best games I've ever played. It's so satisfying learning the attack patterns of a boss and then trying again and again until you defeat them. The open world was huge and there was always something interesting to find. You'll constantly be sidetracked by branching pathways on your way to a destination.  The loot almost always felt rewarding, and even when I was deep into the game I was still finding new areas and mechanics. The ability to spec your character to whatever you preferred play style is great. The enemies were always interesting, some of the bosses had the coolest designs. The art and music were blended together perfectly.  I've completed the main story and I think I've been to every main area of the map but I'm sure there's still hours of content in the game for me should I choose to explore further. I'm glad I gave this game a chance. It won game of the year for a reason.
Elden ring is one of the best games ever made, but its not without its flaws, and some of them are serious ones (need for self nerfing if u want the game to be any challenge, weapon art spam, poor quality of endgame areas, lenght of the endgame etc) . Buy the game you will enjoy it, non of the above should discourage you from trying it out for urself as it is as genre defining as zelda botw, death stranding or likes of it. If you are looking for a game that pushes boundaries of what games can be, then you wont be disapointed, as this is truly next gen experience in many ways. That being said, its not a perfect game, but a strong foundation that gives hope for a future of gaming as a whole.
