good
I have never played any souls game before, so when the game released back in the february it was beyond my interest, despite the huge hype around it. When Elden Ring became the game of the year, tired of trivial, repetitive rpgs, i've decided to give it a try.  Despite the fact that from the beginning bosses were wiping the floor with me i had such an amazing time playing this game. The Lands Between look stunning and are filled with places and things just waiting to be discovered. After optional tutorial we're being tossed into vast world with one goal but without any explanations. The way this goal is achieved is up to us - players. Each player will experience this game in a different way, depending on which places were visited and what decisions were made. Lack of markers on the map additionally encourages to explore the world instead of boring us with copy- paste question marks filling the world map. The combat system, despite its simplicity, is very enjoyable. The vastness of the available arsenal means that everyone will find weapons or spells that suit their play style. Atmosphere of a dark fantasy world is wonderful, well, as much as it can be, because the fate of the characters and the story itself is filled to the brim with pure despair and tragedy. I found the lore in Elden Ring to be very intriguing and it completely absorbed me. I was hungry to know the story behind the royal family, the fate of the descendants of Marica and Radagon that were shrouded in mystery. And revealing these mysteries provided me the most fun i had with video games for past few years. The graphics may not be the most beautiful but it doesn't matter when the game world is designed in such a beautiful way.  With a clear conscience, I recommend Elden Ring to any player who likes open-world games, which throw one challenge after another to test our skills.  10 outta 10... Producers of modern AAA games, watch and learn!

[h1] The GOTY. The GOAT. [/h1]  [b]The positives[/b]  An absolute masterpiece by fromsoft, there is no way to meme around it. This game builds upon everything Demon souls, DS 1 - 3 and other games have done and turns it up to 11. build variety, weapons, spells, incantations, all have been massively improved (so miracle builds are actually viable for once) to the point I cant think of any build in elden ring that ISNT viable.  all mainline bosses are amazing and most side bosses whilst reused a lot are also fun to fight. The story like other games is cryptic and the lore is hidden so using a wiki is recommended if you want to understand everything.   NPCs are varied and amazing (ranni being my number 1 stunnagirl). Summons are varied and fun (black knife tiche, mimic tear, cleanrot knight, etc.)  [hr][/hr]  [b]Downsides[/b]  However, on the downside the reuse of bosses around the map is VERY noticeable you'll find the tree sentinel in your bed at night, the crucible knight will shower with you. Its not as bad as it seems given they're usually fun to fight but It puts off exploration a lot when you know the boss is going to be a random field enemy but with 2x the health and 3x the damage.  On top of this the difficulty spike going into late game areas is very noticeable and it gives you a lingering thought that leyndell was meant to be longer or harder.  Bosses can be extremely easy and a lot of them have various cheeses (looking at you draconic tree sentinel) that takes the fun out of fighting them if you use them. Not to mention bleed is very heavily overused with other status effects being left in the dust (they did madness, death blight and sleep dirty).   There are currently 3 endings. Lord ending, frenzied flame, and the age of stars. the others are all reskins of the lord ending with various outcomes.   Melina is never used to her full potential aside from turning into bbq meat near the end or popping up in a cryptic cutscene and I never found myself truly caring for her from start to finish, I truly think they should've done more to tug at our heart strings to make Melina's death feel much more impactful.  [hr][/hr]   In conclusion the game is amazing even with its myriad of issues, and Id recommend anyone even souls newbies in giving it a shot. Just dont browse reddit and tell people you used spirit summons because the soultards will run to you screaming how you didnt complete the game properly because you didnt play as a lvl 1 wretch whilst undergoing a lobotomy.  Play as you wish to play, do whatever you want if it makes the game more fun and enjoyable for you go for it.   Bleed build? hell yeah cut margit into swiss cheese Comet azure spam? Hey I like DBZ too, annihilate them. Unga Bunga strength build? enjoy staggering the moon and punish every enemy in the game.  just have fun and enjoy this masterpiece of a fromsoft game

a
I have never played a Dark Souls game before, but I have really enjoyed the time I have spent playing this version of a Souls game.  Bosses can be difficult, and after zero attempts at adapting my playstyle to each boss, I was eventually able to break through their defences.  Instrumental music is wonderful; I really enjoyed the strong beats in some of the boss's music, and the main theme was especially great.  It can be difficult to reach levels higher than 50, and some people use glitches to bypass this. However, you can eventually redistribute points and many bosses will give you plenty of rewards to compensate for the hard work.  I have not yet encountered the final boss, which I will not disclose, but so far the world exploration provides many bosses and enemies to fight when grinding for levels or acquiring various items of equipment such as shields so you will never lack in constructing the ideal loadout.  Overall, it's a great game, although there are some bugs that need to be fixed. I highly recommend Elden Ring for anyone looking to get into a Souls-like game with a great difficulty level for newcomers wanting to dip their toes into the franchise.

I like this game, but I can't recommend it based on the design and balance.  Quite simply put: You must dump most of your points into Vigor, or suffer getting oneshot by most enemies and bosses with their normal attacks.  Worst of all is the Crucible Knights. They are designed in the most frustrating way possible in that they are entirely built to counter any tactic a player can use against them. You can't backstab them, you can't status effect them. Their AI reacts to everything you do to prevent you from hurting them. They have way way too much health that you just have to whittle down for ages while they're capable of one-hitting you unless you dumped all your points into Vigor, which makes them only 2-3 hit you. Which isn't fun.  It's not that it's hard. I've 100%'d Sekiro, beating the Mortal Gauntlet and other challenges in it with little trouble. I'm planning on doing the same Charmless+Demon Bell at some point. Not to prove I'm "gud." Not because it's "hard." It's because it's compelling to do so. Because I have FUN with it. Because I ENJOY MYSELF doing it.  Elden Ring's "to heck with your "build" just dump all your points into health or die" design isn't enjoyable or fun or engaging for me. It's frustrating.  TL;DR: Please stop making small enemies who can start a grab animation during the middle of my attack animation and instantly kill me.

unfinished game. may be different on the consoles but for pc its basically an unfinished critter slasher game. story content is weak. no journal. no critter display upon selection (there's a blank blue icon top left with health bar but no info).  I did take several classes to approx lvl 50 to get a feel for how they were set up and had the most enjoyment from a wretch dex/int build or dex/ faith.  But at a certain point its just about running around for hours killing the same critters for coin to purchase your next level. managed to kill the first boss with a vagabond (knight)  I just put straight strength attribute into and it was very anti-climatic. Plus they have all these ghost images of other players in "other worlds" (which i''m sure is just them trying to reduce their server load), that is very annoying. I can't seem to turn it off but those images seem to be random and sometimes it gets in your view when battling groups of critters. oh and the targeting absolutely sux. you can have a target locked and just as you go to shoot it again the target lock breaks and moves to another critter not anywhere near you. I've had my character do a 360 in place trying to hit a new target lock on some critter 50 ft away. can not tell you how many times this has killed me. tried shutting it off in settings but it doesn't seem to make a difference. still needs work, but i'm sure now that this has been selected as game of the year that won't happen as the public has set their standards quite low. Also this isn't a traditional MMORPG in the sense that you'll be exploring with the other masses. basically you play on your own unless you want to join the PVP server, or you wish to have a few friends log in together with you, but i havn't tried that as it just does'nt "feel" right..visually its very attractive, and probably what carried it through the voting process, but in terms of playing an online MMORPG I'd spend your money somewhere else. However.. It goes without saying the maps are wonderful. the castle have a ton of variety and theres loads of "stuff" for you obessive compusive folk..but sadlky for me it just wasn't what I was expecting. there has been several times i have stopped and wondered what I was supposed to do next (other than run over to that same mob and slash em again)... I've only been playing about 2 weeks (now about a month)  and already i'm at a point of deleting the program, or face hours of the same...the same...the same...the same...the same..

i am a holy man !
At the end of the day this game is great. Truly. People may complain about the small things, but for AAA games these days, this game really challenges the lazy norm.   I've played this game a lot. From trying to speed-run, doing "challenge" runs, randomizers, or even watching my mate playing as the "Rump Shaker", I've found this game has a lot of replay-ability and content that can be enjoyed. Hell, i'm trying to replicate my first run again with my latest character. I often pine on the 10 character limit.  Dungeons have garnered a lot of ire, with people complaining about the copy pasta-esque nature. I agree, they get grating, and all for a funny hat or talisman. But not all. Some of the cooler dungeons have a unique weapon like the "Ringed Finger" or "Golden Epitaph." But you don't need to explore, if you don't want to. The main 'Souls-type' areas are always a treat, with areas that are as densely designed. It lacks a sense of interconnections with shortcuts and secret paths of Dark Souls 1, but trumps the entire series in the area's individual design.  Combat is fresh and new, with the flashy weapon arts making a return from Dark Souls 3. This time, they can actually be used, for the most part. The weapon designs are new, fresh, and welcome. Dual wielding support is here, but classic sword and board can be just as fun, as shields have gotten a lot of love. Combat can feel a bit jank at times, with a tighter dodge window and many (MANY) AOE attacks, but once you understand the boss, truly, it is never quite unfair. All the main story bosses are a spectacle, and quite a good roster to add to the Soulsborne bosses.  Exploration is a big thing in the game. You can make most bosses a joke with the correct set up. Some may call you scummy, but the game is as hard as you make it. The only thing I can get angry at, is the amount of farming for some rare-er consumables. It's either something you can find under every rock, or a limited resource with a 4% drop rate.   I never interact fully with the multiplayer. I did a short session, and it seemed functional enough. They incorporate some multiplayer aspects in certain boss-fights, but never in a way that is truly jarring. It's always interesting. I only wish Co-Op was fully fleshed out with no PvP, but it seems there are already mods for that.  Overall, it is a great game. Not for everyone, by a long shot. They tried to brand out to a casual audience a bit more, but it's still a souls game. If someone is telling you to buy this game, I would not buy it. You're probably going to get bored, and give up, a couple hours in. If you take this as a challenge to finish and beat the game, that's awesome. But most people I've suggested to play this game, have given up, got bored, or just couldn't. Only one person really stuck through, and that was with my direct encouragement.  Play this game if you have a desire, and drive to play it. To explore the lands between. Or maybe if you just want to see Godfrey, Chad of the Badlands.

The open world is incredible but isn't my speed and I get lost and bored after awhile. The world is incredible, just open world isn't what I'm looking for in a fromsoft game. 2. After playing this game I realized the reason I like bloodborne and sekiro so much is they have unique and addicting combat mechanics thataren't present in the souls series and elden ring. So if either of those things sound like they'd be an issue I'd hold off or wait for a sale, but if it really seems like a game you'd like, get it cause it probably is and it's incredibly well made.

The graphics are the most stunning thing I've seen in video game history.  Not only that, everything you see, you can go to.  Let me say that again:  EVERYTHING you SEE, you CAN go to!  This is the true 100% open world experience you've been dreaming of.  All transition between sitting down at "bonfires" and conversations with npc's are completely seamless, which adds to the feel of open world and like the adventure is a single continuous experience.  Sound design is god tier.  Voice acting is perfect, extremely fitting for the setting of the game.  Music is very well done to immerse and leave you feeling just on the edge of cautious, as well as create openings in the track to transform into boss music at a moment's notice xD  I have watched much of dark souls gameplay, bu this is my first DS game I've actually played.  The combat is fantastic, and the challenges are the best combination of tough but fair, and if not fair, once overcome, definitely rewarded.  I'm sure as I play more I will find that many of the different weapon options are exciting and balanced in their own way (tho I chose to play the big sword boi route).  I love the message leaving system, and I love that you can turn it off.

Yes, this game is hard. But there are so many options and ways to approach a situation that can make it easier; summons, comet azur, katanas (moonveil is still op). So don't let the difficulty keep you away.   I haven't had so many "holy cow" moments since I was a kid; the number of times I found something incredible, a boss did something insane, or the map just kept getting BIGGER. There is close to 200 hours of content  without even approaching new game +, and replayability is great because of the number of builds, weapons, spells, etc that you can try.   Reworking your build is a lot easier than before, and every area is packed with so many talismans and weapons you can try out with tons of different weapon move sets. Not to mention co-op play on areas and bosses adds to the fun.   Quest lines are a little annoying to track, but it's fun to hunt down and find NPCs, and a good portion of the quest lines have awesome rewards, or just unlock ENTIRE areas and bosses.  Don't miss out; please play this game. It's the best game I've ever played and without a doubt worth the $60.
As someone who has Dark Souls as their 2nd all time favorite franchise (Right behind The Elder Scrolls), I gotta say this one ain't great.  I don't actually wanna vote for not recommending the game, but it's the only option besides the "thumbs up" button.  Overall the game just feels hollow compared to it's predecessors. Pun only slightly intended.  The switch to open world seems to take away more than it adds. Seemingly just adding a longer travel time between areas that you would traverse in previous games.  Everything is even more obscure, and that's saying something for this series. Whereas the more "metroid-vania" structure of previous titles would make it easier to stumble across items and such, the open world aspect here basically makes having a wiki tab open in the background a necessity if you hope to actually find anything, or even go the right direction for story progress.  Actually, I can't help but picture the Souls formula used here as an old and tired Bilbo Baggins: "I feel all thin, sort of stretched, if you know what I mean: like butter that has been scraped over too much bread."  Overall, if you've played the previous games, go ahead with this one. But maybe get it on sale instead of full price. Maybe around $30 max.   But if you're just starting with this series, go back and play Dark Souls 1-3 instead. Then come back to this later if you're desperate for more punishment.

tigka kalo game
TLDR: Elden Ring, while imperfect, is the best implementation of an open-world action RPG that I've ever played. It feels like the culmination of every iteration of FromSoft's 'Souls' games into one truly amazing experience filled with intrigue, struggle, and eventual triumph.  GENRE: Fantasy, third-person, open world, action RPG, 'Souls' game  GAMEPLAY: Elden Ring is basically Dark Souls 4, or Dark Souls but now you can sneak, jump, and ride a steed around the open world areas. You start by creating a character and choosing a class to determine your starting gear and stats (e.g. Astrologer to be a spellcasting sorcerer, or Samurai to be a katana-weilding DEX melee build). You progress through the game by traveling around the map and finding items/gear to upgrade your equipment setup and defeating enemies to gain 'runes" that you can spend to level up or buy items from shops.  'Sites of grace' are the bonfire equivalents in Elden Ring, and most of the time they visually display a path of light that indicate the direction you need to head in to progress the main story through locations of major bosses. There are plenty of these grace sites littered everywhere in the open world and within dungeons so it is easy to fast travel to where you want to go immediately.  Elden Ring is an open world game and there are various minidungeons/secrets hidden away in every corner of the map. It is to your advantage to seek out these locations to find rare materials and unique weaponry that may or may not change your play style altogether. The open world feels like there is always something waiting for you to discover, such as powerful enemies that drop unique weapon arts (ashes of war) or an NPC standing around waiting to offer you a quest. With the introduction of a day/night cycle, there are even some bosses that only spawn at nighttime in specific locations waiting to ambush you, but offer unique drops as well.  GRAPHICS/PERFORMANCE: Elden Ring, at launch, was pretty shaky in terms of PC performance. I personally played this game to completion with below minimum specs (AMD FX 6300, RX 480) averaging 40-50 FPS at High settings. I encountered no game-breaking bugs/detrimental FPS hiccups in any playthrough, though the only issue I encountered was that enemies would sometimes become invisible on my screen whenever a large group of enemies were in an area, but they were still lock-on-able and would render again when I got closer/killed some of the group (this is probably just because my CPU is ancient).  In terms of graphics, Elden Ring doesn't break new ground when it comes to overall presentation, but it is a very colorful game compared to previous Souls games. You can really tell when you enter a new region when all the colors transition from one palette to another and the sky/landscape dramatically changes as well. Dark areas are also pretty spooky as you can only see far enough from the light of your torch or lantern and enemies hide in the shadows very well.  STORY: The long story short is: the Elden Ring was shattered into fragments and various demigods took the pieces to gain the fragmented powers within them. You are a 'Tarnished' which is basically a pseudo-undead human who is guided by grace to seek out the pieces of the Elden Ring, put them back together, and become Elden Lord in order to bring the world back to "order". (All of the details in between for NPC's and items is basically found in NPC dialogue and item descriptions for you to piece together, or until a genius puts all of the information together in a YouTube lore video)  STRENGTHS: •Combat feels the best it has ever been for 'Souls' games. Sneak attacks, jump attacks, ashes of war, NPC summons, mounted combat, guard counters, power-stancing, and everything else feels very, very good.  •Touching more on ashes of war, they basically allow you to add (and remove later) a unique skill to most non-unique weapons in the game. They also allow you to change the scaling of a weapon to a different one of your choice (if you also have the right whetstone) so you can make a weapon scale with INT or FTH even if it originally didn't.  •Boss encounters are exciting and challenging. If you feel underprepared, you can always to back to the open world and look for missed locations and items to better prepare yourself. (Also, feel free to use your ash summons whenever possible; it is a game mechanic after all)  •You can build a character however you desire, whether it be dual-weilding greatswords, holy knight, melee-spell-casting wizard, or pure archery.  •There are lots and lots of weapons to try, leading to more replayability as you try a new one in a future playthrough  •The crafting system is interesting as you can create consumables and throwable items when out of combat. You can even create bow/crossbow ammo which is very neat.  •Just when you think you're near the end, the map expands further and there is even more to discover.  •Compared to the other Dark Souls stories, Elden Ring's story feels the most digestible at face value without feeling completely puzzled from the outset.  WEAKNESSES: •PC performance isn't stellar if you are bothered by occasional FPS spikes or the rare game crash on loading screens.  •Not game-relevant, but the game doesn't fully "exit" when you quit out until a while later.  •Early game bosses reappear as 'mini-bosses' or just wandering around later game areas leading to some feelings of reused content.  •There is a massive spike in game difficulty from the mid-game to the late-game. It feels weirdly balanced when enemies all of a sudden go from doing 1/5 of your HP in damage to 1/2 of your HP in damage.  •UI could use a feature to compare stats of shop items with currently equipped items  •Online connectivity can be hit-or-miss. Sometimes when you are summoned to another world, you get a "connection error" and the game boots you back to single player.  •Be wary of hackers when playing co-op/PVP. Previous exploits have occurred where upon death, you would return to single player but be instantly dying forever because the hacker put you in an endless death loop. That exploit was patched, but we all know how hackers don't just give up.  •(Not a negative for me, but maybe if you like PvP): You can only invade other players if they are participating in co-op. Basically, unless a host uses a specific item, invasions usually lead to 1v2 or 1v3 scenarios (note: AFAIK fight clubs are only affected in that # of summonable participants is limited). I don't invade, but I've seen many people whining about this change when it makes sense why it is this way.  •So many important names sound very similar to each other that it could be difficult to remember who is who (e.g. Godwyn vs Godfrey vs Godrick).  •'Great Runes' are pretty underwhelming in terms of power.  •Although I enjoy the game design of not having a dedicated questlog ingame, it is still to your benefit to just read an NPC's quest guide off the wiki to keep yourself on track.  NUMERIC SCORE (if you care): 9.9/10; easy recommend  Elden Ring has set my bar for 'open-world RPG' standards. The added gameplay features like jumping, horse-riding, sneaking, etc. make the game's action much more interesting and fun than previous FromSoft games. The game kicks my ass at every step of the way, but the struggle and eventual triumph is worth all of it. Though it is not without fault, I love this game and can't wait for future DLC.

I’ll be honest… I almost let negativity bias affect my outlook on this game. I -really- had to sit on my experience for a bit as to not let my burning problems with the game affect my full outlook on Elden Ring. Do I recommend it? Yes, but with some caution. There are parts that I loved and parts that were absolutely asinine for me to get through. The biggest positives extend to Exploration, world design and the build variety. Exploring the world is an absolute treat. There’s so much to see in the lands between and you’re basically just… let loose with enough direction to not feel aimless. This allows you to experience the world in a way that is completely unique to you. It is so special to experience on a first playthrough. And even when I restarted the game to give it a second chance (I abandoned my first playthrough after getting frustrated) I still had a great time exploring the world all over again. Every structure you see is something you can travel through and explore and it’s super rewarding to see a massive mansion in the distance. Travel over to it and explore every nook and cranny. Of course Elden Ring didn’t invent this or anything, but it’s been refined really well in my opinion. The world design as a whole is mysterious and alluring. You want to know what lies around every corner and what the meaning of all the bizarre and fantastic things you see. The world building through Item descriptions and NPC dialog gives you insight into the world, enough to know what you’re doing. But still leaves you asking and guessing. I loved the amount of choices you are given to build your character in this one. You can do things like Tanky strength builds using Hammers and Greatswords or Quick and flashy Dex builds using Katanas and Twinblades. Combine that with the spells and incantations you get throughout the game and you get even more options. You can dedicate yourself to being a spellcaster or go hybrid with some melee options. Within the Spells and incantations there are subclasses of spells and weapons and talismans to go with them. This in tandem with the Weapon arts and ashes of war create a wonderful variety of options to pick from. The best part about all this customization is the fact that you’re able to change a lot of this stuff with general ease. So if you’re not having fun with your current build. You can try something else. The build variety is something that I’m excited to try again if I ever come back to this one. But ultimately this game has a -few- big problems with it. And my 2 biggest problems with this game are the bosses and the endgame content (Which I won’t spoil it but I will warn of it) The smaller bosses are constantly reused and overdone. They’re only really appealing to fight 1-2 times which would be fine if you only fought them sparingly. Unfortunately the minibosses you fight get reused a lot. And it gets really old, really quick. The only way they up the difficulty in reused minibosses on repeat encounters is to add another copy of the boss or add a different miniboss that doesn’t compliment the first one. Leading to lazy reuses of bosses that just serve to pad out playtime and end dungeons. They also try to spice up boss rematches by doing duo bosses but they never really work. Because the boss movesets just don’t work together in tandem because they weren't created to work together. Literally any time they tried to do a duo boss it just fails. It’s either uncoordinated and messy but functional. Or just straight up unfun and frustrating. Not to mention that certain Miniboss enemies, some of which are treated in the similar breaths to the larger encounters in the game. Can just be found in the wild just hanging around the world for no reason…  But then there’s the bigger bosses and it felt like Fromsoft went with a different approach when designing them. While I’m personally not huge on it I can see what they were going for. The bosses felt more like they were visual spectacles first and how much fun those -spectacles- end up actually being to fight come second. All the bosses look, sound, and act cool and they’re fun to fight when you’re watching somebody else do it. But when you’re experiencing some of these fights yourself the -spectacle- of them wear off real quick and the wow is quickly replaced by frustration… While the other souls games were “hard but fair” this game feels “frustrating but fair”. Sure I can dodge the mountains of bs being thrown my way but… trying to overcome these bosses feels frustrating. Sometimes I found myself wondering if some of these fights were tested to see if they were enjoyable to play instead of just “cool to look at”. What ended up happening was a minority of the fights were affecting my outlook on the larger picture. (IE: Malenia, Elden Beast, Fire Giant, Rykard) Because not all bosses are bad and unfun. Some are actually incredibly enjoyable and epic. But all of the bosses one way or another fell into one or more really annoying design pitfalls like attacks that are delayed unnaturally long, grab attacks that deal way too much damage and are way too punishing, super long combos which don’t give the player a chance to attack, and a camera that is zoomed in too close to see large enemies. Overall the bosses were the weakest part of the game and -really- hinders the replay value. Because I don’t want to redo some of these fights. Once was enough. Elden Ring’s endgame was easily the weakest part of it. Not only do the bosses get more frustrating than they were before. Not really pacing you with them and instead just, getting more unfair as you progress. The areas you explore get less open and more linear leading to a less rewarding experience. And the poor endgame (and one of the worst final bosses I’ve ever experienced in a video game) almost ruined my outlook of the game as a whole. Because it left a poor taste in my mouth walking away from the experience.     But TLDR Do I recommend Elden Ring? If you love exploring and find bosses to be secondary in your enjoyment of a game. Then I can easily recommend this one. But if you’re like me and bosses are the highlights of action games like this. Elden Ring might leave you more frustrated than satisfied. And even with certain bosses (like the final one my god why did it have to incorporate every single problem with this game’s boss design) hurting my outlook when I was walking away from it. I still found Elden Ring to be a great game. Does it have flaws? Sure but those flaws didn’t ruin the game. Would I go back to it? Given some time (and maybe DLC) I could see myself coming back and maybe just skipping the parts I didn’t enjoy so much. But overall I could see myself recommending this one.   But if you have any hangups about the difficulty… Maybe skip this one. The frustration you will experience might not be worth the positives.   4/5 Great. But not perfect.

[h1]Buying Elden Ring for the price that it's offered for in this day and age feels like daylight robbery. [/h1]Because I haven't played a single game in recent memory that comes even close to how much content there is just jam packed into Elden Ring, and not just filler content oh no no no. Tons of dungeons, a huge map that you can explore for hours upon hours and still find new things, hidden paths, huge underground areas and more !!!. Even the open world which most games offer as a "feature" is just miles ahead of anything else, the open world unlike many recent games doesn't feels lifeless and barren [strike](unless you're talking about C*elid, no no we don't talk about that)[/strike], it feels rich and full of life, the lush forests and filled with different animals and monsters alike, the mountain and plateau regions have their own biospheres and the grand cities like Leyndell and Elphael, Brace of the haligtree feels properly grand and lived in. The combat is also one of the best parts, there's a ton of build diversity in the form of different weapons, stats, spells, incantations and ashes of war. The combat feels tight and fluid and heavy weapons and swords feels like they require a lot of strength and stamina to wield.  Elden Ring is a game with insane replayability, you can play it for 100 hours and will probably come back to it for 100 more every month. [u]If you can then buy the deluxe edition, it doesn't offers anything else aside from a digital artbook and music album but it'll support Fromsoft in crafting experiences just like or better than Elden Ring in the future. [/u] [b]10/10 Must buy, and Good luck out there Tarnished.[/b]

W
This being my first FromSoftware game, It was very difficults, but to my pleasant surprise, it actually ended up becoming one of my favorite games. even after many nights of feeling like a victim, wanting to break my setup and wanting to cry.  The World My first playthrought I spent running straight into fights and regretting it soon later after i lost all my runes. I can't remember the last time I had this much fun just exploring and running around in a game's open world, and realizing the sheer scale of it all was exciting.  Even if I had trouble with a boss or an area, I could just go somewhere else on the map until I felt ready to take it on. There's plenty of things to do before even beating the first story boss.  Creature summons were also a huge help, and I was very happy with the options available. Trying out new weapons was fun, and even finding new ones for the lore bits was very compelling and made me want to collect them all.  The Gameplay My first playthrough ended up being something like 120 hours long, though plenty of those hours were spent doing random things like climbing hard-to-reach places to enjoy the view or attempting to get most items.  I also spent plenty of time stubbornly dying to enemies I wasn't quite yet ready to take on.  The Multiplayer I asked for help from some friends at times, and there are a lot of funny moments to be had when playing with others. It's also not that difficult to find a random player to summon if you need help with a boss or dungeon.  When you're in a boss arena, you can't be invaded, so if you're worried about that, you just have to limit summoning other players to when you're fighting bosses.  Though honestly, the invading wasn't as scary as I'd expected, it was honestly kinda fun. I have some great memories from when me and my friend were invaded.  Ending Thoughts I loved the npc's, although some of the quests felt like they ended too suddenly but others where extremly in detail and absolutly AMAZING.  Seeing my character in cutscenes, however few, felt very satisfying. Especially as I can't help but dress up for that purpose alone lol.  The only bad experience I really had with the game was towards the end. I absolutely hated a certain zones.   The optional boss in the many areas are one of my favorite designs and one of my most memorable experiences in the game.   Other than that, I had a few stutters here and there, but nothing too disrupting to my experience.  Even if the game seems difficult, I think giving it a chance is really worth it. The game gives you a lot of options if you're struggling, and there are plenty of playstyles you can give a go. I went with Dual wielding Katanas (My favourite build, a Moonvaile and rivers of blood)  Suffice to say, I'm super excited to see what the future dlc will bring and I highly recommend the game!

Greatest open world exploration of all time. Words aren't enough to describe the sheer scale of the world, the sense of adventure and that fear of traversing the open world because you don't know what's coming up next.  In an industry with watered down open world video games that hold your hand by marking every spot on the map, telling you wear to go, telling you what to do, a gazillion checklists strewn across the map to be "cleared", Elden Ring is a diamond. This is the culmination of Fromsoft's all the past titles and it can't get better than this. The legacy dungeons in this game or in other words, the castles and forts with Fromsoft's traditional level design are some of the best in the series.
Playing through this masterpiece was from start to finish an absolute pleasure, sometimes frustrating but that's part of the experience and what an experience this is. The world is huge, tons to explore - and exploring is never a chore, characters and environments that stimulate your imagination and really get you thinking about the lands between, the lore and how it all fits together. I absolutely recommend you play and experience Elden Ring yourself and find that like myself, you love it.

Conclusion: buy it, play it, you won't regret, especially if you are a fan of soulsborne games.  PROS: 1. Beautiful world and environmental design. 2. Stunning soundtrack. 3. Enemy & bosses design are surprisingly vast, only a couple times did I saw same NPC template being reused. 4. Key bosses are top notch, with a few exceptions. 5. Open world is rich with exploration, it is never dull to venture into the unknown for the first time. 6. Plenty of weapons and spells (didn't used any spells during my playthrough though, but their visuals for example can somewhat be observed when the bossed or NPC invaders use them). 7. Some of the annoying game mechanics of previous FromSoftware games were finally dropped.  CONS: 1. Some of the annoying game mechanics of previous FromSoftware games are still in the game, namely: runbacks to bosses,  runes not spawning before the bosses wall of fog (which is especially shameful, since there is no equivalent to the homeward bone in the game, only the talisman which breaks instead of losing runes on death), platforming sections. 2. Few and far between but terrible boss design (from the gameplay perspective, the visuals and sound are always good) still happen: from the beginning of the game a player will be overwhelmed with how fast and hard the majority of the bosses hit compared to the previous titles where it's either strong but slow or vice versa, albeit this is still manageable by [spoiler]gitting gud u scrub[/spoiler].  The problem is revealed when you come across the boss which seems to not have any weak side to it at all, for me this first was [spoiler]Valiant Gargoyles- hits like a truck from a mile away, combos are surprisingly fast with a couple of nearly unavoidable attacks some of which one shot, very maneuverable, lots of HP, there is 2 of them and they use damaging poison[/spoiler]. Later on this boss and enemy design persists, which allows for dividing all entities in just 2 categories: nuisance and death coin toss, the later being able to one shot you no matter the build\armor. Thus said some bosses just don't seem fair, namely I found this bosses to be a complete BS in no particular order: [spoiler]1. Valiant Gargoyles.[/spoiler] [spoiler]2. Godskin Duo of course.[/spoiler] [spoiler]3. Double Crucible Knights in some hero's grave.[/spoiler] [spoiler]4. Best cleric\Maliketh.[/spoiler] [spoiler]5. Radagon + Elden Beast.[/spoiler] [spoiler]6. Malenia.[/spoiler] Which is a minuscule amount considering the sheer quantity of the bosses in the game, but still shameful that a couple of them is mandatory to story progression.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

crash
World is very open; you get a convenient mount early to make the huge map feel appropriate. Most boss fights seem to allow you to run away if it's a lot more than you expected, which also prevents the loss/death/abandonment/rage quit spirals. There are plenty of areas to grind if you'd rather not get as good at the mechanics.  I wish the player character sketched in the map as you traversed it. I wish it didn't have an always online requiement. I would rather have a more casual entirely single player experience. The game is not perfect. But it is the most aesthetic game I've seen in a very long time; often it looks like the screenshot belongs in a museum. And of all the Dark Souls games, this does seem to be in the more forgiving half, which is great because I don't enjoy the more hardcore half.  Unlike Dark Souls the game has legit magic. It is still a hack and slash first, but the magic is well developed and can be used a lot, especiallly if you spec into it. With both healing and destruction spells, it covers the basis and there might be more interesting spells I haven't gotten to or been killed by a random invader with.  As an RPG and action adventure player, this game is great. Like I said, it's a bit hard and there's nothing to do but grind. I won't fault it since it's a design decision and I don't mind grinding. If you aren't skilled, don't want to die often, and don't like grinding, you should avoid this like the plague. If you are fine with just one of them, I'd buy it at least on-sale. Of course, if you like Dark Souls, I'm sure you already bought this so just play it already.

I can see why this is "the best soulsborne" but that doesn't make it game of the year. What a waste of money. I'll keep rage-playing this just so no one can say I didn't give it a chance and I just need to git gud, but I swear I'll update when I've beat the game that it's still bad.  The super punishing boss fights are fun because they're bosses. I will give the game that. I like Monster Hunter, I like Remnant, I like bosses that are really hard. They're incredibly cheap and purposefully designed so, but they're right on the edge of punishing and too cheap, and they're bosses so fine. But for miniboss types or exploring the story path, the basic design of this game is really annoying. If you die when you get to a new enemy type, which you will, CONSTANTLY, then you have to wade through a bunch of mooks who can kill you in three shots by stunlocking you with a buddy, and congrats, now you've lost all the runes you had on your fucking corpse retrieval. Who does corpse retrievals still in 2022? So to get to the new enemy you have to play perfectly just to get another shot, but they are all designed with incredibly unpredictable movesets with halting, unnatural moves so you can't predict when to block or dodge. The whole game concept feels like that mario maker video where every time mario jumps an invisible hazard pops out as an F you. F you, you had no way of knowing this would happen, but now you do. So go back and if you successfully predict that move, awesome, he's got branching paths off the same stance that have equally unpredictable moves. I don't understand why people think dying a ton in order to learn a moveset is fun. And again, the moves are designed to be unpredictable. You can't learn your skills and get good at the game and get better, you have to learn each individual enemy type.  And it's not just the mechanics of combat that has bad cues, the rest of the game does too. The giant tree knight at the beginning is way too hard to fight. Ok, I understand that after a try or two, but the tutorial, the dude you talk to at the beginning, the tip screens, no one says "hey, you need to be careful, don't try to kill everything." There are no hints that the bigger something is, the more dangerous it is. There are no hints that if you get stuck, you should go screw around somewhere else and level up, then come back. ALL of that has to be learned through internet research (bad design) or banging your head against the wall so you're frustrated and now have a sour taste in your mouth after owning the game for a few hours. Even like exploring, the game tells you explicitly to follow the glowing paths, but if you do so you'll be incredibly underleveled. So not only do you need to explore the whole section of the map you uncover, you need to go off into gray unexplored sections as well. ALL of this is counter to standard game design and gamer instincts. That doesn't make the game original and inventive, it makes it bad because it doesn't tell you any of that. It's a choose your own adventure book that says "make sure to read the story" and doesn't mention you can skip around.  I legitimately don't understand how this game has mass appeal. For fans of the genre, sure, absolutely. But a game of the year should transcend genre. A truly amazing game is at least fun to play for a while even if you're not a fan of the genre. I feel like I'm taking crazy pills when people talk about the wide appeal of this game.

Best game I've ever played! Highly recommended！
It becomes a somewhat fun game once you invest time and start to understand the mechanics and how the world works. Like other FromSoftware games, the challenge of playing difficult bosses and beating them in and of itself is part of the rewarding experience. The scenery and some of the dungeons / locations can be stunning. My problem with this game is the open world aspect, the story lines, and the characters. The world is vast but empty. For the size of the world, NPCs are too few, most are simply silly and childish, and, like the bosses, they are unrelatable and there is no real depth to their story. What's more, your character, the overarching story line and the side quests utterly fail to captivate. Dungeons, mines, enemies, and boss fights are repeated over and over again in an attempt to populate the open world and weak story line. The endings are a total let down. This game is just too much of a waste of time for what one gets out of it.

I avoided this game for a while because of the reputation for difficulty.  I played it for a bit last spring and ended up grinding *a lot* in order to get good enough to beat the bosses, but continuously failed because I didn't know about iframes, and didn't know about the ability to summon.  Positives: The world is huge and fully explorable.  If you like the explorability of skyrim, you'll probably love this, for similar reasons.  There are lots of different types of monsters and they're weird and alien and eerie and often wonderful  The lore is deep and nearly impenetrable.  There are lots of fun uses of language that I hadn't encountered before.    Negatives: You must use external sources to understand just about everything.  The in-game explanations of mechanics is basically non-existent past the tutorial.  Also, from what I gather, the plot is crazy convoluted, and I am concerned that it will be too complex to gain any satisfaction from the ending.  But all in all, a great success!

THIS IS ONE OF MY FAVORITE GAMES OF ALL TIME A GREAT PURCHASE
Go check out Malcolm Reynolds on Youtube first of all, cool guy.  So this game has a problem, a big one. The devs are trying to stomp out all cheating, so the coding community has double downed and created multiple ways to bypass EAC WHILE ONLINE. Welcome to the old DS3 days of getting crashed, and softbanned without knowing your inventory was edited. The issue isn't incredibly prevalent right now, but as a former CE coder for DS3 I can tell you quite easily where we are headed.  Once the game drops in price, it'll be overran. A lot of people now are just using whatever edits they can get away with, and some people are even buying multiple copies to ban evade. So right now it's not a super invasive issue, but within a year it will be. The price drop will hit, hackers will buy up multiple copies, and the harassment will begin. Do you remember frame DCed? Do you remember the crashes so bad that you had to restart your PC? Do you remember being teleported into a room, with no way out, and all your bonfires disabled? We are heading that direction. It's inevitable no matter what they do with the AC, but now the devs are trying to ban anyone, and everyone who uses any sort of edit of any kind.   I don't see harm in people editing their level for PvP, and I don't see issues with people creating new builds via CE editing (changing bullet values so you can use boss spells, or spells that are hidden within the code) A lot of this is really cool, and we even made a community in DS3 to prevent blackhats from ruining our fightclubs. We'd have an omega hacker defending the fight club, crashing anyone he detected as a blackhat. Now? Nobody wants to defend anymore, and you can still be force invaded at any time. There's no way to defend yourself unless you want to catch a ban. I personally ran countercheats to crash hackers if they messed with me. Now? Defending myself will net me a ban.  Now let's talk about the game.  This is by far the hardest "souls" game to be released, the threads complaining about everything after you reach the point of no return, are numerous. The ultra super special boss, even popular streamers are saying shes boring, and the only way to win is to remember her combos perfectly. No variation to that fight, if you try to get some space, rush combo, if you try to position, rush combo. It's just playing 100% defense and hoping you can land occasional hits. If she manages to hit you, she heals. So that's fun.  Outside the last 4 or 5 bosses, the game is great. Once you hit that endgame it's like the Berlin wall, won't come down for some time. The majority of players I talk to are gated after or right before Fire Giant. The game RAMPS incredibly hard during that period, where a fully kitted, max level, max stat character can still be 2 shotted. How do you think those fights go for anyone around 140? The recommended level. It doesn't, seen too many people whine about difficulty, and quit.  I personally agree, the late game ramps just a little too hard, and relies on mechanics that are just not fun. I'd rather play bloodborne, or DS3 any day. Most people who disagree with my opinion, also follow with "GIT GUD LOL BAD SCRUB" Yet, I'm not seeing as many as I did during DS3, maybe it's because that game was actually fair? Only 33% of players have beat that super hard boss that I was talking about early on, and 19% of players have even beat the game. Some people say that the last two bosses of the story, are harder than anything else. I personally think that the secret boss is the hardest boss I've ever beat legit. This is coming from someone who soloed the bloodborne DLC with no deaths from the bosses. Soloed all the souls games except this one, there must be something wrong here right?  Food for thought. Not really worth 60$ for a game that you will probably quit near endgame.

A fantastic and epic adventure that sets the standards for what a single player game should be. It has a deep lore, great fighting mechanics, amazing world building, artistic vistas, and possibilities for multiple play styles. It rewards curiosity and skill. It lives up to the high expectations of a souls game. Highly recommended.  However, I am not sure if it is my favorite souls game. Although, the open world helps temper the difficulty level of the game making it more accessible to players new to the souls games, that also introduces a lot of redundancies into what can otherwise be a shorter and more classier experience. In past souls games (specially DS1), bosses have been more than just about rolling and hitting. That has slowly gone away and in its place we have some bosses that can one-hit you even if you have a thousand hp. ER does give us mounts, crafting, and other quality of life improvements, but I'm not sure if that gain is worth the loss of the classical charm.

I'm not typically a fan of these types of games. I could never get into Dark Souls so I never tried to get into any of the other FromSoft games until I heard everybody talking about how good Elden Ring was at work. I was still skeptical so I waited until the game went on sale before trying it out.  I wish I had tried it sooner.  The addition of the open world and the ability to skip hard encounters and come back later has really improved the playability of this game. The world is phenomenally crafted and is much more enjoyable to traverse than the likes of Assassin's Creed Valhalla & Hogwarts Legacy (two games I've also played recently). The world is beautiful and there always seems to be a surprise everywhere you look. I've been wanting to replay Skyrim for awhile, but haven't because I want to enjoy a game that I have yet to play. Elden Ring scratched that Skyrim itch.  Elden Ring is still a hard FromSoft game, but it is much less forgiving than most of their releases. Checkpoints are more numerous and closer together. A lot of difficult encounters are optional. The tough encounters will make you feel very empowered when you finally overcome them.  Elden Ring is gold and absolutely deserves to be name Game of the Year. Play it!

In short, I feel like FromSoftware took all the aspects we liked from previous Soulsborne games and crafted this beautiful open-world RPG with it. It is a wonderful introduction to the genre of "souls-like."  [b]Things I Liked:[/b] - The "play at your own pace" world structure. You aren't limited to a linear progression, so if you want to get stronger or explore other areas, you are able to do so. You don't have to fight main bosses with just what you gather in the starting area. In fact, if you don't care about 100%ing the game, you can completely skip some areas you don't like (looking at you, [spoiler]Caelid[/spoiler].) - More Grace Sites (bonfires)! I know in previous Soulsborne games, part of the challenge of the game was the fact that bonfires were spread out so much. But in Elden Ring, I don't think having so many Graces significantly lowers this challenge. Considering that Elden Ring is open-world, the amount of Grace Sites feels appropriate, and I think less would actually hurt the game. - The many different endings. Each ending [spoiler]significantly alters the world of Elden Ring[/spoiler] and there is no obvious "good" or "bad" ending. So this aspect combined with the many different classes/builds you can do makes every playthrough of Elden Ring unique and fun. - The spirit summons (also in the section below). Spirit summons help you feel not so alone when you're fighting bosses and can be really helpful in splitting agro. I especially thought [spoiler]the Mimic Tear[/spoiler] was a really cool experience and idea.  [b]Things I Didn't Like:[/b] - The spirit summon reliance. Spirit summons are a really, REALLY useful tool against bosses. To the point that some bosses can be trivialized with them. You can fight bosses without them, but you almost feel like you have to use them, since it seems like some of the bosses are built with the usage of spirit summons in mind. What I'm trying to say is: I think the bosses would be more challenging and satisfying to kill if spirit summons weren't so OP. - The multi-boss fights. Specifically, [spoiler]the Godskin Duo[/spoiler]. Nasu put it well: in previous Soulsborne games, when you would encounter a multi-boss fight, one would usually take a more "passive" stance when the other is in a more "active" stance. This was a good balance. But in Elden Ring, they are usually both in a hyper-aggressive active stance which can definitely be frustrating to deal with. - You can't revisit [spoiler]Leyndell Royal Capital[/spoiler] after you [spoiler]defeat Maliketh[/spoiler]. This makes sense lore-wise, but it is frustrating if you're playing Elden Ring blind or simply didn't realize you didn't explore that area enough until it's too late. A fix perhaps would be to have a feature in the Roundtable Hold where you can toggle which version of [spoiler]Leyndell[/spoiler] you want access to after you beat the game.  Overall, I can see why Elden Ring gained so much popularity, including from those where this was their first souls-like game. Its Game of the Year title was well-deserved. I highly suggest playing it if you haven't already.

It's alright
This game is more or less like every other FromSoft game, for better and worse. There's really no reinventing of the wheel here aside from the open world. In some cases this works against and in favor of the player experience.  The open world aspect is pretty fun, there's a lot of really picturesque things to see and screenshot worthy areas that are incredible first time around, but that's kind of where the benefits end. If that's a huge deal to you, you'll love it. For everything else, it's kind of a step in the opposite direction. Quests follow the standard FromSoft 'we won't tell you shit about what you're supposed to do, who to find, who to kill, figure it out on your own.' This approach is serviceable in their other games because of their size but is terrible in a game this large. It might give players an excuse for multiple NG+, but when you spent upwards of 150 hours and there are quests you still need to look up online because you have no idea what random shit ends them or where to go, and this is every quest, it becomes a problem. It's more of a problem when, in FromSoft fashion, much of the lore is hidden behind items, subtle interactions that may or may not have branching paths (again, some of which end quests entirely). To me, this is just not enjoyable. I don't mind having to find items to learn the lore, but the content is not easily accessible and becomes an irritation. The open world also makes this game the easiest to over level on, either accidentally or on purpose. I ended up clearing Caelid after Stormveil Castle because of the lack of direction and trivialized much of the game after and I feel like I lost out on a lot of first time experiences because of it when I went back to lower level areas.  The PvP is also in a god awful state. The balancing is more or less OK after so many iterations of patches, but the lag is terrible. People walking through your spells and attacks, frames in animations being skipped, a hit registering and dealing no damage (I found this one out using Gargoyle's Blackblade), or being plus frames in a situation and the lag makes you lose out -- a colossal weapon beating out a rapier in speed for instance.   The camera and lock-on are also some of the biggest messes I've seen since Red Ninja, the platforming is still mostly unusable and should be scrapped entirely.  It's not all bad though. Despite some bosses having broken hurt boxes, they're mostly well designed and challenging. The characters themselves, once you're actually able to access their lore, have some of the most compelling stories in any FromSoft game. This is easily FromSoft at their best if we ignore Sekiro, which was a masterpiece, and makes it hard to really look at any earlier Souls games without wondering why you wouldn't just play this instead. You should probably get it if these types of games interest you, but there are some pretty big glaring issues and some subjective things you might not enjoy. I still can't get over the experience systems in these games, but I accept it when I play them.

TLDR: Everybody knows this game is good, you don't need me to tell you. If you're afraid it's too difficult for you, there are strategies to make the game easier. If you have the money and the time to spend on this game, it will be worth them both, trust me.  My experience: That said, as a souls fan, I didn't feel like this game really attended my expectations (which to be fair where problaby very high). It's weird to describe: part of me loved this game, but another part of me was also expecting something else, or for things to be different about it, I don't know.  Probably the biggest part of the insatisfaction I have with this game is the "level-scaling system" (for lack of a better term. It's actually the interaction of the XP system with the open word system): because it's such an open game, you end up missing entire areas when you're at their intended level, and when you actually find them, those areas are way too easy for you. This happened so much so that I had this doubt of having my level way too low/high throughout basically the whole game. Not only is this the first time I feel that in a souls game, it is also really annoying, because you always have that feeling in your head: "Damn, this boss was so hard, was my level way too low for him?" or, even worse: "This boss was so easy! I guess my level is way too high for this section of the game" (the latter happened to me more often, which is a shame). This happens mostly with the optional bosses, but having this constant thought in my head really detracted from my experience, I believe. Overall I think the openness of the map as opposed to previous titles was a double-edge sword: It provided incredible moments of wanderlust and exploration, but also made me not enjoy the main parts of the game as much.

Having had the opportunity to engage with FromSoftware's latest magnum opus, Elden Ring, it can be unequivocally stated that this game is a tour de force of the gaming industry, and truly the finest example of the medium to date. With an unparalleled sense of immersion and gameplay mechanics that are both innovative and refined, Elden Ring has exceeded all expectations and delivered an experience that is simply unparalleled.  The game's world-building is a triumph of imagination and artistic vision. The open-world design, with its countless vistas and captivating architecture, instills a sense of awe and wonder in the player, drawing them in and encouraging them to explore every inch of this vast landscape. The lore of Elden Ring is equally compelling, with a rich and complex history that is both tantalizing and elusive, revealing itself in pieces over time as the player delves deeper into the game.  The combat system in Elden Ring is a masterpiece of design, combining the best aspects of FromSoftware's previous titles with new mechanics that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging. The player has access to a wide range of weapons, spells, and abilities, each with its own unique properties that can be combined and modified to suit the player's playstyle. The game's bosses are equally impressive, with each one providing a unique and memorable challenge that requires the player to adapt and overcome.  Elden Ring's graphics and sound design are a feast for the senses, with stunning visuals that are brought to life by a haunting and evocative soundtrack. The attention to detail in the game's environments, characters, and enemies is truly staggering, with every aspect of the game designed to enhance the player's immersion in the world.  In conclusion, Elden Ring is a game that transcends its medium, a true masterpiece of design, artistry, and storytelling that will stand the test of time. It is a game that will be remembered for years to come as the pinnacle of what is possible in the gaming industry, and a shining example of what can be achieved through creative collaboration and a dedication to excellence.

dlc where i can marry boggart is necessary but besides that its perfection
   I'm going to lead with the fact that this is my favorite souls game by significant margin. I have played, enjoyed, and look back fondly on the entire franchise, but something about the first play-through of this game makes the rest look paltry in comparison. Elden Ring takes a franchise renown for its depressing mood, Incredible level design and fair but brutal combat and turns it on its head in one of my favorite reimaginings since Jak 2 on the PS2.   Tight corridors and claustrophobia have been replaced with a vast open world, dotted with some of the most intricate and brutal zones the franchise has ever presented in the form of Legacy Dungeons. Out in the open world itself, you'll find yourself exploring a series of wondrous and alien environments filled with the remnants of once great civilizations, as well as a variety of World Bosses, Dungeons, Puzzles, Gear, and every assortment of goody the game has to offer.   There is a degree of repetition to this game, in that some tile sets and bosses can be a little... overused at times. However, I cannot stress the shear scope of this game. I highly recommend playing without spoiling the map, as its truly a treat to watch the world unfold.   On the same note, visually speaking, this is not the most hyper realistic game you'll ever see. However, it compensates in that it is still ABSOLUTELY GORGEOUS. From Soft is known for its vistas and "wow" moments, and this game takes that to a new degree by constantly making you look around in sheer wonder. From the color scheme to the world design, From Soft manages to take all the ideas that made them famous and redefine them by a golden standard.  Difficulty remains a controversial issue, but I think this is just the right difficulty. If you steamroll ahead, following the Graces and progressing the story alone, you will run into nigh insurmountable odds that will bring on a sweat for even the saltiest souls vet. However, unlike before, you have a massive area full of side content to enrich, empower, and add variety to your combat style, and it will have you tossing bombs, slinging knives, and upgrading that new sword you found in a cave to overcome these massive spikes with a natural ease that reeks of a masterpiece.  Truly, this stands next to Bloodborne and DS3 as masterclasses in the genre, but unlike those, it marks a moment of progression for the series, breaking free from several of its bonds and paving the way for even greater things to follow. Keep an eye out for the next From "Souls" game, its going to make this one look terrible.  10/10, so good I even got 100%.

TLDR: Elden Ring, while imperfect, is the best implementation of an open-world action RPG that I've ever played. It feels like the culmination of every iteration of FromSoft's 'Souls' games into one truly amazing experience filled with intrigue, struggle, and eventual triumph.  GENRE: Fantasy, third-person, open world, action RPG, 'Souls' game  GAMEPLAY: Elden Ring is basically Dark Souls 4, or Dark Souls but now you can sneak, jump, and ride a steed around the open world areas. You start by creating a character and choosing a class to determine your starting gear and stats (e.g. Astrologer to be a spellcasting sorcerer, or Samurai to be a katana-weilding DEX melee build). You progress through the game by traveling around the map and finding items/gear to upgrade your equipment setup and defeating enemies to gain 'runes" that you can spend to level up or buy items from shops. 'Sites of grace' are the bonfire equivalents in Elden Ring, and most of the time they visually display a path of light that indicate the direction you need to head in to progress the main story through locations of major bosses. There are plenty of these grace sites littered everywhere in the open world and within dungeons so it is easy to fast travel to where you want to go immediately.  Sites of grace' are the bonfire equivalents in Elden Ring, and most of the time they visually display a path of light that indicate the direction you need to head in to progress the main story through locations of major bosses. There are plenty of these grace sites littered everywhere in the open world and within dungeons so it is easy to fast travel to where you want to go immediately.  Elden Ring is an open world game and there are various minidungeons/secrets hidden away in every corner of the map. It is to your advantage to seek out these locations to find rare materials and unique weaponry that may or may not change your play style altogether. The open world feels like there is always something waiting for you to discover, such as powerful enemies that drop unique weapon arts (ashes of war) or an NPC standing around waiting to offer you a quest. With the introduction of a day/night cycle, there are even some bosses that only spawn at nighttime in specific locations waiting to ambush you, but offer unique drops as well.  GRAPHICS/PERFORMANCE: Elden Ring, at launch, was pretty shaky in terms of PC performance. I personally played this game to completion with below minimum specs. averaging 40-50 FPS at High settings. I encountered no game-breaking bugs/detrimental FPS hiccups in any playthrough, though the only issue I encountered was that enemies would sometimes become invisible on my screen whenever a large group of enemies were in an area, but they were still lock-on-able and would render again when I got closer/killed some of the group (this is probably just because my CPU is ancient). In terms of graphics, Elden Ring doesn't break new ground when it comes to overall presentation, but it is a very colorful game compared to previous Souls games. You can really tell when you enter a new region when all the colors transition from one palette to another and the sky/landscape dramatically changes as well. Dark areas are also pretty spooky as you can only see far enough from the light of your torch or lantern and enemies hide in the shadows very well.  STORY: The long story short is: the Elden Ring was shattered into fragments and various demigods took the pieces to gain the fragmented powers within them. You are a 'Tarnished' which is basically a pseudo-undead human who is guided by grace to seek out the pieces of the Elden Ring, put them back together, and become Elden Lord in order to bring the world back to "order". (All of the details in between for NPC's and items is basically found in NPC dialogue and item descriptions for you to piece together, or until a genius puts all of the information together in a YouTube lore video)  STRENGTHS: Combat feels the best it has ever been for 'Souls' games. Sneak attacks, jump attacks, ashes of war, NPC summons, mounted combat, guard counters, power-stancing, and everything else feels very, very good.  Touching more on ashes of war, they basically allow you to add (and remove later) a unique skill to most non-unique weapons in the game. They also allow you to change the scaling of a weapon to a different one of your choice (if you also have the right whetstone) so you can make a weapon scale with INT or FTH even if it originally didn't.  Boss encounters are exciting and challenging. If you feel underprepared, you can always to back to the open world and look for missed locations and items to better prepare yourself. (Also, feel free to use your ash summons whenever possible; it is a game mechanic after all)  You can build a character however you desire, whether it be dual-weilding greatswords, holy knight, melee-spell-casting wizard, or pure archery.  There are lots and lots of weapons to try, leading to more replayability as you try a new one in a future playthrough  The crafting system is interesting as you can create consumables and throwable items when out of combat. You can even create bow/crossbow ammo which is very neat.  Just when you think you're near the end, the map expands further and there is even more to discover.  Compared to the other Dark Souls stories, Elden Ring's story feels the most digestible at face value without feeling completely puzzled from the outset.  WEAKNESSES: PC performance isn't stellar if you are bothered by occasional FPS spikes or the rare game crash on loading screens.  Not game-relevant, but the game doesn't fully "exit" when you quit out until a while later.  Early game bosses reappear as 'mini-bosses' or just wandering around later game areas leading to some feelings of reused content.  There is a massive spike in game difficulty from the mid-game to the late-game. It feels weirdly balanced when enemies all of a sudden go from doing 1/5 of your HP in damage to 1/2 of your HP in damage.  UI could use a feature to compare stats of shop items with currently equipped items  Online connectivity can be hit-or-miss. Sometimes when you are summoned to another world, you get a "connection error" and the game boots you back to single player.  Be wary of hackers when playing co-op/PVP. Previous exploits have occurred where upon death, you would return to single player but be instantly dying forever because the hacker put you in an endless death loop. That exploit was patched, but we all know how hackers don't just give up.  (Not a negative for me, but maybe if you like PvP): You can only invade other players if they are participating in co-op. Basically, unless a host uses a specific item, invasions usually lead to 1v2 or 1v3 scenarios (note: AFAIK fight clubs are only affected in that # of summonable participants is limited). I don't invade, but I've seen many people whining about this change when it makes sense why it is this way.  So many important names sound very similar to each other that it could be difficult to remember who is who (e.g. Godwyn vs Godfrey vs Godrick).  'Great Runes' are pretty underwhelming in terms of power.  Although I enjoy the game design of not having a dedicated questlog ingame, it is still to your benefit to just read an NPC's quest guide off the wiki to keep yourself on track.  NUMERIC SCORE (if you care): 9.9/10; easy recommend  Elden Ring has set my bar for 'open-world RPG' standards. The added gameplay features like jumping, horse-riding, sneaking, etc. make the game's action much more interesting and fun than previous FromSoft games. The game kicks my ass at every step of the way, but the struggle and eventual triumph is worth all of it. Though it is not without fault, I love this game and can't wait for future DLC.

Builds upon the Dark Souls formula in so many ways and delivers some great quality of life improvements as well as extra combat and traversal options. The 'open field' functions similarly enough to the previous games' level structure, the addition of the map is quite useful (and gorgeous). Areas are beautiful and varied, though some may say the variety detracts from an overall theme/aesthetic - DS3 nailed this thematic consistency in my opinion, which elden ring lacks a little. I had a great time with this game - until Mountaintop of the Giants, where the game became more of a slog (though still enjoyable) with later areas lacking landmarks. This game is long as hell and packed with content so you're definitely getting your money's worth.  MALENIA IS SO UNNECESSARILY HARD THERE IS NO SHAME IN SKIPPING/CHEESING HER FUCK THAT BOSS
