most overrated game in existence
Allora, questa recensione farà piangere i cringioni fanboy ma infondo ci sono abituato.  Da dove iniziare?  Partiamo dal presupposto che non siamo di fronte ad un titolo divertente. Un souls-like casa From divertente? Comprensibile come domanda, ma lasciatemi spiegare:  Avendo completato chissà quante volte ormai tutta la trilogia souls, mai mi sono [/i]stancato[/i] di giocarci mid run. Certo, ci sono stati momenti di rage dovuti più che altro ad uno sviluppo fatto con il culo ma infondo pochi giochi posso vantare di essere veramente perfetti.  Dunque il problema si pone qui, l'averlo abbandonato svariate volte perché non mi stava invogliando a farlo è un bel problema, dovuta alla mancanza di un vero obbiettivo; "gne gne aiuta la frignona melinda a bruciare l'anello così salvi il mondo" (Mi ricorda l'avventura di un gruppo di gnappette ma ok).  No, darmi una mappa grossa come il Texas, piena di briciole di patatine con un'obbiettivo così generico e vago è una combo disastrosa.  Per fortuna si sono accorti che un solo finale misero come quello sarebbe stato un suicidio, così si sono messi d'accordo per farne altri e almeno Ranni risolleva un minimo la trama; sarà perché puoi interagirci, sarà perché non è criptica ma ti da delle istruzioni precise, sarà che interagirai con altri personaggi a lei legati fanno si che sia l'unico finale degno di nota.  Ora. Non che nei souls ci fosse chissà quale interazione con gli npc o una trama sfonda cervelli, ma almeno li non dovevi andare a tentoni raccogliendo briciole per capire che [/strike]minchia[/strike] fare e sopratutto dove andare. "Uhe Uhee ci sono i falò che nella mappa ti indicano dove andare Uhee", certo, una linea gialla che indica approssivamente 300 Km cubici di mappa inesplorata con all'interno 20 falò e solo uno che indica quello successivo.  Difatti il problema più grande è appunto l'eccessiva ampiezza di una mappa priva di unicità, che per renderla dinamica, hanno spammato le stesse cose da fare, semplicemente aumentando la vita dei nemici presenti. Mettermi 236 (stando alla wiki) boss non rende il gioco più bello, sopratutto se metà di questi si riciclano a vicenda, ma solamente una completition list noiosa e sopratutto toglie quel senso di pericolosità e fierezza che avevano i boss. Ormai tutto è un boss, al punto che alla fine molti di essi li ritrovi come nemici da due soldi in qualche zona più avanti.  Di conseguenza, trama banale e vaga, mappa eccessivamente grossa e priva di contenuto unico, stragrande maggioranza di boss senza una caratterizzazione e solo due elementi che si salvano: Scenari effettivamente belli, certe angolazioni del fiume Siofra sono incredibili e un gameplay fluido, ma grazie al [/strike]cazzo[/strike] è un copia e incolla di DS3 quindi funziona per forza.  Quindi in definiva, dare una sufficienza a questo titolo è impossibile, game of the year rubato aggiungerei, per un titolo che è solamente un souls open world vuoto e senz'anima, che cerca di ricalcare i passi dei suoi predecessori, aggiungendo novità ma in malo modo.  Mi dispiace per chi, toccando il suo primo souls-like, giochi a Elden Ring perché finito questo, si ritroverà senza una vera e propria conoscenza di questo genere.

Pain
if youve never played a FROM game before you might like this one! if you are a long time fan of dark souls expecting a new and exciting experience however... this game will not be satisfying. it has very few differences even in plot and tone with any of FROMs other games. i know people wanna believe the repeating themes serve some kind of purpose. it seems more like cope to me. even if it does mean something, its not any less played the fuck out! at this point its painfully formulaic. and i dont mean in the souls like genre. its for the most part the same team making the same game over and over. do the games keep taking place in empty post disaster worlds because its a stylistic choice or is it because its easy to design? after 7 different titles im thinking its the ladder.   its gameplay is dark souls. no differences whatsoever. bloodborne was unique. sekiro was unique. this has almost no improvements compared to dark souls. instead of improving anything they decided to bloat the game with meaningless and lazily designed features. crafting is practically unused because the drop rates for ANYTHING is egregious!!! The Great runes are largely meaningless and their effects are abysmal for the effort of finding and climbing the right tower. 10% more max hp is as good as it gets. it feels like they quickly jammed this stuff in just to advertise it as a feature instead of actually making it a feature.   the open world is the emptiest and loneliest world i have ever been in. NOTHING HAPPENS! EVER! it rains and fucks over your fire damage occasionally. THATS IT!! the only things of any note are all right in the beginning. the giant dropping from the arch overhead. agheal swooping down. the carian rain of arrows. all the stuff youve already seen in trailers. it is somehow an open world game where every single run is the exact same. nothing different happens.   the npcs are cardboard. they never move. and if they do its between resting at graces. they will say everything in cringy and cryptic ways and basically tell you to go somewhere without any directions. in later patches there is a marker automatically placed where you need to go. was it really so hard for blaidd to say WHERE the comet hit? i wouldve settled for simply "where we first met." but nah. theres now an unmarked hole somewhere. go find it. i wouldnt complain about getting lost if the world were at all interesting. this game feels like im a dumb little kid again playing a roblox fan game on an empty server. the enemies are pathetic and easy. its not even worth killing for how little runes anything drops besides bosses. its so boring.  which reminds me. this game of the year game has the Worst multiplayer in existence. how hard was it to do what the seamless co op mod does? if you want to progress the game with a friend you have to beat each area per player. while getting invaded by another player. why is there no option to AT LEAST prevent invasions? i dont care about this games roblox tier pvp leave me alone! if i could at least complete one area with another player without getting harassed by a pack of ego maniacal neckbeards playing dress up. this review whould be a touch more positive. but dear christ win or lose, you and your friends are getting hatemail. oh you thought league of legends was toxic and un fun? just wait till you make the mistake of winning against an invader. nothing is more persistant than a PvPer with a hurt ego. youll never see or hear the last of them till they invade again and win or have threatened and called you every insult and slur in existance. holy shit its bad.   balance is downright nonsense. i had so much fun actually playing sorcerer for once. and then my whole world crumbled when i found the glintstone kris... the sorcery Comet is the single strongest projectile in the game fully charged it costs 24 fp to cast. glint stone kris is a dagger that just fires a STRONGER FASTER VERSION of Comet for 10 fucking fp!?!? that pretty much destroys any reason to use spells outside of specific uses. this isnt the only case of weapons arts blowing spells out of the game. lightning incantations are pretty good! but out damaged by weapon art versions of spells. its INSANITY how bad this design choice is. the only reason to use them is because it looks cool. thats IT!  i try so hard finding a good fun way to be proud of a run. thats a problem with this games erratic difficulty. i wont argue that the game is to hard or easy because its neither. IT IS BROKEN! bosses are either impossible or trivial depending on your playstyle for instance. if your plan is to do the classic swing swing damage strat. you are sure to beleive that this game is hard. thats because boss IA is reading your inputs and even your queued inputs including rolling and flasks. even worse, bosses are able to cancel attacks or animations with eachother. this combination of mechanics basically creates bosses who truly NEVER STOP ATTACKING. if you keep rolling the boss will keep trying to quickly punish it by starting a new attack string. if you dodge that he will just do it againagain until it lands a hit thus actually letting it continue its intended attack string. every death in this game can be summed up with "oh i thought they were done." some bosses are able to cancel their own hitstun! yeah thats insanely broken! theres another weird interaction where sometimes if you poise break a boss while its attacking it will suddenly be doing the attack when they recover. for instance. falling star beasts charge can be interupted by hitting it in the head. letting you get some hits in. but when it gets up it will suddenly resume the charge full speed with no warnings. commander niall has a massive Aoe attack that he has to charge up first. if you break his stance during the charge up and reposte him. after he gets back up he will suddenly be doing his massive Aoe with you stood right next to him. there is no way this is intended game design! theres broken shit like this but also the player can just use any straight sword and spam square off the entire game. AND THAT WORKS! margit will have his poise broken after 2 uses. this game is such a fuckin mess!!! AND IT GOT GAME OF THE YEAR wtf!? this only scratches the surface of shit thats wrong.  this game is carried so hard by everyone's hype.  its really just a $60 roblox experience with somehow worse PvP.   for the love of god start criticizing games again people! just because miyazaki and martin made it doesnt mean its automatically good. no game should be exempt from actual criticism in the way this game has been for the last year. like seriously guys. fanboys praise this game for shit done in the 90s. wowies it took over 10 years to program horses. is this just a big joke im not a part of or something?

this game is so much fun!
I played DS1 years ago on PS3. Tried DS2, DS3, and BB, and they never really clicked for me, so at first I ignored Elden Ring, despite hearing a lot of good things about it from friends. Eventually I watched some game play and was intrigued enough that I figured I'd give it a go, and an amazing friend of mine bought it for me for my birthday. I. AM. HOOKED. This game is so fun and rewarding to play. You can even play together with friends with the seamless CO-OP mod, although I would recommend playing it by yourself first. The feeling you get when you get your ass handed to you, and you come back later and smack that foe upside their head, is so gratifying. The atmosphere and aesthetics are superb, and the combat is fluid. I haven't beaten it yet, but it's definitely feeling like my GotY, despite getting it only a little over a week ago.

Elden Ring is one of From Software's most polished pieces of work. From music, to atmosphere, to compelling characters, and on top of that all; gameplay that is both challenging and immensely rewarding. Throughout the years I have played many of this style of game, and Elden Ring has been one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had.  If you are someone who likes to throw yourself at something and watch failure after failure until you succeed, this game is for you. That feeling after finally defeating a boss you have been struggling with for hours and hours is something that very few games can replicate.  After 140 Hrs, and still more to come, I fully believe that if you are interested in this game, you should buy it and play.

My gripes with this game run deep.  Starting with the console style gaming.  I play PC for a reason... keyboard and mouse primarily.  Being forced to play where a controller design is intended is very annoying to me.  The game world is vast, and beautiful, and fun to explore.  Enemies look interesting.  The atmosphere is great.  Those are the only pluses I would attribute to Elden Ring.  Combat ruins the game however, in my opinion.  The camera control is lousy and locked targets will switch mid-combat to targets you are not even engaged with.  It is always fun fighting an enemy directly in front of you and having the camera rotate 180 degrees because it randomly locks some enemy behind you.  At that point, you are still facing and fighting the front enemy but with the camera spinning, missing all your attacks, and not even knowing which way is up or down after the vertigo the game puts you through.  Every fight is painful and it is not because of how the enemy fights most of the time, but rather, it is because of how lousy the controls are with keyboard and mouse.  I also believe in fair combat for games, with a decent AI.  Elden Ring is anything but this.  Once you start going into boss fights, all they do is stay on you with either their 10x speed movement, or jump onto you from the other side of the arena.  Your character is very sluggish in comparison.  Not only is enemy boss movement at super speed, but they do not have status bars themselves, other than HP, so they spam boss abilities.  To me, I find it to be a cheaty and lousy AI.  It's not really about tactics but more about learning the rotations and timings.  The AI is just not good.  A lot of people say "git gud" but I think that should be directed at these companies for not developing any kind of decent AI in these games and just going with the same old worn-out model every single time.  This game feels like a step backwards.  Instead of meaningful combat, this game is all about timing that dodge roll.  I find it sad that games have not progressed beyond parkour and the dodge roll. >.>

This may be my favorite open world game ever. The combat is challenging but really fun, the world is immense, with loads of things to do, and the visuals are stunning. One thing I didn't like about it was that you could very easily miss the chance to complete a quest or get some cool loot, and you would often receive instructions from an NPC and have no idea what to do next, but the lack of a clear guide is part of the game. All in all, super fun. 10/10

The landscapes of the different regions offer beautiful scenery and probably more so with high end pc components. Even if you purchase this game at full price, you won't be disappointed, but even I waited for a discount. this game
You know when you read a fantastic book series that evokes your imagination? You know when those books are sometimes super detailed to really drive in the importance of normally small or mundane things? Tolkien kind of does that. Have you ever seen a movie that draws you in with its presentation, the way certain images have a symbolic power and presence the way a great painting does?  Combine these two, and make it into a game where you can walk around such a detailed setting constructed by layers of context and themes and symbols, and you have Elden Ring. It's a game about many things: overcoming hardship, rejection of a corrupt status quo, beautiful sights and exploration, wicked monsters and fantastic characters, and it's also about family and tragedy. It's about many more things, too. What makes Elden Ring great is that, like many FromSoft games, you don't have to pay close attention to the story to keep the game interesting. To play is fine on its own. But the storytelling--which really means "presentation of the setting" in this context--of Elden Ring is exceptional, it is simply art. There is much to gawk at, to consider, to discover, to converse over, to love and to hate. Elden Ring can be played fast and intensely, or slowly and thoroughly. Elden Ring can be tackled as a gamer, or as a historian. Or both, if you are so bold, or at least as invested as I am. I have 700 hours in this game as of right now. It is a phenomenal mark in the history of games--proof that a video game can be as deep, powerful, evocative as the works of Tolkien.    I think that to consider things like "bullshit attacks" or "poor pvp balancing" or "recycled use of content" as detractors of the game to the point where it affects judgment of the piece as a whole, would be like seeing a few typos or different spellings of the same character's name in a great book and then saying the whole book is lesser for having those 'mistakes'. It would be ignoring the purpose or importance of what the piece accomplishes--the book could have the literal best narrative possible but because it has spelling mistakes, you put it aside. That's stupid; it has nothing to do with what the piece is about. Such is the case with Elden Ring. Gameplay, here, is not the number one priority for being the best part of the piece. That is why I think Elden Ring is a 10/10, literal masterpiece.

Alright guess I haven't written a review for this game so I will now. Absolutely no complaints for the singleplayer experience, except the quests are hard to track and npcs hard to find. The co-op is alright, but I wish it was more fluid, like the seamless co-op mod. If you're looking for just the singleplayer experience this game is a must have. Now we get into the pvp. The servers are absolutely terrible. People can go from relatively decent connection to levitating towards you in a idle position, sometimes spells hit you before the cast animation even plays. The arena matchmaking is terrible, long and inconsistent wait times, and it just randomly gets cancelled by the game. Weapons are also very unbalanced. Overall 9/10 for the singleplayer experience and 6/10 for the pvp experience.

Just finished my first playthrough of the game, fully recommend this game to anyone wanting to try out a FromSoftware game. This was the first of which that I had ever played, and it has left a strong first impression. I didn't expect to be able to run the game on high graphics and get smooth FPS, but I'll be damned. The scenery is a sight to behold and the NPCs alongside it just make the game so dynamic. Despite some of the bosses being hard and, sometimes, tedious to fight, they're still enjoyable to go against and the feeling of achievement after beating them is very fulfilling. This game has a very good replay value to the point where I'm content with starting a new build to try out other challenges or endings, or even to see if I had missed out on major quests or bosses since there is a LOT to this game. Decided to take the plunge despite bouncing off Dark Souls and the like and hearing how hard Elden Ring was. Well, don't let that put you off. It wasn't a cakewalk, but just doing everything in the game without grinding levelled me sufficiently that nothing caused me too much trouble. 140 hours I think I saw everything (no appetite for New Game+), I'm sure I never actually "got good", but I did at least learn a little patience instead of button mashing constantly.  The game was very good, but I won't go so far as to say it's personal GOTY material, nor one of the best open world games I've played. It was sufficiently different to keep me interested. There is lore there, if you're willing to hunt for it. Much like the game's systems, there is a distinct lack of explanation or direction. Life's too short: I used a wiki. :P

Absolutely fantastic game, some of the best exploration, narrative and thematic cohesion, and build variety i've ever seen. However: if you're looking forward to the bosses, don't buy this game. the vast majority of bosses in this game are repeats, including even major story encounters, and towards the endgame these encounters become such a slog that at time of this review, i have no intent to finish the game. Go check out Sekiro instead: its combat is designed to actually allow you to FIGHT the bosses instead of standing there and watching them kill you with no real enjoyable way to fight back.

[list] [*][h3]Positives[/h3] Discussing the positives, first of all, the gameplay on this game is improved on many aspects, in terms of combat (like, jumping while attacking), the addition of fast-traveling from the map, and the possibility of riding a horse. Secondly, the world building, it's impressive, there are dungeons, unique buildings,  many unique tematic areas,  and the transition between them. Thirdly, the boss fights are very exciting and amazing at the same time as challenging. Additionally, the soundtrack is awesome, an epic one, [*][h3]Negatives[/h3] On the side of negatives, I will point out the bad optimization, which includes many FPS drops, low FPS, and unusually random crashes, provoking a less enjoyable experience. Lastly, some bosses where really repetitive, mostly the dungeon bosses. [/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2] Elden Ring it's an awesome game, that improves mechanically on many aspects of the previous games with incredible world building, but it has a bad optimization with some repetitive enemies. Despite all that, the game is an 8.75/10.

For the sake of atmosphere and beauty, I started playing Elden Ring. Worthy adventure for creative people and not only. Very beautiful visual style, The game gave me a lot of inspiration. The castle of Azure Liurnia is my reverence. A very magical place that brought me aesthetic pleasure. There were also many other locations bewitching with their beauty. Art is something individual, but I think that in this game everyone will find something for themselves that they will like.

There are also various times where the game logic surrounding NPCs, death, and mechanical rules are inconsistent. After multiple playthrus and 200hrs this has left a poor taste in my mouth.

good
First time to not recommend a From Software Game and even though I had my fair share of fun in it I cannot simply give it a thumbs up. Elden Ring has proved itself to be a huge disappointment and in many areas even a shitshow, especially from the PVP side of things.  here is a list of things that don't sit well with me:  - too much unbalanced and broken stuff geared towards the casual players that can use that to insta-kill without any skill needed for execution. All thanks to the needy-greedy content creators on youtube the game is at all times infested by users of the same OP shit. -Implementing jumping along with jumping attacks was a huge mistake for pvp. They are way too safe with added i-frames, deal too much damage and don’t cost much stamina. Especially terrible on dual curved sword users with bleed that hit 4 times in one jump. - Fighting system resolves around jump attacks, weapon art spam and whatever else broken mechanics the game currently has to offer to make a casual feel like a god without any skill requirement whatsoever. A nightmare when facing ganks. - Huge lack of variety in movesets between weapons.  - Lots of movesets part are redundant. It was so nice to see additional moves and maneuvers, but you quickly notice after a while that a lot of them are pointless. I also really missed the heavy chain continuity pattern after a roll from DS3 in which you would actually do the second attack right away and not the first that you would do from neutral. - Invasions are incredibly host favored with them having all their flasks and on top of that at least one or two friends with them. Single hosts can only be invaded if they specifically >invite< invaders... -_- - Invading near/far is good, but getting back your runes is a drag, especially since the marker on the map is easily overseeable.  - Implementing sneaking was nice, but being able to spam it and hence teabag other people only promotes toxicity (some people are even so lazy that they use it for bowing smh). - Shallow implementation. You can just run past everything. Nothing ever really stands in your way except very few gate keeper bosses. There is no reason to actually fight the creatures around you - none whatsoever. The world is empty and shallow. Exploring solitary sites seldomly bears anything as reward.  - Late game areas are poorly designed and don't provide anything really worthwhile for exploring. - ng+ and beyond is pointless unless you need a specific item that you missed in a quest or that you want to have a second time. - bosses are ridiculously easy when fighting in a group. Since you can also summon spirits you can make it also incredibly easy offline. - Boss design is nowhere near DS3 level  (which were challenging, fun and had incredible soundtrack). Some bosses are lackluster and bring in unfair mechanics to raise the difficulty artificially. The final bosses are all terrible in that regard. Beatable sure, but no fun fight really. Other bosses are usually just copy pasta variants of what you have fought before. There are actually only quite a few unique bosses. The OSTs of the bosses is not really noteworthy. Radagon’s fight theme is the only memorable and great piece (as it is basically the main theme).  - Terrible camera that will get you killed. For instance when close to walls or when facing giant/gigantic foes (looking at you fire giant!)  - Most players get items duped from the getgo which destroys any early game natural balances the game originally had. Nothing has been done on that front – ever. - High level players with late game equipment are often summoned and act like guard dog on steroids. Downleveling does not work well in this game at all. Damage-wise they melt anything in their way. GG From Soft... - when you die to a night opponent you have to set the day time to night everytime AND sit at the site of grace again to them spawn again. So much wasted time. - Overall unfortunately the replayability of this game is scarce. Too much copy pasta content (lots of sekiro stuff including OSTs too), too many lackluster obstacles, too few actual rewards that give incentive to proceed to ng+   This is the first From Software Game I am not sure whether or not I actually would want to buy the DLC if released.

good game
 I was never into souls games but I have to say the scale of the world it self kept me coming back. I've put 255 hours and a lot of those were just exploring. Even during the last couple of days playing I was still discovering new areas and mini bosses. To me, the game is a symbolic representation of depression. Your ability to overcome seemingly impossible odds the more and more you play carries you through out the vast world you were dropped into. Despite the grandeur of the world you journey through, the lack of people and the sense of isolation also become a sub-textual foe. This game has taught me that no matter your skill, you previous experience or, your enjoyment over current circumstances: your mental fortitude is a key instrument to persevere throughout life. In conclusion, I was never good at these types of games, to be fair i am still not, but i feel as though through each impossible task i grew a little more.

Game of the year for good reason.
been a long time since RPG was done right. its a must buy for rpg fans even if you dont enjoy souls like games. i hope other game devs would take note.
Don't let the difficulty hype discourage you. This is just a common RPG game minus the quest markers and journals, quick saves, and tutorials. Like any other RPG, you'll die if you play it like an action FPS. Pay attention to your surroundings and you'll do fine. There is tons of info online to get you going if you want to start the game off easy or if you need more info about anything in the game. I didn't feel like any of the game mechanics were poorly implemented or frustrating, it actually plays very well, at least with a gamepad. I fought all of the optional story or shard bearer bosses and only one of them was a major pain. I didn't 100% the game, but completed various dungeons, cleared the underground areas, and explored much of the overworld area; completed all that in 120 hours.  Never had the game crash or consistently stutter, its main issue is that it is single-threaded. It will try to use all of one CPU core, so it seems like it might briefly lock if something else wants to use that CPU core, but that might have happened 3-4 times for me. I played with an i7-9700K + RTX3090 and the game ran smooth 99.999% of the time. The game may briefly stutter after updating video drivers, I assume it's compiling shaders, but that seems to go away within a minute.  From is basically the Japanese version of Bethesda, they've been building on the same engine for an eternity, stamping out cookie-cutter games running on newer iterations of that engine, so don't expect an audio/visual masterpiece. The art design looks good, but isn't cutting edge, and the audio is alright, but don't expect a fabulous hi-fi experience. The game world is interesting and gameplay is fun.

Fun at peak
I have to first mention that i like to call myself a "souls-veteran". I have played every souls game except Demon s souls and completed them several times! (DS, DS2, DS3, Sekiro, Bloodborne, Elden Ring). I know what im getting myself into when playing these types of gamer or "souls-likes" as you would call them.   Now onto the game itself, i have to say that since this is a souls game it is NOT for everyone, and you WILL die over and over and over until you finally beat that piece of s*** that killed you all those times (looking at you Malenia). That is the formula of these games, you die several times until you memorize the enemy s attacks and get a better chance at beating them.   But i must also say that even though this is a souls game, in my personal opinion it is a good game for new players to the series, as you are not forced to fight everything you stumble upon. You can choose to fight that particular enemy over and over for several hours or you can decide to explore somewhere else, and come back later as this is the first time a souls game has gone full Open-World.   In terms of gameplay there is a lot of different options for players, you can for example use a staff and deal magic damage from long range or choose to summon a FREAKING DRAGON HEAD to spew fire or frost or poison atyour enemies! You can choose to be a big burly warrior with a big a** sword, or you can choose to be more agile and dual wield katanas.  Without spoiling anything too much for new players i have to say that the world is absolutely AMAZING, and the colors can range from pretty and green to red and downright terrifying. (people who has played the game know what i mean by RED and TERRIFYING).   The only complains i have is that the endgame is BULLS*** as enemies deal WAY too much damage, and can also take quite a few hits even with the best weapons and equipment in your arsenal. And the game can stutter in some areas quite often.  In summary, i think Elden Ring is a fantastic game from the genius mind of Hidetaka Miyusaki, and i reccomend people try this game!  I give this game a score of 9/10

Even if you play on controller, you will still be locked at 60 fps. The graphics may look good on console, but if you closely at anything the immersion factor will go out the window. Why is there platforming in a game where my character dodge rolls every time I sprint? Why is there platforming in a game with the worst movement mechanics in all of history???? Oh no I walked to close to a wall and my camera had a seizure and made me jump off the edge for the 1000th time. This definitely feels like skyrim in the aspect of the modding community made the game rather than the actual named developers (With all the cheesing of the bosses and other glitches). If you are on mouse and keyboard and find a way to make it not change targets with moving the mouse, please for the love of God let me know. The biggest challenge in this game isn't the enemies you face, it is battling the clunky mechanics the game forces on you. That enemy went behind a tree so we gonna lock you off of him and make u face some random direction. Oh you wanna lock back onto him? Boom, another random direction of the camera and not the direction of the enemy by any means. I could go on and on, but there are just some examples.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling.  As a result, it is very different from other open-world games. Where in previous titles you followed a general path to success, Elden RIng allows you multiple avenues and tools to navigate. This game drew from the successful gameplay of Dark Souls III while implementing the scenic styles of all Soulsborne titles.  This allowed it to be incredibly diverse in design, where enemy and landscape appearances drew heavily from Elden Ring's predecessors. All in all an absolute must play game.

I mean, its Elden Ring.   This game checks all the boxes: Intricate character customization Great weapon and armor aesthetics Beautiful World Fantastic story line NPCs have character depth Actually challenging Rewards exploration  In my opinion this games world is so full of places to explore that actually feel rewarding. A lot of games I play these days while still being good games have left me feeling as though the worlds themselves are empty regardless of how open they may be. In Elden Ring I feel there is constantly something new to find or something that I passed up on a previous play through. That alone is enough to keep me playing the game for hours, I definitely feel like I have gotten my money's worth. I have logged 900 hours on playstation as well as these 153 on PC. after the work they put into it on PC it runs much better and I encounter very little issues.   If I really had to pick something to list as a con (and this is some deep nit picking) I suppose it would be the grass rendering. On PC it can feel as though it pops up aggressively and suddenly, and this doesn't seem to change regardless of any tinkering with the settings. That being said, it's by no means a game breaker. Elden Ring for me is a 10/10.

An incredible experience your first playthrough, probably the best if not one of the best first playthroughs I've ever had of a game. Make sure to savor and enjoy it because if you're like me, when you go back to experience it again it'll be all too familiar. This is the game I would erase from my memory to enjoy it for the first time again.   Like other souls-likes it'll be frustrating sometimes. Enemies hiding in corners and ceilings waiting to ambush you and take cheap shots, bosses that'll overwhelm and crush you until you die enough times to figure them out. But this game has an unparalleled feeling of exploration and discovery that I haven't experienced in other games that keep me willingly risking those ambushes.   If you want to play Co-op with a bud undisturbed and experience the whole game together, I'd recommend the [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/eldenring/mods/510?tab=description] Seamless Co-op [/url] mod which you can find on Nexus Mods. It'll prevent invasions from other players during Co-op and allow you to play through all areas of the game that may otherwise prevent Co-op in the Vanilla game. Never was a fan of invasions so if you aren't either it is a good solution.

fun adventre game with chalenging bosses
Pros : level design and art direction  Cons : everything else : unbalanced difficulty that goes all over the place, ridiculous final boss, bosses being generally easier than fights against mobs...all the problems inherent to fromsoft games are back with a vengeance (ennemies that never fall off edges, that have infinite stamina and can combo you to death, that hit you through walls, that track you perfectly, etc etc etc).  A decent game that suffers from a lot of balance problems at best, and that feels cheap, lazy, unfair and hard for the sake of being hard at worst. The lock on system and camera are PREHISTORIC, just don't work properly, and are one of the reasons people think this game is "hard". It isn't, it's made artificially hard by dated mechanics that are dumbed down on purpose (eg input buffering, enemies reading your inputs, etc). With more modern mechanics we see in every game nowadays, elden ring would be trivially easy. Outdated game systems from 20 years ago are what makes the game hard.  All in all, it isn't as good as DS1, suffers from the same flaws, and just uses the best ideas fom it without ever managing to equal them. Eg ; I felt suterranean shunning ground was just a cheap and dilluted version of blighttown...most of the good ideas from ER are recycled from previous games.  A pretty good game, absolutely RUINED by a ridiculously unfair and cheap final boss and equally unfair and cheap mechanics that have plagued FS games since DS1.  5.5/10  EDIT : New game + is incredibly boring and pointless, appart from the sublime level design (all over again) and crushing everything with absurdly overpowered stuff. It's the easy mode. I don't get it.  Chances are you already got the best stuff from your first playthrough.  PLUS playing new game + makes all the "busted" mechanics feel even more cheap and obvious and will kinda "taint" your feelings on the whole game.   LET US SEE what the upcoming DLC brings to the table.

Elden Ring is a fantastic game for the right personality. If you are easily absorbed into your activities, then the first 50 hours of this game will feel like a dream. The next 50 hours will feel like your career is now being a Tarnished. After the following 50 hours, you will realize just how early you are in the game with 150 hours played. At this point, you have discarded the ideals of family, friends, obligations, and are pursuing all activities to make you into the true Elden Lord. Alas, the game has now become life, and you are a shell of your former self.   Its for these reasons that I cant enjoy this game, and that i can't stop enjoying playing this game no matter what occurs in life. Thus, I am hanging up the controler for good, and will get my dose of dopamine in other productive means.

sexy game
Overall a great game, some lovey locations and stunning GFX in general for an open world game.  The combat feels clean simple to learn, difficult to master lots of flash backs to Zelda and Scrolls and other large open world exploration.   Class options have some interesting customisation options and combos that make messing around with builds compelling.  The story line was average and they could of used some more interesting names than everything starting with M or G, I cant remember names at the best of times so spent most of the game confused or lost who was who and why I should care.  The locations, puzzle dungeons and sometimes crazy ideas make for a very compelling game and the want to play again with a new build. The mount felt fun to use and the checking every hole and drop felt fun. However...  Negative: The bosses for the large part (not all but most) are just hot garbage, and are the one and only reason I wont consider a replay. Its been mentioned by better people before me, but the ability spam and almost zero time spent balancing them is clear, they feel like a sad after thought rather than a key part of the game and the ones that feel good are just average when compared to other games. Not to mention the awful camera issues on a large number of them. Its just a real shame that its so bad its putting a lot of people, like me, off playing NewGame+.
These are some of the words i gathered to describe this masterpiece: Beautiful, Challenging, Surprising, Frustrating, Rewarding!  It is a Must-play for this genre lovers.

Sheldon Ring  Bazinga
Elden Ring is a game that requires a lot of time investment. It's a celebration of FromSoftware's previous works, but it is certainly not their best one. The couple of bosses in the late game have long combo strings or absurd movement that often leaves the player with little time to counter attack, turning the endgame into a slog for a lot of players. There are tools to mitigate this, such as the multiplayer and spirit ashes, but also cheapens the victory for some players. The build variety is the greatest strength of the game, but the open world nature and inconsistent quality of the bosses discourages many to replay this title.

This is one of the video games of all time. There is no doubt about that. Still, this is not a perfect 10/10 game for me and I will try to explain what I like and dislike about this game. This review is mostly spoiler free. This is my first Fromsoft game and some of the points may apply to all Fromsoft games I only played the first hour of DS3 so I don't know much about other FS titles.  Things that I like:  There is an insane amount of content to do. The exploration in early game feels really good and rewarding. You will meet/find something interesting and useful everywhere you go. There are 300+ weapons,60+ summons 150+ spells, 500+ armor pieces for you to find and make your build. The game feels like a true open world, just go and do whatever you like. You can add awesome skills to your weapon. You can change your weapons' scaling if it's a normal weapon. If you're running a dexterity build and want to wield that Berserk greatsword? You only need the base strength requirement then you can make the sword  scale from dexterity by chaning it's affinity. You can wield very large weapons with one hand most other games will not let you do this. The game is somewhat difficult but you can complete everything, even if you are bad at the game, by using the tools game give you. Playing multiplayer is rewarded with a useful item which is difficult to farm in singleplayer. This is not an entirely sword & roll game, you can make all kinds of bombs, potions, throwing knifes, apply coating to your weapons to inflict elemental damage etc. The game has funny things in it like a big jar dude and funny armors Level and World design is astonishing. Environmental storytelling is very strong. You can tell a lot about what happened in an area just by looking. You can play this game as hack&slash game or survival horror game all depends on your build.  [spoiler] bro becomes a meteor [/spoiler]  Things that I dislike:  Repeating bosses. Some bosses will appear 10+ times. I know it is very difficult to fill a map this big with unique bosses but if you care about it you should know this before. They could have made the world smaller and nobody would complain. Dungeons all feel samey, same enemies with same layoutat the end there will be a the same boss room. The quest system is bad. If you're playing this blind without looking stuff online, chances are, you are going to miss a good portion of the game. NPC quests are literally you talk to a guy then he teleports to  a random location and you talk to him again and repeat.  To unlock 2 entire endgame areas you need 2 items, one drops from a boss and the other one is at a totally random location where you have to hit a random pot to get it. In the endgame exploration is meh, you do some platforming & fighting and find an item, "upgrade material 6" but you can buy the same thing infinitely for a small price at that point. Game performance is bad, the game runs on less frames than some other open world rpg with similar graphics. After you made it into endgame the difficulty spikes up considerably. Not only the bosses but normal mobs will 1-2 shot you unless you have very high health and heavy armor then maybe 2-4 hits. There are normal enemies that  are harder to kill than most of the bosses. The difficulty is unbalanced. There is a boss type of enemy guarding the main boss arena door. He is harder to defeat than the real boss inside. He is on horseback but you can't use your horse, no summons, nowhere to hide from his ranged attacks. He also has more health & hits harder and you can't land a crit attack on him. Certain enemies will punish you for healing, the moment you drink your health potion they will launch a long range attack to interrupt you. People call it input reading and I think it is pure BS. Some fights have a rythm and flow, you can dodge attacks intutively. Some other fights have delayed attacks to trick you. The dude holds his sword up in the air for 5 seconds and you wait for it. I don't think this is fun and does not fit into the context of "melee fighting". A few enemies spawn fires on ground, when you touch it the fire will kill you instantly. This doesn't make sense when you touch fire it sets you on fire then you take damage slowly. You fight very large enemies to die attacks you can't even see since you're just attacking his foot and tickling down his health. Good and interesting characters with very little screentime. Enemies and regions have static level. You are over or under leveled most of the time. You will discover a castle to insta kill the boss inside since you leveled up too much Coop mode is limited, the game limits you in an area with the goal of beating the area boss. You will be sent back to your world after defeating the area boss. There are very useful craftable items which require collectibles that are limited in the world or very tedious to grind. Some aspects of the game are similar to MMORPGs where you farm item b so you can farm item a. Input Buffering, if you press roll 2 times quickly you will roll again after done rolling. This input system is almost never useful it is only there to punish you for spamming buttons. Story is average, there are interesting side quests and lore elements but the main story of the game is you wake up and kill everything. If you look at it there is no story in the game, only a very small number of events happen in your playthrough. A normal playthorugh is literally "go kill the main boss", "ok i made it to the main boss but the door is locked", "go kill 10 other bosses to unlock the door", "kill the main boss". The game is not story driven but lore driven. One of the questline and ending is confirmed to be mistranslated (the ending turns out to have a complete opposite meaning) from the original Japanese script in to English. This raise the question; how much of this game is translated accurately? Second phase of the final boss is the worst type of video game boss. That one boss hits you once and runs 10km away and you chase him the entire figth kind of boss. Many people say the figth was designed with your horse in mind but they forgot to enable it. The game has a system where if a merchant NPC dies you will obtain their shop item and their shop will be available in the hub world. At first this seems like the devs don't want you to miss anything in the game but this is a total scam. You can still miss items.

This is the first review I've ever written, so go easy on me. But as a new Souls player myself I wanted to write about my experience for others looking into the games of the genre for the first time.  [h1] Overview [/h1]  This game is truly phenomenal, and breathtaking at times. Having tried FromSoft games in the past and rage quitting at the first boss because I couldn't get past it, I was a little skeptical of purchasing this game. However the world looked beautiful and I decided to give it a try.   Immediately I was sucked into The Lands Between and its beauty. The world is massive and if you think you can go somewhere you probably can. Combat takes a bit to get used to, but doesn't take too long to become proficient, but can take hours to master. The lore is so deep it is always rewarding when you find a new snippet and can piece together a little bit more about the history of The Lands Between. Questing can be quite difficult at times trying to figure out where to go and what to find, but is very rewarding when you make it to the next step. This game is not for everyone, but it has a lot to offer.  [h1] World [/h1]  Once I opened the door and saw Limgrave for the first time I was taken back at how beautiful it was. After taking in the Erdtree and Stormveil off in the distance I took off into The Lands Between to see where I could go. I was not expecting it to be as open as it was. If you think you can get somewhere, chances probably are that you can get there.   On my quest to acquire all legendary item in the game on my second play-through I explored every nook and cranny in the Lands Between. It blew me away all the places I missed, or thought were unreachable. It also took me to some of the most beautiful places and also some of the hardest, but it pays off greatly to explore.  [h1] Gameplay/Combat [/h1]  Elden Ring is a lot more forgiving than other Souls Borne games due to its open world design. However, it can still pose quite a challenge if you want it to. I say this because Elden Ring is a true open world where as other FromSoft titles are more linear and require some bosses to be beaten to access the next area. There are some areas blocked by bosses in Elden Ring, however, a lot of the word can be accessed without having to engage in these fights. If you get to a boss you cannot beat you can go back into the world to find a better weapon or level up some more to get more prepared. Whereas in other Souls titles you'd just have to "git gud". But if you want a more "true" souls experience you do have the option to go straight to bosses and fight until you git gud.   While I haven't tried all weapon types and styles of combat yet, the combat feels very good. While its a little tedious to learn for new players it does not take too long to be able to at least have a chance against enemies, and theres plenty of areas with smaller bosses to get good and practiced up before going up against main bosses. There are also many different types of weapons that cater to different combat styles so there is something for everyone. Some weapons like colossal weapons are for more experienced players but there are very viable options for people new to this style of game and still make it an enjoyable experience given its difficulty at times.  [h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]  Elden Ring is a beautiful game with a vast open world that highly encourages and rewards exploration. The combat feels very good and offers things to both new and veteran players. The lore is very deep and there is a ton of it if you want to look for it. Which I do highly recommend as makes a fascinating story. If you are wanting to get into Souls Borne games this is a great intro into their genre. After playing through this game several times I now want to go back and accomplish what I never could before and play through the other FromSoft games.

Good game I guess. Here's a good fried chicken recipe:  In a large mixing bowl, whisk together buttermilk, hot sauce (optional, for added flavor), salt, and pepper in a mixing bowl. Add in chicken pieces. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 4 hours. When ready to cook, pour the vegetable oil in a skillet until it is about 3/4 inch deep. Heat to 350 degrees. Prepare the breading by combining the flour, cornstarch, onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil, white pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, and salt in a gallon sized resealable plastic bag or shallow dish. Mix it thoroughly. Working one at a time, remove chicken pieces from buttermilk mixture. Shake it gently to remove the excess. Place it in the breading mix and coat thoroughly. Tap off the excess. Place the breaded chicken into the 350 degree oil. Fry 3 or 4 pieces at a time. The chicken will drop the temperature of the oil so keep it as close to 350 degrees as possible. Fry each piece for 14 minutes, turning each piece about half way through, until the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 165 degrees F. Remove from the oil and place on paper towels. Let them rest for at least 10 minutes before serving.

This is honestly the worst Soulsborne game. The biggest problem is the bosses. If you play without spirits, you often have to dodge the boss for 20-30 seconds before you finally get an opportunity to get a hit in and go back to dodging for 30 seconds. The bosses lack a serious back and forth aspect, and that makes the fights very unsatisfying. This is without mentioning that bosses will randomly add attacks to the end of combo strings that seem "safe." Thus, the fight basically requires rote memorization through trial and error to understand which boss attacks are truly "safe" to respond to with an attack.   If you play with spirits, the bosses become extremely easy and you essentially just abuse the enemy ai flaws. For a series known for its bosses, this game has very few fun boss fights.  The next biggest problem is the open world. While the world is somewhat fun to explore in your first playthrough, the loot often feels spread way too thin compared to past games because unlike past soulsborne games, Elden Ring is an open world game. You often find crap that is irrelevant to your build waiting to find something that may finally get you to change weapons/armor/spells. And in the end, the open world. makes replays a complete slog. The best parts of the game end up being the legacy dungeons that aren't used enough. Overall, From Soft finally lost the ball on this one. I would not recommend the game over any other soulsborne game.

As a individual that really could never find my footing in the dark souls genre, outside of games like Hollow Knight, i Realllly liked this game. It certainly has a lot of the same frustrations you get from Dark Souls, but at least i feel like it's so much more flexibility to play at your pace and overcome these challenges in all sorts of different manners. I highly recommend especially to those that are on the fence because they never got that good experience from the Dark Souls franchise.  easily a 10/10
One of the best games I recently played. Even though a few areas got annoying after a while I very much enjoyed exploring and sometimes just looking at some parts of the world.  There is so much side content that you may not even find. If you want to find things, this time you actually have to look at messages and item descriptions. I myself really enjoyed that. Some say that the reused assets and similar looking caves and dungeons ruin them, but because these areas are completely optional, I am surprised they put even this much effort into those alongside all the other optional and well-hidden areas.  Overall the game is amazing, but this does not mean I would recommend it to everyone. You have to have the affinity to throw yourself at the next thing blocking your way again and again or to try new things until you find a setup that works for the current problem. Reallocating stats in this game can be done fairly early on and quite a few times per journey which is a very welcome thing.

It's that Ratatouille movie scene.  Nothing will beat the wonder and awe I felt playing this game at launch for the first time. Discovery, challenge, adventure, all the while learning from other Tarnished that there was yet more to explore? You could not get me to put it down. Elden Ring single-handedly reignited my love for the RPG genre, and gaming as a whole at the time, sparking my nostalgia for great games of old and burning into me a desire for more. Even as I died, and died again, and again and again.  Even a year later, there's rarely a week gone by that I'm not playing this game. the game is very longer compair to other souls game
Elden Ring is one of, if not the most overrated and overhyped games I have ever played. This isn't a "skill issue" and I don't need to "get good". Pinning blame on the players is a way that I've seen Elden Ring fanboys obfuscate from actual problems the game has. Compared to nearly every other From Software game except maybe Demons Souls or Dark Souls 2, Elden Ring is outshone in nearly every conceivable way. The combat is just unsatisfying, the npcs are some of the worst in the series, and the open world aspect just does not work in the context of a souls-like game. The visual design in this game in general, except for maybe a few specific examples, is just unappealing in a way that makes areas not as interesting as previous games. Elden Ring has inconsistent design philosophies which makes the game feel unnecessarily frustrating at times. The game is filled with gank fights and unnecessary annoyances. A distant ledge that looks to be part of a wall could lead to a secret or may be blocked by an invisible wall that causes you to fall to your death. The game feels like it was made by people who had no communication with each other. The game also suffers from copy and paste, cookie cutter, pre-fabbed dungeons which comprise of nearly all of the games side content. In these dungeons you may find an interesting boss, but it most certainly also appears in at least 3 other dungeons and the reward will likely be not worth the effort you put into the dungeon. All of this could be excused, and I could accept this game as just being a subpar slip into From's library, if not for the atrocious optimization that still hasn't been fixed over a year after release. It is honestly some of the worst I have seen coming from a triple A studio in recent years. If anyone tells you that Elden Ring is their favorite soulsbourne game, either they haven't played many soulsbourne games, or they've seen something in the game that I just haven't. If you are looking to see if this game is worth buying or not, save yourself $20 and buy Dark Souls Remastered instead.

Beautiful. Eerie. Haunting. Frustrating. But compelling. Not the story, as much as there even is any story. But visually and atmospherically, it's compelling. It's oddball in a way that's outlandish but rarely gruesome and not at all cartoonish. It's a world where themes and qualities that don't generally belong together join up and harmonize in a way that strangely seems almost natural. Like with Alice in Wonderland and some Annie Lennox songs. That gets to be soothing, somehow.
Played it more on PS5, but this is my favorite souls game for sure.

[h1] A must play, but only if you have the time [/h1]  I had preordered the game and played around 80 hours in the first month alone. I was absolutely hooked. If I had written a review back then, I would have without a doubt, given it a 10/10.  The world, the mechanics, the graphics are masterfully crafted and I don't think I have something new to say about these. However, I had put a pause on gaming for around half a year not because I didn't want to play but because of the lack of time - a predicament most people can relate to.  These weeks have been a little bit more free for me, so I thought - "I must download Elden Ring, how much I miss it!"  I jumped back into the lands between excited to continue my adventure - only to find out I have absolutely no recollection of what I was doing before, what quests I have picked up and where to go.  I was left stumbled and found little to no enjoyment in slaying enemies with a character I remember nothing about... Which is a shame. I'm not saying a quest log and markers like Skyrim's or The Witcher 3 would have made the game better - even the opposite. But a Morrowind style diary about who you met, what they told you and what you did would have avoided this problem altogether - while preserving the direction of the game.   In the end - I would recommend Elden Ring to everyone who has time to play it every week. If you are a casual gamer with not too much time - save your money for another RPG or wait until you can dedicate your time to finish this masterpiece (What I will be doing)    
An absolute dream of a game for new souls players and old

My first souls game. It's a very good game. The world is captivating and epic. The graphics are good but on close inspection they aren't at the same level as other AAA games, although the art style makes up for it MASSIVELY. I don't think any other game has made dark high fantasy look this good, the world and the atmosphere feels like you're in a painting. The game is challenging as per the norm for soulsbornes but due to the large open spaces and ability to run away from MOST situations, the game gives you a lot of freedom to play and level up at your own pace. I've heard from some "Souls" elitists that it is not perfect and that the other games do some things better, but that is to be expected that no game is perfect. This is a massive open world and there are some areas of tedious and repetitive content, many mini dungeons are samey and some mini-bosses are boring the second or third time you fight a variant. Still, I highly recommend buying Elden Ring. It's something every gamer should experience.

Elden Ring isn't a perfect game, that much is known. I had some technical issues while playing the game (frame stuttering and the occasional crash), but to say that this isn't one of the best games I've played would be as much of a cardinal scene as [spoiler]burning the damn Erdtree[/spoiler].  Now, I'm a complete newbie to souls-likes. Actually, that's not entirely true because I've played Dark Souls 3, however I've never actually completed the game. Elden Ring was the first game I fully completed and gotten every ending for, so here's my take from a completely newbie standpoint.  I found the lore engrossing, which doesn't happen with me every often. The last time I had enjoyed a good story was deltarune and UNDERTALE respectively. A lot of the characters were three-dimensional and ripe with personality, and I particularly loved every single boss on a design standpoint. I'd say that Placidusax and Fortissax were my favorite, but they're both dragons and I have a dragon bias, so I'll say that Malenia's and Elden Beast's designs were my unbiased favorite.  Combat's challenging, that much is obvious. It's a souls game, I wouldn't expect any hand holding, but it's not difficult to the point where its unfair. You have to seriously time your attacks and dodges just so you're sure you don't come crashing face first into Renalla's moon. You actually have to plan ahead and think instead of rushing in and spamming your ash of war until the enemy drops. Sure, Mohg has the non-preventable nihil attack that procs with blood loss three times, but there's a whole crystal tear meant to counter it. Even then, you can literally survive without it by simply healing every time he procs it. The only one I found a little bit unfair was Malenia's waterfowl dance, but since it's been almost a year since the game's launch, there's already a method to dodge it.  Let's also not forget the open-world aspect of this game. I've gotten all the achievements the game had to offer. Still, even after all of that, after all 114 hours of playing, there's still undiscovered catacombs, caves, questlines, bosses...  The music is great. Don't really need to explain that one.  Overall, 10/10, would experience the game again.
100% must play

So much content to explore, massive build diversity and punishing but satisfying combat mechanics. A breath of fresh air to the open world genre giving the player an unguided experience rarely seen these days.  100% worth a squirt!

180 hours with newgame 2 and all achievements investment.  Overall great open world game. If you like souls like games you'll like this game. The open world itself was very full of life and differences, the areas each having their own flare. The main bosses were all unique characters. Side bosses had some repeats, but with so many bosses its not too surprising and can be forgiven though. its an area of improvement. Difficulty was dynamic depending on how good your build is and what your current level is. There is also lots of help to make the bosses easier like ashes.  The npcs you meet along the way are all interesting and none ever felt same in personality. The weapons and abilities available add a lot of dynamics to combat. If I had to ask for one thing to be done a little better, it would be in the endings. [spoiler] 4 of the 6 possible endings [/spoiler] are a bit samey and uninspired because of that.  I'd say its a 9/10. Well worth the money paid for it. I also didn't play for a few months since the game came out, so I didn't experience any optimization issues I hear mentioned.

What I liked: pretty much the entire game was fun for the most part, exploring and taking your time building your level and finding different armors and weapons to use is great. The beginning bosses are pretty decent. Love having a horse to get around, combat can either be great while on Torrent or awful. I do love the game, I completed it three times to get all 42 achievements.  What I did not like: Later bosses, for me, are not fun to fight. It feels good to defeat them but I was also exhausted and still frustrated even though I beat them. I will admit I am not strong at combat and with one boss I had a cooperator help me so I could get the achievement. I do not feel bad about it! Later game also has sparse interactions with regular combat and felt like I just went from one boss and on to another with very little inbetween. I felt there was less to do in regard to exploring in later game, which was a shame as the setting would have been great for it.  Regardless, I would recommend this game. Probably on controller, I played on keyboard and mouse and it was a challenge. If you get discouraged easily or frustrated with dying there is multiplayer as well. Good luck becoming Elden Lord!

ELDEN PEAK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
ELDEN RING™ is just DARK SOULS™ with extra steps, [i]literally[/i], you have to transverse three times as much digital terrain than previous FROMSOFTWARE games (multiply that by two if you're doing co-op, because then you can't use the horsie), much of which is filled with barely anything of worth, many of the starting bosses are later then recycled in evergaols (Godrick equals Godefroy) and you'll see the same mini-bosses or [i]field bosses[/i] as the game calls them every two or three Site of Graces, like the death chicken or the ominous bell knight. Limgrave and Liurnia are very pleasing areas to explore and lose yourself in, they break away from the usual gloomy-depression-inducing-dark-fantasy settings From Software is known for and that is a plus, but soon you'll get thrown in Caelid and the dungeons will remember you which series this hails from. The dungeons are all samey, you get in, beat up some small stone imps and deal with the usual firethrower mechanism or the riding chariot of death and then you find a lever and kill a [i]field boss[/i] and you're good to go — back to just running around with your horse. The NPCs can move their mouths while talking now, that's something that took them a while — I understand. Despite all these gripes I have, I still had fun in a way I didn't really felt with one of their titles since playing DARK SOULS II: Scholar of the First Sin. So it's got that going for it, which is nice.

NIHIL NIHIL NIHIL
Elden Ring operates on one simple idea: You, a weak and frail nobody, have to rise to the occasion and slay hideous monsters, gigantic dragons, legendary kings, ancient gods, and even ferocious madness-inflicting rats in order to accomplish your goals.  This is quickly and efficiently established as you unsuspectingly start the game and immediately get splattered across the walls by a sword wielding, acid spewing spider made out of corpses. You have now discovered that you're in a brutal and apathetic environment that will try to kill you regardless of your complaints.  When you mull over that synopsis, what comes to mind? It sounds unfair, doesn't it? Every aspect of the game is specifically designed to be an obstacle against your progress that you have to overcome, to the point of feeling unfair at many points. And at some points, it is actually unfair. But the task this game demands of you is to put your boots on and push through every obstacle until you finally overcome them, leading to a feeling of accomplishment that wouldn't be there if you just beat the boss in one try.  The basic framework of the gameplay is deceivingly simple, you either attack your enemy, or dodge their attack, but in actuality you will have to consider many aspects like positioning, health and stamina, length and moveset of your weapon, and learn to avoid fatal beginner mistakes like overcommitting on your attacks or panic dodges that get easily punished by your enemies.  The map of the game is truly massive, it is the one of the few, perhaps even the only detailed video game environments that provides a true sense of scale. You see that giant tree? That's not the skybox, that's where you're going. Over the course of the game you will traverse massive lakes, great forests, gargantuan castles, deep and ancient underground cities, and mountainous mountains. Elden Ring succeeds where most open world games fail by being a vertical game, you will be able to visit the highest heights and the lowest depths.  Unfortunately, due to the scale of the world, from a loot perspective exploration is not rewarded nearly as well as previous Fromsoft games. In Dark Souls when you searched through the cracks and crevices of a location off the beaten path you would end up finding a cool sword or armor set, but in Elden Ring it's more likely to be a mushroom for crafting. While this is a valid complaint it's also simply not feasible for the developers to have gone and placed unique items at every little hidden cliffside or dead end. But if you personally enjoy exploration for its own sake and seeing the incredible sights of the game then you won't have any problems.  The most controversial aspect of the game is the multiplayer. The way it works is that you can summon friends into your game to explore together and help you fight enemies. The co-op can be a bit inconvenient because the game doesn't let you go between separate map areas in multiplayer, and it doesn't let you use your horse in multiplayer either.  The part where people are divided though is the invasion system. When you are playing with friends, another player can invade your world and attempt to kill you in order to halt your progress. Many people buy Fromsoft games thinking that they are exclusively a PvE experience and then encounter invaders and it leaves a sour taste in their mouth. The problems people have with invaders range from simply not enjoying having their progress halted by another person, to many invaders using broken meta weapons that are very difficult to counter.  To me, this issue with invaders is closely related to the core philosophy of the game. Just like a difficult boss, invaders are yet another obstacle to your quest that the game mercilessly throws at you. Invaders also have their own obstacles, the game throws teams of 2-3 people at them and they have to be good enough to handle the pressure and use their environment as an advantage in their war of attrition. From the invader's perspective, the host and their summons are the boss that must be overcome.  Though I prefer the gameplay, in my opinion as a whole the PvP in this game is a step down from Dark Souls 3. The previous games had a system called covenants, which were essentially factions that a player could choose that had unique matchmaking and item rewards for co-op and PvP. This system is only just barely present in Elden Ring, and it's watered down. Even in the previous games the rewards for multiplayer weren't that good but now you essentially get nothing except for a good time. The only thing resembling a covenant left in the game are the white and blue cipher rings that respectively allow you to call for help from another player whenever you get invaded or respond to that call for help.  TLDR: This game sucks you in and transports you into a brutal yet beautiful world of fantasy, borrowing heavily from Lord of The Rings and Berserk. 10/10 would solo her again.

Okay, what I'm about to review is in no way hyperbolic and should be taken as an incentive to play the damn game: it's a work of brilliance that does everything utterly right. From the scarcely comprehensible plot, to the graphics and atmosphere, to the loot, level and combat system, everything is on the utmost level. The game is unsurprisingly tough, but for a valid reason: you despair of bosses, and to overcome them you simply have to improve; so the game pushes you to be a better, smarter and stronger player, and once you realize that, it's even more rewarding. When you finally defeat the Elden Beast after 100 tries, you have literally become a god at Elden Ring, and you look back mischievously to the start when you originally believed the first boss was unconquerable. Unsurprisingly, Elden Ring has become GOTY. Congrats!

made me mad
I'm a bit of a cheapskate, not to mention my taste in video games tends to steer me away from the $60 triple-a titles. I'm also not usually the biggest fan of open world games either. They often tend to have way too much wide open space or have a bunch of boring npcs with even more boring quests. However I enjoyed Dark Souls III enough to take a gamble on this one. I'm very glad I did. This game respects my monkey brain of "I wanna run around and kill stuff" more than any other open world or RPG ever has. While the large set pieces are the stars of the show, likely due to their more linear dark souls-y design, the open areas still have plenty of activities, and the exploration feels very organic, so it never feels like going from point A to point B, but rather "that building in the distance sure looks interesting, I'll head in that general direction while checking out stuff on the side." I feel like my $60 has already been worth it, and I've barely made a dent in this game.  Edit: 60 hours in and I do have a few criticisms.  1. The pvp kinda sucks. There's no more random invasions except during co-op, which encourages invaders to be more toxic, since there's a higher likelihood that they'll get 3v1'd.   2. The game feels way easier than previous souls games. I had a little trouble in the early game but once I got my build settled I've pretty much been steamrolling everything.   3. There's a lot of copy/paste. I don't mind the repeated enemies and minibosses so much, since there's plenty of other solid games that do similar things. My big gripe is with some of the later game mini-dungeon layouts, which overuse the trope of "ooo, this layout of rooms is exactly the same as the ones you just went through, oooo, what a labyrinth, you feel lost yet?" like bruh I though we had stopped doing that shit back in the NES era because we all agreed it wasn't fun. It's fine for like, one or two dungeons as a gimmick, but it got old fairly quick.   All that being said, the game is still an incredibly good time, and I'll certainly be seeing it through till the end.

THIS GAME SUCK S
Good game with some MAJOR flaws. What smooth-brained moron thought it was a good idea to give players a +8 weapon when the summoning depends on level and highest weapon level?  If you accidentally get gifted a high level weapon by an NPC (which happens VERY early in the game), then you won't be able to summon or be summoned by most of the population.  The game also tells you to go east after the first area, but the east is actually a mid/late area of the game, so....  Lots of the bosses get stuck on geometry.  The game suddenly gets major lag spikes in the middle of fights (not very often, but still, I'm running a high-end system and there's still lag spikes? Wtf is up with that?).  They removed homeward bones, why? Terrible design choice.  The story is meh, I loved all the souls-borne lore but this game's story isn't very captivating.  The combat, when it works right, is a lot of fun.  The graphics are pretty.  Good sound design.  So-so music (out of all the Souls Borne games, this one probably has the most forgettable soundtrack for me).  Everyone kept clamoring about how difficult this game is, but I've been plowing my way through this with little effort. I think they're just not used to the enemy delaying their attacks. It's probably one of the easier souls-borne experiences.

Beware of dog
After a long hiatus due a hand injury, I've finally finished it and it's one of those gems that I feel like has impacted me on almost a spiritual level so I wanted to just leave a review.  It's GOTY for a reason.  That being said, expect a little bit of jankiness, but get ready for a huge world to get lost in. Lots of challenges to tackle in your own way.  Beautiful screenshot worthy vistas.  Frustrating and scary moments. Jaw dropping enemy designs. Tons of weapons, spells, armor to try out. Take the time to interact with the characters and read item descriptions to give you an idea of the shattered world your character has arrived in, there's a lot more than meets the eye.  I have a few gripes, namely that there are so many weapons and items but there is a hard limit on how many times you can re-spec your character, it limits experimentation and creativity. The item upgrading system, well, let's be real, a handful of systems are a bit convoluted too. But don't let that stop you. I recommend a blind experience but look up things when you need to because the game doesn't explain things very well, specially if you're new to souls games. Don't be afraid to try it.  The game at it's core is about perseverance. It's a souls game, it's brutal. Don't give up. Some of the bosses took me days to learn and beat, but the feeling of overcoming a challenge like that is just bliss.   Take breaks if you need to, explore different areas and try various methods to beat the bosses. Elden Ring has so many more ways to play the game than the older souls games and to make it easier on yourself if you want to by using summons or summoning help. Or you can challenge yourself and self impose your own rules. That's the beauty of it.
