Surely the greatest game ever, and as a 57 yo finishing this was so good. I have been playing games since the zx spectrum and there is nothing that compares to this. Amazing.
Look, there are many reasons to dislike or bounce off a Fromsoft game.  They're usually pretty drab and grey and rotting in aesthetic, they're fantastically and infamously hard to the point that a portion of the playerbase is somewhat obnoxious about it, the story tends to be vague and depressing, the controls are a little obtuse.    But I have generally always *tried* to like Fromsoft games, because they are clearly both genre defining and exceptional at what they are trying to do.  I bounced off every single one that I tried - including this one- until I picked it up again, months later, because I was drawn back by the things I had *liked* about it.    Elden Ring still has an ugly, drab, rotting aesthetic.  It is also filled with beautiful landscapes suffused with bright color and golden light, and just genuinely impressive visuals all over the place.   Elden Ring is still hard as hell.  It is also a game that allows you to level up to the point where you can easily handle bosses without having to painstakingly learn every one of their moves, while traversing literally wherever you want, wielding a wide array of toolkits and summons to address problems, and picking and choosing what encounters you think are worth your while.  Elden Rings controls are still obtuse and odd.  They work pretty well on a controller, nonetheless, and as you play you will keep finding oddities in the movesets, little things like attacks you can trigger off of dodges on certain weapons, all the while allowing you to customize and experiment with a huge array of weapons that range from abusively simple to fascinatingly complex.  Elden Rings story is still vague and depressing.  The open world aspect of it makes it fascinating to unpack, with every little piece of the environment and every new character you meet teaching you something fascinating, as well as some characters being *very* upfront with you about the story and the things that have happened.   It's also a game who's rich history was half penned by George R.R. Martin, who as usual is exploring some stuff in a way that just kinda vibes with the general Fromsoft vibe.  It all clicked this time.  So now I am into Elden Ring.  I have roamed the entirety of Lingrave and covered a huge portion of Liurnia and Caelid, I have tried four different characters and am excited about a fifth.  I've learned how to parry and I've learned how to dodge and jump and how to twohand when needed and what spec seems most powerful to me (it's claws and scholarly weapon), and I've learned that all the stats are cool but you should really put points in Vigor too.  Parts of the game seem easy now.  Other parts still have a challenge I am excited to seek.  I'm having a really good time.  I cannot emphasize this enough: it is frankly cooler to like things than to hate them.  It is absolutely more fun to meet a game where it is at and embrace what it is offering.  This game is wildly, perfectly good if you can do that.  And if you do not know how to meet a Fromsoft game where it is at, this is the best possible die roll that you will find a way to.

SCORE: 8/10  Elden Ring initially gripped me in a way few other games have. The starting area of Limgrave is superbly designed, offering a significant amount of enemy variety, enticing landscapes and plenty to explore. The sense of awe and wonder is strong, perhaps unrivalled among open world games.  The areas that immediately follow it maintain a high level of quality, even if not quite high as the opening area. The repetition of the caves, catacombs, etc. was starting to wear a little thin, the amount of reused bosses was becoming more noticeable and my frustration at how little of the loot I was finding was relevant to my build was growing, but the first fifty hours or so were nevertheless extremely engaging.  Unfortunately, there is a point in the game at which those minor flaws start to become major ones. The enemy variety is extremely front-loaded, leading to dozens of hours of playtime in the latter half of the game fighting almost nothing but reused enemies. Exploration became unrewarding when it began to dawn on me just how few of the things I was finding I even considered using. The repetitive open world filler content had long worn out its welcome.  The more I played, the more I began to think this is not some new, innovative approach to open world design as many people claim. If, for example, clearing out an enemy camp in an Assassin's Creed game is considered a bad example of content to put in an open world, I don't see how clearing out a copy-paste catacomb, fighting a boss I've seen several times before at the end of it and opening a chest to get a weapon I'll never use is much of an improvement. The presentation of this content, choosing not to mark it on the map beforehand and put a check mark next to it when you're done, is welcome. But the standard of the actual content itself once you find it is not any better than what other open world games have to offer.  As with many other open world games, I think Elden Ring would be better if it showed more restraint. There is simply just not enough interesting content to fill its huge world. It's a game with many memorable moments, but almost all of those came in the first half of the ninety-five hours I spent playing it.

Once in a great while, a game comes along that seamlessly combines impeccable gameplay, a wondrous world, incredible tone-setting music, and unparalleled art direction. That game is From Software’s Elden Ring, an action RPG that channels the best aspects of the genre. This absurdly ambitious open world captivated my curiosity, enticed me with puzzles, secrets, and mysteries, and served up unbelievably satisfying moments as I experienced one of the most extraordinary adventures of all time. From my initial foray into the world to the final moments, every step of the journey is a note in a personalized epic that kept me coming back for more. The Lands Between is a world full of discovery, and while a clear path forward exists for those seeking guidance, roaming the lands unfettered without a particular goal in mind often yields surprises. I often had a spot to explore marked on my map and got off-track along the way, sometimes leading to entirely new areas and feature-dense zones. The grandiose world is chock full of characters, quests, and various dungeon crawls ranging from tiny catacombs to massive multilayered tombs. While the journey starts with little caves, mines, and other dungeon delves, these experiences become more complex. Two-room affairs eventually become intricate teleport puzzles or scenarios where you discover unusual ways to interact with the environment, like learning to use traps for traversal or sniffing out secret walls. Your character is incredibly customizable, which I found highly rewarding. You can attach various skills and scaling mechanics across the board, allowing you to truly create your own vision of a traveling hero. Respecialization and alterations allow you to finely tweak your creation without worrying too much about experimentation along the way as you arm yourself with everything from explosive pots to potent perfumes to complement your ever-growing arsenal. The open world is majestic, dripping with flavor and atmosphere, and full of fabulous finds. However, the legacy dungeons are the stuff of legend, often connecting to the outside from multiple points. These curated sprawls are a dream to dissect, and Elden Ring often offers different ways to maneuver through these areas. The big bosses, generally found at the end of legacy dungeons, feel like wonderful wars against demigods. These brilliant set piece battles are thrilling exclamation points to an outrageous odyssey, absolute spectacles, and masterful combinations of tension and triumph. Elden Ring has the distinction of having the best and most challenging boss battle in any From Software game to date. Hidden away and optional, this encounter had me waking up in the middle of the night to come back and crash against its beautiful and terrifying destruction over and over again. After finally besting this opponent, I let loose a triumphant victory roar there while sitting in the dark and wearing my pajamas, wanting nothing more than to experience the encounter again. This example speaks to how unbelievably compelling and immersive Elden Ring is; I regularly put it down with the intent of doing something else and found myself back within minutes. There is always one more gnawing mystery to unravel, one more boss to beat, and one more hidden route to find.  Elden Ring challenged me, captivated me, and enchanted me, an unyielding deluge of discovery and artistic vision unbound. Elden Ring represents a truly amazing combination of various game elements that all come together to create something fascinating, special, and unforgettable. Elden Ring isn’t just the best game this year; it’s one of the best games ever made.

Look, I could write an entire essay about this game here, but I don't wanna waste neither your or my time, so here's the short of it: the art direction and the level design are amazing, you'll have a hard time convincing me any other developer has an art direction team on par with From Soft, they're just the best in the industry. The exploration is absolutely amazing. The bosses are bad. They're visually impressive, often being great spectacles to behold with all their spells and effects, but when it comes to the gameplay itself they're nothing more than cheap. Remember "tough but fair"? That's gone. Bosses always have lots of huge AoE homing attacks they can spam infinitely, zero down time between attacks, are specially designed with a "gotcha" mentality, with attacks specially engineered to catch you not matter what, and all of them have a correct way of being fought here; you either play by the "meta" or you're in for a bad time. Like to experiment with different builds and items? Look elsehere, there's no room for it here. I didn't play by the meta 'cause I didn't know what it was until after I finished the game; wanna know how I got through them? Over levelling and brute forcing. They're frustrating even in victory.  That's it, great game, bad bosses. That's the short of it.

TL;DR: Decent game, but nothing groundbreaking or innovative in Soulsformula nor in Openworld games really to warrant  goty.  Just to make clear, I do like and enjoy FromSoftware's works. So all respect for Miyazaki and his team. And I like the game, even though to me it is more or less just Dark Souls 4.  Will most likely still play more and finish ER at somepoint.  But since there is no "Mixed" review I'll give a thumbs down.  If you liked previous soulsgames and are fan of the genre, then most likely you'll find something to enjoy from here too. If you are new to soulslikes, then this might not be your cup of tea.  (To add that I wasn't really on the hype train waiting for ER, was more less "might as well buy for shits and giggles" and for me it has paid itself back.)  FS has proven time and time again that they can make great worlds with interesting areas, but on Elden Ring, I personally feel that some of the magic was lost due to the shift of open world. I think that From is more strong when building interconnected labyrinths like the ones in Bloodborne and Dark Souls 1 to compare. In ER they've managed to do this the Legacy set pieces very nicely. They are straight up comparable to previous works of FS.  The world is pretty, but pretty alone doesn't make it good. Even with all the vistas and PoI's the world at times feels empty and recycled (Though recycling in ER is a problem in itself at times) and after a while you won't be spending that much time on the map itself anymore since fast travel makes travelling on Torrent obsolete.  I think that ER provides a fair challenge when compared to other soulsborne games, the difficulty is on par and the option of being able to do something else when facing a wall is a nice addition even though you've always had the ability to go back and grind (if one chooses so) unless you wanted to throw yourself against that wall till it breaks.
Incredible game, every thing about this game is perfect. The story, the lore, the world, the soundtrack, every picturesque location, and every jaw dropping boss fight is so perfectly crafted. Don't let the difficulty dissuade you from experiencing this game. One of the greatest of all time

GOTY without any questions asked. I've never properly invested time into any souls games before but Elden Ring is very much approachable by someone with 0 experience with souls games
I have been playing FROM Software games since DS1 came out on the 360. I have tried to like these games over and over. I have played DS1 from many different angles and many different classes, but have never seen the appeal. To me, playing these games just feels like training yourself to be really good at executing a half-baked feedback loop process with extremely broken tools, and Elden Ring is no exception. Not only does this game exemplify everything wrong with the design of FROM games, but it doesn't even do it in an original or groundbreaking way like lots of people would have you believe. The combat is almost exactly like DS1, and the bosses are an odd hybrid of styles and presentation from Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. The open world is lifeless and dull, and the game dumps needlessly obtuse exposition with no explanation of other parts of the lore or why you as the player should care. It's just "go on a great quest, oh chosen Undead!" Yeah, I haven't seen that anywhere else... except it's the premise for every FROM game since Dark Souls. Truly I am absolutely baffled as to how this game won any awards, much less Game of the Year. If you want a video game that you can install, have fun with, and put down until you wanna play again, this is NOT the game for you. If you like games where you have to sink an extreme amount of time and research into the world's lore, the broken combat system, and the general obtuse and bloated design of the game in hopes that you MIGHT be capable of squeezing out even the smallest crumbs of fun from it, then be my guest here. Hopefully I can at least get a refund so I can say I spent my money on a game I will actually play instead of a game that I boot up, play for 5 minutes, be reminded why I didn't buy at launch, die due to broken hit detection, and turn off again for 3 or 4 more weeks. Maybe I'm old school, but I think video games should be fun right out of the box. Part of the reason I love PC gaming specifically is because there is so much variety to be had in terms of game experiences, whether in terms of "pick up and play" or "big time sink" type games like this one. And that is definitely not to say that all games that require you to put time and research into them are bad; some of my favorite games are Stalker, Silent Hill, and Disco Elysium, all games that require you to retain and put effort into the world and just being in the game. But this game, to me, epitomizes the soulless AAA product machine that gaming has become. "Explore the open world!" Why? Is there anything worth seeing there? Is there a good story? Or does everything in this game ultimately serve as just fluff in between hours of grinding that you're expected to just enjoy without any clear motivation as to why you should be enjoying it? And even then, when the story DOES show up, it's the exact same pseudo-verbose fake Tolkien crap FROM has been spoon-feeding their blood-loyal fans since Dark Souls.  Seriously, if you want to waste your time "getting gud" at a broken ass game, at least do it with Bloodborne. You'd be doing yourself a service to save up the money to buy a PS4 just to buy Bloodborne over playing this one. I'm probably SOL on getting a refund, so if you see I have higher hours now than when I wrote this review, it is because I am simply trying to complete the game to get my money's worth and uninstall it so I can go back to playing something else.
The absolute sense of wonder from exploring such a massively detailed world and being able to discover so much unique content completely organically is liberating and breathes a breath of fresh air into the open-world genre. Pair that with refined Souls-like combat, build variety, replayability, story-telling, and lore and you easily have one of the best games of the year if not of this generation.

This game just isn’t made for me but If you're a soul-gamer fanboy or a masochist, this game is juuuuust for you;  This game hide behind "show don’t tell" / "open-world" / "Soul game" as an excuse for poor storytelling and no personality. Overall the game is tedious, boring and random, with brief conversations and minimal NPC interaction (even when you confront important characters), just kill everything and get the loot... because everything wants to kill you... because.  Quests are all over the place with no way of tracking and by the time you find another NPC or a hint you don't even remember what you were working towards and you don't care. you can fight a boss or jump through hoops to complete an area just to get an item that is useless. main items are hidden away in places you overlooked with no good reason and no way of you knowing that.  On the bright side... the game is visually beautiful and the models and combat mechanics are amazing.
I will rate it 8/10 (more on this below)  This game is purely designed for a true rpg experience i.e there would be no guidance or linear lore progression. You can go anywhere you wish but you will have to figure things on your own. To some people its exactly what they want, and for some it would be a terrible experience.  Things you will experience: - 1) Beautiful Landscapes 2) Sense of true exploration 3) Frustration (because the game is designed to be hard and is unforgiving, but you will get used to it). 4) Epic feeling/sense of accomplishment once you beat a certain boss. 5) Little to no happiness, dark world.  Things elden ring need to have for me to give it 10/10  1) Easy mode - It enables casual gamers to have a lore experience and not grind for an hour to learn boss patterns to beat them, it might be something a souls fan would love but a casual gamer is not looking to experience that. They just want to experience the art of the game and lore.  2) Game mechanics/rules need to be fair for everyone in the game - For eg In elden ring you cannot cancel your animation, but some bosses do not respect it. (Malenia) and every spell should have some cooldown to it to prevent npc from constantly spamming it due to error in programming.  3) A guide (Yes a guide) - As mentioned in point 1, the majority of gamers play games casually. So a guide system would be helpful (something like questhelper from World of Warcraft). It can try to guide a player for a more linear progression.  4) Option to re-fight a boss - Personally when I finished the game, I wanted to fight certain bosses because those were fun. But unfortunately you cannot and the only option is the new game+, I don't feel like doing the same again just to fight bosses. Especially when I have already finished 100% of the game. There is no incentive in doing so when you have already explored the whole game.  5) True coop: I don't know how can such a beautiful game have such a bad co-op experience, it has been solved upto some extend by modding community when they created "Seamless co-op". But true co-op in elden ring would have made it 100x better in my opinion.  Overall, the game is gonna give you a great experience. Go for it! :)

This is legit the BIGGEST open world game I have ever played in my life. The sheer detailing of every region be it the art direction , enemy variety , level design , ambience & music is pure exquisite craftmanship  from the developers. Despite the open world design & approach borrowing it's idea from ZELDA , Elden Ring absolutely takes it to another level making it an experience unlike any other game I have played. The game is bigger than anybody can fathom. At times it could be quite overwhelming to keep track of the regions you have discovered, the NPC interactions and the constant breaking of questlines but it's quite unique on how the game doesn't dump details at your face and rather rewards you for exploration and discovery with it's rich and mysterious lore. I also think this is by far the most accessible FROM SOFTWARE game mainly because of the amount of choices you are left with to approach the game. The game play and combat though is detailed & vast doesn't necessarily have the learning curve complexity of their PREVIOUS game SEKIRO. Some of the biggest issues I had with the game are the poor optimisation for PC performance despite a locked 60 fps even in my 3060 GPU. Most of the Dragon battles I faced had extreme stuttering in terms of performance. Also there are some questionable design choices in the UI , for instance every time the game has a popup window in the middle of a battle when I resummon Torrent after he is dead. I get the need of it in the initial stages of the game but why does it continue till the very end. It's very much distracting and can quite lead you to your death at times. At least they should have included an option to turn it off in the settings. Also for a game with it's absolutely incredible number of bosses , the biggest enemy you will ever face is going to be the CAMERA. As the POPULAR saying goes : " YOU CAN ESCAPE THE BOSSES , BUT NEVER THE CAMERA "    9/10 - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Great!
Boy oh boy, this game is nothing less than great. Not only is this game cinematic the combat is fun the difficulty although at times can be a bit unfair is rather enjoyable, Being my first souls game I enjoy the experience a lot. Given that the game is cinematic which already makes an open-world game fun to explore, the music and looks tell you everything about the area. An example of this would be both the Leyndell Sewers and Caelid both of those areas feel uninviting as if you aren't supposed to be there. To be honest you probably aren't wanted there of the things that lurk in those places but that's what I love about the game the music, and the view all tell the same story of what's going on it, The game crafts and blends it all together beautifully. For the most part, all the bosses are fun, there are a couple of mini-bosses I dislike a lot and someone of them even required me to do some of those annoying ones for the completion of some character storylines, ( and a couple of boss fights that are required for the main story to progress that is horrible if you aren't prepared ). The game feels very rewarding for going out of your way to find things, and fighting the boss fights makes me feel like a badass when I finally manage to win. The story in Elden Ring also was amazing, a lot of people may say Elden Ring has no story, but that isn't the case it just has a different variation of storytelling. Such as Frenzy Flame (which the story starts at the very beginning of the game) or the story about the Lord of Blood (which is also something you'll likely run into). These little aspects affect the entire story and the more you learn about it the greater the connection grows with characters and the more it will hurt when some of said characters die. Elden Ring is truly a great game, regardless you mean the lore of a boss that you fought previously or a battle that you prepared for hours in advance. I personally felt a drive to win against those bosses as I imagined a world where they won and they succeeded. I would say this game is worth buying even at full price, but I wouldn't blame you for waiting for a sale.

Hands down, undoubtedly the game of the year. The sheer scope and grandeur of the game, along with its sense of exploration and wonder are just simply unmatched - among the very best that games have to offer.  It plays as a truly great game for the first 2/3rds of a typical playthrough. After which, I am dumbfounded by how sharp the drop-off is. How can a game provide 40 hours of near-perfect experience, and be tarnished by 20 hours of uninspired and truly baffling decisions at the end? From poor use of repeated content, and poor late-game balancing, to truly boring and at times truly unfair late-game bosses. It's frustrating how sullied my experience is with the game because of how padded and unnecessary certain sections and bosses during the late game were. (Youtube video essays such as Joseph Anderson, VG Matthew, and NeverKnowsBest's do a great job detailing these more than any review you will see here)  This game is well worth playing, it's an experience that almost universally - is agreed upon as near perfect at least until the late game. However, the joy of finishing the game is simply not there for me. I didn't feel that sense of triumph in overcoming adversity and culminating in a fitting end to the story - instead, I am simply glad that it is over.  Along with BoTW, this has shown me what a truly great game is like - at least in some aspects. I am glad that this game has inspired me to get into playing more singleplayer games where competitiveness is not the be-all and end-all. 10/10

yes
I've had an off on again relationship with fromsoft games. I absolutely loved Dark Souls in 2011 and i have played nearly all there titles. The problem is my tolerance for these sorts of games seemed to have diminished over the years as life can be stressful as it is without enduring that stress through my favourite pastime (Gaming) BUT here's the thing that elevates Elden RIng to be my favourite Fromsoft game....this is finally accessible to all levels of gamer.  The game is accessible for a variety of reasons, the Open World allows you too play at your own pace levelling up as you do but the main reason (and it really is a game changer) is there is now summoning posts outside every boss fight and most locations. This means you can obtain help from another player if (Much more likely when) you get stuck. This is a genius move that now enables this to be enjoyed by everyone rather then the hardcore end of the market.  The game isn't perfect, You can't pause the game which can be a real headache, the camera angle can be a pain and your steed's jumping (Seems to be a slight button delay) can cause a bit of frustration but the word frustrating isn't what i would describe this game which is a first for me when referring to fromsoft games. The vast open world with its unique, varied and vast locations truly outweigh any small negatives anyway This also contains some of the best character design in any media!  If you've delayed playing this due to past experiences with fromsoft then you owe yourself to try this. I would safely assume that you won't be disappointed.
brrr
Before Elden Ring, I had never played a From game before. But I was intrigued by all Elden Ring’s 10/10 ratings and the comparisons to Breath of the Wild, one of my favorite games.  This is a review for people like me, who are intimidated by the reputation for difficulty but are still willing to consider it because of all those stellar ratings.  OVERVIEW  The plot, such as it is, is Lord of the Rings, except you want to seize the One Ring for yourself so you can conquer Middle-EarthTheLands Between. In typical video game fashion, the ring has been split into multiple pieces and you have to find and murder the owners of each piece.  From a gameplay perspective, this means you explore ruins and dungeons, kill enemies, get better equipment and magic, level up, and repeat many times. There’s no other plot to speak of. NPC’s exist, but they mostly spout obscure and unintelligible gibberish.  Developer From Software is infamous for offering only Hard Mode with no lower difficulty or accessibility options, and they did the same here. If you like to play on Story Mode, find Normal Mode in other games very challenging, or need accessibility settings beyond controller remapping, From Software doesn’t want your business and you can stop reading now.  THE INTRO  This is not a noob-friendly game, starting with character creation. You start with a class selector, with eight different class options. Each class has a bunch of numbers and symbols, but there’s no explanation of what any of those symbols mean or what abilities that class has.   Then you pick a starting “boon”, from about fifteen options. What does this do? Is it important? Also no explanation.  The combat tutorial is a brazen “fuck you” to noobs, because they stick it off the side where you can easily just walk right past it, and even when you go through it it barely explains how any of the systems work.  After the tutorial, same story. As you gain power, you pick stats to level up and pick weapons and equipment. When you do this, Elden Ring’s developers give you a stats screen full of tiny, barely-legible numbers.  Fortunately, my husband is a Dark Souls fan who had already played the game. He helped me pick a class, pointed out the tutorial that I wandered past, explained how blocking works, pointed out more stuff when it was clear I didn’t understand some system, and gave me pointers on how to pick stats to level up.  Having someone to help was absolutely essential. Without my husband’s advice, I would have given up in frustration within the first two hours.  THE GOOD PARTS. THEY’RE REALLY GOOD  Once past that initial hurdle, things got a lot better.  The world design is S-tier. You walk (or ride) around, and look at the environment, and you can be sure that no matter which direction you go you will find something. Quest markers and checklists are nonexistent. Points of interest are common and clearly telegraphed, while the path to get there is not always obvious, so you have to look around and figure out what to do.  No matter what the point of interest is, what you find there will almost always be combat.  Combat being the only objective sounds like it would be repetitive, but it isn’t.  By varying the size and shape of battle arenas and the types of enemy groupings, Elden Ring makes encounters become completely different even when facing enemies you’ve seen many times before.  Elden Ring keeps this variety up for the whole game, which is truly remarkable for how big it is.  Unfortunately, the game doesn’t have much to find that’s not combat. You’d expect that in a hundred-hour game they would liven things up a bit, but there are no towns, no puzzle shrines, no suspiciously placed rocks that hide collectibles, few platforming challenges, and no hidden paths to jawdropping views. Even so, the content that does exist is pretty great.  BUT IS IT TOO HARD?  Well, no and yes. And ultimately, yes.  It took a few hours to get the basics down, including some advice from my husband. After that, I would characterize it as “challenging but fair”. Even regular mobs deal a lot of damage and you have a very limited supply of healing potions. Traps and ambushes are common.  But it will normally not take you more than a few tries to take out a group of regular enemies, and if it’s too hard you can just move on and come back to slaughter them later. At least for a while.  The bosses are a different story. The boss difficulty is not reliably matched to the difficulty of the dungeon it’s in. Sometimes the bosses are easily dispatched, but often they are absurdly, unfairly difficult. The game seems to be expecting you to try bosses dozens of times before you win.  Many games have implemented this sort of challenge design well, but Elden Ring isn’t one of them. Instead of instantly respawning you near where you failed, the game routinely sticks respawn points several rooms away from the boss chamber, the battles are long with no mid-battle checkpoints, and the death animations and load times are glacial.  I started timing one these battles, and found that for every twenty seconds of fighting the boss, I spent twenty-eight seconds on death animations and loading screens, and another fifty on walking from the respawn point back to the boss chamber. What a waste of time.  Eventually, I gave up on even trying to fight the bosses. Instead, I would clear the rest of the dungeon, unlock the boss chamber, and come back fifteen or twenty hours later to fight the boss. Occasionally, this resulted in a truly epic battle where I survived with a sliver of health. Sometimes, it was a tough but fair challenge. But it most often resulted in a pushover.  Then I got near the endgame (I think), and the game collapsed. I had done every bit of content I could find, and no matter where I went everything was too hard. The five headed dragon guarding the fourth shard? The remaining optional overworld bosses I had skipped?. The optional minidungeon I had skipped? The next legacy dungeon blocking the critical path? Everything was too hard, in every direction.  That was when I gave up, over a hundred hours in.  I probably *could* have cleared it by playing the game’s way, trying each challenge dozens of times, spending the majority of my playtime on loading screens and walking from respawn points to bosses and tough enemies. Or I could have embraced the fact that this is technically a JRPG and ground mobs for hours until I got another twenty  levels. But why? That’s not fun.  BUY OR NO BUY?  Overall, Elden Ring was a bizarre mix of really spectacular top-tier content and frustrating bullshit. This world design is everything I’ve wanted from an open world, so much better than other titles, and the combat is often fair and well-designed.  But the hostility to players who don’t already understand the systems and a terribly implemented “try over and over until you get it right” approach to boss design are really bad.  So should you play it? Well, if  you can mitigate the atrocious load times because you have a current-gen console or high-specs PC. Statistically, you probably don’t, but maybe you do.  You have a friend who already played the game and is willing to advise you.  You’re ok with giving up and not finishing the game.  If you have all this stuff, go for it. Otherwise, skip.  Final rating: 1/10. I feel weird giving a game I spent a hundred hours on such a poor review, but “it was eventually so frustrating I gave up” loses a lot of points. This is literally one of the greatest games I have ever played. Is it perfect? God no. There are plenty of things holding it back from being perfect.  And yet, Elden RIng is still a masterpiece. An awe-inspiring soundtrack, a map of incredible scope, and enough varied and unique encounters to fill up that map to the point that I can still pinpoint the location of wolves in Limgrave. Ridiculous levels of build variety allows for a great deal of replayability. A large cast of unique bosses, many of which have a mountain of buildup that, if you are paying attention, makes you feel like you are facing off against Gods and Titans that should be revered rather than slaughtered.   And, my personal favorite part of all this, Elden Ring is jam-packed with lore. There are ancient civilizations, long-lost deities, body-snatching demons, eldritch horrors, and yet the most pertinent questions that have rattled around in my head for the past year since the game launched pertains to the very characters that you can talk to in-game. If you are willing to sink in the time, you will realize that significant parts of the story do not add up, but hint at secrets to be solved.   Truly, this is a game that I hope developers come to learn from. Not copy, god, please don't copy. Just try and learn from what works, what doesn't work, and be inspired to push the boundaries even further.

First off, let me be clear by saying this game is absolutely phenomenal. If you have a really beefy computer. I can tell this is a game that would be one of my favorites of all time, due to some areas being less demanding and running well.   If you're like me and you have a computer only slightly above minimum requirements listed on steam, do not expect to have a good time. If there was a mixed option, I'd pick it, but there isn't so I can't.   This game barely runs at 720p on the lowest settings at an acceptable FPS, and often it will decide to stutter like crazy in some areas, many of those areas coming after you're likely to be eligible for a refund. There are many areas where the instant I walk into it my FPS dips below 10 and stays there, which makes the game run in slow motion. I have tried to the best of my ability to play through it, but I just can't in good faith recommend this to anyone on the fence about if their computer can handle it. I have not had performance nearly this bad in any other Fromsoft game. The minimum performance specs listed below are a lie and in reality you want a computer much better than that for it to run acceptably.  They really need to do better on these ports or at least list their specs more accurately.  EDIT: I managed to get more reliable and acceptable performance by editing my registry to boost the game's CPU priority. This is still a negative review since you should not have to mess with your registry to change CPU priority. Lmao.  After having beaten the game due to being able to not play in a world of slowed time, I can really say this game is incredible, though, so take this review as a recommendation if your computer is significantly better than minimum specs.  That being said, I really hope PC ports of this quality aren't reoccurring trends for Fromsoft.

Not worth the frustration. Devs are way too reliant on stun locking as "difficulty", enemies always scale to kill you in 2-3 attacks in each new zone and basically cheat, i.e. attacks going through terrain / walls, attacks that have large arcs or invisible areas of effect that don't require actual contact with your model, crappy camera and targeting exploited with cheap one shots, attacks that can't be blocked / parried, etc.. For all the people talking about how this game needs so much skill, they sure seem to miss the point where you don't need skill, it's 100% pattern recognition, and most of the videos you see about this game are meme builds or exploits that avoid the combat the game is somehow praised for. So many assets are re-used that if you can clear the first zone, you'll be set for 95% of the rest of the game. I'm so sick of fighting dragons I just roll my eyes when I see them now.  And then there are bugs. Quest lines can break because you teleported into a place, some NPCs don't appear because you *didn't* teleport into a place, quests that don't begin until you talk to a random NPC on the other side of a map with no indication they would know anything about it. Without the wiki you wouldn't know even half of what's in this game, and with it you just get frustrated by how half assed everything is. Quality of life is a completely foreign concept to these devs.

I don't recommend this game to casual players especially those who like to play with friends.    Like all souls games, unless you have hundreds of hours to dedicate to get good at this game it will only frustrate casual players who only have a couple hours a week of gaming time because, you know... life... additionally, though there is a large amount of lure in the game it does a horrific job at telling the story, finding quest givers and littered with translation errors that makes the lure even harder to understand.  script was written in japanese and translated to english... very poorly. even Youtube creators will comment how difficult piecing the story together is.  Furthermore, the game punishes you for playing multiplayer. the moment you enter or welcome a player to your game you are immediately open to invasions forcing you into unwanted pvp. LOTS of griefers in the starting area. don't play with friends if you're just a casual player or get the multiplayer mod (seemlesscoop) where you can play with friends and not deal with stupid unwanted pvp. some players are not into that and shouldn't be forced into it. the game has an arena for pvp, that should be enough...there is a play offline option but then you can't play co-op.  Thank god for modders fixing bad developer decisions.  games like these are always funner playing with friends, why the devs decided to punish you for it is something I will never understand.  another issue is that if you've never played a souls game before be prepared for extreme lack of instruction. there is a small tutorial that shows you how to swing your weapon and move around... aside from that, good luck, figure it out, you're on your own...  long story short. although I will continue playing the game I cannot in good conscious give this game a good review with all the poor development decisions made...

Game of the Year 2022. it deserves its recognition.  I have played every Fromsoft game at this point, and i can confidently say that i think that 'on average' this is by far the best game they have ever made. i say that because i would say that many of their titles seem to excel in 1 subject specifically as compared to Elden Ring.  i would say that;  -Dark Souls 1 has still the best Replayability,  -Bloodborne still captures the audience harder with its Gothic/Lovecraftian theme, setting, and narrative.   -Dark Souls 3 Contends a better Co-op experience, and an almost universally better PVP experience.   -Sekiro has a much more 'perfected' Gameplay (with a sheer lack in Variety due to lack of weapons)  that being said, if all of these other titles are a 10/10 in thier specific catagory of what they did right, the rest of the game doesnt add up to what Elden Ring has done. Elden Ring has made it so that every thing they did was a 8-9.5/10 so every thing about this game, is at least great, if not perfect. and then the sheer quantity of content in this Game easily dwarfs most of the other titles by a landslide. why Liurnia, Elden Rings 3rd Zone, which is only about 12% of its map. is aruably the same size as all of Dark Souls 1.  so to summarize. Elden ring isnt necessarily the best in very aspect compared to previous From Titles, i would however say that it is at least the 2nd best at everything those previous ones excelled at. and they delivered everything together is such sheer quality, and Quantity, that this is essentially one of the best games that I personally have ever played.  So all in all, I'd give Elden Ring (Pre-DLC) a 9.7/10

Game difficulty is set to lethal from the start which makes it hard and frustrating to learn, being one shot in the tutorial by a psuedo-boss at the end is saying something.  The game's design is very unusual as it shows a level of focus on killing the player that I have not experienced in other games, something that is apparent with the very high death count I've accrued.    I quantify my appreciation for this game in comparing it to Witcher 3, a game I played up to the hardest setting 'Death March' and logged over 1000 hrs.  In the first 30 minutes of Witcher 3 I found the game to be fun, interesting, and wishing to play more.  In the first 30 minutes of Elden Ring I found myself asking how is it I avoid dying in combat to exacting parry timers, advanced enemy AI, and vague scaling in enemy strength.    At this point I've cleared the Tree Sentinel and three minor bosses in caves, in lieu of satisfaction of achievement it's just the relief of one less thing trying to chase me down and kill me.  The encumbering system of relying on potions to recover and hoping to find the next respawn point mirrors the relief as treading water is a reality because everything respawns if you rest to refill the potions which can place a drag on progress.  I am skeptical that I will finish the game with the trend it carries on with.  I would say this game appeals to people who enjoy balancing on the edge of a knife, because it doesn't seem meant for the average gamer.  I had wondered why there were rage videos on Youtube for the game, while I can't say a game can incline me to such a response now I can feel sympathy for their irritation.

The game is great honestly, it has its downsides but they aren't that big of a deal. If you are new to a "Souls-like" then understand that the game is not meant to guide you through it, you are meant to explore, and be challenged by the enemies, so Expect to die, alot at that. after bashing your head against a boss a dozen times and finally beating them, you'll get a sense of true achievement. If an enemy is to hard then find a new path or explore a new area. The "Main Story" is elusive if you don't pay attention to dialogues and the cut scenes. and there are multiple endings based on how or what you do in the game. Perhaps to helping a Certain NPC or killing another will change the outcome. Again if you wanna be challenged try the game out with an open mind, and if you don't like Challenged... Elden Ring is a must-play for fans of action role-playing games. The combination of FromSoftware's renowned gameplay mechanics and George R. R. Martin's worldbuilding expertise results in a rich and immersive experience. The open world is vast and stunning, filled with interesting characters, challenging enemies, and hidden secrets to discover. The combat is satisfying and strategic, with a variety of weapons and magic spells at the player's disposal. The online multiplayer adds an extra layer of excitement, allowing players to join forces and tackle difficult battles together. The story is well-written, drawing players into the world of Elden Ring and making them feel invested in the journey to repair the titular Elden Ring and become the new Elden Lord. Overall, Elden Ring is a triumph of game design, delivering an unforgettable experience that will keep players entertained for hours on end.

Difficult, but absolutely beautiful to play, and only difficult if you're getting greedy with your attacks! Very intuitive to work out what you need to do - even if you're not the best gamer!
As with any game with a dodge-roll, there's only two ways to make it difficult; adding jank or forcing the player to avoid multiple attacks at once. Elden Ring goes for the former, adding start-up frames to your dodge roll and large, lingering hitboxes for enemy attacks. There's a large amount of recycled content, hitbox issues when using small weapons, and rather linear progression despite trying to be an open-world. My final issue is that because FromSoftware is always trying to one-up the difficulty of the game, bosses end up having infinitely extendable combos, punishing you for trying to learn a boss and squeeze as many hits out as possible. This issue is only exacerbated by certain near-undodgeable attacks, such as Margit's/Morgott's triple swing, Godrick's wind gust start-up, and Radagon's elden shattering.
.
I absolutely adore this game, the graphics are beautiful, and make me wish I myself were exploring the lands between. The gameplay is much like other dark souls games, but much smoother, and in my opinion, engaging. The story is like that of no other, and the game doesn't feed you any of the lore, its scattered throughout item descriptions, quests, cutscenes, and other npc dialouge. The game promotes exploration and even gives you tools to help on your journy, such as torrent, the goat horse thing, your spectral steed who will take you through the lands between. The game has so many build options, you can practically play the game any way you like. All characters have some kind of lore for you to find, the music in this game is also another point that I'd like to cover, it is absolutely stunning. All in all, I would reccomend this game a thousand times over, but keep in mind it is still a souls game, so expect difficulty, but do not break, I believe in you all my fellow tarnished, and I wish you luck in your adventures in seeking out the Elden Ring.

Elden Ring is the first first souls/souls-like game I have ever played and it does not leave a good impression on the genre and the team at From Software. For a game released in 2022 It is about 10 years behind what would be expected for this era of gaming. Firstly this game is capped at 60 fps which is a sheer let down, even new gen consoles can run at 120+ fps so they had literally no excuse. Even the PC community was able to fix this within a few days of release so it cant of been that hard for a AAA gaming studio. (using the communities fix removes all online features which is why I did not use it). Furthermore the PC port for Elden Ring is terrible, controls are clunky and clearly designed for controllers, fortunately you can rebind right, well yes you can but From Software managed to fuck this up as well leaving PC players with minimal options compared to other games. If any other AAA game was released in this state they would be ridiculed beyond belief by the community. In conclusion the technical aspects of this game are severely dated for this generation of gaming and there is no one else to blame but the team at From Software and their incompetence to produce a game even mildly up to standard with the times.

They stuffed ambush, mini-boss fights, and all sorts of shenangians in every corner of the map. Whenever you feel like exploring, you just end up dying from unnecessary surprises. The devs want you to die every five minutes or so. Oh, look what a nice view over there, let's go check it out. Whoops, a crucible knight jumps out of nowhere and obliterates you. As soon as you die, the game respawns all enemies and you lose your progress. The bosses are ludicrously aggressive and don't play by the same rules as you do.   I am not whining because I couldn't beat them. I destroyed every one of them, even the disgustingly crazy Goddess of Rot fight. Check my achievements if you don't believe me. Those fights aren't enjoyable and you just want to get it over worth as soon as possible.   The devs built such a beautiful world. Unfortunately, they only want you to have PTSD rather than an enjoyable experience.

What an incredible journey, I finally completed Elden Ring almost one year after buying it and 100+ hours. I really enjoyed this one, it was one of those games I thought about and wondered what to do next even when not playing it. After completing it I started Playthrough 2 and I'm excited to travel back through the lands again. The community are brilliant and helped carry me through some of the more difficult bosses. As a Dark Souls fan this game took some of the best parts from the series with new improvements and changes and made it into a huge open world.
I'm very surprised by the variety in mechanics, the landscape and the level of thought given to the quests (and consequences of said quests). The theme and story of the game is overall quite dark, but that was to be expected.  Great game with boss fights that force you to think, usually there isn't just one best solution. If you like to be challenged this is the right game for you. Can't wait for more!

I usually play Fantasy RPG with vibrant-themed world. Ive trid Dark Souls on my friend's PC and its really hard for a first timer into Fromsoftware games. You can easily hardlocked into a boss and cant progress without defeating it first, and the world is grim from the start. In Elden Ring you can appreciate the beuty of the world first before seeing the grim part of it, and it'll make you appreciate the lore behind it more. and when you struggling with a boss you can go somewhere else and make you character stronger as well knowing the games mechanic while doing so. The only boss required to progress the story is at the end of the story and by then you will already know the game's mechanics and character build is done. good
Before starting the actual review, huge thanks to [b]director: Hidetaka Miyazaki[/b], [b]writer: George R. R. Martin[/b] and last but not least the [b]development team: FromSoftware[/b] for creating this beautiful and still "git gud" challenging video game for us to enjoy.  Also congratulation for winning the [b]The Game Awards 2022 - Game of the Year[/b] and the [b]Steam Awards 2022 - Game of the Year[/b] trophies at least (on top of the bunch of other awards).  TL;DR If you have liked the previous Dark Souls games or looking for real challenge from a action RPG genre, you just don't have any excuses for NOT to playing the [b]ELDEN RING[/b]. [b][u]It's that awesome and worth of every single coin you put into it.[/u][/b]  For those who haven't tried out any of previous Dark Souls related games, I really recommend you to give it a try. Like previous games Elden Ring gives you life lessons of not giving up when you face the impossible obstacle, there is always solution to get pass that, even if it means making decisions that are not easy.  Started playing with Intel i7-8700K & RTX 3080 -> a bit over middle way through upgraded to AMD 7600X & RTX 3080.  This review is written in POV of character with following setup (can contain spoilers);  [spoiler]Magic caster (lvl 165 50,50,30,13,13,70,8,10), no summons & spirit/war ashes used, no parrying, no great runes activated, no PVP, Malenia and every other boss beaten in single playthrough, zero respeccing, zero guides watched.[/spoiler]   [h2][b]Story & Graphics and Environment[/b][/h2] Following the similar path as the previous [b]FromSoftware[/b] games, the [b]Elden Ring[/b] moves story forward via cutscenes and having conversations with NPC's. You won't get every necessary detail right away, but inspecting the environment, NPC's told stories and item texts, give you at least some knowledge of this vast, mystic and gruesome story and game lore.  To get the whole picture, I recommend watching an video from YouTube after finishing the game. I will guarantee you'll be shocked to find some of the NPC lore and backgrounds later.  The game doesn't include a "Quest-tracker" itself, but some guidance is provided by the map. This means you might accidentally skip some "cool side-quests". To those who really want to see every bit of story, I recommend following community tools like Wiki or YT videos.  Once opening the first doors, you'll be welcomed to the 'the Lands Between'. The visuals and environment almost made me cry, for just being alive to experience this kind of magnificent graphical output. It's just so life-like and unreal at the same time. Being playing at the same time couple other open-world RPG games but their visual output isn’t even near what [b]Elden Ring[/b] is able to produce.  Few YT channel recommendations (not all Lore related): [url=https://www.youtube.com/@VaatiVidya/videos]VaatiVidya[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLVxgcx0CKkjo9lE40sUdRjhTHfF6XORub]Zullie the Witch[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/@ymfah/videos]ymfah[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/@Fextralife/playlists]Fextralife[/url].     [h2][b]Gameplay[/b][/h2]  What can I say, the 'git gud' mentality will get you eventually. The game sets quite early that world isn't fair for you. You'll encounter many enemies and bosses with different movement, attack patterns alike, which some may be easy for your current build. Eventually you'll face the most absurd obstacle where it can get frustrated to continue. But be smart, learn from your mistakes and change/upgrade few things and brake through like a wrecking ball.   Movement was the very key of my playthrough, and the Light/Medium armor sets felt at the end the best option. There is definitely better ways to play out than my way, but after unlocking certain "mixture", magic felt overpowered as I was able to Kamehame-haa the bosses straight to face and beat it under 10 seconds (this said thou I was also in some cases way above the enemies or the area level itself).  Guarantee there is some even brain dead builds available on lower level to beat every boss of the game but that is the main aspect of the gameplay itself. You have the vast variety of options to move, attack, defend and ease the gameplay to the max if necessary.  This is also the thing I'd like to see in other open-world RPG genre games in the future. [b]*Cough*, other AAA-game studios, please other take notes and put them into your games, but not behind a paywall.. Thank you.[/b]   [h2][b]Soundtrack[/b][/h2]  Once you start the game, your ears are going to bleed of liquefied diamonds. It is like a another dimension gods were living just to place every track preciously to time freeze bubble, so once you step inside of it. You're the one who lives the moment of an epic tale of the game.  Soundtrack is an masterpiece of an composer work from [b]Tsukasa Saitoh, Shoi Miyazawa, Tai Tomisawa, Yuka Kitamura, and Yoshimi Kudo[/b] and the orchestra work from The Budapest Film Orchestra. Do check out the [url=https://bandainamco.lnk.to/Elden_Ring_ST]Official Soundtrack[/url] even if you haven't purchased the game yet.   [h2][b]Conclusion[/b][/h2]  [b]ELDEN RING is the best game ever made on year 2022 (and probably 2023).[/b] Buy it, play it, enjoy it, suffer from it and git gud you [b]Tarnished one[/b].

I could try to write an essay on how much I love this game and how much I recommend it, but honestly, that's stupid.  It's been forever since a AAA game managed to meet any kind of expectations, and this far surpassed mine.  I'm a huge souls fan. If you love soulsborne games, you'll love this. If you want to try a game in the genre, this is the perfect entry point.  Replayability is near infinite, the world is huge and dense, the art design is gorgeous, the lore is fascinating, the bosses are insanely fun and the music is phenomenal.  This is a truly special and rare type of game that only comes around once in a while. Elden Ring doesn't necessarily innovate or break new ground for the souls series or open world games, but it damn near perfects the formula in my opinion.  I like this game a lot, and I think you will too.
There will never be another game like this. Ever. It deserved all of the awards it won and more. Never has a game left me with such emptiness after I beat it. After the credits rolled I genuinely asked myself "What now?" and the answer was obvious. Play it again.

A LONG game, and is longer than you think it will be. But SO satisfying and SO good and just GOTY hands down.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As a huge fan of previous fromsoft games i regret not playing Elden Ring earlier. You may look at this games graphics and think its from 2016 or something but when you start playing it instantly encapsulates you and feels a lot better than most of the newer games. Art style and ambiance is fascinating. I regularly find myself just running around and viewing the beatiful scenery without doing anything else. It shows that artists are really the masters of their craft. I also love how fromsoft use music in their games. Its really something magical. Combat is super fluid and satisfying. Open world is amazing, exploring is extremely enjoyable. Weapon variety, ashes of war and sheer number of skills you can get makes the character customization a lot deeper than other fromsoft games and its really fun to try different things on the run. While its probably not so optimal, if you are just exploring every little nook and cranny you'll probably over-level and faceroll the bosses anyway so dont shy and try different things! Haven't finished it yet but i can already tell this will be one of the best games i've ever played.
One of the best what else can you say? I have two different characters with 80+ hours on my xbox and about 3 splitting my 119 hours on the pc. Super fun, runs well, and multiplayer is fun if you can get into it.
I want to go home 
I was never really a soulsborne fan. I played DS1 and DS2 back when they first came out and hated the games. I wasn't accustomed to the playstyle nor the difficulty. Jump forward about a decade, I'm older and more patient. Watched my buddies play the game, figure I would give it a try. Short of 200 hours played, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Visually stunning, fun and challenging combat, a large variety of weapons and builds. I'm on my 4th playthrough and I am going to try to get as much of the lore as I can.   Long story short, if you are a Soulsborne fan, buy Elden Ring. If you are not, come back in a couple of years and try them again. You may find your opinion of the game type has changed.

Tato hra je totální master piece  Elden ring byla má první hra od vývojářského studia From Software a musím říct, že na mě studio udělalo obrovský dojem a hry od něj budu hrát i nadále. Ale co podle mě Elden Ring udělalo natolik úžasným?  World: Postupné objevování světa je skvělé a až na výjimky se už od začátku můžeme dostat kamkoliv, což ve hrách vždy rád vidím, ale v Elden Ringu mě to potěšilo ještě více svojí různorodostí, až už travnatý a hornatý Lim Grave, pustý a děsivý Caelid, jezernatá Liurnia či jednoduše nádherná Siofra. Všechno to jsou opravdu krásně vybudované a obsahem narvané lokace ,u kterých se vám oči ani prsty nudit nebudou. Každá nabízí své unikátní nepřátele i atmosféru, která by se dala krájet. Jak rád bych opět zažil ten pocit co jsem měl při prvním spuštění. Ten pocit po touze objevovat a prozkoumat ten svět, který se předemnou právě otevřel do posledního koutku. A že má co nabídnout. I po spuštění NG+ se mi podařilo najít lokace o jejichž existenci jsem do teď neměl ani páru. K lokacím mám jen jednu jedinou výtku a to směrem k Weeping Peninsula, která toho dle mého nemá zas tolik co nabídnout, ale zase nechci říkat, že by se jednalo o něco špatného.  Gameplay: Postava je krásně responzivní, reaguje přesně jak klikám a ani jednou se mi nestalo, že by opravdu dělal něco co sem nechtěl. U každého špatného rollu jsem věděl, že je to má chyba, stejně tak u každého pádu při platformové pasáži. Možná ovládání Torrenta je trochu prkené. Ovládání v soubojích je jednoduché na pochopení, příjemné a na ovládání. Ještě bych chtěl vypíchnout jak hra přistupuje k questům. Žádně question marky, které mi ukazují kam mám jít. Nic takového v Elden Ringu nenajdete. Sice možná některé questy budete procházet dle návodů na Wiki/YTB, ale to mi vůbec nevadilo. Naopak mě to těšilo tím jak hra není zbytečně zahlcená a není tam nic zbytečně navíc. Dále bych chtěl zmínit summons, kterých je ve hře opravdu dost. Postupem času odemykáte lepší. Summons můžete získat u traderů nebo z bossů. Které si pak vylepšujete stejně jako zbraně.  Příběh: Osobně bych řekl, že studiem loru jsem strávil ještě víc času než na hře samotné. Propracovaná historie a malinkaté detaily, které ho doplňují, mě uchvátili více jak jakákoliv fantasy kniha či film co jsem kdy viděl. George Raymond Richard Martin odvedl při tvorbě tohoto světa naprosto fenomenální práci. Dobrá práce Georgi  Finální verdikt: I přes to, že bych o Elden Ringu byl schopen mluvit dlouhé hodiny, udělám to jak stručně jen můžu: 11/10 +příběh/Lore +mechanika hry +prostředí +grafika +soundtracks ... Užijte si tento mistrovský kousek

If you have played other Fromsoft games - you already know what to expect. More or less same formula, just way, way better.  If you are not a "souls" fan, but like the look of this game, I would suggest:  1) Ignore the willy waving macho BS of the online fanboys.  2) Play offline. I have no desire to become part of some 16 year old's fantasy, and I find that there is more than enough to keep one interested in single player mode.  3) If you find the game difficult, there are mods for the PC version that can help you. (See points 1 and 2).  4) There are several really good walk through guides on YouTube to help you avoid walking around aimlessly :-)

This is my first true FromSoft game. I own DarkSouls 3, but didn't get invested into it until right before playing this game at the same time as my friends. My friends and I decided to play this game without looking anything up on the internet for help. I beat the final boss and have started to look things up for the first time. This is a very fun game when playing with the correct attitude. You die a lot, it's part of the game. You sacrifice your life to learn something new, you purposefully lose your runes during the next attempt at the boss so they don't distract you the next several attempts at beating it, you try, try, try again, then tweak setups before trying more. I really have enjoyed playing this game, and I hope to enjoy playing it more now that I can learn things from others online.   As a side note: I have no idea what just happened plot wise... game is pretty vague in the plot department if you don't know where/how to pay attention.

dog!
My overall take: Wow. Where to even start. This is the first souls game I have ever played. I come from playing games like Destiny 2, Horizon Zero Dawn, Mass Effect, etc. Sometime the games being "hard". I did not know what hard was until I played this game. Nor have I ever had this much of challenge for a game. Other games are somewhat challenging, but this one tests your skills. Some of you will be slightly frustrated, some angry, and a select few give up the game when you keep trying to kill the sentinel at the starting area. But those who don't you will find yourself comparing other games to this game. Once you complete elden ring, every game you play after this will be a cake walk. This is a fantastic game. The world is so large with all sorts of enemies and items littered around the area. You actually have an incentive to explore in order to face the next boss. None of the quests are pointless skinned objectives. Every level up and item you get will bring you a step closer to becoming lord.   Aspects: The parts that relieve you from the frustration is the messages on the ground. They can be helpful, but sometimes they can be funny and humorous. Read them when you have the chance. The number of main quests in this game aside from the linear story, are all meaningful and have purpose. The Items depending on your combat style will help you in your progress. Find Bell items to help get more items to level up your weapons. Explore the world. You spend plenty of time leveling up to get to the next boss. You might as well explore.   The World:  This game shows that art style is supreme when presenting a game. It may not be bringing your console or pc to its knees because of its graphics, but it beautiful in its own unique way. There will be times you just stop to admire how beautiful the game is. The world is so big. I didn't realize there was an underground area until mid way through my playthrough. There is so much in this world. You can spend hundreds of hours and you will never see all of it.   Combat:  Skill is everything. Be mindful and strategic. You can spam if you want but be strategic about it. Find the way you like to fight at the beginning of the game and not further in. I learned using a regular axe of the most the way until midway then I switched weapon type and took some time to learn. Long story short find the way you like to fight and stick with it, while improving your skills.   End Review:   I have never played a game that required this much skill. I was frustrated many times, but when you beat a boss it is so rewarding and feels great. I hope you all enjoy the journey to become the Elden Lord.

111 hours and I'm not recommending it. Good God.  Pros: Level design, character design, environment art, music: all of these are top-tier and will keep you going throughout a very long journey.  Cons: People confuse obfuscation with mystery and bad UX with challenge. To complete this game, you will have to consult a wiki. Not because it is hard (which it is) but because they do very little to tell you where your objectives are. Perhaps they expect you to endlessly wander around the world in hopes you bump into that NPC again. If they put them on the critical path line, maybe that would happen but it is often just in a random spot. That isn't serendipity; it's just being opaque. Maybe the nonsense story would make a bit of sense if information was organized or if there was a basic quest tracker. I don't need a bunch of UI elements to tell me exactly where something is, just try and respect the player a little bit. Did you know that you essentially have to upgrade HP more than any other stat or you will be one-shotted by nearly everything in the game? Would be nice to know, especially since you can only recast your stats halfway-ish through the game.  Speaking of respecting the player, if you are going to be tough as nails, you have to be spotlessly bug free. Unfortunately, attacks go through solid objects at random and frame drops will eat your lunch at the worst possible times. There's little joy when you eventually succeed; just relief that an annoying element is done. Luckily, you can often beat bosses by tricking the AI or leveraging a bug in the environment so I guess two can play at that game.   And who decided that this game where the character rightly feels like he is wearing forty pounds of armor should be a platformer?   I'm happy I roughed my way through it, but I can't see myself recommending it to anyone. It's an interesting game, but not what the incredibly toxic community exalts it as. It's a bleak game with a few truly exquisite moments outweighed by a preponderance of slog. And now I'm finally free of it.

yes
Elden Ring is a Challenging yet rewarding experience as you traverse through large open world landscapes permeating with enemies and bosses of all different shapes, sizes and attack styles. The game (much like the soulsbourne series in general) is an excellent personification of life itself. Focusing on a format where through your many struggles and setbacks, if you learn from your mistakes and persevere, you will prevail. Their are multiple different classes to choose that allow you to play the game how you see fit, so their is no right or wrong way to play and is purely up to player on how best to approach a situation and to embrace or strategise your strengths and weaknesses. The game is also very well polished (a rarity in modern gaming) with clear forethought in its design, very minimal bugs were present in my play through and the combat seems very well balanced. The story is conveyed mostly through lore, requiring the player to research the details of the characters and they're history, ambitions & goals to create a better understand of the world. Some may be disappointed in its lack of presence but personally this works in favour of the game, as its there if you are interested to learn, and if you're not then just carry on and it won't matter (Radahn has the best backstory btw). needless to say I adore Elden Ring and look forward to seeing more from Fromsoftware :)  tl;dr Overall Elden Ring is easily the best way to get into the Soulsbourne series of games, its challenging yet rewarding, has fairly balanced combat, the open world is mesmerising, extensive lore. their is lots to love about this game   10/10   GOTY for 2022
First time going into a dark souls like game not really knowing what to expect but boy did this game blow my mind out of the waters. Great game. Great setting. Great story :)

what the fuck
This is the worst FromSoft game I have ever played, and the second worst Soulslike behind Salt and Sanctuary.  I am so disappointed.  Moving to an open world has absolutely killed all joy, all tension, all skill and hardship that defined the Souls series. I am completely alone in a bland, empty world with no noteworthy npcs, copy pasted dungeons, the ability to completely invalidate entire sections of the map by accidentally leveling up (you know, playing the game) or just spawning a summon that dumpsters any boss.  Open world worked in the Witcher because it had a story, and characters to make the world feel alive or at least give you a purpose for what you are doing.  Not to mention that it looked and played far better with better quality of life inclusions.  Riding a horse sucks, scanning the map so you don't miss important items or entire NPC questlines sucks.  Enemy design is a joke where they will literally have a seizure if you hit them too much.  You can't compare shop items to ones equipped because this game was apparently designed in 1997.  FromSoft tried to shove a square peg into a triangular hole and failed miserably.  If the next game is this sloppy I don't see a future for FromSoft other than a dead company or an Activisionesque shit pusher.

i'm very new to elden ring (this is my first fromsoft game!) so i'm still getting destroyed by most enemies and making mistakes as i learn the game, but even with the many deaths i've had so far i've been having so much fun! there's lots to do here as the open world is incredibly expansive, the animation looks great, and the ost is a banger.
I didn't play any of the souls games prior to this, but heard good reviews from this so tried it. And even in the first few minutes I got bored, the graphics felt cheap to me like pubg for some reason and the controls weird (Who jumps with F instead of space and selects OK with E and back with Q?).   But as I played just 30 mins more the next day and faced my first boss it kicked off, I started to see what it was about. There is nothing more satisfying than failing a boss multiple times, getting stronger and more skilled and finally beating it after an hour. I saw the attention to detail in the story lines, the beauty of certain cut scenes and scenic points, and the sheer size of the map to explore.   And don't forget the amount of freedom the game offers you. You can customise your character and it's combat style to the smallest detail. And it does not have to stay that way, I changed from a tank class to a sorcerer in just a matter of minutes because I enjoyed that style more. You are not constantly reminded of quests you accepted. So you have to remember which made me form a bond with those characters by making them the focus instead of just completing to get items. I've watched some of the lore people have got on youtube to expand my knowledge of this world even more. And the story has multiple endings (as I've heard) from the choices you make. An RPG in its truest essence.  I can now truly see the love and effort the developers put into this game, and see it as a form of art and an experience worth the time and money. I can wholeheartedly recommend this game, one of my best by far.

10/10
This review is written from a (perspective) run I tried to do with a standard classic greatsword playthru with no summons, incarnation,passive buildups which open up my eyes on ER flaws a lot more:    The Main Bosses aka the Legendary Bosses that you are required to beat are honestly not that fun or satisfying.  It seem like they all share the same type of behaviour:  -spam every attack possible with little to no cooldown in-between each attack and ability.  -leave a 0.5 second window for the player to both react on and deal damage in -Evade if the player is close to them for more then 2 seconds. -have a back/tail attack if you manage to out-maneuver them and strike from behind. -Still being able to instantly kill you even with 60+ Vigor.   And even when you manage to outplay them they will find a way to punish you. Out of all main bosses that I played against the only ones that was fun more me was Godfrey and Rykard.  The mid to late game bosses are some of the most dull and annoying encounters as well:  Radahn: Honestly not the worst but just feel like a chore if anything. Draconic Tree sentinel: I mean its already a tree sentinel reskin with just some added abilites that they spam even more with. Morgott: Spam and very small attack windows if you try to avoid damage. Fire giant: ridiculous large arena and tanky HP. You are not even fighting a boss, just its feet.  God skin duo: Reskin fight of the Godskins noble but you have to fight 2 instead of just 1 and you need to kill both of them twice.  Makelith. Spam.  There is to much waiting and too little combat cause of all the spam attacks and Evades.  This also leaves a lot of weapon types unviable for PVE cause of how slow you attack with them. By the time you started your swing animation with something like a colossal sword the boss could already gotten 5 hits on you.    I am not saying its impossible to beat them with standard "balanced true-soul experience gameplay" builds But its not fun   Fromsoftware balanced the game way to much around co-op and arcane/int/ability builds it indirectly nerfed standard sword and no-abilites meele gameplay which is a bummer.  On my first playthrough all I used was a katana with bleed buildup and scarlet rot dragon ability and it was pretty much ggs.  +Game is still really fun +there is so much to do +Good replayability  +Fun and intresting side quests as well side quest bosses +tons of different builds and playstyles you can do and test out (even if some of them are straight up busted or really underwhelming without specific items)   In the end of the day ER is primarily a RPG game so it make sense to a degree the way its balanced and designed  If you however want something that offer a more linear and rewarding basic melee gameplay you should probably look into DS3 or Sekiro.
