It's an OK game but unfortunately I found it EXTREMELY grindy. As a relative newbie to the souls games, having only played some early stages of Sekiro when visiting a friend, I didn't quite know what to expect. The online debate didn't miss me so the mantra of "tough but fair" was definitely familiar. Bulletpoints: - the combat is entertaining but unfortunately my reflexes aren't as sharp as they used to be so I can't say I found it particularly enjoyable. It ultimately relies way too much on grind to compensate for slower than average response times. While I understand the logic of git gud and I did invest a lot of time into the game in the end the mechanic of farming plebs for level up points un-engaging. Even if I ultimately bailed, the purist are right about no difficulty slider, and the amount of time i sunk into it shows that the gameplay loop is more than good enough. - the story is meh, pretentious drivel or maybe it's just not for me. - the atmosphere works but not really something to write home about. It wasn't one of those things that had me giddy to open the game again, but maybe it's just that dreary isn't something I search for in my free time.  By the time I realized killing dragons wasn't triggering a spark of emotion I had to accept that it was time to stop. Not recommending the game only because 60$ for a game not worth finishing that also relies a lot on fast reflexes and persistence seems a bit steep. Felt the same with Sekiro when I had to kill 10 mobs covertly before I could attempt the larger boss, Doing it once was exciting, but by the time I beat the boss, it was like a 3-4 minute chore I have to do before I was allowed to actually enjoy the game.

10/10  Pros: •	Perfect visual and music •	Spectacular combination of open-world with traditional Soulsborne locations •	Challenging and rewarding combat •	Quests require exploration Cons: •	Boss AI frequently gets stuck •	Lots of repetitive bosses •	Some attacks and combos are almost impossible to evade •	Ping in PVP is frustrating •	Sometimes crashes  Summary: Even hearing people complaining that the game is a Dark Souls 4, I can simply say that it is not just a Dark Souls 4. It’s the Dark Souls 4 in open-world, with plot easier to grasp and a combination of the best features and mechanics from previous games. Generally, its not as perfect as DSIII, but taking into consideration me playing the former years after release, and this game just after the first day patch, after some updates it would receive a 10/10. 
It's pretty great, I would recommend to anyone looking for a challenging RPG.

Makes you feel like a kid playing video games for the first time. The world is vast and strange, exploring it is exciting and scary at the same time. The graphics and music are amazing. Combat is relatively easy to understand but hard to execute well, after a while you realize how much variety there is and it will drive you to explore new ways of playing.   It is an adventure game with some of the best combat systems out there. There is not an easy to follow story, you will piece things together as you play. The more you pay attention and search for it, the more you will understand and enjoy the lore. You don't have to though, the game is amazing however you choose to enjoy it.

GOTY
I get that a lot of people like this game, and there are many likable things about it. It's certainly a complete and high quality game (unlike most games released these days). The early sequence with the castle is great, exploring was fun... sometimes. But unfortunately this is a wiki-game. I'm gonna compare this a lot to BotW because that was a good open world game. If you're not playing a basic strength build or know how to find the overpowered weapons you're guaranteed to have a bad time.   The rpg mechanics are fundamentally unfun here. If you put points in multiple stats to use cool new items you will just have an incredibly weak character. Instead focus on only one stat and use almost no items. Great thanks, love that. Imagine if that happened in BotW? I guess the idea is to make more than one character. But nah. I'm good.   But then the real fail is still coming. So far, these issues existed in DS3 & DS1, but those games are still incredible. So why is this one particularly awful? *  This is such a wiki-game it hurts. The summoning bell is given randomly at night time at the first bonfire. What an incredibly dumb decision. Why does it feel like this game was designed to randomly make some people have a good time and for some people the game will be unplayable? This didn't happen to me, I was able to buy the bell at firelink shrine for some reason. There are many more examples of dumb shit like this. *  Open world does us no favors here. Randomly stuck in crystal cave with only enemies that one shot me? Why? Copy paste dungeons with weak rewards. I snooze. Breath of the wild shrines were always unique and interesting. An endless array of locked doors to which I must randomly find keys? Why?  Okay so you want me to explore. I'll try that. Crossed a bridge, fought some giants. That was pretty fun, cool stuff. Now what, it seems to be a dead end. Do I need to go inside the bridge? Jump at a certain angle? There must be a secret I missed somewhere. No, it turns out this is a place you can go to after you beat Godrick. Otherwise it's a waste of time.  How twisted is this. You want me to explore an 'open world' but in reality you want me to randomly stumble to find the intended linear path.  Just take assets and give me DS4 instead. I thought I might just follow a walkthrough so I could experience it without the tedious metroidvania openworld dogshit. But it just feels like a chore to be honest. A wiki-game will always be a wiki-game. Can put this one in the same bucket as dwarf fortress. It really pains me to bash Elden Ring since so many other people seem to like it. I liked DS1 & DS3 so I thought I would be like them. But alas, I am not.

9.5/10  Absolutely incredible, I love it to bits, and it may even be my favorite game EVER(Breath of The Wild being it's competitor. We'll have to see If Tears of the kingdom can best either though.) I'd say it's a must have if you love open world games, though if you don't enjoy the punishing difficulty, I Suggest going to nexus mods and downloading an easy Elden Ring mod. Or at the very least, a mod that rebalances the game. I have no doubt that many may find that statement blasphemy, but I believe it's fine as long as the user is having fun.    I do have one issue though, and that is how quests are handled. A concerning amount of quests in the game, perhaps even most of them, are incredibly hard to follow. Really the only one that's easy to follow is the default main story quest. Most others require incredible luck, unending wit, or a simple google search for a guide. If they included a quest book of sorts, with simply reminding you of what npcs have said, and some slight nudges in the right direction, it would improve the game greatly. I'd go as far as to give it a 10/10 if there was.  TL;DR I fully recommend it. I love it dearly, despite not having even finished it, and give it a 9.5/10. It would be 10/10, if they included a quest book, and perhaps some much needed rebalancing.

10/10 Marriage Simulator.
I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Elden Ring and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Getting to NG+5 on the non steam version, I can definitely say I've played a lot more than my steam hours states. This game has got to be one of my favourite games in terms of how it just seems to grab my attention at every moment. I always have a goal to reach, a quest to complete, a skill to hone.  Always having something to strive towards, that changes as frequently as it does in elden ring is something truly wonderful - it's never a dull moment - and is one of the few progression-based games I can confidently say I have not gotten tired of after a few hundred hours. DLC to come soon I hear, so I will be looking forward to that, but for now - community creations are splendid for adding a little bit more to the game that you just needed, such as; different combat styles, gameplay changes, difficulties, graphics, fixes, styles and presets  10/10 gameplay (difficult if you want it to be, easy if you want it to be) 10/10 graphics (actual game areas are visually splended; but in terms of just graphics itself, you can also mod in high quality textures, meshes and RTGI if you feel it doesn't suit your needs) 7/10 performance (some VERY small bugs you may run into once in your entire playthrough, as well as some slight FPS stuttering in certain areas {both fixable with mods})  Would 9/10 recommend to everyone, I'll save that extra 1 for that specific audience that seems to always despise souls-type games.

Rather than explain why Elden Ring is great (it is if it wasn't obvious), I wanted to use this review to highlight two incredible mods for the game: Seamless co-op (which makes full co-op exploration and progression possible) and Elden Ring Reforged (rebalances several mechanics/weapons/skills/etc., adds difficulty scaling, adds a semblance of "classes", adds content, and more). Both mods have elevated the experience for me beyond the vanilla experience, and I highly recommend them even if you're just starting out.

gud game
Elden Ring is basically an open world version of the Dark Souls games with some serious improvements. The first improvement being there's a story at play that doesn't require heavy investment into paying attention to the item description based lore. That lore is still there, so don't get that crossed. The second huge improvement is that there's real platforming to do, though it only plays out in fights or boss battles some of the time. Most combat isn't much different than in the Souls titles, however, we've a dedicated jump button, ash summons, and several other tools at play we didn't in those other games. Would go on, but I'm pretty sure most people already know what to expect of a Souls-like game. My only word of warning is that this isn't Dark Souls. It's much easier if you wanna make it easier. It's also much harder if you wanna make it harder. By which I mean Elden Ring is really Dark Souls with options. A lot of different options to every fight and choice you make in game just about.  The PC version at this point in time is the best place to play Elden Ring in my opinion. Runs very smoothly. That said, I'm writing this at 200+ hours and leaving only the last boss to beat. (It seems like there's a lot of things in the PC version of the game that isn't on the console versions, though I'm not mentioning any of that because I'm uncertain if it's due to the updates since launch or not.)
It's ok
One of the best games I ever played, even with the boss repetition and some horrible design choices, it still stands high as a masterpiece, though I have to warn you: THIS ISN'T DARK SOULS 3, and if you play it as dark souls 3, you will suffer. Most of the negative reviews I've seen face this issue, they say the game is unfair because their roll spam doesn't work, when the game literally punishes that, this is elden ring, use the new mechanics to your advatage and not just try to replay ds3 2 but ow.

(Had to put up review because I'm at 69 hours)  Some pros:  *Spectacular open world, without overbearing markers and logs, emphasizing exploration. *Memorable, distinct atmosphere and design. *You can tell there's worldbuilding of unusual quality hiding in the background (probably GRRM work). *Excellent, well-balanced combat which rewards you for paying attention and preparing. *Best game since Witcher 3.  Some cons: *Performance issues on PC (mostly stuttering) *The difficulty curve, and how you progress through the game, is somewhat poorly executed and balanced, but it's fine. *Probably not the best UI and control scheme. *A lot of players who think the high difficulty means they're special for beating the game.  10/10 Game

The greatest FromSoftware game I've ever played and the best open world RPG. Everywhere I go there's something to find some new boss to fight some new weapon, a new incantation, sorceries, bows, shields just something worth finding and the good feeling I get when I do so. This game has attached itself to  the receivers in my brain that have turned into ELDEN RING receivers instead. The first 40 hours of the game are honestly the best experience I've had in a while and I wouldn't trade it for anything else.     There is a reason why I said the first 40 hours though, after leaving the capital city, Leyndell, the quality takes a dip. And a DIP at that. Most bosses I saw in very special places and got to fight at the end of long questlines are just in mines and out in the open just sitting there for no reason. In the early game whenever I got to see a big enemy I always wanted to fight and best them but in the snow covered mountaintops all I've ever done is just wave past with Torrent.   I think the issues in the game can be fixed, but the community's point of view towards issues are also something to be wary of. The "hardest" fight, Malenia, is barely hard if  you're using every tool the game gives you to beat her. The reason a lot of the bosses in the game feel like they were made for Sekiro and not Elden Ring and there being no way (literally no way, like there isn't a single way you don't take damage in some bosses' attacks) is because you aren't using Spirit Ashes to pull aggro from the boss, which seems like that's what they were balanced towards. However, I will agree that spirit ashes feel like you're "cheating" towards the latter stages of the game (especially mimic) and balancing them will no doubt prove extremely difficult for FromSoftware.      Overall, this game is the greatest open world RPG to come out in 2022 and before that and I reckon it will stay that way for a while.

Waiting for DLC...
This game is beautiful, but once I got to the Mountaintops, I stopped being able to appreciate it.  Elden Ring's -- like the Dark Souls series before it -- is a combat system built on limitations. Every offensive and defensive option is carried out with either stamina or focus (that is, if you're using magic or ashes of war.) You've also got input buffering to deal with, where button presses have a noticeable delay, and the game registers every input, which WILL lead to accidental panic rolls, drinking flasks one too many times, and doing a mistaken follow-up R2 after doing a jump attack.  It's a feature endlessly at odds with the committal controls. You can't cancel your animations, so a good handful of player deaths are a result of people failing to account for an enemy's unavoidable punisher(s) while they're stuck in some animation. This wouldn't be such an issue if enemies didn't all have uniquely rapid combos they can chain together endlessly, and that's on top of everything being way too fast and two-shotting you in the endgame. Not even just bosses, but regular enemies. Many bosses and enemies are simply designed with movesets meant to counter the "few" combat mechanics you have at your disposal.  However, I have to say "few" in quotes because there is a wide variety of spells in the game, along with many special attacks you can add to weapons in the form of ashes of war. If you're able to find an effective combination of these things, you can trivialize a lot of the fights, but this solution highlights my main grievance with this game. If something isn't working, you're not meant to adapt to an enemy until it does. You're meant to trivialize the shit by min-maxing. That kind of stuff may be fun for PVP, but, unless they're an invader, enemies don't play by the same rules you do.  All of this wouldn't be such a problem if there were another angle to the gameplay, but fighting your way through the world is the only thing your character is good for, sadly. And that's a real shame when you have such cool a setting with so many major characters. Imagine pledging fealty to a Shardbearer with a kneel emote in the middle of battle or something, and then you get to join their faction instead of just killing every single one of them. That's the kind of shit I play RPGs for, but all you get here are fragmented questlines you need spoilers just to complete, and omniscient item descriptions.  My final note: I know nothing of the game's community or meta or what-have-you, but if the only way I can enjoy or beat a game is by looking up everything and playing it someone else's way, then the game just ain't for me. And on the off-chance you're anything like me, then it probably ain't for you either.

The only other game from From Software that I played was Dark Souls II: Schoolar Of The First Sin (DS2:SOF) wich I enjoyed a lot but I noticed that it was a really hated game from From Software and that Elden Ring was receiving a lot of praises and also won a GOTY so I tought "If their most hated game is this good then their most loved game must be extremely good!" but I ended up hating it ¿What's my problem?  -Attacks often have ridiculous delays. The problem with the delays is not that they take too long it's that the enemy simply stands there with their weapon up with little to no animation so you basically have to see them do the animation and start counting, get hit and remember to how much you counted everytime they do that attack again to properly dodge it. This happens for the whole game, even the final boss does it.  -Chain attacks are too fast sometimes. Sometimes the enemy follows an attack with another so fast that you still are on the roll animation you used to dodge the first attack, this doesn't happen very often but it's very frustrating when it does specially when it stunlocks you to death.  -The open world is too open. This one is more personal, probably most people will love this but I can't leave a zone peacefully without feeling like I missed half of the things it has to offer, and this does happen, unless you use a wiki to see where everything the zone has to offer is then you will miss dungeons, legendary armaments/magics and even NPCs with questlines. This probably helps make every person's walkthrough more unique when not using the wiki.  -Plenty of reused bosses. There are both reused bosses behind fog walls and on the overworld and because of the delayed attacks and the fast chain attacks finding a reused boss on the overworld as a normal enemy, respawning and all is painfull.
It is one of the most captivating games I have played in a while, Fromsoftware creating masterpieces back to back, from Bloodborne, to DS3, to Sekiro, and finally Elden Ring, they never let down once in many years.  If someone reviews this game and says it is overhyped without atleast having 20 hours into the game or atleast getting to the point of fighting Rennala, that person needs to GIT GUD. (jk) Tho I would enjoy a boss rush mode and even though it also felt the bosses weren't meant for this combat, the bosses are a visual eye candy and absolutely incredible to fight! (Not you godskin Duo)  Rating:  ☑️3D Platformer? Check ☑️Bosses which can make you rage quit? Check ☑️Do you need to git gud? Yes  ✅10/10, not maidenless anymore

Fun game for people who enjoy challenge, utilize the tools at your disposal and keep trying to learn how the game is meant to be enjoyed, dying a lot is to be expected until you get the attack patterns of enemies / bosses down and the satisfaction of beating a boss that was giving you a hard time earlier is a integral part of the experience, only downside is the addition of larger world and mount mechanics but those can be ignored since mounts are not usable within "dungeons" / most boss arenas, all in all a good game with a lot of variety for playstyles if you don't like the game with a certain weapon try others or incantations / sorceries, fextralife has a robust wiki for all the information you need to make a proper build and to enjoy the game with items that suit your playstyle, experiment and upgrade your weapons and level your vigor to 40 for best experience  final note: if you want a good melee build try two katana type weapons dual wielded and do dodge roll attacks, jump attacks and crouch attacks, bleed is strong and katanas have inherent bleed build up to them, remember dying is not defeat, quitting is

GOTY! Amazing Game
Ill be honest.  I've never really ever liked single player games. I've tried the whole lot of them, none of them I ever really liked or for any matter, got into at all. It took me a long time of debating on this one after seeing all the praise it got, but as you can see, i'm here. Some people call this game misdirected, or maybe even "too hard" But I call it the closest thing you can get to perfection in a video game. Here's why:  Elden Ring teaches you about discipline, it teaches you about commitment, and it also teaches you about freedom. There is a common misconception behind this game, some people say its too cryptic to know where your going. Which is the complete opposite of why this game absolutely excels. Elden Ring gives you absolute and total control of where you want your character to go in the open world it provided. You will rarely find any aspects of the game that limit you to where they want you to go. Making it the absolute holy grail of open worlds.   Elden Ring will help you with real life scenarios and issues, This game will ultimately help to train you to achieve your goals, because throughout playing this game not only to you have to manage your anger (as did I) but you have to push through when you find a certain aspect difficult. Which is why the intense difficulty of the game makes it different and refreshing from every other game currently out there.   The Story is stunning, as well as the visuals. Cutscenes are almost as if not more immersive than a film. You will find yourself immersed in the world of Elden Ring immediately.   Even if you don't consider yourself a video game type of guy, or a single player type of guy, I recommend you try this game out. Take my word for it, its great.

I love everything
Really fleshed out combat game-play supplemented by stunning visuals. It never gets old testing a new weapon or spell on some enemies, or finding a secret mini dungeon hiding between the rocks. I easily sank way too much time into this game, and it's open world quality lets you go as fast or slow as you want to.
I'd recommend this game to people who are looking to challenge themselves, I have 97 hrs as of this review but haven't gotten very far (shield only playthrough is my furthest). stuttering can be a problem but is manageable most of the time, some enemies can be just unfair due to their "model box" and "slash box" overlapping (the collision push against your character prevents damage) at least for some weapons. I recommend not getting help from other players on first playthrough, as you'll probably kill fun bosses too fast to experience their movesets and have a gap in practice with later bosses.   In short: has some kinks but overall is a great game, experience it to the fullest :)

cool game i think
Took me 200 hours to beat it. As someone who likes to take their time and explore as much as my intuition guides me, this game is a GEM. I don't think the story is even slightly good, at least as far as presentation, and most of the quests do a really bad job of getting you attached to characters or even allowing you to understand what's going on at all, but that is overshadowed by the fact that the combat and exploration are so incredible, that I've never played a game that even comes close to how pleasant these aspects of the game are to interact with. Not even Breath of the Wild comes close. Elden Ring does everything Breath of the Wild tried to do, but better in every way. Dungeon crawling, exploration, stimulating a sense of community, combat, etc.. Even in way of the story tbh, and I personally really don't care for this game's story (even after watching dozens of hours of lore videos) so that's saying a lot lol.  This game is one of — if not — THE BEST video game I've ever played. It's not perfect though. I personally don't like that the game discourages you from experimenting with weapons by forcing you upgrade them before they have any meaningful combat effect. Some of the quests are just ridiculous and force you to use a guide or have a friend tell you what to do, which don't get me wrong, isn't just clearly a bad thing. When Zelda came out, a goal for the developers was to put in secrets and whatnot so that players can share important details with each other and stimulate a sense of community. Because of the cryptic nature of Elden Ring's quests and general design, Elden Ring succeeds in creating a healthy sense of community, which I believe Zelda failed at, especially in comparison to Elden Ring.  Elden Ring will leave its mark on gaming and will change the way developers move forward and make decisions. By missing out on Elden Ring, you're missing out on history. I've heard this kind of praise before playing the game, and was iffy about its validity, but I was wrong to doubt it.  Incredible game. Oh, Elden Ring!  *Small spoiler warning for boss names*  Absolutely brimming with great content, Elden Ring surpassed my unhealthily high expectations. As a veteran of the series, I was very hyped for ER (probably too much), yet the game still blew me away. The small dungeons were what I was most worried about. Most games of ER's size tend to re-use dungeons, and while some of them feel samey, they were clearly made with a lot of effort. Their difficulty progresses very well throughout the game, and the late game ones are worth every minute of exploration.   The bosses are outstanding, but Dark Souls 3 and Bloodborne are still (in my opinion, this is very subjective) the games with the best fights in the series. Elden Ring's best bosses have minor flaws which make them just a bit more annoying than enjoyable. To give examples: Malenia's damage output and Waterfowl dance; Mohg's bloodflame covering the entire arena, making bloodloss unavoidable if you're too unlucky; Rykard's nearly unavoidable exploding skulls; Placidusax's huge health bar that makes the fight an endurance test like no other; and so on. However, don't get me wrong: All of these bosses are still very fun. These flaws are minor annoyances.   The music is truly outstanding, and I have nothing negative to say about it. Morgott, Mohg, Malenia, Placidusax, The Godskin Apostles, and many more amazing tracks are among the series' best.  The graphics are nothing revolutionary, but the art style is unforgettable. There is a geoguessr game for ER (lostgamer.io), but all the locations are so distinct from one another that it's very easy to guess them all just from a single playthrough. Boss designs, area designs, everything is so full of life that you wonder how they managed to make it all in 5 years.  Conclusion: one of the best games ever made, well worth the money, and then some. Fingers crossed that FromSoftware will keep up the tradition of making the DLC the most epic and over the top (in a good way) experience in gaming history.

Questo gioco non è solo un Dark Souls in cui puoi saltare, è un open world originale e innovativo. Ogni dungeon, ogni singola zona di interesse da qualcosa di unico non randomico e realmente utile. Hai la sensazione che ogni singolo dungeon sia servito alla crescita del tuo personaggio e non perchè hai ottenuto 2 anime, 20 monete e 1 ciabatta in più di prima come in qualsiasi altro gioco, ma perchè hai ottenuto un oggetto che non avresti potuto trovare da nessun' altra parte e che potrebbe realmente servirti in futuro. Lo stile artistico è incredibile, ti fa dire "wow, che grafica pazzesca" anche se in realtà è una grafica di 5 anni fa, perciò non credete a chi dice che la grafica di Elden Ring è brutta perchè anche se dal lato tecnico non sorprende è comunque migliore di Dark Souls 3 ed è accompagnato da uno stile unico ed estremamente elaborato. Dal lato difficoltà non è una passeggiata ma poteva essere più difficile. Tolto il boss finale che credo di esserci arrivato sopralivellato avendo fatto letteralmente tutto prima di arrivarci, quindi credo sia normale mi fosse risultato troppo semplice, i boss dei dungeon secondari sono tipo 6 e vengono ripetuti più volte con qualche leggera modifica nell'arena e nelle mosse. Essendo di partenza non troppo difficili, capite che alla quinta volta che lo affronti è quasi un nemico normale, ANZI, certe volte lo diventa davvero. I boss di trama sono impegnativi, ma almeno io non credo di aver mai superato i 15 try con nessun boss. Gli unici boss che mi sono risultati davvero difficili, e quando dico difficili dico DIFFICILI, sono un boss opzionale e nascosto e un boss primario particolare dove dovresti evocare 5 - 6 persone ma l'ho voluto affrontare da solo, nessun altro. Tutti gli altri boss sono difficili solo se perdendovi nella mappa ci arrivate sotto livellati. Pecche del gioco? La magia. Oh, ogni arma che trovi 3 volte su 4 scala in fede. CHE PUALLE, ho capito l'albero ancestrale fatto di luce e sacro, ma cazzo se voglio fare una build no magia rispetto a chi ha fede e intelligenza posso usare 3 armi in croce, il coltello preso dalla cucina di Melina, una pantofola e i miei pugni. Ogni volta è un "Si, sapevo che c'era un dungeon qui" che finisce in un "si va beh ma che ca". Che poi sono pure fighe quelle armi, ma sono tutte in fede. MA a parte questo, le magie e le stregonerie sono rotte. Ho giocato insieme ad un mio amico con una build solo magia, io contro i boss con la mia build solo melee avevo una vera sfida, impegnativa e divertente, lui primo try, usa la magia da distanza, non ha bisogno di imparare il moveset dei boss perchè sta sempre lontano e fa comunque i miei stessi danni se non di più, easy gioco finito. In conclusione, gioco che merita, grande stile, impegnativo ma non esagerato come alcuni pensano, originale, estremamente rigiocabile, longevo e personalmente molto divertente. Alcuni mini boss sono troppo riciclati, le armi tendono troppo verso la fede e la magia è OP e rovina l'esperienza, ma non è niente rispetto ai moltissimi lati positivi che il gioco ha. Se vi piacciono gli open world rpg e non volete tutto servito su un piatto d'argento, è il gioco che fa per voi. Solo un consiglio, almeno per la prima run cercate di tendere al melee e non troppo alla magia, avrete un esperienza estremamente più divertente e soddisfacente

I want to first say that I don't want to recommend, or not recommend this game.  For some it will be phenomenal, while for others it will be terrible, and that is just a fact.  It's a shame I am forced to select one or the other.  Since the game is so hyped in one direction, recommended, I guess I will do the opposite in the spirit of balance.  I don't get the appeal of games like this.  They are TOO hard to enjoy.   If you want the exploration that is expected in an RPG, you will find it here, but every bat can kill you unless you also enjoy mastering combat.  I don't want to do anything more than press a button to swing a sword, or cast a spell, and perhaps dodge or block like you do in GW2.  If you are like me then I recommend you avoid this game regardless of the rave reviews.  I played this game much longer than I expected because I spent $60 on it, but here are the issues as I see them:  Pros: 1.  Exploration of the open world is really second to none.  This is a fantastic open world with a mystery and excitement to it akin to Everquest 1 when it first released. 2.  The variety of mobs is fairly high 3.  The graphics and ambient sounds are well done 4.  The first act of the game, when mobs are not ridiculous and everything is new, is simply the best experience I have had in years.  Most reviews go on and on about this same thing so I won't reiterate it here.  What most reviews don't mention are the negatives, and there are negatives for many types of players despite the thousands of positive reviews.  Cons: 1.  Tedious:  if you die you lose  all runes which are collected like gold would be in most games, but are also the only way to level; you get one shot to pick them up again, but if you die they are gone for good along with every single bit of progress you have made in earning them.  Also, when you die ALL previously killed mobs respawn and you have to fight your way back through them.  I despise repeating things, and this game is designed to kill you over and over so you will spend a lot of time repeating stuff. 2.  There is no real sense of getting more powerful.  Sure there are mobs you eventually become stronger than, but you are always just a few unfortunate hits and stuns away from death no matter your level, experience, or gear.   3.  There is no way to adjust difficulty, so if you become mentally weary of the fights and just want to explore the world and story on a slighty lower intensity, you can forget it. 4.  After reaching the capital you will notice that mobs move beyond challenging into the realm of being unfair.  They have stuns, endless combos, ridiculous jumps, unblockable hits, and are so large and fast you cannot outrun them; nevermind the encounters in quests or dungeons which occur in cramped quarters where you have to master combat to have a chance.  You may like to master combat, but the truth is there is luck involved in many of the boss fights, and not everyone likes the combat as much as the exploration or other things. 5.  There is no quest journal to track steps completed, or even repeat goals or remind you of NPC names, or locations where you found them.  That isn't just not holding your hand, that is stupid and not respecting your time. 6.  The story really isn't very good at all.  I understand that is subjective, but many players couldn't tell you the story if you asked them, unless they had read it from a third party site.  Even if you do know it, it is boring, and RPGs are supposed to be story-driven, so a weak or non-compelling story-line is a problem. 7.  You will experience burnout if you are like many others who have stated they eventually just skip fights and run straight through zones in the endgame, just wanting to say they completed the game, and for it to be over.  In fact, I've read that many, myself included, have decided to not complete the game because it has become a chore. 8.  There are hidden features like using gestures to unlock hidden areas supposedly.  Well, you first have to find the gestures, then find the areas to use them, and then figure out which one to use.  I would normally like such a feature, but I find it annoying in this game.  If you try the game you will see what I mean. 9.  The game implements soft caps on stats to force you to diversify your build and try different things.  Look, if I want to max a stat and use the same weapon the whole game, then that is my business.  Stop artificially forcing me to try play-styles I don't like.  There is more to say, but there isn't much point when a game is so highly rated.  The game has real issues for certain gamers that will continue to be dismissed by the fans who say that I need to get better at the game.  But you see, I don't WANT to get better.  I just want to enjoy the Elden Ring world using MY playstyle, not yours.  This is one of the only developers that has decided they absolutely will not do that; it is their MO.  I am all about developers deciding what type of game they want to make, and sticking to it.  Elden Ring does that and I say good for them, but the result is a gamer like me is eventually driven away.  Fans of this series are happy about that, because they are so scared the things they like will be changed, or that their bragging rights will become meaningless as more people can kill the bosses they do, but I think this is silly.  There is some multiplayer functionality, but in the end this is a single player RPG and one gamer's sense of accomplishment shouldn't hinge on another gamer being shutout of the experience of the game to protect fragile egos and placate irrational fears.  Let as many people as possible experience and enjoy the fantasy world created I say.  For the reasons just stated, the game is so hyped that I believe the reviews never give you a fair assessment of the negatives, or at least the full picture.  This game isn't just "not for everyone because it's hard."  This game isn't for everyone because it has problems like any other.  It doesn't have the best boss fights that exist, even if that is your thing.  It is a challenge, and it is well done, but there is a HUGE segment of gamers that are also wasting their time with this game because it makes ZERO allowances for them in the end.    I find myself wanting to explore every nook and cranny because the world is that good, but I cannot stand the stupid boss fights and respawning of mobs anymore.  It has become tiring.  I cannot stand that I can't turn the difficulty down if I want to.  I cannot stand that  the game is designed to make you repeat stuff because it wants you to die to experience a sense of accomplishment.  Hey, if that's you then great, but it isn't me, and this game doesn't take a player like me into account.  I wish it did.

first off, praise the Elden Ring!
One of the best games ever made, very worthy of winning GOTY, insane replayability with the insane amount of builds you can make, areas you can explore and different ways you can play the game. The main bosses are great (The last one is a bit underwhelming), the side bosses are okay, if you don`t like repeating bosses you can just skip them, the scenarios and the setting of the game is absolutely gorgeous, every weapon in the game is usable and can be pretty good if you know how to build around them, so every playstyle is viable.   The only area this game really lacks in is modding, modding is hard and a pain in the ass compared to most other games, also all the running around when in new game+ but that is understandable to keep the game`s progression path.  The only reason I can`t give this game a 10/10 is because that is of course reserved to the perfect games, with no flaws, this game has some flaws, the end-game is flawed, the last boss is flawed, and the endgame is pretty important to get right, but besides that it`s such a great game that a 9.8 is very much deserved and it definitely worth your money, it is a MUST PLAY game, and if you haven`t played any FROMSOFTWARE game before, just keep at it, don`t give up and you will have a great time. Enemies with attacks cooler than your own. Over the top bosses that make your character feel shit. Slow lumbering combat, against enemies with lightning fast attacks. Terrible level up system with stats that make little difference. Terrible loot, I mean what loot? Open world that feels empty, with vague quests littered sparsely throughout. Npcs with no emotions and vague dialogue. Very basic enemy AI.  This feels like a game that was made decades ago and had a remake to look better. The only positives is that the game looks gorgeous, and the areas and dungeons are really well made. Even though the bosses are way over the top to your normal character they are also really cool.  The difficulty is all over the p[lace, some normal enemies will kill you instantly and the some do hardly anything, some little enemies are sometimes harder than the bosses. I think bottom line, people like the difficulty, and it's created a cult like following. But remove the difficulty and you will see how basic and boring these games actually are, and difficulty does not make a game better, a game has to be good even if its easy.

this fun fr
Elden Ring is one of the most challenging games there is, while still being extremely fun.  I don't remember very many dull moments.  It is also, to me at least, the most beautiful graphics.   Each cave, tunnel, or catacomb (and their bosses) is different and it takes a while to get to know them well enough to get through them successfully.  I love the concept of summoning either spirit ashes or other players to help with the tough fights.  It can be a bit lonely in this single-player game so having that extra help makes it a lot of fun, even if you don't really need to use them.  It can be dark and very spooky at times; particularly when you're sitting at a Site of Grace and Melina suddenly appears and sits next to you.  The lore behind the story of Elden Ring is very interesting and sometimes a puzzle in itself, to be solved in later versions i suppose.  I have recommended the game to many friends and they have all fell in love with it as i did.

Elden Ring is like the culmination of every FromSoft game, taking aspects of each and mashing them together in yet another exercise in masochism. Visually stunning, large open world, solid and extremely unforgiving gameplay, interesting lore and characters, hours and hours of stuff to do.  Yes, it's difficult. If you've played anything from Demon Souls to Sekiro, you know that there can be a steep learning curve. But once you grow to master the combat, the game becomes all the more rewarding. It's like everything you wanted out of an FS title had a baby with Skyrim. Even if you aren't a fan of SoulsBorne games, Elden Ring has a lot to offer for most gamers who have patience and an open mind.   What are you waiting for, foul tarnished? Play the game.

A game that's both a wonderful entrance to FromSoftware's catalog of games, as well as being an open world game to stand alongside the best of the best.   Throughout the game is a never-ending sense of wonder and discovery that, to the extent I've played, feels as if it's a living world all of it's own, with an extreme attention to detail in it's sprawling environment, and variety overflowing to the extent it baffles me that actual human beings could have made something this vast and creative.   An excellent game in almost every right, I hope to see more like this in the future!

[b] At the time of writing, I have beaten Elden Ring seven times, almost beaten it an eighth time, and achieved 100% completion in terms of Steam achievements. This is a good game. A great game. But it's held back from being perfect by a couple things. [/b] Elden Ring is one of the most solid games ever created, and rivals the rest of the FromSoftware catalogue for best title they've ever created. The problem is, Elden Ring seems to have taken a tip from the original Dark Souls by making the second half of the game filled with unnecessary difficulty spikes, that make the game less fun and more frustrating than challenging. One such example of this is a section in the optional area of the [spoiler] 'Consecrated Snowfield' [/spoiler], this section is known as [spoiler] 'Ordina, Litgurgical Town' [/spoiler]. In this section there seems to be a lack of thought in the design, and it pairs the weakest part of these games - the platforming - with archer enemies placed in hard to reach positions that fire both very quick, and very fast. Alongside this, there are invisible assassin enemies who can crit you and then go invisible once more, leaving only a small window to actually hit them. Another example of this difficulty, and what I consider the main one, is the bosses - the bosses in the second half seem to have too much health, and deal too much damage, with almost all of them after [spoiler] Morgott [/spoiler] being able to 1 to 3 hit you depending on your build. This, I do not find challenging, just completely unfair; the worst offender is by far [spoiler] The Fire Giant [/spoiler] who might be the most infuriating mainline boss From has ever created. On the other hand, this title is the most expansive, most open and offers the most diverse build variety of any of the titles that FromSoft have created before. I also think this is among one of its most polished titles, which is why the unnecessary difficulty in certain sections makes it so frustrating as a title. Why bring down the quality of this game by designing unfair, and thus unenjoyable sections in a near perfect title? I think it has something to do with the legacy that FromSoftware has left behind with their souls-like genre; that of the idea that a souls-like must be difficult. This in turn can sometimes result in artificial difficulty over real challenge in order to make the game fit this image of being a 'difficult game'. However, I must whole-heartedly recommend this title, as it's easily one of the best games I've ever played, and probably will ever play.

One of the best game's I've ever played
I apologize for my ineloquency - I usually don't write "reviews" but I just need to get this out of my system, so to speak.  First things first, if you're planning to play Elden Ring as your first "souls-like" - please, try Dark Souls 1 instead. It's an all around better game.  As for this game, I can't for the [i]life[/i] of me fathom why it was so praised.  Maybe I'm just tired of the generic "souls" formula, or maybe it's just my MDD that keeps gets worse.  But Elden Ring - in my opinion - is by far the worst, so to say, "souls-like" developed by FromSoftware - Dark Souls 2 included. Now, I think the developers/designers responsible for creating the "overworld" map indeed did a fantastic job, and the beginning of this game was somewhat promising.  However, other than that - Elden Ring is a creatively bankrupt, tedious, unbalanced, at some points borderline broken and worst of all - simply boring - mess.  Balancing issues aside - the game's main problem, I think, is that it's obscenely bloated with copypasted content: - Copypasted locations - which ruined any kind of atmosphere/immersion and disincentivized any point in exploration - the strongest, so say, aspect of previous From's "souls-clones".  Even the major late-game locations are heavily, if I'm not mistaken, the correct term is - "asset-flipped" versions of previous locations - and there's only ~7 of them in the entire game.  The other ~52 areas are just small "mini-dungeons". They in particular are just horrendous. Sure, you get some kind of - usually worthless - item at the end of yet another Cave/Crypt (that's all there is to it to the variety). But everything looks exactly the same - what was even the point? I mean, it would've been nice if the combat system wasn't so repetitive, but unfortunately - it is.  Even Bloodborne did it better with its random Chalice Dungeons.   - Copypasted enemies. In comparison with From's previous titles, in which each area usually had an array of unique enemy types, Elden Ring exhausts most of its, so to say, bestiary in barely ~1.5-3 hours of gameplay.  After that, it's, once again - just the same exact mobs that exponentially turn into obnoxious damage-sponges. And it really doesn't help that quite a lot of creatures (and player's character) repurpose animations assets from From's previous games - mostly Dark Souls 3.  - Majority of bosses (a lot of which were reused as regular enemy mobs) were also haphazardly copypasted.  And all the story-bosses felt completely unimaginative, forgettable and, with exception to a couple of end-game ones - trivial.  I even bothered to stop leveling at some point and used a guide on how to NOT get accidentally overpowered - which is an easy thing to do, because this game has a rather broken progression system.  The battle content designers, also, seem to have ran out of ideas and made the main bosses rely on cheap "delayed" attacks, annoying lingering AOEs and 1-shot gimmicks - particularly towards the very end of the game. Which, in my opinion, made this game into the most "sluggish" one in the series, despite added jump move from Sekiro - especially for melee characters. Magic is completely overpowered, by the way - I refuse to believe it was thoroughly playtested. One of the bosses, in particular - "Malenia, The Meme of This Game" - was clearly not designed for Elden Ring's combat system at all. Honestly, just google it.  It's really unfortunate that they messed up that badly - especially after aforementioned Sekiro, which had amazing bosses and an even better combat system in general.  Well, to spout at least something positive - I'd say Radahn (a giant goofball on a small horse) - one of the main mid-game bosses, was pretty decent because developers for once actually tried something unique with this one... and he also looked memorably amusing.  But overall, I didn't like Elden Ring. I think it's a barely mediocre game and It's really quite a shame that it wasn't criticized into oblivion - like Dark Souls 2, for example.  And as an another little side note to those who for some reason liked PvP in previous games, even though I'm in no position to talk about it.  Due to severe balancing issues - PvP here is objectively broken, there's no faction system and invasion-mechanic is also fairly "strange" too.  According to developers, to make invaders less of an issue for players - it's now only possible to invade ganks/groups. I think it just encouraged the use of broken builds and twinking. And for some absurd reason invading someone during a boss battle is also possible and, I should add, there's an easily accessible suicide bomb flask which can 1-shot majority of players (was kind of entertaining a couple of times). Ingenious!  Anyway - again, I apologize for my insane digital rumblings.

After seeing probably around 98% of this games content throughout the course of over 130 hours on a single playthrough, Elden Ring easily makes for one of the greatest open world titles I've ever played. While I personally preferred the souls series' more linear style Elden Ring does do a great job at bringing the mechanics into an open world alongside so many small quality of life improvements that add up quite nicely. My main criticism would be that the overall quality of boss fights had some minor trade-off for more quality exploration but whether that counts as a net positive or negative is going to vary based on preferences. Mechanically it takes all the best parts of the Souls series and adds some great new elements, combat has so many more routes to find your preferred playstyle via Ashes of War, power-stancing, and mounted combat in many areas, new environments are incredible with particular note going to Caelid and the Haligtree as some of the coolest areas to come from a Fromsoft game, and of course practically bottomless rabbitholes for theorizing on lore. Absolute recommendation for anyone interested.

ebdon rong
This is Dark Souls, but with an open world, and this is the biggest disappointment. The open world is not really interesting to explore and it serves only to move from one dungeon (or world boss) to the next one. And the dungeons and bosses are subpar to Dark Souls 1, I feel. Maybe that's because that game was groundbreaking in many aspects, and Elden Ring is just more of the same. In fact, it really feels like a remix of every other Soulsborne game, and the only new move is the ability to crouch ala Sekiro. There's nothing really innovative in terms of content: the weapons, the enemies, the location design - we've seen it in FromSoftware games before.  Does this mean Elden Ring is a bad game? No, and I totally recommend it, but only because there's nothing else of the same quality on the horizon. But Elden Ring could have been so much more, so much better. Alas...  Honestly, after finishing the game with 100% achievements and beating all key bosses (including Malenia), I can definitely say that the hardest enemies in the game (as in all other Soulsbornes) are camera, controls and performance. I thought 12900k and 3080Ti would be enough for 1440p gaming for a few more years, but no, FromSoftware managed to keep the videocard at 80-90% load at all times, with fps sometimes dropping to 40-50. And camera + controls is the same clunky stuff that I remember back from Dark Souls Prepare to Die Edition. Also, data streaming is really bad. Despite me having 32Gb RAM + 980 Evo Pro, sometimes the game totally froze when loading in a new part of the location.  Well, in the end, it's part of the FromSoftware games DNA, I guess. If they were perfect, they would be too easy. In fact, Elden Ring is already much easier than Dark Souls 1/2/3 and Bloodborne, and even infamous Malenia is not that hard when you exploit her weaknesses (I killed her with a bloodloss build). For instance, it took me 80 hours to beat every key boss and do everything in Elden Ring, while the first Dark Souls took me 70 hours to beat, but I only killed one DLC boss out of three. And I played over 100 hours of Dark Souls 3 without getting all the achievements. So even though the game world looks massive, in terms of length Elden Ring is shorter than its predecessors due to lower difficulty.  So, bottom line, a good Soulsborne game, much more user friendly than the previous ones, but not in any way groundbreaking.

The game is great on a controller.  The mouse and keyboard controls are awkward, and not everything can be rebound.  Upon starting the game, the icons that tell you what to press are for the gamepad not K&M.  You have to go into the sound (yes sound) menu to change it.  I can't recommend this to people on PC who aren't also going to use a controller.  Also the game can take seconds to minutes to shutdown properly before your cloud sync can begin.  This is incredibly awkward if you play on multiple devices and shut one down before the game actually exists.

The longest and most content filled Souls game ever made. Lots of possible builds along with flashy movesets for weapons and magic. Really interesting story with multiple endings based on your progression throughout the whole game.  First playthrough took me 100 hours to complete, going through most optional areas (not 100%). Lots of optional content, keep in mind that there are quite a bit of reused bosses and enemies (some are reskins, some are direct copies). I do not believe this game is as replayable as the others in the series due to how massive the game is. The best part of this game is how it naturally nudges you to explore, without revealing too much. There cool twists and bizzare creatures that must be slain!
Rise, Tarnished...  Let those words course through your mind as you take up arms and battle against legions of mighty monsters and gods on your journey to become Elden Lord! Do you have what it takes to succeed, or will you be trampled underfoot mercilessly by the likes of Godrick the Grafted and Malenia Blade of Miquella? Only you can answer that question, lowly Tarnished. Though patience and discipline are necessary to succeed in these harsh lands, I know that you can triumph, lowly Tarnished though you may be. Now, rise if you would, for that is your fate!   Beautiful, stunning game. Could not recommend Elden Ring highly enough. The Lands Between has been the most gorgeous setting in a game that I have experienced in a very long time. The story and characters are hauntingly sublime. Though challenging and at times frustrating, the experience has been truly exhilarating and wonderfully fulfilling. Praise the Elden Ring!

Hello chosen undead. I mean unkindled.... no... ashen one? Oh tarnished! This time you are called tarnished, whatever. (I'm wondering when will From Software run out of ideas what to to call your cursed husk walking the new land in each game) You are embarking on another Dark Souls adventure diluted in Open World formula this time instead of interconnected dungeons.   Yeah you were expecting the place to look quite f**ked up, and insanely beautiful at the same time, but these developers still surprise me in each game. So you walk out in this beautifully f**ked up world, and by the time you finish your gaming experience will be enriched once again with unforgettable moments, amazing boss fights, just as your vocabulary will be enriched with countless new curse words  Many called this game a direct evolution of Souls games, but it's more like a different take on the genre, changing the format instead of evolving it really. But it worked. Those who are new to these titles, because Elden Ring hype was great, definitely should go back and play some Dark Souls also. If you finished this, you can't say "I suck at Dark Souls" because you just finished one. And all these games are unique in their own way.  Oh, by the way PVP is garbage here also. So don't expect some well polished pvp. The latency is just as bad, or even worse than in any other Souls games, the amount of, bugs, gliches, bunny hopping, dodgerolling comedy is amazing :D Invasions don't exist either, they are invitations, they are only calling it invasions for the sake of calling it that.  Anyway, it's a must have, must play, must beat every boss game in your library, it met and exceeded all expectations. Cheers!

My first perfect game on Steam. Elden Ring brings the best of Dark Souls to a beautiful and massive open world RPG. Even more than combat, exploration was truly the most satisfying aspect of this game for myself. A lot of the very best content in this game is hidden behind obscure paths and caves making it so rewarding when you stumble across it. Massive cinematic set pieces in the background make not only for spectacular views upon high ground, but your next potential destination as you can visit practically everything that you see.   However, the bread and butter of this game is definitely the combat. Bosses are very difficult but very fair when taking into account the vast array of weapons, spells, armor, ashes of war, and spirit ashes. With so many choices, character customization has never been so deep in the Souls Series and when combined with the open world, it really makes for a wonderful RPG.  I really couldn't recommend this game enough. It's truly worthy of the praise it received and I can't wait for the DLC.
behold... one of the best games ever
I do not understand why the game is so hyped, if this is what a "game of the year" is, I am loosing my hopes.  The game was clearly made for consoles and porting the user interface and controls to PC was probably done by accident or an working student, but this is not the main problem. The controls are flawed even with a controller, for example there is no walking backwards or sideways which makes hitting enemies unnecessarily hard. The game concept is so swallow: Loot, Level, Kill... why? Because of a indoctrinating lengthy intro video at the start of game which spoon feds you the "why" in the fashion of a online training video about the new corporate culture. After this you a set free into a beautify looking, but empty feeling, open world with bare minimum physics and half brain dead AI... and for that you better pull out your reading glasses, because you are going to read a lot of tool tips trying to explain the non-intuitive menu. From this point on wards there is not much more going on that to loot, level, and kill poorly scripted AI that tries to kill you for no good reason.  For me this game has nothing to offer, because its just a grind for the sake of grinding without any real reward. I would refund it if I would not have bought it with a discount from a 3rd party.  TL;DR: Nothing is interesting beside the pretty game engine. Would refund if I had not bought a key from a 3rd party.

mimic is the friend we made along the way
The lands of Elden Ring are vast and wild, filled with dangers lurking at every turn. But, there is also beauty to be found in this world, and I found myself drawn to explore it. The combat in Elden Ring is a true test of skill and bravery. I've faced challenges I never thought possible, but with each defeat came new knowledge and the desire to try again. The story is like nothing I've ever encountered before. It is a tale of power, of magic, and of destiny - I had to lookup a whole lotta youtube videos for this. The soundtracks are like haunting melodies that lingers in my mind long after I've stepped away from my PC.   This is my first "souls-like" experience, each victory feels earned and I find myself eager for more. The game is a masterful fusion of difficulty, atmosphere, storytelling, and exploration, and is sure to be a memorable experience for those who embark on its journey.
Cant Segz Godrick
